short_title: Initiative to improve the Food Supply Chain
Feedback:
SOMO's feedback on Inception Impact Assessment (EC Initiative to improve the Food Supply Chain)

Together with other NGOs in various international NGO coalitions with representation in most EU member states SOMO, the Centre for Research on Multinational Corporations, has been addressing unfair trading practices in EU food supply chains since 2009 . SOMO’s interest in UTPs relates to mitigating their potential and actual detrimental impacts on (smallholder) producers and workers especially in developing countries. The problem of UTPs and its detrimental effects on food supply chains have the gradually been acknowledged widely and linked to increasing power imbalances. SOMO and allies have been advocating for a legislative approach with strong EU coordination to effectively counter UTPs and have made a number of recommendations to this end in 2014.  SOMO therefore welcomes the EC’s serious consideration of this type of action in the form of the EU regulatory framework which it outlines in Option 3. 

More specifically SOMO thinks that the framework regulation should allow for an independent enforcement body that is able to receive anonymous complaints, keep information confidential and has the power and means to initiate ex officio investigations on the basis of information gathered that abusive trading practices have been applied. The body should also have the mandate to apply effective sanctions (including fines) to stop perpetrators from continuing to apply UTPs and be able to coordinate enforcement across the EU. 

Many EU member states have now introduced a range of regulatory measures to counter UTPs. Whereas it is unclear yet whether these measures are always effective it is clear that there is no level playing field for victims of UTPs imposed by EU actors. When member states have policies for UTPs they differ to some extent from country to country. In the Netherlands for instance, there was a voluntary system analogous to the EU level voluntary and educational system the SCI. However, the pilot, as it was called, was stopped by the government meaning that there now is no formal instance at the national level where victims can hope to seek remedy. Without strong EU coordination and equal standards and enforcement in different member states there is the risk that UTPs continue to be applied from member states with laxer policies such as the Netherlands. In this context SOMO also likes to draw attention to its recent research on joint procurement by supermarkets in different countries in the form of international supermarket buying groups. The research  shows that international supermarket buying groups create conditions that facilitate UTPs being applied to their suppliers.

short_title: Initiative to improve the Food Supply Chain
Feedback:
The following is the views of the Ulster Farmers Union representing 11,500 growers and farmers in Northern Ireland.

Due to the changes to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), farmers have become increasingly market focused, seeing themselves as the very important first stage of an integrated supply chain.  For many, this transition has been thwarted by a grocery market and its supply chain which is not functioning correctly.  Although there are good examples of suppliers and retailers working well together, in general, the food chain is characterised by a lack of transparency and unrelenting downward pressure on prices and margins, which, if left unchecked, would place many UK primary agricultural sectors in jeopardy.
 
Individually and collectively farmers seek to be valued in their supply chains and to be represented at all levels.  The benefits from farming to the Northern Irish Economy cannot be underestimated.  A flourishing agriculture creates confidence in local communities and creates jobs both on farm and in the local agri industry.  Northern Ireland farmers operate to high standards and the local rural economy is dependent on the continuing success of the food and farming industries.  
 
The value of the food and drink processing in Northern Ireland according to DAERA statistics in 2015 was valued at £4.42 billion and directly employing slightly over 21,500 employees therefore it plays a substantial role in the Northern Irish economy. Farmers and growers in Northern Ireland would like to see food and drink manufacturers improve their commitment to Northern Irish agriculture, both in terms of increased sourcing of NI produce and in communication between farmers and manufacturers. A comprehensive supply chain should look to combine and improve food retailing and manufacturing assurances combined with greater education of the primary production in the food chain and its protection for consumers through its production. To be effective, any strategy must be underpinned by a legislative framework to act as a deterrent to poor behaviour and give producers confidence that issues are being addressed.
 
Incentives for food processors should exist to develop collaborative and (fair/honest/meaningful) supply chains with their suppliers.  Resources should be provided to support the development of stable, longer term pricing models and primary producer collaboration which can lessen the impact of income volatility and improve business confidence.  The impact of price volatility on farming businesses and the rural economy should be further assessed to identify additional solutions to establish income stability.
 
Finally, it must not be ignored the very real impact an unpoliced, poorly functioning supply chain has on food security and our ability to have access to affordable, traceable, safe and nutritious food. The current fragility in the supply chain has been highlighted in recent times by high profile incidents such as the horse meat scandal in 2013.

A CONFAGRI apoia as tentativas feitas pela Comissão Europeia com vista o melhoramento do funcionamento da Cadeia Alimentar sobretudo porque um problema Europeu deve ter uma abordagem Europeia.

Nos tópicos mencionados as nossas posições e sugestões:
1)	Práticas Desleais e Abusivas
As práticas desleais e abusivas são infelizmente bem conhecidas e aceites como uma das bases de desequilíbrio na cadeia agro-alimentar.
Portugal têm vindo a trabalhar neste assunto desde 2011, com a constituição da PARCA - Plataforma de Acompanhamento das Relações na Cadeia Agroalimentar. 
O trabalho desta Plataforma centrou-se:
•	Alteração e adequação legislativa à nova realidade, nomeadamente através da Alteração do Decreto-lei relativo às Praticas Individuais Restritivas de Comércio (com implementação deste diploma foi atingido o fim de uma etapa e não o fecho do processo estando atualmente está em análise a implementação deste do mesmo); 
•	Elaboração de um código de Boas Praticas de adesão voluntária (assinado por todos os parceiros da PARCA mas em fase de implementação);
•	Criação de um organismo de observação da cadeia agro-alimentar - debatida mas ainda estamos longe da sua conceção final. 

Reconhecendo que o problema das Práticas Desleais e Abusivas é Europeu, a CONFAGRI defende neste ponto a opção 3. 
Para um mercado interno Europeu funcionante as regras e condições de negociação entre parceiros (intra e inter EMs) devem ser estabelecidas a nível da União, tal deve ser o objectivo de um Quadro Legislativo Europeu.
Sendo fundamental definir quais as principais práticas desleais e abusivas é também necessário reconhecer as diferenças em termos de força negocial entre os actores envolvidos. Assim o anonimato, sanções, bem como, controlos adequados devem ser devidamente equacionados em tal Quadro.
É também muito bem vista a posição de um provedor Europeu, com devidos poderes refletindo a dimensão europeia do sector.

2)	Transparência
A transparência nos mercados é fundamental para o seu melhor funcionamento. A CONFAGRI apoia a opção 2. 
Uma total transparência na cadeia agro-alimentar só poderá ser conseguida se existirem dados comparativos e de análise estatística fiáveis. 
Devem ser fomentadas as competências dos Observatórios Europeus – através da disponibilização de todos os dados estatísticos, por sector, incluindo nomeadamente os preços praticados junto dos consumidores, com o retorno periódico do trabalho de monitorização dos preços finais. Sem estes dados, não é possível discutirmos qualquer tipo de aumento de transparência, nem será possível uma correcta adaptação dos sectores aos mercados em que se inserem. Assim, só através da implementação de um sistema de informação estatística credível e atempado que permita conhecer inequivocamente a relação de preços ao longo da cadeia se conseguirá aumentar a transparência no funcionamento da cadeia agro-alimentar.

3)	Cooperação entre produtores
O problema da baixa concentração ao nível do sector produtivo é fundamentalmente estrutural. A enorme diferença em número e em poder económico entre produtores e retalhistas é um indicador claro de uma cadeia agro-alimentar desequilibrada.
É fundamental continuar a apoiar o desenvolvimento de organizações económicas de agricultores. Neste aspeto as Cooperativas Agrícolas podem desempenhar um papel fundamental, pelo que é necessário criar mecanismo de apoio a estas estruturas organizativas (nomeadamente através do reconhecimento imediato das Cooperativas como Organizações de Produtores no âmbito da OCM única), que pela sua estrutura tão especial garantem princípios fundamentais de responsabilidade e democracia exigidos ao desenvolvimento de cadeias de fornecimento transparentes e integradas.
É por este motivo que a CONFAGRI considera a Opção 2 como mais interessante, sendo no entanto importante uma análise sectorial da sua aplicação podendo ser de extrema importância, nomeadamente, aprofundar outras medidas de acção que possa

Landwirtschaftliche Erzeugnisse sind maßgeblich für die Lebensmittelversorgung der europäischen Bevölkerung. Eine abwechslungsreiche Ernährung, reich an Gemüse, Obst und Vollkornprodukten wirkt sich positiv auf die Gesundheit aus.

short_title: Initiative to improve the Food Supply Chain
Feedback:
ICOS welcomes this initiative by the European Commission to improve the functioning of the food supply chain. Farmer-owned cooperatives play an important role in this supply chain- they integrate the roles of the producer, processor, marketer to add value and provide security for farmers. ICOS therefore supports action being taken which will strengthen the position of farmers and their cooperatives and improve price transparency, while highlighting that this action should respect the hugely positive role of cooperatives in providing balance to the food supply chain.  

Unfair Trading Practices
The vast majority of Irish cooperatives, across all sectors, are small or medium sized. This puts them at a disadvantage to downstream highly-concentrated businesses in the retail sector. As a result, they are often exposed to unfair and sometimes abusive trading practices, as is the case across the entire EU. ICOS therefore supports this EU initiative to combat unfair trading practices (UTPs) and ensure a fair and equitable food supply chain, that provides cooperatives with a level playing field and will allow them to develop their business activities for the benefit of their members. 

We believe that a purely voluntary approach, such as the Supply Chain Initiative, is not sufficiently effective. We need a system which combines this voluntary code with a robust independent enforcement system that can receive and act upon anonymous complaints on abuses in market power, and address them through the use of sanctions. 

Additionally, with many Irish cooperatives exporting to other EU countries and beyond, the current varied national legislation and mechanisms to address UPTs provide inadequate enforcement and are a leading to a fragmented internal market. We therefore believe that the third policy option outlined in the inception impact assessment is the most fitting and effective solution to protect the single market and adequadely addressing the issue. 

Market Transparency
ICOS very much supports the proposed increase in market transparency, for which we have been calling, for a number of years. Greater market transparency can provide many benefits for all operators in the supply chain, ensuring greater bargaining power for producers, but also helping to combat market volatility. Greater market price transparency would enable the functioning of a European Futures Market which  would allow farmers and their cooperatives to either lock-in or hedge a prices, for a least a portion of their supply and therefore ensure a better and more stable price for their produce. 

However in order to achieve the necessary degree of market transparency, increased standardisation is needed across Member States as regards to the definition, collection, reporting and presentation of data. The focus must also be on improving transparency across the entire food supply chain, not just on processor level, but particularly within the distribution and retail stages and also on ensuring the reliability of the data. 

Producer Cooperation
ICOS welcomes the initiative for provide clarity on producer cooperation under EU competition law within the context of the future CAP policy reform. Cooperatives are the most effective, socially responsible and sustainable form of producer organisation. They are the most effective way for producers to increase their bargaining power and generate greater value from the supply chain. We therefore reaffirm the necessity for agri-cooperatives and other producer organisations with an economic activity to receive a derogation from EU competition law and reiterate our call for the future CAP policy to emphasise and actively promote the position of farmer owned co-operatives in Europe. Additionally we call for any new horizontal rules or proposals under this initiative to respect the role and functioning of these farmer-owned cooperatives.

short_title: Initiative to improve the Food Supply Chain
Feedback:
UOKiK President's view on unfair trading practices issue

Poland has lately adopted a piece of legislation on counteracting the unfair use of contractual advantage in the trade in agricultural and food products that entered into force on 12th July 2017. This decision was made as a result of unsuccessful attempts to regulate the matter on the trade organizations’ level. Agricultural and food industry is a specific market that is particularly prone to unfair trading practices, which grossly deviate from good commercial conduct and are contrary to good faith and fair dealing and also are unilaterally imposed by one trading partner on its counterparty. 

Polish act addresses the issue of the relations between all actors in the food supply chain (farmers–purchasers and other agents: distribution chains, wholesalers). The proceedings pertaining to the new regulations are conducted by the Office of Competition and Consumer Protection with its head, UOKiK President.  UOKiK is now running the comparative analyses on how this issue is dealt within various EU and non-EU countries. What seems to be crucial in this regard are the examples of undertakings’ conduct penalized by EU countries as well as the way of dealing with so called ‘fear factor’ of the parties enjoying weaker commercial position. Polish undertakings, in the course of informatory meetings and in further correspondence, seemed to be particularly interested  in the kind of practices that are going to be considered as unfair and whether the identity of the entity submitting the complaint will remain confidential.  

Polish approach to the problem of unfair trading practices is rather a compromise in the light of various initiatives at national and European level. The new law comprises general provisions along with the definition of unfair trading practices and includes the exemplary list of the practices considered to be unfair. Important in this approach is that the aggrieved party must be always indicated in the UOKiK President’s decision, nevertheless the proceedings are conducted exclusively ex officio, what guarantees confidentiality of the party submitting the complaint. 

Regardless of the Polish government’s idea of European legislation that will embrace the issue on the EU level and will include relevant tools of an enforcement (Options 3 or 4) UOKiK as a National Competition Authority responsible for fighting UTPs, supports separate initiative to formulate the tentative Guidelines (Option 2) that would mainly deal with raised issues. That includes extended list of unfair trading practices and  the proposed ways of counteracting  the risk of retaliation on the weaker operator (farmers). The guidelines could also include the proposed methodology of examining given case and deciding whether the practice is unfair indeed. The methodology shall consider the manner of assessing the bargaining power, stipulating the examined market (whether it is equal to relevant market in the meaning of competition law) and the level of dependency of the weaker party on its stronger commercial partner. As far as UOKiK’s view is concerned all abovementioned shall be conducted in the form of correspondence and periodic meetings, where experience and best practices would be discussed by bodies responsible for combating the UTPs at national level. In the view of the UOKiK, it might make the enforcement more dynamic and thanks to the complex experience of numerous partners, might as well advocate good practices and enable countries for a fast reaction to new forms of UTPs. Vital for the whole process seem to be an ongoing  exchange of the experiences in the field of promoting the knowledge on the UTPs among the undertakings and how to inform the weaker participants of the market about their right to file complaint with the relevant authority.

short_title: Farm Sustainability Data Network (FSDN) – compiling data on farm sustainability
Feedback: The Farm Sustainability Data Network can be instrumental in improving our understanding of farm sustainability and supporting decision making to promote more sustainable farming practises, particularly by incorporating data on their environmental and social practises. The conversion of the Farm Accountancy Data Network into the Farm Sustainability Data Network needs to ensure: - classification of farming into general and principal types of farming to provide a framework for understanding, analyzing, and supporting the diverse agricultural systems that contribute to global food safety, socio-economic viability and environmental stewardship. - benchmark farm performance against predefined standards, best practices, or similar farms to identify areas for improvement and drive operational excellence. It is essential for driving continuous improvement, enhancing competitiveness, and achieving long-term sustainability in agriculture. Aggregation and comparisons of the situation of groups of holdings needs to be guaranteed. - tailored advice and guidance to farmers including digital literacy support, ensures that they can effectively provide and utilise data and technology to improve their operations. This personalised assistance helps farmers adopt sustainable practices and optimise resource management. - better meet the policymaking challenges of the green transition with a multifaceted approach that addresses various aspects of policy development, implementation, and evaluation. - access to pseudonymised data for research purposes. By leveraging pseudonymized data responsibly, researchers can unlock new knowledge, address pressing challenges, and contribute to the advancement of science and innovation. - interdisciplinary and long-term planning and vision facilitating policy integration - stakeholder engagement: engaging stakeholders, including farmers, researchers, policymakers, and industry representatives, fosters collaboration and ensures that the Farm Sustainability Data Network reflects the needs and priorities. - use of data for cap strategic plans: the Farm Sustainability Data Network can support Member States in the design and implementation of Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) Strategic Plans by providing data-driven insights and recommendations. This collaboration enhances the effectiveness and efficiency of CAP initiatives, ultimately contributing to the sustainability of European agriculture.

However this depends on the relevant aggregate data on climate impacts being made available when and where useful in timely manner, in an efficient and simplified way to the right stakeholders. This goes beyond parties engaged in academic research, but needs to encompass especially pilot schemes and ground-truthing emission-reduction and adaptation initiatives with farmers in real-world settings - and particularly where the aim is improving livelihoods within frameworks of improved and fairer contractual relations. In order to better achieve the objective stated in preamble 17 of the regulation, Environmental Defense Fund Europe makes drafting proposals accompanied by justifications in the accompanying document, in order to make the relevant data more accessible and useful.

short_title: Revision of olive oil marketing standards
Feedback: Introduction The European Commission opened a feedback period (18 December 2023 15 January 2024) on draft delegated regulations on updating the marketing standards for Olive oil. We appreciate this opportunity and thank the Commission services for the possibility to give our feedback. The feedback concerns the new limit values for the characteristics of olive oil set out in Regulation (EU) 2022/2104, which are set in accordance with the IOC Trade Standard applying to olive oil and olive-pomace oil (IOC Trade Standard). The IOC Trade Standard changed with regard to one chemical parameter, Δ-7-stigmastenol, and Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/2104 should be amended accordingly. Thus, the act amends Annex I of Delegated Regulation (EU) 2022/2104 with regard to the chemical parameter Δ-7-stigmastenol. Considering that a modification of the current legislative setting is open, we would like to consider suggestions further modifications that do not only relate to the Annex of the Delegated Regulation 2022/2104 and the issue of Δ-7-stigmastenol as it follows: 1. Article 3 Blends of olive oil with other vegetables - Delegated Regulation (UE) 2022/2104 Modify Art 3 of the Delegated regulation by extending national prohibition of such practices -the blends of olive oil with other vegetable oils- to the whole of the EU internal market. We consider that the modification of the regulations must contemplate the elimination of these mixtures throughout the European Union, as it is already the case in certain Member States. In this way, fraud will be easily avoided in such cases where the national market prohibits the actual process of blending on its territory, but not the sales of it. This practice violates the rationality of the correct functioning of the internal market within the Union. The justification is based on the effort made by companies and organizations in the sector to obtain a genuine and authentic product, differentiated by its quality, organoleptic characteristics and its health benefits, and from which other fat manufacturers try to take advantage. This practice may confuse consumers while putting at risk the image of the olive oil sector. insisting on the impossibility of detecting the percentage of the components of the mixture, and therefore, It is impossible to guarantee the consumer the veracity of the product they are purchasing, opening a wide window to fraud. 2. Article 4 Packaging Hermetic stop in Horeca - Delegated Regulation (UE) 2022/2104 Extend the obligation of paragraph 1 concerning the opening system that can no longer be sealed after the first time for packaging formats equal or exceeding five liters also to oils intended for consumption in restaurants, hospitals, canteens and other similar collective establishments. Maintaining the olive oil bottling requirement is essential in order not to jeopardize food safety and to fight against fraud and adulteration, as well as to create a level playing field on the market for EU producers.

short_title: Certification for hops and hop products
Feedback: Following the European Commissions plans to modernize the certification system for hops and hop products (current Regulation n.1850/2006), Copa and Cogeca would like to stress the optimal functioning of the currents system that assures quality controls and top marketing standards for European hops. The European Commission intends to update the system through two secondary legislation acts: a delegated regulation and an implementing one concerning the marketing standards and the certification and control systems for hops and hop products. Content Copa and Cogeca would like to stress the following points of concern: 1. The certification authority designed by the Member State offices shall be allowed to officially certify hops qualities and to appoint third parties as certification centers. No other entity such as approved operators shall be given delegated powers to implement such an activity. We believe that only certification authorities or designated certification centers have the know-how and the administrative infrastructure already in place that will guarantee the high level of their services. Opening certification actives to actors rather than the certification centers risks putting in jeopardy the strong certification system that represents the building stone of the strong European hop production. Opening to the possibility of national level decisions would also risk fragmenting the quality certification of hops and it could lead to favor fraudulent practices. Overall, the certification system as it currently stands does not pose any administrative burden to producers and, on the opposite, assures them that the care and quality of their production will be strongly enforced and recognized. Despite the bulk of the costs must be bored by the hop growers and the processors, reputation, reliability, traceability, and credibility of their production depends on a strong certification system. 2. Any criteria (minimum requirements) regarding seed content shall be part of the certification. The current definition sets the threshold for identifying seedless hops when the seeds weight is lower than 2% of the whole weight of the hop. We do believe that this definition is appropriate, and it represents an indirect measure of quality. We welcome the provisions as in the draft text. 3. Isomerized products shall be excluded from the certification. The difficulty in tracing the origin of hops once they had gone through isomerization as well as their processing method would prevent on-point and precise quality checks (in line with Art 1 (3), Reg 1850/2006). We argue this practice to be allowed but outside the scope of the certification standards. We welcome the provisions as in the draft text. In particular, we suggest the followings amendments: Recital 4 Remove or approved operator. Recital 8 Remove Or if the processing is carried out by approved operators. Recital 10 Remove and should be allowed to approve operators. Recital 11 Remove and approved operators. Recital 12 Remove or an approved operator. Article 2 (4) Remove at the premises of an approved operator. Article 2 (7) Remove or by an approved operator. Article 3 (1) Remove or by an approved operator. Article 4 (1) Remove or approved operator. Article 8 (1) Remove or if the processing is carried out by an approved operator. Article 9 (3) Remove or the approved operator. Article 10 (2) Remove and may approve operators. Article 12 Delete Article 12. Article 13 (1) Remove references to approved operators. Article 15 (1) Delete point d. Delete or the withdrawal of the approval of an operator. Article 16 Delete and approved operators and their code numbers.

Feedback: Bonjour Le régime d'équivalence présente de nombreux désavantage pour les consommateurs et les producteurs européens - un même logo pour des produits non UE qui ne réponde pas au même cahier des charges avec le risque de se retrouver avec des produits de traitements non autorisés en Europe - manque de transparence sur les cahiers des charges non UE puisque non accessible aux consommateurs et aux producteurs -manque de traçabilité de l'origine des productions des intrants et des pratiques de productions -manque de contrôle des qualités nutritionnelles et bactériologiques des produits non UE étiqueté bio par rapport aux produits UE -Concurrence déloyale par rapport aux producteurs européens Avec ce régime d'équivalence la commission européenne ne protège pas les consommateurs et les producteurs européens C'est pourquoi je demande la suppression du régime d'équivalence au profit du régime de conformité Merci

short_title: Imports of organic products – recognised third countries and control bodies (updated list)
Feedback: Étant producteur de Spiruline en France, je trouve indécent ce régime déquivalence car il permet aux producteurs hors UE (souvent asiatiques) de faire rentrer leur Spiruline dans les magasins bio français alors quil nous est impossible de connaître les exigences de leurs cahiers des charges. Et quand on connaît les qualités de leau déplorables de ces pays, on peut légitimement se poser beaucoup de questions sur la qualité gustative et sanitaire de ces produits qui inondent notre marché. Cette Spiruline est largement majoritaire en France et cause un préjudice vis-à-vis des producteurs français qui défendent un modèle paysan. De plus limportation de ses produits de moindre qualité sont source de pollution, de par leur production et leur transport jusquen Europe. Un autre aspect de ce problème de régime déquivalence et la traçabilité qui est la plupart du temps impossible sur les produits non UE. Afin de garantir une sécurité sanitaire et une qualité optimum aux consommateurs, ainsi quà fin de soutenir l'agriculture européenne, je pense quil est préférable de supprimer ce régime déquivalence au profit du régime de conformité, qui serait beaucoup juste et équitable.

short_title: Imports of organic products – recognised third countries and control bodies (updated list)
Feedback: On n'y comprends rien à ce régime d'équivalence Bio étranger ! Pourquoi les chinois par exemple ne sont pas obligés de se conformer aux cahiers des charges européens ? on ne sait pas ce qu'il y a dans les cahier des charges bios étrangers , visiblement il n'y a pas aucun contrôle du côté européen . Ce manque de transparence nuit à la confiance et personnellement, je n'achète plus rien de bio qui vienne de l'étranger car je n'ai aucune confiance dans ce bio là, le bio étranger est autorisé à mettre des produits interdits en Europe depuis fort longtemps ! D'ailleurs cela jette le doute sur l'ensemble du Bio car il faut toujours vérifier le pays producteur ce qui n'est pas toujours clairement indiqué, voir c'est trompeur : parfois même, on trouve la notion de fabriqué en France mais "production non UE", on cherchant un peu je découvre que c'est chinois, indien ou autre mais tout le monde ne fait pas l'effort de se renseigner et se trouve clairement abusé en pensant acheter français alors que cela vient de l'autre côté de la planète (bonjour le côté écologique !) Ce régime d'équivalence est même clairement une tromperie pour le consommateur, il peut même nuire à sa santé et pour finir, il mets en plus nos propres producteurs bio en difficultés (voir ce qui se passe depuis quelques temps pour le bio) Il me paraît donc indispensable de supprimer le régime déquivalence au profit exclusivement de la conformité.

short_title: Imports of organic products – recognised third countries and control bodies (updated list)
Feedback: Les consommateurs ont le droit d'être convenablement informés sur la manière dont les produits achetés ont été produits. Aujourd'hui, le régime d'équivalence ne permet pas une traçabilité rigoureuse et comparative des pratiques entre les différents pays d'origine. En tant que producteurs de plantes aromatiques et médicinales, nous remarquons qu'il n'y aucune garantie quant à la traçabilité des pratiques qui sont mises en œuvre au delà des frontières européennes que ce soit sur les procédés de productions ou les intrants employés. Certains produits chimiques sont autorisés ailleurs et cela engendre une concurrence déloyale vis-à-vis des producteurs en Europe. Et cela nuit en particulier à tout le tissu des petits producteurs qui s'engagent par conviction dans la voie de l'agriculture biologique et pour qui le maintien des pratiques biologique est parfois un coût important. Le régime déquivalence crée une distorsion de concurrence pour les producteurs bio UE face aux producteurs non UE et est de toute évidence plus favorable aux industriels. C'est pourquoi nous souhaitons que ce régime soit remplacé par un régime de conformité afin que les pratiques puissent être comparée en toute transparence et que les importations de produits bio hors UE. Cela est d'autant plus important que le label bio aujourd'hui est utilisé quelle que soit les origines des matières premières. Seule la mention en tout petit "agriculture UE/nonUE" marque la différence ce qui n'est pas très lisible pour les consommateurs. Enfin, dans le contexte actuel de l'impérieuse nécessité de s'orienter rapidement vers une transition écologique efficace, marquer la différence entre les produits bio hors UE et les produits bio UE permettrait au consommateurs de faire un choix plus éclairé et aurait sans nul doute un effet favorable à la relocalisation de la consommation des productions européennes offrant une plus grande souveraineté alimentaire et augmentant la décarbonisation liée au transport des marchandises. Nous demandons donc la suppression du régime d'équivalence au profit du régime de conformité. Audrey BENAVENT, porte-parole du Syndicat SIMPLES (Syndicat Inter-massifs pour la Production et l'Economie des Simples)

short_title: Imports of organic products – recognised third countries and control bodies (updated list)
Feedback: Le régime déquivalence crée une distorsion de concurrence pour les producteurs de PPAM de l' UE. La suppression du régime déquivalence permettrait de créer plusieurs milliers demplois pour la filière PPAM qui est en plein essor dans l'UE. Le régime déquivalence détruit le modèle de production paysanne au profit dun modèle industriel. il est à l'encontre de la protection de la biodiversité. Le régime d'équivalence mettra en danger les ressources naturelles, car il existe de nombreux pays (Chine, Nepal, Inde, Turquie, Maroc etc.) où la surexploitation des PPAM est manifeste et met en danger la biodiversité mais où le faible coût de la main d'oeuvre et sa faible qualification ne permet pas une cueillette soutenable *www.syndicat-simples.org .

short_title: Imports of organic products – recognised third countries and control bodies (updated list)
Feedback: Les régimes déquivalence doivent être supprimés. Opacité/absence dinformations sur les produits : certains cahiers des charges étrangers ne sont pas disponibles ou trop permissifs. Logos Bio UE /hors UE pas distincts sur le produit : trompe le client, perte de confiance, informations erronées. Risque sanitaire : pas la même réglementation/normes sur lutilisation de certains produits et/ou mode opératoire que lUE. Pas de traçabilité. Bilan carbone des produits/intrants importés : en contradiction avec les engagements Européens et les dernières COP Concurrence déloyale : coût de production moindre dans de nombreux pays ou le cahier des charges et la réglementation est très permissif. (hygiène, code du travail, produit interdit en UE.) Le résultat est une concurrence déloyale pour les producteurs européens, des risques sanitaires pour le consommateur et délétère pour lenvironnement. Pour toutes ces raisons le bon sens vous impose de faire votre devoir, devoirs que les citoyens européens vous exhortent. Pierre-André M. producteur de spiruline.

short_title: Certification for hops and hop products
Feedback: Wir wenden uns mit unserer Stellungnahme gegen das Vorhaben der Kommission, künftig eine Selbstzertifizierung von Hopfen und Hopfenerzeugnissen durch einen "approved operator", also einen Hopfenerzeuger oder -verarbeiter unter bestimmten Voraussetzungen zu ermöglichen. Nach unserem Wissensstand gibt es in der EU keinen Mitgliedsstaat mit etabliertem Hopfenanbau, der sich für die Selbstzertifizierung von Hopfen und Hopfenerzeugnissen ausgesprochen hat. Die Kommission missachtet mit ihrem Vorhaben die Erfahrungen und Wünsche der betroffenen und erfahrenen Hopfenbaunationen und handelt somit gegen deren Interessen. Dies wird gerechtfertigt mit Rücksichtnahme auf kleinere Hopfenproduzenten und dem Bemühen dort mögliche Erschwernisse zu vermeiden. Die jahrzehntelange Erfahrung der Menschen und Staaten, die eine Zertifizierung OHNE der Möglichkeit einer Selbstzertifizierung in der Praxis umsetzen, bestätigt, dass die Zertifizierung tatsächlich kein Erschwernis darstellt. Den hierzu notwendigen Aufwand halten wir für durchaus vertretbar, zumal der Aufwand bei der Selbstzertifizierung aufgrund der hierfür notwendigen Voraussetzungen gerade für die kleinen Hopfenerzeuger nicht unerheblich wäre. Aus diesem Grund sollte das bewährte Verfahren ausdrücklich beibehalten werden. Das Vorhaben der Kommission würde bedeuten, dass für eine mögliche geringe Entlastung von nur wenigen Hopfenpflanzern und -verarbeitern ein starkes und bewährtes Instrument zur Vermarktung und Rückverfolgbarkeit aufgegeben werden soll, welches weltweit ein sehr hohes Vertrauen genießt und nicht zuletzt dadurch den so wichtigen Export europäischer Hopfen unterstützt. Eine kleine Vereinfachung für vermutlich nur wenige Hundert Hektar Hopfen in Europa steht im Vordergrund und die weiterhin erfolgreiche weltweite Vermarktung von ca. 30.000 Hektar europäischen Hopfens im Wert von mehreren Hundert Millionen Euro würde geschwächt. Das ist für Bayern mit der europaweit größten Hopfenanbaufläche nicht nachvollziebar. Die Bewertung der angestrebten Erleichterung einerseits und die Bedeutung des Zertifizierungssystem in seiner bisherigen Ausprägung ohne Selbstzertifizierung mit einem sehr hohen Vertrauensgrad seitens der weltweiten Brauwirtschaft andererseits durch die Kommission stehen im Gegensatz zu der uns bekannten Beurteilung in der Hopfenindustrie. Aus Sicht der Hopfenindustrie würden die positiven Folgen der Vereinfachung überbewertet und die negativen Auswirkungen auf die weltweite Brauindustrie stark unterbewertet. Solche Fehleinschätzungen können zu folgenreichen falschen Entscheidungen führen. Aus diesen Gründen spricht sich das Bayerische Staatsministerium für Ernährung, Landwirtschaft und Forsten gegen die Zulassung der Selbstzertifizierung im Europäischen Hopfenbau durch die geplanten Delegierten bzw. Durchführungsrechtsakte aus.

short_title: Certification for hops and hop products
Feedback: Copa and Cogeca would like to stress the following points of concern: 1. The certification authority designed by the Member State offices shall be allowed to officially certify hops qualities and to appoint third parties as certification centers. No other entity such as approved operators shall be given delegated powers to implement such an activity. We believe that only certification authorities or designated certification centers have the know-how and the administrative infrastructure already in place that will guarantee the high level of their services. Opening certification actives to actors rather than the certification centers risks putting in jeopardy the strong certification system that represents the building stone of the strong European hop production. Opening to the possibility of national level decisions would also risk fragmenting the quality certification of hops and it could lead to favor fraudulent practices. Overall, the certification system as it currently stands does not pose any administrative burden to producers and, on the opposite, assures them that the care and quality of their production will be strongly enforced and recognized. Despite the bulk of the costs must be bored by the hop growers and the processors, reputation, reliability, traceability, and credibility of their production depends on a strong certification system. 2. Any criteria (minimum requirements) regarding seed content shall be part of the certification. The current definition sets the threshold for identifying seedless hops when the seeds weight is lower than 2% of the whole weight of the hop. We do believe that this definition is appropriate, and it represents an indirect measure of quality. We welcome the provisions as set in the draft text. 3. Isomerized products shall be excluded from the certification. The difficulty in tracing the origin of hops once they had gone through isomerization as well as their processing method would prevent on-point and precise quality checks (in line with Art 1 (3), Reg 1850/2006). We argue this practice to be allowed but outside the scope of the certification standards. We welcome the provisions as set in the draft text. We propose the following changes to the text: Recital 3 Add A solid and certain certification system assures that the quality of European hops and hop products is respected and that European hop growers get recognition of their work, after the following phrase: Breweries pay great attention to the quality of the hops used in the brewing process because that ingredient has a big influence on the taste of the final product. Recital 6 Remove or by approved operators. Article 3 (m) Remove and approved operators. Article 3 (p) Remove the whole paragraph. Article 8 (1) Remove or by approved operators.

short_title: Indication of ingredients for aromatised wine products
Feedback: Gerne nehmen der Verband Deutscher Sektkellereien e.V., der Bundesverband der Deutschen Weinkellereien e.V. sowie der Bundesverband Wein und Spirituosen International e.V. die Gelegenheit der Stellungnahme zum Entwurf eines delegierten Rechtsakts zur Verordnung (EU) Nr. 251/2014 wahr: In Artikel 1 Absatz 1 des Entwurfs des delegierten Rechtsakts zur Verordnung VO (EU) Nr. 251/2014 ist geregelt, dass der in aromatisierten Weinerzeugnissen verwendete Grundwein nur als solcher betitelt innerhalb der Zutatenliste des aromatisierten Weinerzeugnisses angegeben werden darf gefolgt mit einer Aufzählung der im Wein enthaltenen Zutaten in einer Klammer (z.B. Zutaten: Wein [Zutaten des Weins], Zucker, Aroma, ). Nicht vorgesehen ist hingegen die Möglichkeit, alle Zutaten des aromatisierten Weinerzeugnisses ohne Verwendung des Wortes Wein einzeln aufzulisten (z.B. Zutaten: Traubenmost, Zucker, Aroma, Sulfite, ). Den allgemeinen lebensmittelkennzeichnungsrechtlichen Grundsätzen entsprechend sollten daher neben der Variante, das Wort Wein mit der Auflistung der Zutaten in einer Klammer anzugeben, alternativ sämtliche in dem aromatisierten Weinerzeugnis enthaltene Zutaten entsprechend ihres Gewichtsanteils in mengenmäßig absteigender Reihenfolge aufzählend angegeben werden dürfen. Mehrfach verwendete Zutaten, wie Zucker, könnten somit zusammengefasst werden und würden nur einmal entsprechend ihres Gewichtsanteils in der Zutatenliste aufgeführt. Im Übrigen ist aus unserer Sicht eine Klarstellung in Artikel 1 Absatz 2 des Entwurfs dahingehend erforderlich, dass nur die in Anhang II der Verordnung (EU) 1169/2011 gelisteten Allergene im Rahmen der Etikettierung aufgeführt werden müssen.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: Fevia verwelkomt de evaluatie van de UTP-richtlijn. Eerlijke handelspraktijken zijn een voorwaarde om kwalitatieve en betaalbare producten op de markt te brengen en om antwoorden te bieden op maatschappelijke uitdagingen. Fairness in de toeleveringsketen wordt erkend als een noodzaak voor een duurzaam en veerkrachtig ecosysteem. UTP's kunnen de winst en marges van voedingsbedrijven onder druk zetten, waardoor de investeringscapaciteit van bedrijven afneemt. Daarom is deze wetgeving essentieel voor de voedingsindustrie.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: LTO NEDERLAND supports the feedback of COPA. LTO remains supportive of the EU legislative against unfair trading practices in agrofood and the ornamental sector (live plants). Although in the Netherlands, the ACM and De Geschillencommissie have received limited reponse and complaints so far, LTO believes the new legislation has helped to define to operators what is and what isn't 'unfair'. This has helped to raise awareness. Operators know the 'red line' while negotiating contracts. This is difficult to measure but this effect should be considered a result of the new legisation. LTO finds it necessary that branche organisations may submit complaints on behalf of individual members in order to protect their identity. It would be good if the competent authorities report yearly about the state of play i.e. number of complaints received and in process. Article 210a sCMO should be added to the scope of the UTP meaning agreements about higher sustainability standards which yield a determined price premium.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: La Unión de Pequeños Agricultores y Ganaderos (UPA) es una organización profesional agraria que agrupa, representa y defiende los intereses de los profesionales de la agricultura y la ganadería en España. UPA cuenta con más de 80.000 afiliados en toda Españas cuyos titulares son pequeños y medianos agricultores y ganaderos. La directiva de prácticas desleales supone un punto de inflexión con el reconocimiento explícito de desequilibrios importantes en cuanto a poder de negociación entre proveedores y compradores de productos agrícolas y alimentarios y la existencia de prácticas comerciales desleales. La debilidad de la producción y su mermada capacidad de negociación viene por su atomización, pero también por el hecho de que la mayoría de los productos son perecederos y eso introduce una debilidad palmaria en el proceso de negociación. Se trata de una norma imprescindible que debe dar un paso más y contemplar como práctica prohibida la destrucción del valor de la cadena alimentaria. Sólo se puede concebir operadores que generen valor cuando el producto pasa por sus manos y no se puede permitir la destrucción del mismo entendiendo como tal la venta de un producto a un precio inferior al de adquisición incluyendo los costes generados en dicha transacción o modificación del producto. Conceptos como la venta a resultas que supone de hecho que el operador no tenga ni soporte ningún riesgo empresarial porque liquidará a su proveedor a lo que resulte según el precio al que haya, a su vez, vendido él o la venta a pérdidas deben ser prácticas prohibidas en la reglamentación comunitaria. Respecto al ámbito, la UPA cree que debe ir más allá de los productos agrícolas y alimentarios para abarcar algunos productos no alimentarios, como flores y plantas ornamentales Respecto a los plazos de pago en el caso de que haya entregas periódicas debe establecerse un criterio más restrictivo no permitiéndose fijar una fecha de pago y a partir de ahí considerar 30 días porque es una vía para incumplir el espíritu de la norma. De igual forma ante entregas periódicas continuadas se deben agrupar dichas entregas mensualmente de tal forma que los 30 días empiecen a contar desde el día 15 del mes en cuestión. La definición de prácticas prohibidas grises no deja de introducir un criterio de discrecionalidad porque ese posible acuerdo al que hace referencia la directiva en muchas ocasiones viene o puede venir obligado por la parte compradora, por lo que en opinión de UPA debería pasar a ser prohibidas sin condiciones. Cuando hay situación de dependencia económica entre denunciante y denunciado cobra capital importancia preservar el anonimato del denunciante. Se debería habilitar procedimientos totalmente seguros que garanticen que las denuncias que se hagan a través de organizaciones de productores o asociaciones agrarias puedan ser tenidas en cuenta sin tener que indicar el nombre del o de los denunciantes que representan. Seguramente el miedo a represalias es el freno más importante que tiene la directiva para alcanzar sus objetivos. Junto a las sanciones en España se está demostrando que es clave la publicación de las empresas sancionadas y el motivo de la sanción. El daño reputacional derivado de una mala práctica es mucho más coercitivo que el propio económico derivado de la sanción. Por tanto, es imprescindible conocer quien realiza prácticas desleales. Finalmente aunque se salgo del objeto de esta directiva, UPA considera que si lo que se quiere es asegurar una renta justa a los productores y que éstos reciban una compensación justa por el trabajo que realizan a través de la venta de sus productos es fundamental que se empiece a considerar la negociación colectiva sectorial como un instrumento clave que permite equilibrar la relación de fuerza en el proceso de negociación. Pedimos que se permita realizar a través de los representantes de los agricultores y ganaderos un proceso de negociación que fije condiciones generales de entrega, calidades....

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: LInstitut Européen pour le Droit de lAnimal (lInstitut) accueille favorablement lappel à contribution de la Commission européenne sur lévaluation et le bilan de qualité de la directive sur les pratiques commerciales déloyales au sein de la chaîne d'approvisionnement agricole et alimentaire. Dans ce cadre, linstitut tient à attirer lattention de la Commission sur la situation économique préoccupante des éleveurs qui ne bénéficient pas pleinement des garanties offertes par la Directive 2019/633. Deux situations contractuelles constituent un terrain particulièrement propice aux pratiques commerciales déloyales : les contrats d'intégrations établis avec les entreprises commerciales et les contrats liant les agriculteurs aux coopératives agricoles desquelles ils sont associés. Il serait pertinent dans le cadre de cette évaluation de prêter une attention particulière à ces situations afin de dresser un état des lieux fidèle des pratiques commerciales déloyales et envisager des solutions pour y remédier.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: Das Forum Fairer Handel der Verband des Fairen Handels in Deutschland - bekräftigt die Notwendigkeit einer starken Gesetzgebung zur Bekämpfung unlauterer Handelspraktiken (UTP) in globalen Lieferketten, um kleine Lebensmittelproduzenten und bäuerliche Familienbetriebe vor Einkäufern zu schützen, die ihre Marktmacht missbrauchen. Die Richtlinie (EU) 2019/633 über unlautere Handelspraktiken in den Beziehungen zwischen Unternehmen in der Agrar- und Lebensmittelversorgungskette (UTP-Richtlinie) war ein wichtiger Schritt, um gerechtere Beziehungen zwischen den Marktteilnehmer*innen zu fördern. Mit Blick auf das am 09. Juni 2021 in Kraft getretene Agrarorganisationen-und-Lieferketten-Gesetz (AgrarOLkG), mit welchem Deutschland die UTP-Richtlinie umgesetzt hat, bedarf es jedoch Anpassungen, um Produzent*innen am Beginn der Agrarlieferketten in Deutschland, der EU und weltweit zu stärken: Adressierung der Problematik niedriger Erzeugerpreise: Die UTP-Richtlinie adressiert das für viele Erzeuger*innen drängende Problem niedriger Erzeugerpreise, die häufig noch nicht einmal die Produktionskosten decken, nicht ausreichend. Regelungen wie sie in Spanien mit dem Verbot des Einkaufs unterhalb der Produktionskosten eingeführt wurden, zeigen erste positive Wirkung, wie etwa jüngste Entwicklungen der Rohmilchpreise zeigen. Durch ein Gebot des Kaufs zu kostendeckenden Preisen ähnlich der Regelungen in Spanien würde der Preis eines Produktes auf den Erzeugerkosten aufbauen, was den Preisdruck von oben nach unten in der Lieferkette einhegen würde. In Verträgen sollten künftig folgende Aspekte verbindlich vereinbart sein: Menge, Preis, Qualität (z.B. Weidehaltung), Laufzeit und Zahlungsziel. Eine solche Vertragsgestaltung würde Überproduktion und Lebensmittelverschwendung verringern, weil nur die Mengen erzeugt werden, die zu kostendeckenden Preisen weiterverkauft werden können. Einführung einer Generalklausel: Die Klausel muss unlautere Handelspraktiken grundsätzlich verbieten und so Ausweichbewegungen von Käufern in Richtung anderer Druckmittel stoppen. Dies würde verhindern, dass Käufer die im AgrarOLkG bzw. in der UTP-Regulierung aufgelisteten Verbote umgehen und andere unlautere Handelspraktiken anwenden. Überführung der bisher grauen in schwarze Handelspraktiken: Die bisherige Erfahrung zeigt, dass sich unlautere Handelspraktiken bei ungleichen Verhandlungspositionen erst durch klare Verbote einhegen lassen. Solange die Marktmacht der Käuferseite erheblich größer ist als die der Erzeugerseite, müssen bisher graue Praktiken verboten und in schwarze überführt werden. Anwendungsbereich für Erzeuger*innen und Lieferanten außerhalb der EU klarstellen: Gemäß Art. 1 Abs. 2 UAbs. 3 UTP-Richtlinie bzw. § 10 Abs. 1 S. 1 AgrarOlkG erstreckt sich der Schutz vor unlauteren Handelspraktiken auch auf solche Erzeuger, die ihren Sitz außerhalb der EU haben. Allerdings ist der persönliche und räumliche Anwendungsbereich nicht eindeutig geregelt. Damit Erzeuger*innen aus Drittstaaten, die in die EU liefern, ausreichend vor unfairen Handelspraktiken geschützt werden, muss in der Nachfassung der Richtlinie eine Klarstellung des Anwendungsbereichs erfolgen. Insbesondere die Umgehung der Anwendbarkeit durch Zwischenschaltung von Einkaufsgesellschaften außerhalb der EU muss verhindert werden. Verschränkung der UTP-Richtlinie mit der geplanten Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (CSDDD): Beide Richtlinien sind für die Verbesserung der Produktionsbedingungen und ihrer Auswirkungen entlang globaler Lieferketten wichtige erste Schritte und können sich gegenseitig gut ergänzen. Um die Ziele der beiden Richtlinie wirksam zu verstärken, sollte die UTP-Richtlinie um ein Verbot ergänzt werden, welches Vereinbarungen untersagt, die aufgrund des Verhältnisses von Forderungen und Gegenforderung die Gefährdung der Ziele der CSDDD nahelegen.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: EuroCommerce, the EU association for retailers and wholesalers, welcomes the possibility to provide comments to the European Commission as part of the initial stages of the evaluation of the Directive on unfair trading practices in the agri-food supply chain. As a measure based on the agriculture provisions of the Treaty, the Directive should be assessed against its impact on farmers. The entry into force of the Directive on unfair trading practices coincided with very unstable agri-food markets. The Commission should consider such economic context when conducting its assessment as to whether the rules achieved their intended aim and if more time is needed to evaluate the effects, given some rules only entered into force in 2022. Over-implementation of the Directive in certain member states (through new practices or by extending the scope of the rules to large multinational suppliers) can create risks to legal certainty and burdens to companies wishing to operate cross-border in the EU. Extending the scope of the rules to large suppliers brings no benefits to farmers and can have negative effects on consumers in the form of higher prices. The Commission should ensure that national transposition of the Directive is compatible with EU single market rules. Further reflections are shared on our paper.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: Unión de Uniones de Agricultores y Ganaderos (TR ID) Registro de Transparencia 643875852019-50 Tras la entrada en vigor de la Directiva (UE) 2019/633 del Parlamento Europeo y del Consejo, de 17 de abril de 2019, relativa a las prácticas comerciales desleales en las relaciones entre empresas en la cadena de suministro agrícola y alimentario; una de las obligaciones de la Comisión Europea al respecto de la misma es la evaluación de cara a efectuar un seguimiento y comprobación de la eficacia de las disposiciones contenidas en la misma de cara a conseguir sus objetivos. En el marco de esta evaluación se ha abierto una convocatoria de datos de forma que las partes interesadas pueden hacer llegar información al respecto de cómo la Directiva está determinando una mejora en las relaciones en la cadena alimentaria. En este sentido, Unión de Uniones de Agricultores y Ganaderos viene trabajando para mejorar la posición del primer eslabón de la cadena con respecto al resto, por lo que ha considerado oportuno responder a esta convocatoria de datos. El análisis que se realiza se ha encuadrado en el ámbito de España, analizando la Ley 16/2021, de 14 de diciembre, por la que se modifica la Ley 12/2013, de 2 de agosto, de medidas para mejorar el funcionamiento de la cadena alimentaria; que es la Ley a través de la cual se traspone la Directiva en el ordenamiento jurídico español. Además, en el proceso de dicha trasposición, fruto de las reivindicaciones del sector agrario estatal, la Ley ha establecido disposiciones más allá de la mera trasposición de la Directiva, que tenían como objetivo reforzar la posición de los agricultores y ganaderos en la cadena agroalimentaria. Sin embargo, fruto del análisis de la organización, se considera que en dicha Ley faltaron elementos cruciales para mejorar esta posición y además las herramientas establecidas no parecen haber conseguido que los agricultores y ganaderos perciban un precio justo por su trabajo, al menos de forma significativa en cuanto a precios. Como principales conclusiones de los datos presentados, se destacan: - La Ley 16/2021 española introduce elementos no contemplados en la Directiva 2019/633 y errores en la trasposición de la misma, hecho que esta organización ya ha denunciado a la Comisión Europea. - El aumento de las capacidades y funciones de las autoridades de ejecución, en este caso de la AICA O.A., no ha venido acompañado de un aumento en las asignaciones presupuestarias o la ejecución de las mismas, que le permita desarrollar dichas responsabilidades, así como deficiencias en la coordinación entre autoridades de ejecución. - La Ley 16/2021 incluye disposiciones que van más allá de lo dispuesto en la Directiva 2019/633; que se han presentado al sector como una gran herramienta de protegerse frente a los eslabones superiores de la cadena, como la necesidad de que en los contratos el precio pagado supere los costes de producción, sin embargo, en la aplicación de la Ley se han establecido mecanismos que han entorpecido la efectiva aplicación de esta disposición. - El régimen sancionador de la Ley 12/2013 no parece estar modulado de forma que las sanciones que se interponen tengan un carácter disuasorio. - En el proceso legislativo se pudieron haber considerado propuestas que suponían herramientas de importancia que contribuirían a reequilibrar la relación entre eslabones de la cadena e impedirían la destrucción de valor dentro de la misma que, sin embargo, no fueron incluidas en los textos reguladores.

short_title: Unfair trading practices in the agricultural and food supply chain
Feedback: L'Ilec-La Voix des marques représente plus de 100 fabricants de grandes marques dans le secteur des produits de grande consommation. Ces fabricants sont présents dans tous les territoires de France avec plus de 1000 sites, dont 500 sites industriels. Ils emploient directement 150 000 collaborateurs et transforment plus de la moitié de la production agricole française en volume. 60 millions de leurs produits sont consommés chaque jour par les citoyens français. L'Ilec et son organisation européenne l'AIM coopèrent depuis de longues années avec les fédérations représentant les autres acteurs de la chaîne agro-alimentaire et avec les décideurs politiques français et européens afin déradiquer les pratiques déloyales. Ces pratiques imposées par la partie détenant un pouvoir de marché supérieur à son partenaire commercial doivent être bannies car elles sont injustes moralement, conduisent à des inefficacités sur le marché au détriment des opérateurs vertueux et enrichissent indument la partie forte au détriment de toutes les autres parties prenantes. Les initiatives politiques contre ces pratiques ont dabord pris la forme dinitiatives volontaires soutenues par lensemble des acteurs comme la Supply Chain Initiative au niveau européen, puis devant linefficacité de cette méthode, à ladoption de dispositions législatives contraignantes au niveau français puis européen avec ladoption de la directive européenne sur les pratiques déloyales en 2019. Cette directive aura constitué un premier pas important avec la création dune liste de pratiques reconnues comme déloyales dans tous les Etats membres, la création dautorités de contrôles et dun réseau européen pour partager des bonnes pratiques. En revanche, la base juridique de la directive avait empêché les parlementaires européens daller aussi loin quils le souhaitaient, excluant de fait un certain nombre dentreprises, et par ricochet leurs fournisseurs agriculteurs, de la protection offerte par la directive. Par ailleurs, les table-rondes organisées par lIlec, avec la participation de la FNSEA, des décideurs politiques européens et des parlementaires à Bruxelles ont permis de mettre en exergue un certain nombre daméliorations nécessaires : une meilleure harmonisation entre les Etats membres dans lapplication de la directive, une meilleure prise en compte des pratiques par nature transfrontalières des alliances européennes de distributeurs qui se multiplient et un accroissement des moyens du réseau européen des autorités de contrôle pour appréhender ces pratiques transfrontalières limpératif de réaffirmer la complémentarité entre le droit européen et les lois de police des Etats membres qui encadrent les relations commerciales entre fournisseurs agro-alimentaires et distributeurs. Dans cet esprit, l'Ilec décide de contribuer à cette consultation pour aboutir à un cadre réglementaire européen complet, cohérent et favorable à une chaîne dapprovisionnement agro-alimentaire durable au bénéfice de tous.

short_title: Imported organic products - Supervision of third countries, control authorities and control bodies
Feedback: OPTA Europe - www.opta-eu.org - is the membership organization representing the interest of EU organic processing and trade companies. Its membership encompasses 12 EU Member States plus 2 non-EU countries. Taken together, the companies represented by OPTA Europe account for a large share of total EU import & export and processing of organic products. OPTA Europes members are committed to deliver safe and trustable organic food to EU consumers, whatever its geographical origin. We thank you for the opportunity to comment on these draft rules and for issuing a WTO notification opening the consultation to trading partners in third countries, as they are the first affected by the additional reporting and evaluation obligations imposed by this rule until the expiry of the recognition of the third countries or control authorities and control bodies. As a general comment, we believe that trade plays a key role in the promotion worldwide of EU sustainability standards. We hope that the additional control obligations imposed by this Regulation will be accompanied by capacity building activities for trading partners in emerging countries, to encourage them in the development of organics. For example, by increasing trainings on EU organic rules for responsible staff of controlling authorities at national, regional or local level under the Better Training for Safer Food program. Our specific comments on this draft regulation: -The EU has recently laid down the details and the format of the information for competent authorities of EU Member States to report on the results of official investigations concerning cases of contamination with products or substances not authorised for use in organic production (Commission Regulation 2023/1195). We suggest taking this updating opportunity to harmonize, to the extent possible, the reporting obligations on official investigations to be made available by third countries competent authorities with those required to EU Member States competent authorities, in particular when it comes to contamination with non-authorized products or substances. -When evaluating the capacity of Member States to assist the Commission on the review of recognition of third countries, the criteria of the number of votes in the Committee does not necessarily reflect its competence. The concentration of organic imports in certain EU countries implies that some national authorities have larger expertise, thus are more qualified. We suggest introducing additional criteria to ensure that Member States assisting the Commission are sufficiently skilled. In closing, we deplore the complexity of the EU legal framework for organics, which represents a real barrier for operators and trading partners with less resources for regulatory screening to access the proposed rules and to bring their viewpoint in public consultations on topics impacting them.

short_title: Imported organic products - Supervision of third countries, control authorities and control bodies
Feedback: Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit zur Kommentierung dieses Verordnungsentwurfes. Als Assoziation ökologischer Lebensmittelhersteller e.V. (AöL) vertreten wir die Interessen von 130 führenden Bio Unternehmen im deutschsprachigen europäischen Raum. Viele unserer Mitglieder sind international tätig und beziehen ihre Rohwaren und Produkte aus Drittländern. Wir begrüßen den Vorschlag der Kommission in der Überwachung von Kontrollbehörden und Kontrollstellen, sowie Drittländern, die Expertise der EU- Mitgliedsstaaten enger mit einzubeziehen. Wir halten es dabei für sehr wichtig, dass die Rolle der Mitgliedstaaten eine beratende bleibt. Wie die aktuellen Auswertungen der TRACES-Statistiken aus Juli 2023 zeigen, sind die Kompetenzen im Bereich Bio-Importe innerhalb der EU-Mitgliedstaaten jedoch sehr un-terschiedlich verteilt. Der überwiegende Teil der Importe wird in den Niederlanden, Deutschland, Frankreich und Belgien abgewickelt. Während in anderen Ländern keine oder nur sehr wenig Importware in die EU eingeführt wird. Wir würden es sehr begrüßen, wenn diese offensichtliche sehr unterschiedliche Erfahrung mit Importvorgängen bei dem Hinzuziehen der Mitgliedsländer als Co-Rapporteure bedacht wird. Vorzugsweise sollten nur solche Mitgliedstaaten, die auch die entsprechenden Qualifikationen im Bereich Import haben mit dieser Aufgabe betraut werden. Sollte das nicht möglich sein, schlagen wir vor, in den nach Artikel 4a, Absatz 1 vorgeschlagenen Zweier-Teams eines der Mitgliedsstaaten mit vertiefter Erfahrung im Bereich Import zu benennen oder weitere Kriterien zu definieren, welche für die Auswahl als Co-Rapporteur zu erfüllen sind. So kann garantiert werden, dass die Co-Rapporteure eine qualifizierte beratende Unterstützung für die Kommission leisten können. Weiterhin schlagen wir vor, die Aktualisierung der Verordnung (EU) 2021/1342 zum Anlass zu nehmen, um die Einzelheiten der Informationen über amtliche Untersuchungen, die von den zuständigen Behörden der Drittländer zur Verfügung zu stellen sind, so weit wie möglich mit den Informationen zu harmonisieren, die von den zuständigen Behörden der EU-Mitgliedstaaten zur Verfügung gestellt werden müssen, insbesondere wenn es um Kontaminationen mit nicht zugelassenen Erzeugnissen oder Stoffen geht. Diese wurden erst kürzlich in der Verordnung (EU) 2023/1195 genauer festgelegt.

short_title: Amendment of the list of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Ik wil graag mijn bezorgdheid uiten over het toelaten van 'biowaste' als meststof binnen de biologische productie. Als consument wil ik garanties hebben dat de bioproducten die ik koop geen schadelijke stoffen bevatten of beduidend minder dan in andere producten. Enerzijds is het goed om circulair te werken, en reststromen/afvalstromen te hergebruiken, maar anderzijds moet er voldoende aandacht en voorzichtigheid zijn dat vervuiling, schadelijke stoffen niet overal in de natuur verspreid worden. Met het toelaten hier van biowaste binnen de bio, moeten er garanties zijn dat er geen schadelijke stoffen, vervuiling, residuen van pesticiden, microplastics, zware metalen verspreid wordt binnen de bio en overal in de (bio)-voedingsketen opduikt. We moeten er op toe zien dat er geen nieuw milieuprobleem gecreëerd wordt, dat we schadelijke stoffen in kleine concentraties gaan verspreiden, zowel in de natuur als in de voeding. Wanneer ik bioproducten koop doe ik dat omdat ik denk dat deze zuiverder zijn, producten gekweekt zijn op een zo natuurlijk mogelijke wijze volgens vastgelegde regels, minder pesticiden, in gezonde bodem, etc. Wanneer dan binnen de bioproductie afvalstromen gebruikt worden die mogelijks verontreinigd zijn met residuen afkomstig van het plantaardig of dierlijke biowaste, dan begin ik mij wel vragen te stellen over de kwaliteit van het bioproduct in de toekomst. De voorwaarden waaronder voorgesteld wordt om biowaste toe te laten binnen de biologische productie zijn beperkt. In het voorstel worden er limieten voorgesteld voor zware metalen. Echter worden er geen limieten voorgesteld voor bv. residuen van gewasbeschermingsmiddelen, microplastics. Waarom niet? Microplastics is reeds een groot probleem. Zijn er reeds studies voorhanden die aantonen dat de gecomposteerde biowaste geen residuen van pesticiden zal bevatten, geen schadelijke stoffen zal bevatten, geen microplastics? Zijn er studies beschikbaar die aantonen dat het gebruik van biowaste de bioproducten en de bodem van de biolandbouwer niet zal verontreinigen? Enkel limieten opleggen voor zware metalen en niet voor andere mogelijke vervuilende componenten is onvoldoende. Kan er geen analyse opgelegd worden die aantoont dat er geen residuen aanwezig zijn?

short_title: Amendment of the list of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Genanvend Biomasse (Name in English: Danish Biomass Recycling Association) thanks you for the opportunity to contribute to the consultation on the Organic Regulation. Overall, we want to promote the possibilities for the recirculation of nutrients and valuable substances in the biological resources in society and in organic agricultural and food production in line with the principles of the ecological cycle approach. Comment to Annex II: We suggest the definition of "biowaste" to be: biodegradable garden and park waste, food and kitchen waste from households, restaurants, catering businesses and retail premises and comparable waste from food processing plants and ingredient companies. Biowast is also derived residual flows from the above types of biowaste. To include the food processing plants and ingredient companies will contribute with recirculation of large and continuous nutrient flows from the companies. Danish Biomass Recycling Association represents the bio-recycling industry in Denmark. The purpose of the Association is to 'Keep the organic resources in the loop. We work for and stand together on the desire to recycle more, recycle better and recycle safely. There is not one solution, there is not one path, there is not one application that trumps all others. Diversity in products, in applications, in technologies is the way forward, but always with the common goal: to preserve the valuable substances as best as possible in the biological cycle.

short_title: Amendment of the list of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Comment to Annex II: A substantial amount of the worlds energy consumption is utilized for nitrogen fixation (fertilizer) and removal (wastewater treatment). Concentrated process waters originating from food/feed industry resources and fertilizer value are presently lost during wastewater treatment; thereby not supporting circular economy. Consequently, we suggest expanding the definition of bio waste submitted for Biogas production to include fractions of other materials than vegetable and animal bio waste. Thereby allowing concentrates from water treatment in the food industry to be recirculated and reduce water stress by water reuse. In our case, we specifically think of Nitrate from a mineral source, which is used as processing aid or detergent (nitric acid) in the food industry. It eventually ends up in waste water. We have an opportunity to concentrate the nitrate, and the water stream with nitrate can be used to replace ground water mixed with bio waste for biogas production. The nitrogen will end up in the biomass after gas production and can be used as fertilizer. So, recirculation will improve significantly, if definition of bio waste is expanded to include residual flows from companies like ours, which produces ingredients for food.

short_title: Amendment of the list of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Je souhaite partager mes craintes quant à l'autorisation des biodéchets comme fertilisant en agriculture biologique. Bien qu'en règle générale il y ait un tri à la source, certains types de biodéchets pourraient présenter un risque pour l'agriculture bio. Il a par exemple été établi que le tri des déchets ménagers par les citoyens n'est pas parfait et que des plastiques se retrouvent dans les biodéchets; leur digestat peut donc devenir une cause de présence de microplastiques dans nos sols. Aussi, comment la condition "only vegetable and animal biowaste" suffit-elle à assurer l'absence de pesticides dans les digestats qui seront utilisés en agriculture biologique étant donné que ces produits peuvent être issus de l'agriculture conventionnelle? Des études seraient nécessaires afin d'établir si les biodéchets peuvent être une source de contamination qui porterait atteinte à l'intégrité du système de production biologique. Alternativement, une condition supplémentaire (analyse de résidus de pesticides) serait nécessaire pour qu'un digestat puisse accéder au marché biologique.

short_title: Amendment of the list of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Beste, We wensen te reageren op het voorstel van verordening dat voorligt. 1. biowaste We kunnen ons niet vinden in het toelaten van biowaste in de bio zoals het nu voorligt in het voorstel, nl. zonder voorwaarden die garantie bieden dat er geen contaminatie mogelijk is van residuen en micro-plastics naar bio. De biolandbouwer moet garanties kunnen hebben dat de compost vrij is van residuen. Het toelaten van biowaste in de bio vormt een risico voor het binnenbrengen van microplastics en residuen van pesticiden binnen de biologische productie. Het vastleggen van voorwaarden inzake pesticidenresiduen en micro-plastics is noodzakelijk temeer de EGTOP over deze 2 aspecten bezorgd is in haar advies. Het advies van EGTOP luidt Reflections and conclusions The Group is concerned about the presence of plastic and microplastics in composts and digestates from bio-waste which can derive from packaged food, roadside cuttings, etc. Plastic packaging of overlaid or spoiled food, not unpacked before composting, is an essential input path. Once plastic particles have entered the bio-waste they can hardly, if at all, be removed technically. The Group outlines that the input of plastic into composting and digestion plants should be minimized. The Group is also concerned about the presence of pesticides, pesticide metabolites and other contaminants. Het voorzorgsprincipe en zorgvuldigheidsprincipe dient toegepast te worden, en de studies en een monitoringsysteem eerst afgewacht te worden vooraleer te oordelen of biowaste al dan niet kan in biologische productie. Indien biowaste alsnog opgenomen wordt als mogelijke input voor biologische productie dan vragen we dat er voorwaarden in de biowetgeving ingebouwd worden zodanig dat de biolandbouwer garanties krijgt dat de compost residue vrij is. Niet enkel voor zware metalen dienen er limieten te zijn, maar ook voor residuen van gewasbeschermingsmiddelen en micro-plastics, elementen waarover EGTOP bezorgd is. Voorwaarden mbt residugehalte en microplastics, monitoring ontbreekt in voorstel van verordening. 2. tartraten We noteren dat er enerzijds een voorstel van horizontale wetgeving voorligt inzake tartraten dat voorstelt om het gebruik van tartraten te schrappen voor jelly, jams,... Anderzijds is er het EGTOP rapport van 2022, die adviseert over de nood voor gebruik van tartraten in jams, jellies binnen de biologische productie. Het voorstel van verordening om de bijlage van Ver 2021/1165 aan te passen, stelt een uitbreiding van het gebruik van tartraten voor, dit gemotiveerd op het ingediende dossier en het advies van EGTOP, nl. het gebruik van tartraten in jams, jelly, ... Vraag is of de uitkomst van de horizontale wetgeving inzake tartraten nu niet best afgewacht wordt vooraleer te beslissen om het gebruik van tartraten uit te breiden binnen bio, in het bijzonder E337. Zoniet zou dit de indruk kunnen geven dat tartraten (E337) kunnen gebruikt worden in de biologische productie voor de productie van jams, jellies,.., terwijl er op horizontaal niveau net een voorstel voorligt voor de afschaffing van gebruik van tartraten voor jams, jellies, .... We stellen dan ook voor om de discussie op horizontaal niveau af te wachten en/of de twee voorstellen van wetgeving op elkaar af te stemmen. 3. Low risk substances We kunnen ons niet vinden in een algemene toelating binnen bio van low risk substances, dit zonder enige voorafgaande check met de bioprincipes en criteria. We zijn voorstander van een case by case benadering. Criteria worden gebruikt voor de aanduiding van low risk products onder de horizontale wetgeving, maar deze criteria verschillen van deze die van toepassing zijn binnen bio. We stellen een eenvoudigde procedure voor dat enkel de criteria onderzoekt die noodzakelijk zijn voor bio, zoals "werd de actieve stof al dan niet chemisch gesynthetiseerd?". Aan de hand van deze procedure kan dan beslist worden om de low risk substance al dan niet toe te laten in bio.
