Feedback: This amendment to Implementing Regulation (EU) 2021/1165 is of real interest to the organic-based fertiliser industry, as it broadens the scope of bio-waste eligible for use in organic farming. This addition seems to fit in perfectly with the circular economy approach. However, ECOFI members feel that certain points need to be clarified to avoid any over-interpretation by Member States - see comments below: - Scope of bio-waste concerned by this entry in Annex II of EU Regulation 2021/1165 : => Add clarification: Composted or fermented bio-waste (the term "biowaste" being defined in art. 3 of the Directive 2008/98/EC* of the European Parliament and of the Council). - Traceability : => Ask operators involved in the collection and treatment or recovery of biowaste to ensure the traceability of flows throughout the chain. - Unpackaged biowaste: => In order to comply with the principles of the circular economy, bio-waste that has been sorted at source and then deconditioned on a platform for which a deconditioning activity is authorised by the national authorities should be authorised. => Add in the specific conditions column: Bio-waste that has been deconditioned after sorting at source is authorised. - Heavy metals : => The contaminant thresholds set by RUE 2021/1165 for composted / fermented bio-waste are authoritative. => Specify: Compost or bio-waste digestate must comply with the maximum concentrations in mg/kg of dry matter for the following contaminants: cadmium: 0.7; copper: 70; nickel: 25; lead: 45; zinc: 200; mercury: 0.4; chromium (total): 70; chromium (VI): not detectable - Macroscopic impurities : => Regulation (EU) 2019/1009 sets inert/impurity criteria for compost (CMC 3) and digestate (CMC 5). => Ask the EC to include these thresholds in the "composted or fermented bio-waste" item of the AB regulation to prevent Member States from setting more stringent criteria on their own initiative. short_title: Evaluation of  the Common Agriculture Policy measures in the outermost regions and the smaller Aegean islands
Feedback: Les agriculteurs des RUP souhaitent attirer l'attention de toutes les parties prenantes sur la résolution du Parlement européen du 13 juin 2023 sur l'évaluation de la nouvelle communication de la Commission sur les régions ultrapériphériques, et notamment sur l'urgence d'augmenter les dotations financières du POSEI. Les agriculteurs des régions ultrapériphériques soutiennent également le rapport de la Commission européenne du 7 décembre 2021 sur l'adaptation du POSEI aux réalités et aux besoins des producteurs des RUP. Cette adaptation est liée à la grande flexibilité du POSEI qui peut être adapté chaque année afin de prendre en compte les nouveaux enjeux et problématiques liés aux filières de production. Le POSEI a permis de maintenir la compétitivité des filières traditionnelles exportatrices vers l'Europe continentale (notamment les filières viande, lait, banane et canne à sucre) et a permis à ces filières d'évoluer vers une agriculture plus intégrée. Cependant, presque tous les secteurs de production des régions ultrapériphériques sont confrontés à des questions phytosanitaires, commerciales et sociales de plus en plus complexes. Dans ce contexte, le manque de marge de manœuvre budgétaire résultant de la non-augmentation du budget POSEI depuis 2007 pénalise gravement les producteurs et limite le développement des activités essentielles et connexes au niveau local. Les enveloppes financières du POSEI doivent être augmentées au plus vite et doivent au moins permettre de compenser l'augmentation des coûts de production agricole. Ces coûts ont déjà augmenté de 19,6 % depuis 2013. Le POSEI doit également être doté d'un instrument de révision budgétaire afin de pouvoir répondre en temps utile et de manière appropriée à d'éventuels besoins financiers, évitant ainsi de perpétuer la situation dans laquelle le POSEI se trouve depuis 2007. Les plafonds du RSA fixés dans le règlement POSEI pénalisent le dynamisme des différents secteurs. La fixation des plafonds devrait être laissée aux États membres et aux gouvernements régionaux, dans le cas des Açores et de Madère.

short_title: Evaluation of  the Common Agriculture Policy measures in the outermost regions and the smaller Aegean islands
Feedback: A Federação Agrícola dos Açores, em coordenação com as organizações parceiras francesas e espanholas, chama a atenção de todos os intervenientes para a Resolução do Parlamento Europeu, de 13 de junho de 2023, dedicada à avaliação da nova comunicação da Comissão sobre as Regiões Ultraperiféricas, nomeadamente para a necessidade urgente do reforço das dotações financeiras do POSEI. Os Agricultores das Regiões Ultraperiféricas subscrevem igualmente o relatório da Comissão Europeia, de 7 de dezembro de 2021, sobre a adaptação do POSEI às realidades e necessidades dos produtores das RUP. Esta adaptação está ligada à grande flexibilidade do regime POSEI, que pode ser adaptado todos os anos de modo a poder ter em conta novas questões e novos problemas associados aos setores produtivos. O POSEI permitiu manter a competitividade dos setores tradicionais que exportam para o continente europeu (nomeadamente o setor da carne, dos laticínios, da banana, ou da cana-de-açúcar), e possibilitou que estes setores evoluíssem para uma agricultura mais integrada. Quase todos os setores da produção das Regiões Ultraperiféricas são, todavia, confrontados com questões fitossanitárias, comerciais e sociais cada vez mais complexas. Neste contexto, a falta de folga orçamental que resulta do não aumento do orçamento do POSEI desde 2007 está a penalizar gravemente os produtores, e a limitar localmente o desenvolvimento das atividades principais e conexas. Os envelopes financeiros do POSEI devem ser, por conseguinte, aumentados com a maior brevidade possível e devem, pelo menos, poder compensar o aumento dos custos da produção agrícola. Estes encargos já aumentaram +19,6% desde 2013. Os envelopes financeiros do POSEI já não estão adaptados às diferentes realidades regionais e, como tal, devem ser aumentados para satisfação das necessidades prementes e das especificidades das RUP. O reforço das dotações financeiras do POSEI deve ter em consideração: A não atualização das dotações orçamentais face aos valores da inflação acumulada desde 2007; O sucesso das taxas de execução e a aplicação generalizada de taxas de rateio, por consequência; O aumento dos constrangimentos regulatórios, para poder responder adequadamente às obrigações, às ambições e aos objetivos climáticos e ambientais da União Europeia; O aumento galopante dos custos de produção; O enfraquecimento generalizado das proteções tarifárias; O recurso sistemático e gradativo aos auxílios estatais/regionais para complementar as limitações orçamentais dos envelopes comunitários do POSEI; Satisfação das necessidades agrícolas regionais e nacionais.

Os agricultores das regiões ultraperiféricas também apoiam o relatório da Comissão Europeia, de 7 de dezembro de 2021, sobre a adaptação do POSEI às realidades e necessidades dos produtores das regiões ultraperiféricas. Esta adaptação está ligada à grande flexibilidade do POSEI, que pode ser adaptado todos os anos de modo ter em conta novas questões e problemas ligados aos sectores produtivos. O POSEI permitiu manter a competitividade dos setores tradicionais que exportam para a Europa continental (nomeadamente os sectores da pecuária, do leite, da banana e da cana-de-açúcar) e permitiu que estes setores adotassem práticas agrícolas mais integrada. No entanto, quase todos os setores de produção das Regiões Ultraperiféricas são confrontados com problemas fitossanitários, comerciais e sociais cada vez mais complexos. Neste contexto, a falta de margem orçamental resultante do não aumento do orçamento do POSEI desde 2007 está a penalizar gravemente os produtores e a limitar o desenvolvimento de atividades essenciais ao nível local. Os envelopes financeiros do POSEI devem ser aumentados o mais rapidamente possível e devem permitir, pelo menos, compensar o aumento dos custos de produção agrícola. Estes custos já registaram um aumento de 19,6% desde 2013. O POSEI deve também ser dotado de um instrumento de revisão orçamental que lhe permita responder atempadamente e de forma adequada a eventuais necessidades financeiras, evitando assim perpetuar a situação em que o programa se encontra desde 2007.

short_title: Farm Accountancy Data Network (FADN) – recording data on farm production
Feedback: A rede de informação contabilística agrícola assume especial relevância na análise e na tomada de decisão para o setor agrícola Europeu, contudo, há aspetos a melhorar tais como: A base de recolha de dados a existente é obsoleta e desajustada da realidade atual, inclusive a nível tecnológico. Deveria ser criado um software de raiz, na linha dos que já são utilizados ao nível das contabilidades, ajustado às necessidades atuais e de acordo com as exigências da Autoridade Tributária. Eventualmente interligar o software utilizado na RICA com os disponíveis no mercado para a realização de contabilidades. Talvez equacionar a disponibilização de fundos europeus específicos para que cada estado membro possa desenvolver softwares com este objetivo. Promover o aumento de colaboradores (agricultores) na cedência de informação - Sendo a cedência de dados voluntária, verifica-se uma enorme dificuldade em angariar novos produtores. A colaboração representa para o produtor uma exposição de dados pessoais a terceiros e uma necessária disponibilidade de tempo adicional sem qualquer contrapartida. Deveriam ser equacionadas ou contrapartidas para os agricultores colaborantes (monetárias, majorações de ajudas, reduções de obrigações ou impostos). Em alternativa, tornar a colaboração para beneficiários de fundos comunitários como obrigatoriedade (de x em x anos e selecionados apenas de acordo com as necessidades (ao nível da amostra para a região ao nível das OTE/DE). Simplificar a informação a recolher A informação necessária a recolher é demasiada exaustiva e frequentemente desajustada do objetivo principal. Se o objetivo são dados económicos, não faz sentido que por via da RICA se insista, por exemplo, na recolha de dados relacionados com unidades de fertilizantes ou fitofármacos. A recolha de informações para outros fins que não os económicos devem ser considerados por outras vias. A exigência exaustiva de detalhares dificulta a recolha e tratamento de informação, tornando-a demasiado morosa e maçadora para o produtor. Promover formações periódicas ou sessões de esclarecimento para os técnicos que trabalham na RICA Neste contexto, seria importante considerar a realização de fóruns direcionados aos técnicos da RICA (a nível EU). O objetivo seria a partilha de conhecimentos, a troca de ideias de modo a considerar da melhor forma possível as especificidades de cada país e cada região, em alguns casos muito particulares como é o caso das RUPs.

Feedback: Eurogroup for Animals strongly believe that on-farm marking is necessary to ensure traceability and clear, correct information for consumers on the provenance of the product they are choosing. short_title: Marking of eggs on farm as general rule
Feedback: Muchas gracias por ofrecernos la oportunidad de participar. Marcado de los huevos en el centro de producción (explotación): como productor estoy de acuerdo con la modificación. Considero que es la única manera de poder ejercer inspecciones con unas mínimas garantías y con ellas perseguir y limitar lo máximo el posible fraude. El marcado en el centro de producción dará credibilidad al sector y garantías a los consumidores en su elección y a los ciudadanos en general por la necesidad de utilizar la trazabilidad ante un riesgo de salud pública. Solo debe admitirse el marcado en el primer centro de embalaje al que lleguen destinados los huevos cuando la trazabilidad entre la granja donde los ponen las gallinas y el centro de embalaje esté bien garantizada de manera objetiva. Para ello debe ser precisa, como exige la modificación propuesta, una autorización administrativa basada en criterios objetivos que ofrezcan la necesaria garantía. Actualmente podemos decir que no se pueden ejercer inspecciones, pues son diferentes departamentos inconexos los que inspeccionan los centros de producción y los de embalaje, incluso pueden estar bajo las órdenes de distintas autoridades competentes sin comunicación entre ellas. Con la norma actual en vigor es posible que al mismo centro de embalaje puedan llegar transportados automáticamente por una cinta trasversal huevos de diferentes naves de producción con sistemas de cría distintos sin ninguna posibilidad de diferenciarlos y a la vez, que también lleguen huevos sin marcar de diferentes sistemas de cría procedentes de otras regiones y por lo tanto inspeccionados por otros servicios inconexos. Creo que es totalmente oportuna la modificación para ofrecer las garantías del principio de trazabilidad que caracteriza a la producción europea, así como para proteger a los productores y a los consumidores.

Feedback: Yttrande från Svenska Ägg, the Swedish egg Association, angående översynen av EU:s Handelsnormer för ägg Svenska Ägg tackar för att vi har fått möjlighet att yttra oss över förslaget till ändringar. Utkast till Delegerad förordning 3.1 Märkning av ägg Äggbranschen i Sverige anser att förslaget till ändring kan accepteras förutsatt att Medlemsländer kan bevilja undantag för så att äggen märks på den första äggförpackningscentralen. I Sverige är det vanligt att äggpackerier tvättar ägg i en godkänd äggtvätt. Det innebär att om äggen stämplas på gården kan producentkoden tvättas bort vid tvätt av ägg på packeriet. short_title: Marking of eggs on farm as general rule
Feedback: Sobre el artículo 1 del Proyecto de Reglamento, que propone el marcado en la granja de producción, e incluye el punto 2.a, que deja que los EE.MM. permitan eximir del marcado en granja y autorizar a que se marque en el primer centro de embalaje al que se entregan los huevos: Es importante que se mantenga la redacción actual en este punto: 2. El marcado de los huevos conforme al apartado 1 se realizará en la explotación o en el primer centro de empaquetado al que lleguen los huevos. Que para marcar en el primer centro de embalaje se exija una exención por las autoridades nacionales complica la gestión del marcado por los operadores. Hay muchos casos en los que el marcado en el primer centro de embalaje es la opción óptima y no debe priorizarse el marcado en granja. Este es, por ejemplo, al caso de las cooperativas de producción de huevos, o de las empresas que tienen un funcionamiento similar, con varias instalaciones de producción y un centro de embalaje en el que se reciben, clasifican y pesan los huevos para su envasado. Ambas optimizan recursos, frente a la necesidad de invertir en marcadoras en cada granja, que seguiría siendo una opción disponible para quienes deseen aplicarla. El marcado en la granja de producción no impide el fraude, que es la razón de fondo de esta propuesta: si alguien quiere poner un código de otra granja en su marcado, no se lo impide el hecho de tener la marcadora instalada en la granja. Y los operadores tienen la obligación en todo momento de mantener la trazabilidad de los productos, así como de demostrar que se mantiene la coherencia entre las cantidades producidas y las vendidas de cada tipo de huevo que se gestiona en el centro de embalaje por las empresas del sector. Por el contrario, los centros de embalaje que clasifican los huevos de diferentes partidas y granjas de origen tienen perfectamente establecido el sistema operativo para el cambio del código del productor cuando se produce la entrada en la clasificadora de los huevos de cada origen. Por otro lado, marcar en la granja añade una dificultad adicional para la gestión posterior de los huevos: complica que en el centro de embalaje puedan incorporarse a los huevos otras informaciones en el marcado (la fecha de consumo preferente, por ejemplo, que exigen algunos clientes), puesto que podría tapar la información del productor al superponerse ambas marcas. O la gestión de las partidas que se destinan a la exportación, y que pueden requerir que el huevo no lleve marcas en la cáscara. La gestión de los pedidos en las empresas grandes con varios centros de producción se hace en el centro de embalaje, dende se definen los lotes que deben enviarse a distintos clientes de forma centralizada. El marcado previo en la granja impide que se apliquen las excepciones citadas, que suelen ser exigencias de los clientes. Por ello, es nuestra propuesta que se mantenga la redacción actual del Reglamento 1308/2013.

short_title: Marking of eggs on farm as general rule
Feedback: Coldiretti agrees with the Commission's objective of improving the traceability and transparency of the egg supply chain, including with the labelling of eggs from the place of production, because it is certain that the label on the farm guarantees greater traceability of the supply chain and the certainty that there is no risk of confusion in the passage of eggs from the farm to the packing centres. It is a safeguard instrument, especially for operators, especially the smaller ones, to discourage the import of "anonymous" eggs on the internal market, but also from the point of view of health, to ensure greater safety for consumers. In order to ensure greater transparency and avoid confusion, we believe that the possibility of applying the egg marking derogation at the first egg packing centre should not be given. On the other hand, it proposes to exempt from the obligation to mark eggs farms that have 50 hens and carry out direct sales of eggs, (in Italy they benefit from the exemption from stamping as provided for in Article 2 of the Decree MIPAAF of 11 December 2009), as with such dimensions, a limited number of exchanges and quantities is carried out , in a restricted local area on the basis of an already recognizable and direct relationship between producer and consumer. Rules on marking and labelling requirements for eggs imported from third countries should be laid down on the basis of the principle of reciprocity. The information on the egg is not mandatory on the outside of the packaging, while it would be important, even for the consumer, that the country of origin of the eggs was also reported on the outside of the package in full, not with an alphanumeric code that is not immediately read, but with information that shows the indication of the country where the eggs were produced (eggs produced in Italy, Poland, Romania), to give the consumer more information, and therefore to choose with greater awareness having the availability of clearer information. Finally, these transparency measures must also be adopted for egg products used in industrial processing. It should also be indicated in the finished product (pasta, sweets, etc.), the origin of the country of origin of the eggs used.

short_title: Marking of eggs on farm as general rule
Feedback: Valoramos la obligación de marcar en la explotación y dar la opción a las autoridades de cada país para autorizar el marcado en el primer centro de embalaje como un elemento muy negativo para el óptimo desarrollo del sector de huevo de consumo en España. La estructura productiva de España se basa en que muchas granjas de tamaño pequeño/mediano tienen su propio centro de embalaje. Las de mayor tamaño tienen un único centro donde reciben huevos de diversas granjas del mismo grupo empresarial. Es en el centro de embalaje donde se marcan, clasifican y envasan los huevos con un control y respeto total a su trazabilidad. Al mismo tiempo hay una optimización de la maquinaria y recursos del centro de embalaje evitando que cada granja deba invertir en los elementos de marcado. Además, la propuesta de marcado en granja no ofrece más garantías contra supuestos fraudes que el marcado en el primer centro de embalaje. La opción de que el estado miembro autorice el marcado en el primer centro de embalaje no nos parece una alternativa óptima ya que define como preferente el marcado en granja y establece una transición para que sea la única opción posible. La propuesta es mantener la redacción actualmente vigente en el Reglamento 1308/2013.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit der Stellungnahme zu den beiden Verordnungsentwürfen betreffend die EU-Vermarktungsnormen. Der Waren-Verein der Hamburger Börse e.V. (kurz: Waren-Verein) vertritt als Bundesverband des Groß- und Außenhandels die Interessen der Importeure von Trockenfrüchten, Schalenobst, Gemüse-, Obst- und Fischkonserven, tiefgekühltem Obst, Gemüse und Fischprodukten sowie von Bioprodukten. Unsere Mitgliedsunternehmen sind primär kleine und mittlere Import- sowie Abpackunternehmen (KMU). Der Waren-Verein begrüßt, dass Nusskerne und Trockenfrüchte weiterhin nicht der generellen EU-Vermarktungsnorm unterliegen sollen. Die in den Verordnungsentwürfen vorgesehene Herkunftskennzeichnung sollte auf freiwilliger Basis erfolgen. Falls die Herkunftskennzeichnung dennoch verpflichtend eingeführt werden sollte, erachten wir einen Übergangszeitraum von 24 Monaten ab Inkrafttreten der Verordnung für unbedingt erforderlich, um Verpackungen umzustellen, technische Voraussetzungen an Abfüllmaschinen zu schaffen und ggf. Behörden personell und räumlich angemessen auszustatten. Da es das Ziel der Herkunftskennzeichnung ist, die Verbraucher*innen in der EU bei informierten und nachhaltigen Kaufentscheidungen zu unterstützen, sollten alle Maßnahmen in den geplanten Verordnungen fokussiert auf dieses Ziel hin und unter unbedingter Berücksichtigung von Bürokratieabbau und Effizienz für Behörden und Wirtschaftsbeteiligte festgelegt werden. Die Kontrolle der Herkunftskennzeichnung sollte daher dort erfolgen, wo diese Informationen vorliegen sollen. Dies sind die Absatzstätten und Läger, in denen Produkte für Verbraucher*innen angeboten und gelagert werden und nicht beim Import, was einen umfangreichen Bürokratieaufbau auf Behörden- und Unternehmensseite zur Folge hätte. Der Ort der Herkunftskennzeichnung auf der Verpackung sollte analog zur Kennzeichnung des Mindesthaltbarkeitsdatums geregelt werden, da zu erwarten ist, dass eine chargengenaue Kennzeichnung im entsprechenden Druckfeld beim Abfüllen der Produkte stattfinden wird. Es wäre notwendig, differenzierte Übergangsregelungen zu definieren, die sich am Zeitpunkt des Inverkehrbringens der lang haltbaren Waren orientieren, wie bei anderen Verordnungen aus dem Bereich Lebensmittelsicherheit bereits praktiziert. Der Kennzeichnungsvorschlag für Mischungen sollte auf keinen Fall weiter ausdifferenziert werden.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: FRUCOM is the European Federation representing the traders in Dried Fruit, Edible Nuts, Processed Fruit & Vegetables, Processed Fishery Products. We would like to comment on the draft Commission proposals on the marketing standards. FRUCOM is in favour of voluntary origin labelling for the final consumer, because of changes in availability due to e.g. poor crop in some origins, re-processing used in some third countries to confer origin, technological constraints and need to focus on the key issues. Setting up the traders database, inspection bodies, acceptance of declarations by the customs based on certificate of conformity or waiver: all these seem disproportionate burden on operators and public authorities compared to the expected value added. FRUCOM is in favour of removing pecans, macadamias in shell and pine nuts in shell from the requirements of the marketing standards, as they are imported in small quantities. Pistachios in shell (unroasted) should be removed as well. They are imported in large quantities into the EU and freshly roasted and packaged in the EU, for reasons of quality and freshness but also tariffs. Pistachios in shell are hardly ever sold to consumers unroasted, so it doesnt make sense to apply the whole set of marketing standards to them. The exception from the application of marketing standards (so from the origin obligation) should be valid for all products "intended for processing", not only for products intended for processing into one of the processed products listed in Part X of Annex I to Reg. EU 1308/2013. Otherwise, for example, operators usually selling nuts to clients of the bakery sector would be obliged to report the origin on the labelling. In case a mandatory origin indication becomes applicable, the companies would need longer than 1 January 2025 to implement it sustainably. It requires using up and changing packaging material and technical adaptation, e.g. new larger printers to print the country of origin together with the Lot-No. and best before date. At least 3 years transition time will be necessary. For the whole comments, please see document attached.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Wij zijn TopFresh. Specialist in de teelt en verwerking van wortelgewassen met een passie voor de snackwortel. De impact van de nieuwe wetgeving zal groot zijn voor ons en voor onze sector. Door de nieuwe verordening zullen producten die prima geschikt zijn voor menselijke consumptie niet meer als dusdanig verwerkt kunnen worden. Hierdoor neemt de voedselverspilling drastisch toe. Het kunnen verwerken van deze producten is een kracht en waardevolle toevoeging van de vers gesneden groente verwerkende industrie aan het verminderen van voedselverspilling. Door deze regels op te leggen aan de vers gesneden groente verwerkende industrie en niet aan de diepvries en conserven industrieën ontstaat daarnaast oneerlijke concurrentie. De voorgenomen aanpassingen zijn ten opzichte van de Farm to Fork strategie een zeer tegenstrijdige beweging doordat voedselverspilling juist zal toenemen. De voorgenomen aanpassingen werken kostprijsverhogend. Deze kosten zullen door producenten doorberekend moeten worden, waardoor consumenten uiteindelijk meer betalen voor vers gesneden groenten en fruit. Met het oog op een gezonde levensstijl is het belangrijk dat de consumptie van verse groenten en fruit toeneemt, terwijl een stijgende prijs dit juist kan tegengaan.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Ons bedrijf betreft een coöperatie met telers van tuinbouwproducten. Ons bedrijf levert een diversiteit aan verse groenten en fruit aan diverse snijderijen. Bij levering aan snijderijen gaat het product vaak ongesorteerd van het land in kisten naar de klant. Hierbij zijn er met de snijderijen afspraken gemaakt aan welke kwaliteitseisen het product moet voldoen. Wanneer deze producten door de nieuwe regelgeving niet meer ongesorteerd mogen worden geleverd aan snijderijen zal dat grote gevolgen hebben voor o.a. handlings- en verpakkingskosten. Deze kosten zullen significant gaan stijgen en hierdoor zal het product moeilijker of niet verkoopbaar worden aan snijderijen (product wordt te duur). Tevens zal er hierdoor onnodig product, welk niet helemaal aan de kwaliteitseisen voldoet, niet meer verkoopbaar zijn en vernietigd moeten worden. Dit leidt tot voedselverspilling en draagt zeker niet bij aan de duurzaamheid van de teelt/ productie.

Feedback: We thank the Commission for the work done and the enormous amount of time and patience to discuss views and scrutinize proposals. Please consider the comment below. ANNEX V POINT 2.7. short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Wij protesteren tegen het voorstel voor de nieuwe verordening, omdat 1. Voedselverspilling en extra (verpakkings-)afval: We niet alle champignons meer kunnen gebruiken welke wel geschikt zijn voor consumptie, daar ze niet voldoen aan de handelsnorm. Dit betekent dat we dus een reststroom krijgen die niet meer gebruikt kan worden. Dit leidt tot voedselverspilling en vernietiging van economische waarde. Dit wordt een afvalstroom welke tegen extra kosten afgevoerd dient te worden, terwijl deze champignons nog heel goed verwerkt hadden kunnen worden. Dit leidt ook tot extra verpakkingsafval- en kosten. Producenten krijgen nu nog een restwaarde voor deze champignons en dan zullen ze extra kosten krijgen. Dit leidt tot verlies van inkomen! 2. Nutteloze verpakkingslast: De champignons, welke geschikt zijn om vers te snijden, worden in bulk verpakking aangeleverd en per pallet aangeduid. Door deze verordening zouden de champignons aan verpakkingseisen in de handelsnormen dienen te voldoen en wel per krat aangeduid moeten worden, terwijl deze kratten enkel intern tussen producent en verwerker gebruik worden. De aanduidingen zijn derhalve extra lasten en in dit proces nutteloos en overbodig. 3. Extra verwerkingskosten: Omdat het land van oorsprong van de champignons op het etiket vermeld moet worden, wordt het productie proces constant onderbroken om etiketten te wisselen/aan te passen. Dit betekent dat er meer tijd nodig is om een productie run afgewerkt te krijgen. Dus extra verwerkingskosten. Alle producten dienen getraceerd te worden. Dit wordt gedaan door een goede ingangs- en uitgangsregistratie. Dit staat los van de aanduidingen op de verpakkingen. Indien er een mengsel van diverse origines wordt verwerkt, is nog steeds via de registraties traceerbaarheid mogelijk. Mengsels van diverse origines dienen mogelijk te zijn, anders leidt ook dit tot extra kosten in verband met behandelingskosten en tijd, meer voedselverspilling en verpakkingsafval. 4. Energieverspilling: In het kader van duurzaamheid en CO2 uitstoot is dit geen goede ontwikkeling, het kost meer energie omdat processen constant onderbroken worden, machines constant opnieuw moeten stoppen en gestart moeten worden, langere productiedagen, kost meer energie. 5. Oneerlijk speelveld/concurrentie: De nieuwe verordening betekent ook langere productieprocessen dus ook meer arbeidskosten, wat weer hogere prijzen gaat veroorzaken, wat ook weer oneerlijke concurrentie te weeg brengt ten opzichte van lage lonen landen in de EUR en niet EU landen, zoals bijv. Oekraïne en Engeland. Ook ontstaat er een oneerlijke concurrentie met de champignons voor verwerkte industrie (blik, pot, ecopouch, diepgevroren), daar deze champignons niet aan de handelsnormen hoeven te voldoen! 6. Minder consumptie gezonde producten: Deze procedure leidt tot een hogere consumentenprijs, waardoor de kans groot is dat consumenten minder gesneden groenten en fruit zullen gaan consumeren, terwijl consumenten juist meer groenten en fruit zouden moeten gaan consumeren. Banken Champignons

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Wij zijn Tuinderij Vers een groentesnijbedrijf in Brielle Zuid Holland. Wij verwerken een groot assortiment aan verse groenten en fruit in meer dan 200 verschillende gesneden groenten producten met een korte houdbaarheid (gemiddeld 6 dagen). De verse groenten en fruit producten worden dagelijks vers aangevoerd van verschillende telers en uit allerlei verschillende landen. De verse groenten en fruit producten worden dagelijks vers gesneden, gewassen en verpakt (7 dagen per week) en richting de consument getransporteerd. Hierdoor zorgen we er mede voor dat deze verse groenten producten gemakkelijk beschikbaar zijn voor de consument en hiermee dragen wij mede bij aan een hogere groente consumptie. Gezien de snelle doorloop en korte houdbaarheden is het belangrijk dat we verschillende batches grondstoffen achter elkaar door kunnen blijven draaien zonder onnodige stops om diversen landen van herkomst te scheiden en te labelen. short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Quick Introduction of our Company Our family owned company is more than 50 years active in the industry of IV gamma . In the beginning we produced 7 million packaging a year. Nowadays 7 million packaging pro week in 5 modern factories which more than 2000 people. At the moment we are open our new state of the art vegetable factory in Greenport Venlo, which daily will process 320.000 kilo raw material directly from the field into ultra fresh ready-to-cook vegetables and (meal) salads We supply these IV gamma products to supermarkets, fast food chains, wholesalers, catering businesses and inflight caterers. Every day we make more than 300 different products for our customers in 4 EU lands. Consumers are choosing IV gamma products because of their convenience in combination with the attractive price. Our main points of concern in DRAFT are: 1. Article 5.1.a. Excluding the IV gamma fresh-cut industry form the definition of industrial processing. This significantly restricts the sourcing of the IV gamma fresh-cut industry to products, which have to meet the requirements of marketing standard (general, specific or UNECE marketing standard). IV-Gamma facilities have to source product that is minimum of class II or the general marketing standard. Sourcing of "Ugly" fruit and vegetables or of industrial quality (oversized, broken, damaged product) is not anymore allowed. Consequence: A)The power of Hessing is that we buy already 50 years long the entire field of farmers without foodwaste! ! The exclusion goes against any possible alignment of the objectives of the Farm-to-Fork Strategy B) Unfair competition between frozen, canned Industry versus IV gamma. C) Lost of freshness, higher handling cost and more food waste by first sorting the entire field in marketing standard. 2. Art 8. Unclear whether origins are allowed to be mixed in single ingredient products (for example: shredded lettuce form Spain/Italia). short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: We are Royal Vezet and are the biggest producer of fresh convenience fruits & vegetables in Holland. The impact of the upcoming law is the following for us 1. Currently we can work continuously in production as we do not have to split batches from different origins. With the new law we need to separate the different batches in our proces which will take substantial time and costs. This will drive up costs significantly up to 25 eurocents per bag of fruit and vegetables. 2. Storage also needs to increase as we need to split batches which will increase costs and use of land 3. We expect this effect to be even more impactfull in the future, as we will need to spread risks geographically due to climate change. (where we can use one country of origin now, we might need to use three in time) 4. The extra costs will be passed on the endcustomer, which will bring an additional barrier for European consumers to eat and live healthy. 5. This will drive up health care costs significantly 6. Besides impact on health it will be counterproductive for the targets the Green Deal wants to achieve, namely taking care of our planet as the plantbased diet will be more expensive 7. The fact that we will not be regarded anymore as being part of the processing industry and we need to comply to the Dutch KCB norms, will make it more difficult to source raw material. For example: if a cucumber is outside of class 2, we currently can process it but not anymore when this law is in place. This will drive up costs and increase foodwaste substantially

short_title: Review of egg marketing standards
Feedback: Regulation 2022/2258 describes the date of minimum durability of consumption eggs in paragraph 10. Reference is made there to a study by the Efsa of 10 July 2014. The period of 28 days is based on a test with artificially contaminated eggs that have been opened and then kept at a temperature of at least 20°C. This test is based on a worst case scenario. In this age of food waste and sustainability, you can't use an entire consumer sector on one single test. Moreover: the same study also states that salmonella on the shell dies over time. We also had a laboratory conduct our own research into the germ count of eggs and it turns out that after a longer period of time the germ count hardly deviates from that of a fresh egg. The following is also important. We are an egg packing station and if we export eggs outside the EU, a date of minimum durability (best before) of 6 and 3 months applies. As an example: as soon as eggs are shipped to the Middle East, a best before date of 3 months is common. If eggs are shipped to the African continent, a best before date of 6 months is common. It is therefore possible that one batch of eggs from poultry farmer A, which is divided among three customers, is given a best before date of 28 days, 3 months and 6 months. Knowing this data, our sector cannot explain to the European consumer that an egg can only be kept for 28 days after laying! This is the right time to take a critical look at this and to adjust this period to acceptable values, so that the environment is less burdened with unnecessary food waste and which fits in with the policy of sustainable business. For more information about this, please do not hesitate to contact us.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit der Stellungnahme zu den beiden Verordnungsentwürfen betreffend die EU-Vermarktungsnormen. Der Waren-Verein der Hamburger Börse e.V. (kurz: Waren-Verein) vertritt als Bundesverband des Groß- und Außenhandels die Interessen der Importeure von Trockenfrüchten, Schalenobst, Gemüse-, Obst- und Fischkonserven, tiefgekühltem Obst, Gemüse und Fischprodukten sowie von Bioprodukten. Unsere Mitgliedsunternehmen sind primär kleine und mittlere Import- sowie Abpackunternehmen (KMU). Der Waren-Verein begrüßt, dass Nusskerne und Trockenfrüchte weiterhin nicht der generellen EU-Vermarktungsnorm unterliegen sollen. Die in den Verordnungsentwürfen vorgesehene Herkunftskennzeichnung sollte auf freiwilliger Basis erfolgen. Falls die Herkunftskennzeichnung dennoch verpflichtend eingeführt werden sollte, erachten wir einen Übergangszeitraum von 24 Monaten ab Inkrafttreten der Verordnung für unbedingt erforderlich, um Verpackungen umzustellen, technische Voraussetzungen an Abfüllmaschinen zu schaffen und ggf. Behörden personell und räumlich angemessen auszustatten. Da es das Ziel der Herkunftskennzeichnung ist, die Verbraucher*innen in der EU bei informierten und nachhaltigen Kaufentscheidungen zu unterstützen, sollten alle Maßnahmen in den geplanten Verordnungen fokussiert auf dieses Ziel hin und unter unbedingter Berücksichtigung von Bürokratieabbau und Effizienz für Behörden und Wirtschaftsbeteiligte festgelegt werden. Die Kontrolle der Herkunftskennzeichnung sollte daher dort erfolgen, wo diese Informationen vorliegen sollen. Dies sind die Absatzstätten und Läger, in denen Produkte für Verbraucher*innen angeboten und gelagert werden und nicht beim Import, was einen umfangreichen Bürokratieaufbau auf Behörden- und Unternehmensseite zur Folge hätte. Der Ort der Herkunftskennzeichnung auf der Verpackung sollte analog zur Kennzeichnung des Mindesthaltbarkeitsdatums geregelt werden, da zu erwarten ist, dass eine chargengenaue Kennzeichnung im entsprechenden Druckfeld beim Abfüllen der Produkte stattfinden wird. Es wäre notwendig, differenzierte Übergangsregelungen zu definieren, die sich am Zeitpunkt des Inverkehrbringens der lang haltbaren Waren orientieren, wie bei anderen Verordnungen aus dem Bereich Lebensmittelsicherheit bereits praktiziert. Der Kennzeichnungsvorschlag für Mischungen sollte auf keinen Fall weiter ausdifferenziert werden.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: FRUCOM is the European Federation representing the traders in Dried Fruit, Edible Nuts, Processed Fruit & Vegetables, Processed Fishery Products. We would like to comment on the draft Commission proposals on the marketing standards. FRUCOM is in favour of voluntary origin labelling for the final consumer, because of changes in availability due to e.g. poor crop in some origins, re-processing used in some third countries to confer origin, technological constraints and need to focus on the key issues. Setting up the traders database, inspection bodies, acceptance of declarations by the customs based on certificate of conformity or waiver: all these seem disproportionate burden on operators and public authorities compared to the expected value added. FRUCOM is in favour of removing pecans, macadamias in shell and pine nuts in shell from the requirements of the marketing standards, as they are imported in small quantities. Pistachios in shell (unroasted) should be removed as well. They are imported in large quantities into the EU and freshly roasted and packaged in the EU, for reasons of quality and freshness but also tariffs. Pistachios in shell are hardly ever sold to consumers unroasted, so it doesnt make sense to apply the whole set of marketing standards to them. The exception from the application of marketing standards (so from the origin obligation) should be valid for all products "intended for processing", not only for products intended for processing into one of the processed products listed in Part X of Annex I to Reg. EU 1308/2013. Otherwise, for example, operators usually selling nuts to clients of the bakery sector would be obliged to report the origin on the labelling. In case a mandatory origin indication becomes applicable, the companies would need longer than 1 January 2025 to implement it sustainably. It requires using up and changing packaging material and technical adaptation, e.g. new larger printers to print the country of origin together with the Lot-No. and best before date. At least 3 years transition time will be necessary. For the whole comments, please see document attached.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Wij zijn TopFresh. Specialist in de teelt en verwerking van wortelgewassen met een passie voor de snackwortel. De impact van de nieuwe wetgeving zal groot zijn voor ons en voor onze sector. Door de nieuwe verordening zullen producten die prima geschikt zijn voor menselijke consumptie niet meer als dusdanig verwerkt kunnen worden. Hierdoor neemt de voedselverspilling drastisch toe. Het kunnen verwerken van deze producten is een kracht en waardevolle toevoeging van de vers gesneden groente verwerkende industrie aan het verminderen van voedselverspilling. Door deze regels op te leggen aan de vers gesneden groente verwerkende industrie en niet aan de diepvries en conserven industrieën ontstaat daarnaast oneerlijke concurrentie. De voorgenomen aanpassingen zijn ten opzichte van de Farm to Fork strategie een zeer tegenstrijdige beweging doordat voedselverspilling juist zal toenemen. De voorgenomen aanpassingen werken kostprijsverhogend. Deze kosten zullen door producenten doorberekend moeten worden, waardoor consumenten uiteindelijk meer betalen voor vers gesneden groenten en fruit. Met het oog op een gezonde levensstijl is het belangrijk dat de consumptie van verse groenten en fruit toeneemt, terwijl een stijgende prijs dit juist kan tegengaan.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Ons bedrijf betreft een coöperatie met telers van tuinbouwproducten. Ons bedrijf levert een diversiteit aan verse groenten en fruit aan diverse snijderijen. Bij levering aan snijderijen gaat het product vaak ongesorteerd van het land in kisten naar de klant. Hierbij zijn er met de snijderijen afspraken gemaakt aan welke kwaliteitseisen het product moet voldoen. Wanneer deze producten door de nieuwe regelgeving niet meer ongesorteerd mogen worden geleverd aan snijderijen zal dat grote gevolgen hebben voor o.a. handlings- en verpakkingskosten. Deze kosten zullen significant gaan stijgen en hierdoor zal het product moeilijker of niet verkoopbaar worden aan snijderijen (product wordt te duur). Tevens zal er hierdoor onnodig product, welk niet helemaal aan de kwaliteitseisen voldoet, niet meer verkoopbaar zijn en vernietigd moeten worden. Dit leidt tot voedselverspilling en draagt zeker niet bij aan de duurzaamheid van de teelt/ productie.

short_title: Revised marketing standards for fresh fruit and vegetables, bananas, nuts, dried fruit and pulses
Feedback: Wij protesteren tegen het voorstel voor de nieuwe verordening, omdat 1. Voedselverspilling en extra (verpakkings-)afval: We niet alle champignons meer kunnen gebruiken welke wel geschikt zijn voor consumptie, daar ze niet voldoen aan de handelsnorm. Dit betekent dat we dus een reststroom krijgen die niet meer gebruikt kan worden. Dit leidt tot voedselverspilling en vernietiging van economische waarde. Dit wordt een afvalstroom welke tegen extra kosten afgevoerd dient te worden, terwijl deze champignons nog heel goed verwerkt hadden kunnen worden. Dit leidt ook tot extra verpakkingsafval- en kosten. Producenten krijgen nu nog een restwaarde voor deze champignons en dan zullen ze extra kosten krijgen. Dit leidt tot verlies van inkomen! 2. Nutteloze verpakkingslast: De champignons, welke geschikt zijn om vers te snijden, worden in bulk verpakking aangeleverd en per pallet aangeduid. Door deze verordening zouden de champignons aan verpakkingseisen in de handelsnormen dienen te voldoen en wel per krat aangeduid moeten worden, terwijl deze kratten enkel intern tussen producent en verwerker gebruik worden. De aanduidingen zijn derhalve extra lasten en in dit proces nutteloos en overbodig. 3. Extra verwerkingskosten: Omdat het land van oorsprong van de champignons op het etiket vermeld moet worden, wordt het productie proces constant onderbroken om etiketten te wisselen/aan te passen. Dit betekent dat er meer tijd nodig is om een productie run afgewerkt te krijgen. Dus extra verwerkingskosten. Alle producten dienen getraceerd te worden. Dit wordt gedaan door een goede ingangs- en uitgangsregistratie. Dit staat los van de aanduidingen op de verpakkingen. Indien er een mengsel van diverse origines wordt verwerkt, is nog steeds via de registraties traceerbaarheid mogelijk. Mengsels van diverse origines dienen mogelijk te zijn, anders leidt ook dit tot extra kosten in verband met behandelingskosten en tijd, meer voedselverspilling en verpakkingsafval. 4. Energieverspilling: In het kader van duurzaamheid en CO2 uitstoot is dit geen goede ontwikkeling, het kost meer energie omdat processen constant onderbroken worden, machines constant opnieuw moeten stoppen en gestart moeten worden, langere productiedagen, kost meer energie. 5. Oneerlijk speelveld/concurrentie: De nieuwe verordening betekent ook langere productieprocessen dus ook meer arbeidskosten, wat weer hogere prijzen gaat veroorzaken, wat ook weer oneerlijke concurrentie te weeg brengt ten opzichte van lage lonen landen in de EUR en niet EU landen, zoals bijv. Oekraïne en Engeland. Ook ontstaat er een oneerlijke concurrentie met de champignons voor verwerkte industrie (blik, pot, ecopouch, diepgevroren), daar deze champignons niet aan de handelsnormen hoeven te voldoen! 6. Minder consumptie gezonde producten: Deze procedure leidt tot een hogere consumentenprijs, waardoor de kans groot is dat consumenten minder gesneden groenten en fruit zullen gaan consumeren, terwijl consumenten juist meer groenten en fruit zouden moeten gaan consumeren. Banken Champignons

short_title: Review of egg marketing standards
Feedback: Regulation 2022/2258 describes the date of minimum durability of consumption eggs in paragraph 10. Reference is made there to a study by the Efsa of 10 July 2014. The period of 28 days is based on a test with artificially contaminated eggs that have been opened and then kept at a temperature of at least 20°C. This test is based on a worst case scenario. In this age of food waste and sustainability, you can't use an entire consumer sector on one single test. Moreover: the same study also states that salmonella on the shell dies over time. We also had a laboratory conduct our own research into the germ count of eggs and it turns out that after a longer period of time the germ count hardly deviates from that of a fresh egg. The following is also important. We are an egg packing station and if we export eggs outside the EU, a date of minimum durability (best before) of 6 and 3 months applies. As an example: as soon as eggs are shipped to the Middle East, a best before date of 3 months is common. If eggs are shipped to the African continent, a best before date of 6 months is common. It is therefore possible that one batch of eggs from poultry farmer A, which is divided among three customers, is given a best before date of 28 days, 3 months and 6 months. Knowing this data, our sector cannot explain to the European consumer that an egg can only be kept for 28 days after laying! This is the right time to take a critical look at this and to adjust this period to acceptable values, so that the environment is less burdened with unnecessary food waste and which fits in with the policy of sustainable business. For more information about this, please do not hesitate to contact us.

short_title: Requirements for control bodies controlling operators in third countries for organic products sold in the EU
Feedback: The European Organic Certifiers Council (EOCC) gathering 73 Control Bodies and Control Authorities, has been active from 2017 to prepare the switch from equivalence to compliance regime. EOCC would like to remind that this is a collective process, involving Control Bodies (CBs), Accreditation Bodies (ABs) and the European Commission (EC). Before CBs' recognition for the purpose of compliance: EOCC acknowledges all efforts performed by CBs to prepare the implementation of the REG 2018/848 in Third Countries from 01.01.2025. In order to be active in Third Countries, CBs need: - to adapt their internal procedure (documentation, IT systems, training of inspectors, among others) according to REG 2018/848 and all related secondary legislation; - then to be accredited by ABs (Witness Audits, Office assessments) - then to apply for recognition by EC (European Commission) by fulfilling a technical dossier with ABs reports in the dedicated OFIS tool. For CBs already recognised for the purpose of equivalence, Witness audits performed during the two last years (included in the last accreditation cycle of 4 years) can be taken into consideration. EOCC takes good note of this current proposal to extend from the current 2 last years to the 3 last years the Witness audits that can be considered to be inserted in the technical dosser for the CBs recognition for the purpose of compliance. EOCC welcomes this proposal for the CBs that did not apply yet for recognition. The effectiveness of this measure will depend on the date of publication of this text. After CBs' recognition for the purpose of compliance: This current proposal intends to create an intermediate cycle of two years after the date of CBs recognition, before the normal 4 years cycle of surveillance starts. For EOCC, as long as the witness audits have been done for each category of products in equivalence before the application for recognition in the last 2 or 3 years, it is feasible to perform the witness audits in compliance in the normal accreditation cycle, that is to say within 4 years. This current COM's proposal (implying high accreditation's costs concentrated in two years in place of four years) will have an economic impact on CBs active in Third Countries, in the first two years of their recognition, mostly between 2025 and 2027 or later, in a very unpredictable economic context. On this, EOCC would like to underline that the first CBs' recognition might not cover the entire current CB's geographical scope, implying uncertainty on CB's income during the first years of their recognition. Therefore, EOCC kindly asks the withdrawal of the proposal related to this intermediate cycle. Doing so, will remain the upcoming surveillance cycle of four years, already challenging compared to the current 5-years cycle. EOCC remains at disposal to further discuss this bilaterally.

short_title: Requirements for control bodies controlling operators in third countries for organic products sold in the EU
Feedback: OPTA Europe (www.opta-eu.org) is the membership organization representing the interest of European Organic Processing and Trade companies. Its members account for a large share of total EU trade and processing of organic products and play an essential role in an efficient supply chain. Imported commodities are essential for EU organic processing companies. Because organic imports are mostly products not or little produced in the European Union, in case of insufficient recognized control authorities/control bodies, EU processing companies would be forced to pull back operations, as they would not have the possibility to switch to alternative supply sources. Discontinuity of imports will also limit the choice of EU organic consumers. In light of the above considerations, we welcome the Commissions efforts to ensure a smooth transition from the equivalence to the compliance import regime and to avert possible risks of trade disruptions, like this proposed draft regulation to ease the procedural requirements for the recognition and supervision of control bodies/control authorities responsible for certifying operators in third countries. Another key element to ensure that the new import regime does not create unnecessary burden for EU companies is business predictability. Considering that EU operators need 6-12 months to make the necessary adjustments resulting from a change of the control body responsible for certifying their suppliers in third countries, we kindly ask the Commission to regularly inform EU stakeholders about the evolution of the list of recognized control bodies/authorities and to ensure that the final list is communicated at least one 6-12 months in advance. Thank you very much for considering our comments.

short_title: Template for reporting on investigations due to contamination with non-authorized products in organic production
Feedback:
The Biodynamic Federation Demeter International e.V. is an umbrella organisation with 47 members organisations in 36 different countries across the world. It is the only organic association that has built up a network of individual certification for biodynamic farming worldwide, the Demeter brand. The Federation would like to thank the Commission for the opportunity to comment on this draft implementing regulation and hope that the following considerations will be taken into account. 

It should not be assumed that every positive finding must be documented. Only cases that give rise to a suspicion of an infringement should be subject to an official investigation in line with Art. 29 (1) of EU Regulation 2018/848 and documented in accordance with the model and, if necessary, reported to the Commission. A mandatory reporting of every positive finding might not only lead to a considerable increase of the number of cases to be documented but would also imply additional costs and administrative burden for the operator without guaranteeing significant improvements for the consumer. 

Regarding the documentation of the cases, a distinction must be made between cases of contamination that are accidental and unavoidable, in short that are not due to a concrete fault of the operator, and cases of contamination that are the responsibility of the organic operator and consequently give rise to suspicion. It must be possible to classify a finding as accidental and unavoidable. Only results of official inspection by control bodies or control authorities must be documented. The findings collected during those inspections could be considered in case an official investigation is opened.

Feedback:
Der Bund Ökologische Lebensmittelwirtschaft ist der Dachverband für den Bio-Erzeuger, Bio-Verarbeiter und Bio-Händler in Deutschland. Gerne ergreifen wir die Gelegenheit uns zu dem Rechtsakt zu äußern: 
1. Nur Fälle, die einen Verdacht auf einen Verstoß begründen, sollten gemäß Art. 29 (1) VO 2018/848 einer amtlichen Untersuchung unterzogen und gemäß dem Muster dokumentiert und ggf. an die Kommission berichtet werden. Es soll nicht darauf abgestellt werden, dass jeder Positivbefund dokumentiert werden muss. Sonst wird sich die Zahl der zu dokumentierenden Fälle gegenüber heute stark erhöhen. 
2. Insbesondere dann, wenn die KOM auf der Dokumentation vieler Fälle bestehen sollte, ist es sehr wichtig, dass in dem Muster eine Unterscheidung für die Fälle von Verunreinigungen, die zufällig und unvermeidbar sind und nicht durch ein konkretes Verschulden des Bio-Unternehmens bedingt sind, sowie für die Fälle, die einen Verdacht begründen und im Verantwortungsbereich des Bio-Unternehmens liegen, vorgesehen werden (in Spalte 7 und 8). Es muss möglich sein, einen Befund als zufällig und unvermeidbar zu klassifizieren. Bei den Maßnahmen wäre das auch als Grund zu benennen, warum keine Maßnahme notwendig ist. Im Umkehrschluss kann auch eine erhöhte Aufmerksamkeit der Behörden auf benachbarte konventionelle Betriebe, die Kontaminationen bei Bio-Betrieben verursachen, eine mögliche Maßnahme zur Vermeidung von Kontaminationen bei Bio-Betrieben sein. 
3. Es muss daran festgehalten werden, dass nur Ergebnisse der amtlichen Untersuchung durch Kontrollstellen oder Kontrollbehörden dokumentiert werden müssen. Die im Rahmen von privaten Qualitätssicherungs-Maßnahmen erhobenen Befunde werden betriebsintern dokumentiert und gegebenenfalls ergehen Meldungen an Kontrollstellen gemäß Art 28 2. d) VO 2018/848. Diese Befunde können ggf. dann eingebunden werden, wenn eine amtliche Untersuchung eröffnet wird. 
4. Es ist wichtig zu klären, wer für die OFIS-Dokumentation zuständig ist, wenn mehrere Kontrollstellen involviert sind, und wie die Aufgabenteilung zwischen Kontrollstellen oder Kontrollbehörden sein soll. Die Dokumentation desselben Falls durch mehrere Kontrollstellen bzw. Kontrollbehörden erhöht Aufwand und Kosten, führt zu Doppelarbeit und erschwert die Zuordnung der Fälle. 
5. Das Fehlen einer Speicherfunktion bei dem OFIS-Eintrag wird ebenfalls Aufwand und Kosten für Kontrollstellen bzw. Kontrollbehörden erhöhen, weil bei technischen Problemen das Muster immer wieder von vorne bearbeitet werden muss. Eine Speicherfunktion sollte deshalb vorgesehen werden. 
6. Da das OFIS-Muster erst dann ausgefüllt werden soll, wenn ein Fall abgeschlossen ist, und auch keine Speicherfunktion vorgesehen ist, sollten die OFIS-Meldungen zur Untersuchung von grenzüberschreitenden Verdachtsfällen - neben der Dokumentation in OFIS mit Hilfe des hier vorgegebenen Musters - bestehen bleiben. 
7. Da das neue Muster zur Dokumentation in OFIS erwartungsgemäß erst 2023 (oder spät 2022) zur Verfügung stehen wird, sollten die Ergebnisse der amtlichen Untersuchungen erst ab 2023 in OFIS dokumentiert werden müssen. Eine rückwirkende Dokumentation der Fälle für 2022 ist aufwändig. Der erste zusammenfassende Bericht sollte dementsprechend für März 2024 vorgesehen werden.

short_title: Template for reporting on investigations due to contamination with non-authorized products in organic production
Feedback:
Der Ökolandbau ist die einzige rechtlich regulierte Garantie auf "nachhaltige" Landwirtschaft, die uns in Europa zur Verfügung steht. Seine Rechtsregeln sind bewusst als "Prozessstandards" gestaltet: Sie verpflichten den Öko-Unternehmer, Prozesse zu gewährleisten - weil er in einer Welt aus 70-90% konventioneller Landwirtschaft keine Produktgarantien verantworten kann. 

Wenn die neuen Regeln zur Untersuchung von Kontaminationen vorsehen, dass jeder Positivbefund gemeldet werden muss - und nicht nur derjenige Positivbefund, der auf einen echten Verstoß seitens des Öko-Unternehmers hin deutet - dann schafft diese Regulierung einmal mehr ausschließlich Hürden für die Öko-Betriebe und große Mengen an Bürokratie, ohne damit für den Verbraucher nennenswerte Verbesserungen zu bewirken. Die EU würde ein Mal wieder ihre eigenen Ziele aus der Farm-to-Fork-Strategie konterkarieren, insbesondere das Ziel einer effektiven Förderung des Ökolandbau und den Ausbau auf 25%. 

Ich bitte Sie daher, im Interesse einer ökologischeren Zukunft der Landwirtschaft, nur solche Befunde meldepflichtig zu machen, die auf einen Verstoß hindeuten, und keinesfalls alle Positivbefunde!

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Dutch Meat Importers Associations feedback Already in 2013 an EU study showed that the standards used measuring the water content of poultry meat were incorrect. The EU importers of poultry meat organized in the UECBV have mentioned this in a letter to the EU Commission. One might expect that once the EU legislation on marketing standards would be changed that this incorrectness would be immediately corrected. Legislation is putting boundaries between which people, companies etc have to move. If something is put incorrect on a label this can lead to actions against the people or companies. Already for years the EU Commission is pushing companies to put something on a label which is not only incorrect, it also does cost a lot of money, which would not have been the case if the right standards would be used. The EU Commission is now proposing to carry out test for the coming 5 years in order to get a grip on the standards. Strange enough these test are only carried out on EU products. Import products will not be part of this study. In the mean time the imported products still are foreseen to be controlled on basis of wrong standards which will be unacceptable. Furthermore it could well be that different genetic strains are used in the poultry meat production which picture would not be obtained. Different genetic strains would also need different standards. EU poultry meat for export which will not reach the EU consumer is put outside the obligation for control on the water content of poultry meat. Import poultry meat which will go for industrial processing, will also not reach the EU Consumer, only after industrial processing. This poultry meat should also stay outside the control on water content control. The DMIA fully underlines the UECBV s position also handed in for this public consultation.

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Axelborg, May 19, 2023 Feedback- Public consultation marketing standards for eggs The Danish Egg Association and the Danish Agriculture and Food Council Poultry are very pleased with the current changes proposed in the revised marketing standards for eggs. As representatives of the Danish egg sector, we are convinced that the proposed changes will provide better terms for the free range egg sector. We also support that this delegated act removes the date of minimum durability for eggs, the marketing of aromatized eggs and the allowance of installation of solar panels in the open-air area. Despite being very pleased with the currently proposed changes we feel the need to stress a couple of other points, which are not taken up in the revised marketing standards: Preservation and handling of eggs (Article 4, 3.): We question the opportunity for some member states to wash the eggs on an authorized pack-ing station. This opportunity should be open to all member states, provided that those centers operate in accordance with national guides for egg-washing systems and the eggs are only sold in the original member state. The allowance for some countries but not others is distorting the market and not given a level playing field for all producers. Imported eggs (Article 22): As the EU has one of the highest standards of animal welfare and corresponding production costs, we only find it fair that if eggs and egg products produced to non-EU standards find their way to the EU markets, they should be easily distinguishable as not being produced to EU standards. The current conditions for the provision of information are difficult to read and not immediately visible to consumers. The information Produced to non-EU standard should be printed on the front or on the top of the egg tray with letters at least 15 mm tall. We support the marking of eggs on the production site, but only as long as it is also allowed to exempt eggs from being marked at the production site, if it is carried out in the first packing center to which the eggs are delivered. And this allowance should be handled by the member states without any further demands than the current legislation. Best regards Jørgen Nyberg Larsen Danish Egg Association

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: To the EU-Commission - Public Opinion about Marketing standards for poultry It is important to modernize the marketing standards for poultry meat in the European Union to ensure the continuity and effective functioning of the common market organization. The implementation of harmonized, specific marketing standards would greatly benefit industry, trade, controlling authorities, and consumers. However, despite the welcome revisions, the standards have remained largely unchanged since their inception, despite significant advancements in the sector. The use of new production methods, particularly in terms of water content, has not been fully considered. That being said, the inclusion of new poultry cuts in the definitions is a positive step that would help reduce food waste and cater to growing demand. We would also like to take this opportunity to urge the Commission to mandate transparent and mandatory origin labelling for all products containing poultry meat, including fresh, frozen, and processed products sold in restaurants, canteens, and catering establishments. This labelling should clearly indicate whether the product is of EU or non-EU origin. We believe that this labelling requirement is in line with the objectives of the Farm to Fork strategy and would reinforce the message to consumers that poultry meat in the EU is produced to higher standards. Furthermore, we would like to highlight the possibility of labelling products from a single MS when the entire production chain is within that MS. The idea of defining national production systems is a positive one, but further clarity is needed on how this would be implemented. About different rearing systems in Art 10 and 11: Its difficult to have an opinion regarding the possibility of defining national production systems if it is unclear how the MS will make the definition. Lower stock intensity compared to the standard in the EU legislation (the standard level is 42 kg/kvm2 in the EUs Welfare directive) should be a standard as extensive indoor barned reared. Without any specific requirements, more than low mortality at the maximum level in the EU directive is an incitement for using more antibiotics. The marketing standards are old-fashioned and not applicable to different production systems. Free movement indoors or free-range indoors We apply for a standard for free movement for chickens indoors in the barn should be possible since the EU marketing standards do not today give that possibility in the definitions in Article 10. Since 40% of Swedish consumers think that chickens are reared in cages it is necessary to clarify the modern poultry meat production in the EU. It clarifies to production system by using the explanation of the product: free range indoors. Either all standards should include barns production if the poultry is reared indoors in the barn, or no one of all standards. All chickens for poultry meat in Sweden are reared in the barn. Add free range indoor with low stock density (max 36 kg/kvm2 or at least every which under the maximum level in the EU-directive, 42 kg/kvm2) with higher welfare quality indicators, for example, Controlling program for foot pad dermatitis program, no beak trimming, low antibiotic treatment. We do not understand why having a difference between free range and traditional free range- traditional for whom? Finally, the definition of slow-growing differs between the MS necessary therefore to put a standard for what is slow growing. Kind regards Maria Donis The Poultry Meat Association

En effet, sil est adopté, il permettra aux volailles rurales de continuer à contribuer à une alimentation durable et de qualité et à maintenir une protection efficace des consommateurs contre toute tentative de publicités mensongères ou trompeuses. Depuis les années 90, les normes ont été un outil responsable pour le maintien et le développement de la production complémentaire de volailles dans les campagnes. nous demandons donc de maintenir des normes de commercialisation essentielles et protectrices pour notre modèle délevage que des consommateurs.

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, die bestehende Vermarktungsnorm 543/2008 und deren Überarbeitung sind nur schwer mit dem angestrebten Tierschutzzielen aus den EU-Verträgen vereinbar und behindern eine Weiterentwicklung des EU-Geflügelmarktes hin zu nachhaltigen Produkten. Sie benachteiligen Geflügelhalter:innen aus extensiven Haltungssystemen. Die Kastration von Hähnen (Kapaune) erfolgt immer noch in Ländern ohne Betäubung. Die Hoden werden den Tieren aus dem Körper gerissen. Das ist eine barbarische Methode und sehr schmerzhaft. Ein Teil der Tiere überlebt diesen Eingriff nicht. Wird die Kastration nach dem Stand der Technik durchgeführt, also in Narkose und unter prä-, intra- und postoperativer Analgesie kommen wir ggf. mit dem Tierarzneimittelrecht in Konflikt, da die notwendigen Tierarzneimittel ggf. nicht für Hühner zugelassen sind bzw. gar nicht in Tabelle 1 der VO (EG) Nr. 37/2010 gelistet sind. Andernfalls erfolgt das nicht, weil die Kosten dafür hoch sind. Auch ist die Kastration nicht notwendig. Die Effekte sind zu vernachlässigen. Die Empfehlung ist: Kapaune für die Lebensmittelproduktion eu-weit zu verbieten. Wie werden Bruderhähne aus Zweinutzungsrassen oder Hahn und Henne von langsam wachsenden Mastlinien dabei berücksichtigt? Diese sind keine Legelinien, deren Sternum ist aber ebenfalls ggf. nicht mehr flexibel aber auch noch nicht verknöchert, weil deren Aufzucht entsprechend lange ist. Diese Tiere sind auch deutlich schwerer, jünger und qualitativ anders zu bewerten als ein Suppenhuhn oder ein alter Hahn. Wie sind diese einzuordnen? Die Empfehlung ist: Für diese Tiere ebenfalls eine geeignete Definition zu finden. Die Einordnung der Tiere über das Brustbein konterkariert sämtliche Bemühungen, Tiere langsamer wachsen zu lassen, um Schäden durch zu schnelles Wachstum zu vermeiden. Die gesamte Definition im Bereich der Geflügelfleischgewinnung sollte über Tageszunahmen und Alter erfolgen. Hierbei sollte der Schwerpunkte auf langsam-wachsende Tiere liegen. Die Begriffsbestimmungen müssen angepasst werden an die der Richtlinie 98/58/EG sowie Richtlinie 91/630/EWG und Richtlinie 2007/43/EG. Ebenso sollten diese mit den Begriffsbestimmungen der Öko-Basis-VO (EU) 2018/848 und deren DVO (EU) 2020/464 harmonisiert werden. Das Festhalten an Foie gras widerspricht ebenfalls den EU-Verträgen bezüglich Tierschutz. Leberpasteten können auch ohne eine gezielte Erkrankung der Tiere hergestellt werden aus normalen Lebern von Gans und Ente. Eine fütterungsbedingte Hypertrophie der Leberfettzellen für die Herstellung von Fettleberpasteten ist nichts anderes als eine Fettleber und damit eine Erkrankung. Hinzukommt, dass die Verabreichung der dafür notwendigen Futtermengen durch Zwangsfütterung erfolgt, was die Tiere an sich bereits Schmerzen, Leiden und Schäden beim Einführen der Trichter/Schläuche aussetzt. Die Empfehlung ist: Nur noch Leberprodukte aus gesunden Lebern zu genehmigen, die gezielte Produktion von Fettlebern zu verbieten. Die Angaben von Mindestgrößen bei den Lebern sind ebenfalls herauszunehmen. Bezüglich Wasseraufnahmevermögen: Es sollte auch bereits beim Wachstum berücksichtigt werden, dass schnell wachsende Tiere einen höheren Muskelwasseranteil haben als langsam wachsende Tiere. Auch hier sollte es eine Begrenzung geben, um die Zucht auf immer größere Tiere, die keinen Mehrwert hinsichtlich der Fleischqualität bringen, zu begrenzen. Hinsichtlich der Definition von Freilandhaltung sollte diese auch nicht schlechter gestellt werden als in der ökologischen Haltung. Eine reine Weidehaltung ist für Geflügel eher als tierschutzwidrig zu sehen. Es bedarf entsprechender Unterschlüpfe. Agroforstsysteme und Photovoltaikanlagen sind geeignet und sollten in der Definition für Freilandhaltung berücksichtigt und nicht ausgenommen werden. Vielen Dank! Freundliche Grüße

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Le foie gras fait partie de notre patrimoine gastronomique européen. Le foie gras est un produit de terroir par excellence. Je pense que des normes de commercialisation fortes pour le foie gras peuvent protéger les consommateurs contre les pratiques frauduleuses, et par conséquent préserver notre savoir-faire unique. Cest la raison pour laquelle, je soutiens le projet dacte délégué de la Commission européenne qui maintient la définition du foie gras cru. En effet, le poids minimum des foies - 300 g pour les canards et 400 g pour les oies doit être conservé afin de sassurer que les foies ont été suffisamment engraissés, et ainsi garantir à la fois un produit authentique aux consommateurs et la confiance en lappellation prestigieuse « foie gras ». Fier de ce produit, je compte sur ladoption de normes de commercialisation ambitieuses par la Commission européenne.

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Je suis éleveur de palmipèdes gras en France depuis 1998. Le foie gras fait partie de notre patrimoine gastronomique français et européen. Spécialité culinaire ancestrale devenue emblématique dun savoir-faire en matière de gastronomie, le foie gras est un produit de « terroir » par excellence. Symbole de plaisir,de partage,et de convivialité, les consommateurs européens, et notamment français, y sont très attachés. Au vu du prestigieux et de la grande valeur du produit qu'est le foie gras, seules des normes de commercialisation robustes peuvent protéger les consommateurs contre les pratiques frauduleuses, et par conséquent préserver notre savoir-faire unique. Cest pour cela que je soutiens le projet dacte délégué de la Commission européenne qui maintient la définition du foie gras cru. En effet, le poids minimum des foies - 300 g pour les canards et 400 g pour les oies doit être conservé afin de sassurer que les foies ont été suffisamment engraissés, et garantir à la fois un produit authentique aux consommateurs et la confiance en lappellation prestigieuse « foie gras ». Très majoritairement acheté par les consommateurs, lacte délégué devrait contenir une définition du foie gras transformé. Cette définition permettrait déviter que des produits qui utilisent la dénomination « foie gras » alors quils nen ont ni les propriétés, ni les qualités gustatives ne circulent sur le marché

short_title: Review of poultry marketing standards
Feedback: Eurogroup for Animals calls for the removal of the requirements for minimum liver weights from the EU Regulation on marketing standards for poultrymeat as they are arbitrary and are the reason for the continuation of the inhumane, cruel practice of force-feeding. A vast body of scientific evidence points to the immense negative welfare effects of force-feeding, among which a prominent example is the SCAHAW report published already in 1998 (25 years ago!). 25 years and countless scientific studies later, EFSA announced in their scientific opinion on duck, geese and quail welfare that all husbandry systems used in foie gras production systems should be avoided. It is imperative for the credibility of EU institutions to consider the input of EU scientific bodies when revising legislative acts. Furthermore, the current requirements for minimum liver weights discriminate against small farmers, who are extremely important to ensure a sustainable agricultural system. 22 EU Member States have outlawed the practice of force-feeding. The European Commission has the opportunity to improve the lives of great numbers of ducks and geese farmed for foie gras with a simple deletion of these arbitrary and cruel requirements, simultaneously ensuring a better market for farmers and acting in accordance with the wishes of EU citizens. EU citizens prove time and time again that animal welfare is an important value for them and that they believe animal welfare should be improved in the EU. We strongly believe that the Commission will follow the will of the citizens and prove that it is a leader in animal welfare standards.
