short_title: Organics - Details on records to be kept and declarations to be communicated by operators
Feedback:
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren in der Kommission! 

Der vorliegende Entwurf enthält einige spezifische Vorschläge betreffend einer EU-Zertifikatsdatenbank, den die IG Kontrollstellen Österreich für problematisch erachtet, da die dargestellte operative manuelle Eingabe sowohl krisen- und fehleranfällig als auch als nicht marktrelevant zu bezeichnen ist. Die laufend notwendige Aktualisierung der Daten stellt darüber hinaus einen hohen zusätzlichen bürokratischen Aufwand dar, der das Bio-Kontrollsystem damit zusätzlich verteuert. Wir möchten insbesondere darauf verweisen, dass Zertifikate für die Unternehmer ein wichtiges Dokument im Rahmen der Wareneingangskontrolle darstellen. Diese werden derzeit sehr effizient und erfolgreich über private Bio-Plattformen (zB. www.bioc.info, www.easy-cert.com oder www.oekokontrollstellen.de u.a.) zur Verfügung gestellt und von tausenden UnternehmerInnen genutzt. Teilweise bieten diese Plattformen auch spezifische Direktinformationen über zusätzliche Qualitätsaspekte von privaten Bioverbänden oder Services für die Erstellung von Freigabe-Listen für die Unternehmen, womit das Bio-Qualitätsmanagement vereineinfacht abgewickelt werden kann. Der Zusatz-Nutzen einer Zertifikatsdatenbank auf TRACES in der gewählten Form kann von den österreichischen Kontrollstellen daher nicht nachvollzogen werden - insbesondere da der Informationsgehalt der obligatorischen Angaben in den Zertifikaten über eine bloß sehr allgemeine Spezifikation des Unternehmens nicht hinausgeht. 

Wir möchten daher darauf hinweisen, dass folgende Kriterien unbedingt Berücksichtigung finden sollten, um eine erfolgreiche Implementierung der neuen EU-BIO-Verordnung mit 01-01-2022 zu gewährleisten: 

1) Eine EU-Zertifikatsdatenbank sollte frühestens mit 01-01-2023 implementiert werden. Im Jahr 2022 sollte diesbezüglich prozessorientiert   
    unter Einbindung bestehender Plattformen primär an der Etablierung von automatisierten Lösungen via Schnittstelle gearbeitet werden. 
2) Bestehende Zertifikatsdatenbanken sind bestmöglich einzubinden - denn diese werden derzeit von den Bio-Verarbeitern auch explizit genutzt!

Bezüglich des vorliegenden Entwurfes haben wir uns auch erlaubt ganz konkrete Änderungsvorschläge in der englischen Version vorzunehmen. Diese finden Sie im angehängten File. 

Wir hoffen auf eine konstruktive Berücksichtigung unserer Hinweise und Vorschläge, 

mit biologischen Grüßen für die österreichischen Bio-Kontrollstellen (ABG-LW, ABG, BIOS, LVA, Lacon, LKV, SGS, SLK)

DI Dr. Wolfgang Pirklhuber (Sprecher der IG-Biokontrollstellen)

short_title: Organics - Details on records to be kept and declarations to be communicated by operators
Feedback:
In relazione al Regolamento in oggetto FederBio, la Federazione del Biologico Italiano, segnala:

Articolo 1: concordiamo con la scelta di avere un unico modello di certificato ed un unico luogo dove è possibile reperire i certificati di tutti gli operatori europei, un sistema informativo centrale dell'UE dove i certificati biologici siano facilmente consultabili è sicuramente un bene in quanto semplificherebbe e renderebbe il controllo dei certificati più efficiente. Però riteniamo che il sistema proposto attraverso l'utilizzo di TRACES, per quanto riguarda gli operatori biologici Europei, debba essere utilizzato per la sola "pubblicazione" dei certificati e non per la "emissione". Si ricorda che l'emissione di un certificato è il risultato di un processo che inizia con una notifica all'Autorità Nazionale Competente designata e continua con la valutazione e il rilascio dei certificati da parte delle Autorità o Organismi di Controllo Nazionali designati, pertanto, il certificato è il risultato del processo di certificazione e dovrebbe essere rilasciato nel sistema in cui si svolge il processo di certificazione. Inoltre vincolare l'emissione dei certificati ad un unico strumento informatico, in caso di blackout del sistema, metterebbe a rischio l'emissione dei certificati di 270 OdC europei andando a causare sicuramente problemi a innumerevoli operatori biologici, considerando che in Europa ci sono più di 400.000 operatori biologici certificati, e una parte di loro riceve 2 o più certificati ogni anno, significa che il sistema dovrebbe gestire centralmente molto più di mezzo milione di certificati all'anno.

Si segnala infine che risulta inaccettabile dover caricare i dati a mano sul sistema TRACES in quanto ad oggi non sono attivi sistemi di web services (o strumenti simili) obbligando gli OdC di imputare gli stessi dati più volte (su sistemi proprietari, su sistemi Nazionali e su Traces) con  l'ovvio rischio di errori di imputazione.

Concludendo si chiede pertanto di definire che il sistema TRACES servirà alla pubblicazione e non alla emissione dei certificati e di posticipare l'entrata in vigore dell'Articolo 1 dal 01/01/2022 al 01/01/2023 al fine di poter affrontare e risolvere i problemi sopra indicati.

Articolo 2: Considerando che le visite ispettive presso le aziende biologiche avvengono 1/n volte all'anno o addirittura ogni 24 mesi in applicazione dell'art 38 comma 3 del Reg. UE 848/18, FederBio condivide l'importanza di definire registri sia contabili che colturali, fondamentali per permettere una adeguata attività di controllo del metodo biologico che comprenda misure  preventive  e  precauzionali, tracciabilità e bilanci di massa.  Ci si auspica anche una gestione digitale delle registrazioni legate a sistemi già in uso per la PAC onde evitare duplicazioni di adempimenti, semplificare e evitare disallineamenti dei dati e consentire controlli incrociati con maggiore facilità. Si concorda pertanto con l'entrata in vigore di tale articolo per il 01/01/2022.

Articolo 3: si condivide la specifica richiesta di un "programma di produzione" per le unità agricole (compresa la zootecnia) e di acquacoltura e la messa a disposizione degli OdC di tale "programma" prima della data indicata dall'autorità competente. Si ritiene tale soluzione fondamentale per poter pianificare correttamente le attività ispettive legandole alle reali produzioni previste, e non solo alla storicità dell'azienda da controllare. Si concorda pertanto con l'entrata in vigore di tale articolo per il 01/01/2022.

Articolo 4: si concorda con l'entrata in vigore per il 01/01/2022 solo per gli articoli 2 e 3, mentre come indicato sopra per l'articolo 1 si chiede il posticipo al 01/01/2023 per le ragioni sopra esposte.

Cordiali saluti
FederBio

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
EuroCommerce welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback to the “Supplementing Regulation by laying down specific criteria and conditions for the checks of documentary accounts in the framework of official controls in organic production and the official controls of groups of operators”.   

Food retailers and wholesalers are a central actor in the food supply chain: they are in daily contact with Europe’s 500 million consumers and they operate efficient systems ensuring the reliable and safe distribution of foods. They work to meet consumers’ demands, including regarding the supply of organic products, and help them lead a healthy and sustainable lifestyle. 

Together with our partners in the supply chain our sector has been actively promoting organics products providing consumer choice. For this, commerce needs sufficient and regular supplies of quality organic products to be able to respond to increasing consumer demand. New regulation should support further growth along the whole food supply chain, and to maintain consumer confidence. 

Our specific feedback on the draft text is as follows: 

Article 1 - Checks of documentary accounts: 

(1.1) => It is not clear from the draft text how long the operator is required to keep documentation, financial records etc. 

(1.2.) => We support the fact that during the traceability check and mass balance check, the selection of products to be checked is based on a risk-assessment instead of a specific number or percentage of products.

(1.4) => Regarding the elements for mass balance check:  In supply chain systems at retail level organic products are not separated from conventional products in loss accounting. For this reason, loss for organic products can only be estimated. 

We therefore suggest reformulating this paragraph as follows: 

-	point g, “any estimated losses, increase and decrease in quantity of product at any stage of production, preparation and distribution”.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
The Bundesverband Naturkost Naturwaren (BNN) e.V., based in Germany, represents organic processors, wholesalers and retailers. We welcome the improvements proposed by the Commission in this public consultation. We still would like to point out the following points:

Article 1 - Checks of documentary accounts:

Traceability checks: Operators in the EU are legally obliged to trace their products only one step back to their suppliers. If these suppliers (e.g. importers) are not willing to communicate their own suppliers to their buyers, the operator has no means to trace the product back to the original producer. This is of particular importance in long supplying chains and for products from third countries. For regular traceability checks as they are proposed in this draft, it is enough to go one step back.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
BÖLW, the German umbrella association of organic farmers, processors and traders, acknowledges the improvements compared to the previous version. We have the following suggestions. 

Article 1: Checks of documentary accounts

•	Traceability checks: Operators in the EU are legally obliged to trace their products only one step back to their suppliers. If these suppliers (e.g. importers) are not willing to communicate their own suppliers to their buyers, the operator has no means to trace the product back to the original producer. This is of particular importance in long supplying chains and for products from third countries. For regular traceability checks as they are proposed in this draft, it is enough to go one step back.

Input for the Public Consultation on the draft Commission Delegated Regulation supplementing Regulation (EU) 2018/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council by laying down specific criteria and conditions for the checks of documentary accounts in the framework of official controls in organic production and the official controls of group of operators

26/08/2020

Prüfung von Dokumenten - Artikel 1 

•	Rückverfolgbarkeitstest: Unternehmen in der EU sind gesetzlich verpflichtet, ihre Produkte nur einen Schritt bis zu ihren Lieferanten zurückzuverfolgen. Wenn diese Lieferanten (z.B. Importeure) nicht bereit sind, ihre eigenen Lieferanten ihren Käufern mitzuteilen, hat der Unternehmer keine Möglichkeit, das Produkt bis zum ursprünglichen Hersteller zurückzuverfolgen. Dies ist von besonderer Bedeutung bei langen Lieferketten und bei Produkten aus Drittländern. 
Natürlich wäre es gut, die Rückverfolgbarkeit bis zum Ursprung zu überprüfen. Dies ist notwendig, um zu überprüfen, ob jeder Akteur in der Kette die Anforderung an die Rückverfolgbarkeit erfüllt, und von besonderer Bedeutung im Falle eines vermuteten oder festgestellten Verstoßes. Die Rückverfolgbarkeitstests sollten also zunächst einen Schritt zurückgehen und je nach Risiko erweitert werden.
Bitte prüfen!

Amtliche Kontrollen von Unternehmergruppen - Artikel 2

•	Ausbildung: Die Schulung der Landwirte in ökologischer Produktion und zu den Anforderungen der Öko-Verordnung sollte zu einem obligatorischen Bestandteil eines internen Kontrollsystems (ICS) werden. Schulung und Anleitung für Landwirte können zur Vermeidung von Verstößen ebenso wichtig sein wie der Kontrollbesuch selbst. Es reicht nicht aus, dass nur der ICS-Manager geschult werden muss.
•	Umstellungszeit: Gegenwärtig besteht die Tendenz, dass in Drittländern keine angemessenen Umstellungszeiträume umgesetzt werden. Aus diesem Grund schlagen wir vor zu prüfen, ob angemessene Umstellungsfristen für neue Mitglieder, neue Produktionseinheiten oder neue Betriebe sichergestellt und umgesetzt werden.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
EZA Fairer Handel GmbH has been working with numerous small farmers' organizations in Africa, Asia and Latin America since 1975. Together with them, we work to improve their living conditions and strengthen them as central actors in the supply chains of many products.
The overwhelming majority of the smallholder organizations with which we cooperate has chosen to work according to the criteria of organic farming in recent decades - despite the most difficult conditions in their countries. Through Fair Trade and organic farming, smallholder families not only achieve higher prices for their product, they also make a significant contribution to climate protection and provide consumers with high-quality products. Their organizations - cooperatives and other producer associations - not only guarantee democratic co-participation, but also provide training for their members (including in organic farming and the implementation of solid internal control systems) as well as social and economic support.
We are therefore - together with our trading partners in the Global South who have given us their feedback on points of the planned EU organic regulation and proposed changes - very concerned about the far-reaching consequences that individual points of the new EU-regulation might have. 
We ask the Commission to adapt the planned EU-regulation in such a way that disadvantaged small producers and their organizations will continue to have the opportunity to get their products organically certified within the organizational structures they have created and to offer them as such, without creating insurmountable bureaucratic, financial and organizational hurdles for particularly disadvantaged small producers from the Global South. 
Otherwise, we fear that numerous smallholder organizations built up in recent decades could lose their access to the European organic market, which would lead to a dramatic weakening of an already highly disadvantaged sector, destroy income opportunities for small producers in the Global South and promote poverty. 
We therefore endorse the recommendations of IFOAM, which are based on many years of practical experience, and recognized, international Fair Trade networks, and ask the Commission to take them into account - also in the sense of global responsibility to strengthen the prospects of small-scale and organic farming and the actors involved particularly in the Global South.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
Comments from the Pacific Organic and Ethical Trade Community [SPC POETCom]
26 August 2020

Introduction:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this draft act. POETCom’s comments focus on the Regulation (EU) 2018/848 draft rules for Grower Groups, which are a common and expanding scheme for organic certification across the Pacific. As a member of IFOAM Organics International POETCom has been actively participating in the development of these rules and submitted comments on 12 August 2019. As IFOAM Members we fully support the four November 2019 IFOAM Organics International proposals as solutions to protect organic integrity while encouraging the expansion of the organic movement in the Pacific.   We therefore submit them as our proposals as well, with the addition of POETCom comments.

• IFOAM Proposal: IFOAM strongly advocates that cooperatives, federations of cooperatives, and processors/exporters with affiliated farms continue to be recognised as certifiable legal group entities. 
POETCom Comments: Legal registration varies widely across the Pacific making this “one size fits all” requirement difficult for some groups. The IFOAM proposal to allow flexibility while assuring integrity is a good solution.

•	IFOAM Proposal: IFOAM recommends deleting the new requirement which requires the residue sampling for 2% of the members of the group. It would significantly increase the cost of the management of the group. In a group of 2000, it would mean to collect and make lab analysis of samples from 40 members every year. 
POETCom Comments:  Although testing is an important part of organic regulation, mandatory testing without risk-based justification is not a good policy and would greatly increase certification costs.  In the Pacific, testing can be difficult and expensive.

•	 IFOAM Proposal: IFOAM does not recommend linking a maximum group size limit to a single legal personality. Instead it is suggested to require large groups to have a clustered structure that ensures a close supervision of the internal control system (ICS). This would allow for partial de-certification of the group by decertifying defined ICS clusters if the ICS would be found to be failing only in one of these. If a size limit is established, the limit should be for the purpose of certification only. It should be possible that different cluster groups of 2000 farmers use the same Internal Management and Control System, and that they are all under the same legal personality. 
POETCom Comments: We agree that the key to a successful Grower Group is the Internal Control System [ICS].  There are many examples of grower groups with high numbers and high quality.  We feel this restriction would limit growth in the Pacific especially for some products like Coffee, Cocoa, Coconut and Kava.  The proposed clustered structure has been successfully incorporated in the Pacific where a grower group has producers on multiple islands.

•	IFOAM Proposal: As for external controls from certification bodies, IFOAM recommends continuing the square root approach, and additionally setting a minimum control rate of 3-5%. A minimum of 3% would result in higher control rates only for normal risk groups of more than 1200 members. The currently proposed 5 % would mean that all normal risk groups with more than 400 members (the vast majority of existing groups) will require a higher number of inspections compared to today. The harmonization of the quality and thoroughness of the external farm inspections of group members by the certification body remains a key challenge and efforts will be needed to ensure it, especially if the total number of inspections increases. 
POETCom Comments: We agree that the current system needs to be revised and endorse the IFOAM recommendation to continuing the square root approach, and additionally setting a minimum control rate of 3-5%.  

<END>

Feedback:
Prüfung von Dokumenten - Artikel 1 

•	Prüfung Rückverfolgbarkeit: Unternehmen in der EU sind gesetzlich verpflichtet, ihre Produkte einen Schritt bis zu ihren Lieferanten zurückzuverfolgen.  Evtl wäre ein Klarstellung, dass im Rahmen der Kontrollen diese Rückverfolgbarkeit bei eingehenden Waren bis zum Lieferanten und bei ausgehender Ware bis zum Abnehmer erfolgen sollte, hilfreich um Missverständnisse zu vermeiden.

Amtliche Kontrollen von Unternehmergruppen - Artikel 2

•	Ausbildung: Die Schulung der Mitglieder von Unternehmergruppen in ökologischer Produktion und zu den Anforderungen der Öko-Verordnung sollte zu einem obligatorischen Bestandteil eines internen Kontrollsystems (ICS) werden. Schulung und Anleitung für Gruppenmitglieder sind ebenso wichtig sein wie Kontrollbesuche selbst. Es reicht nicht aus, ICS-Manager zu schulen.
•	Umstellungszeit: Derzeit besteht nicht die Gewähr, dass in Drittländern angemessene Umstellungszeiträume eingehalten werden. Daher ist eine obligatorische Prüfung der Einhaltung und Gewähr angemessener Umstellungszeiten gerade bei Unternehmerguppen sinnvoll und notwendig.

short_title: Contingency plan for ensuring food supply and food security
Feedback:
At Corbion, our purpose is to sustainably preserve what matters: Preserving food and food production, health, and the planet. We do this by using science to propel nature’s ingenuity.

Corbion is the global market leader in lactic acid and its derivatives. Our sustainable solutions provide an alternative to fossil-based ingredients or building blocks across a wide range of industries such as food, home & personal care, animal nutrition, pharmaceuticals, medical devices, and bioplastics.

In 2020 Corbion has been recognized by global environmental non-profit CDP for its actions to cut emissions, mitigate climate risks and develop the low-carbon economy, securing a place on its prestigious 'A List'. Corbion received the Platinum sustainability rating (top 1% of all companies assessed) in this year's EcoVadis CSR assessment that evaluates 4 areas: environment, labor practices, fair business practices and sustainable procurement. In addition, we partner and collaborate with our direct suppliers and engage with other stakeholders involved in our agricultural supply chains to promote our vision for sustainable agriculture. See our sustainable agriculture policy for more information.

Corbion welcomes the European Commission’s intention to set up a common EU food crisis response mechanism in the form of a permanent forum with the Commission, member states and food supply stakeholders. We at Corbion are offering and developing solutions for 5 of the 10 breakthrough technologies that can help feed the world as defined by the World Resource Institute.

A crucial way to make the response mechanism effective for all of Europe is to set up proper preventative measures for ensuring a robust European food system. Certain examples are already identified in the inception impact assessment, such as exchanging best practices and informing the public, engaging with international trading partners and using a solid, up-to- date evidence base. 

These measures could focus on:

• Minimising food waste. Food losses and waste account for 6% of global GHG emissions and if it was a country would be the third largest emitter in the world. Corbion therefore develops sustainable food solutions to help preserve food and texture, extend shelf-life, and provide nutritional benefits. Solutions include our natural ferments based on vegetables and fruits and our family of sodium and potassium lactates such as PURASAL. These can extend shelf life by up to 100% by reducing the growth of spoilage bacteria

• Promoting the use of organic substitutes. For example, to keep global fish stocks in line with maximum sustainable yields, Europe has to find a solution to address the global demand increase for long chain omega-3s in order to reduce the pressure on wildly caught fish. Corbion has developed AlgaPrime DHA, an abundant, clean and sustainable source of long chain omega-3. AlgaPrime DHA can help reduce the dependency on fish oil in aquaculture and animal feed, and helps support animal, oceanic and human health.

• Removing dogmas about the role of food and feed crops on land use and food security. As our population increases, so does the demand for global resources. Arable land could become scarce and it is therefore of utmost importance to use the most efficient crops available. Unfortunately, this has recently led to certain draft legislative initiatives to mark the use of food and feed crops as bio-based feedstock for the manufacturing of chemicals and plastics as unsustainable. It would be regrettable if those misconceptions, that we have also addressed in the relevant consultation, would be carried over in this initiative.

We remain at your disposal for further discussions and support!

short_title: Contingency plan for ensuring food supply and food security
Feedback:
Le 12/12/19, Françoise LABORDE, sénatrice de la Haute-Garonne, a présenté un projet de résolution intitulé "Résilience alimentaire des territoires et sécurité nationale", directement inspiré des travaux de Stéphane LINOU, récemment primés au Forum des Risques Majeurs. (https://www.thebookedition.com/fr/resilience-alimentaire-et-securite-nationale-p-367243.html) / https://www.utip.io/stephane

« Aujourd'hui, production et consommation ne sont plus territorialisées et même les zones rurales sont alimentairement vulnérables, perfusées par le ballet des camions de la grande distribution, l'autonomie alimentaire de nos territoires n'étant en moyenne que de 2 %...
À l'heure des cyberattaques, du dérèglement et des catastrophes climatiques, du terrorisme et de l'effondrement de la biodiversité, la déterritorialisation de la production et de la consommation alimentaires n'est pas analysée comme risque stratégique. Des signaux nous alertent pourtant: la moindre annonce de blocage routier vide les magasins, avant même toute pénurie, allant jusqu'à provoquer des émeutes, comme il y a peu en outre-mer.
En cas de force majeure (sachant que les plans ORSEC ne répondent pas à la question soulevée), le déficit de capacité à subvenir localement à l'un de nos besoins primaires, celui de se nourrir, est flagrant, et les populations ne sont pas préparées. »

Assurer un niveau minimum de sécurité d'approvisionnement alimentaire (garantir une chaîne résiliente allant du foncier agricole nourricier jusqu'au consommateur) était ce sur quoi reposait grandement l'ordre public, jadis essentiellement assuré au niveau municipal.
Ce 12/12/19 au Sénat, après que le Ministre de l’Intérieur le 16/05/19 (déjà sur cette question) répondait à Françoise LABORDE que « ce sujet est relatif à un « Risque Majeur » », notre Gouvernement a validé cette analyse et ces orientations. Il a notamment déclaré :
"Les risques pesant sur la sécurité alimentaire ne s’arrêtent pas aux frontières des pays défavorisés. La France, comme l’ensemble des pays industrialisés, est elle aussi directement concernée, malgré une production de denrées agricoles importante et supérieure à ses besoins. La réduction des surfaces agricoles, l’artificialisation des terres, la raréfaction des ressources hydriques, l’hyper-sophistication des chaînes d’approvisionnement et la dépendance extrême aux énergies fossiles, sont autant de facteurs qui rendent notre système alimentaire particulièrement vulnérable face aux menaces systémiques. La question du lien entre résilience alimentaire des territoires et sécurité nationale mérite d'être pleinement prise en compte, eu égard à l'actualité. Le Gouvernement est globalement d’accord avec l’esprit et les orientations de cette proposition de résolution."
Ainsi, si la non résilience alimentaire des territoires préoccupe officiellement le gouvernement du pays le plus concerné par la PAC, il est logique que ce sujet soit réellement intégré à celle-ci et faire l’objet de travaux de la Commission Européenne. 

Tous les échelons devront jouer un rôle au sein du continuum de sécurité. L'annonce des crises systémiques nous fait rentrer en «territoires inconnus» et chaque échelon peut prévenir et gérer ces crises. Nous nous questionnons désormais sur l'apparition d'externalités de sécurités, jusque-là invisibles, issues d'orientations économiques et spatiales passées qui montrent aujourd'hui certaines limites. Ainsi, la question de la résilience alimentaire territorialisée articulée à l'ordre public, pensée avec l’UE et accompagnée par un « Etat local facilitateur », pourraient être la première pierre posée (en passant par une large acculturation aux risques) dans l'édification d'une véritable résilience globale.
Il est nécessaire d’enrichir, avec ce sujet, la Loi n° 2004-811 du 13/08/2004 de modernisation de la sécurité civile et grand temps d’aborder le plus vieux sujet du monde (le lien entre l’alimentation et la sécurité) sous l’angle du continuum sécurité défense.

short_title: Contingency plan for ensuring food supply and food security
Feedback:
The German Poultry Association welcomes the contingency plan for ensuring food supply and food security in EU in event of future crises. The European food system has proven resilient and successfully managed to provide healthy and high quality food to the European citizens. The industry has done its very best to ensure food security and safety, while the situation was challenging.
A contingency plan with clear rules is therefore necessary and important!

The poultry meat sector came under huge pressure mainly due to the almost overnight disappearance of large sections of key demand from restaurants, hotels, and catering, as well as to mobility restrictions and to new sanitary requirements. 

The German Poultry sector, who provides a highly valued protein sources to the European Population was struck by the sudden closing of borders, leading to shortages in workforce in all branches, starting from the laying hens, ending in the slaughter houses. Due to the long practiced and close trade relations among member states of the European Union, a sudden closing of borders must be avoided at all costs.  
The loss of an entire market segment is hard for 

The communication amongst the member states needs to be precise and quick, especially when it comes to transportation of living animals. Clear communication from the authorities to the officials must be ensured. The room for interpretations should be as small as possible. We support the implementation of the so called "Green Lanes". A long delay leads to negative effects on animal welfare. 

The German Poultry Association supports the creation of a common EU food crisis response mechanism – and we find that it is of huge importance that the stakeholders in the food chain will participate in the permanent forum, together with the Commission and the Member States. This will without any doubt result in the most efficient results.
We also support the inclusion of international trade in the contingency plan. A globalized world needs responses that cover global trade.

short_title: Rules for operators in the EU and obligations of Member States as regards organic products originated in third countries
Feedback:
BioNederland is the association for organic producers and importers in the Netherlands. Together the members of the association account for 80% of the turnover in Dutch trade and processing of organic products. 

BioNederland has – tried – to assess the impact of the proposals in this procedure. Our general comment is that, although we appreciate the Commissions and Memberstates effort to enable a workable solution for the organic imports, the timing and diversity of the many different secondary acts makes it a very complex topic. Our suggestion would be to assess the impact of the combined changes that are now proposed before finalising the legislative procedure.  For this public hearing we would like to make the following comments. 

Doc: Ares(2021)3872826 - 14/06/2021
COMMISSION IMPLEMENTING REGULATION (EU) …/...of XXX laying down rules on documents and notifications required for organic and in conversion products intended for import into the Union
•	Article 2 (2)  and Article 2(3)  “after the release” for free circulation 
Comment: A first consignee and consignee could also receive the products before the release on the market. The status of the product should not be mixed with the physical process. 
Suggestion: maintain the current regulation definition of Art 2(d) of 889/2008: ‘first consignee’ means the natural or legal person to whom the imported consignment is delivered and who will receive it for further preparation and/or marketing;
•	Art 2(4) “exempted from official controls at border control posts in accordance with Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2021/xxx4 (DA SANTE)”
Comment: a reference to another DA without number makes the impact of this article completely unclear. 
•	Art 4 
Comment: there are some new boxes added to the COI: 19, 20. 22. Are they all “must”? 
•	Art 7; “verification of compliance”
Comment: what is meant with the verification of compliance? Reference to another DA makes it unclear and it is extremely important for the impact of this article. 
•	Art 7: “suspected non-compliance”
Comment: this needs to be a substantiated suspicion and not a simple mistake or omission can be checked and easily corrected. 
•	Art 8: transition rules for paper certificate 
Comment: we hope that the paper certificate will soon be completely replaced by the TRACES system.

short_title: Rules for operators in the EU and obligations of Member States as regards organic products originated in third countries
Feedback:
Comentarios al documento Ares(2021)3872826  sobre ciertas reglas para la importación de productos orgánicos en la UE

La Agencia de Regulación y Control Fito y Zoosanitario – AGROCALIDAD, entidad encargada de la regulación y control de la sanidad del sector agropecuario y la inocuidad de los alimentos en la producción primaria en Ecuador, agradece la oportunidad de presentar sus comentarios al documento Ares(2021)3872826  que detalla ciertas reglas para la importación de productos orgánicos en la UE, en particular: reglas que deben seguir ciertos operadores de la UE para la importación en la UE de productos orgánicos, y obligaciones después de su despacho a libre práctica en la UE (para que luego puedan venderse como cualquier producto fabricado en la UE), así como  Obligaciones de los países de la UE de notificar los casos de incumplimiento detectados durante los controles oficiales de los envíos a la entrada en la UE de productos destinados al mercado de la UE.

Una vez revisada la información se solicita tomar en cuenta los siguientes comentarios: 
Ecuador es uno de los principales exportadores de productos orgánicos a la Unión Europea, por lo cual solicitamos que los procesos internos para su ingreso puedan continuar de manera rápida y segura en el futuro para evitar afectaciones que puedan ocasionar una desmotivación para los importadores debido a trámites excesivos o complicados. 

Entendemos que las reglas se enfocan en los procedimientos que se deben cumplir en destino, no obstante como país exportador es necesario asegurar que los productos no sufran ningún retraso para su ingreso debido a que podría tener un impacto en su vida en percha. Por ejemplo, si dos departamentos (autoridades y aduanas) tienen que otorgar su autorización esto podría provocará un retraso.

Por otro lado, en caso de que  las importaciones orgánicas deban ser notificadas con anticipación con su fecha exacta de llegada, es probable que existan cambios, lo cual implicaría que se deberán realizar correcciones que retrasarían sus procesos e incluso incrementar los costos que también podría afectar tanto a importadores como a exportadores.   

Finalmente, pedimos que se habiliten los procedimientos y procesos probados para que las importaciones orgánicas puedan continuar funcionando sin problemas en el futuro y de esta manera evitar que las importaciones orgánicas sean mucho más difíciles y, por lo tanto, más caras, lo cual puede disminuir el interés afectando a terceros países que dependen del comercio actual con la Unión Europea.

short_title: Rules for operators in the EU and obligations of Member States as regards organic products originated in third countries
Feedback:
In the frame of the Feedback mechanism on IADAs on Trade Rules, the European Organic Certifiers Council (EOCC), gathering 65 Control Bodies (CBs), Control Authorities and national association of Control Bodies, welcomes these acts and would like to share : 
- the comments directly implemented in the enclosed documents, through track changes. Sorry for the inconvenience as the attachments were not to be downloaded on this Website of the Commission, though the format is pdf. Attachments have been sent directly to the Organic Team. 
- as well as the following additional remarks: 
               -            Imports out of the scope of the COI
The current regulation defines in detail the procedure for business-to-business transactions. However, our society is moving towards a more digitalized system. What about companies based in third countries that may be selling through e-commerce directly to final consumer? There are more and more companies located in Third Countries, with products stored in Third Countries, that send packages of organic products to the individual final consumers. These products are not submitted to the import requirements nor to custom duty. EOCC is well aware that this situation is not unique to the organic sector, goes far beyond the organic sector and implies the commitment, at COM level, of other DG than DG AGRI. However, we think that this issue should be discussed and addressed with the sector in the coming months. 
               -             Art. 4.1 of DA
                              A COI shall be issued before the consignment leaves the third country of export or of origin. 
                                            According to Art. 5.3, there is a flexibility of 10 days to change the information related to Box 13, 16, 17. 
                              There are some events where it happens that other pieces information, not related to Box 13, 16, 17, must be changed. This is, for example, in the case of 
                                                           - need to enter a financial intermediary that was not identified before the leaving of consignment: Box 6
                                                           - change of BCP (Box 10): A shipment arrives to another Point of Entry as initially planned.
In these cases, there is no other option than to replace the COI. In case a CB replaces the COI in order to amend other information (than Box 13, 16 or 17), this will mention a date after the leaving of the consignment. Hence, as per regulation, it would not be in compliance.  
                            EOCC would welcome an official procedure for such events when some pieces of information need to be replaced in the COI. 

EOCC hopes that these remarks could be taken into account during the feedback mechanism and stays available for any further exchanges on these points.

short_title: Rules for operators in the EU and obligations of Member States as regards organic products originated in third countries
Feedback:
Deutschland ist ein Hauptimportland für Bio-Importe innerhalb der EU und ist in besonderem Maß davon abhängig, dass Bio-Importe auch künftig zügig und sicher erfolgen können. Dafür ist es notwendig, dass die eingespielten Verfahren und Abläufe auch in Zukunft funktionieren. Allerdings stellen wir fest, dass es, obwohl die Beratungen abgeschlossen wurden, noch viele Stolpersteine gibt, die eine reibungslose Abwicklung von Bio-Importen gefährden. Aufgrund der hohen Importquote innerhalb der EU darf kein Verfahren eingeführt werden, das Bio-Einfuhren unnötig verzögert oder erschwert.
Folgende Punkte sehen wir als dringend änderungs- und klärungsbedürftig an:
1. Der Großteil der Bio-Importe soll über Orte der Freigabe zum zollrechtlichen Verkehr erfolgen, phytosanitär oder veterinärrechtlich kritische Waren (sogenannte SPS-Waren) sollen über Grenzkontrollstellen eingeführt werden. Hochrisikowaren im Sinne der Öko-Verordnung unterliegen verstärkten Bio-Kontrollen und müssen beprobt werden. Damit Bio-Importe weiter reibungslos funktionieren, muss eindeutig geklärt sein, welche Waren über welche Stellen eingeführt werden müssen. Und: Die Orte der Einfuhr müssen so benannt werden, dass angepasst an die hohe Einfuhrquote in Deutschland genügend Stellen vorhanden sind.
2. Bisher erfolgten Öko-Kontrolle und Verzollung in Deutschland durch die Zollbehörden. Es ist fraglich, ob dieses Verfahren weiter fortgeführt werden kann. So ist nicht geklärt, ob die „zuständigen Behörden“ für die Öko-Kontrolle weiter die Zollbehörden sind oder ob zusätzlich Länderbehörden (die Öko-Kontrollbehörden oder welche?) den Teil der Bio-Kontrolle übernehmen müssen. Diskutiert wird sogar, ob Öko-Kontrollstellen dafür zuständig sein könnten. Wenn künftig zwei Dienststellen (Behörde und Zoll) eine Sendung abfertigen müssen, dann wird das naturgemäß zu einem verzögerten Ablauf führen. Durch die Kombination von Dokumentenprüfung und Zollabfertigung war bisher jederzeit eine zügige Abwicklung möglich. Und: Diese zusätzlichen Strukturen in einem Hauptimportland wie Deutschland an allen Orten der Einfuhr neu aufzubauen, ist eine große Herausforderung, die innerhalb von wenigen Monaten nicht zu bewältigen sein wird. 
3. Die Öko-Kontrolle muss stattfinden, bevor die Verzollung erfolgen darf. Wenn die Öko-Kontrolle nicht durch die Zollbehörden erfolgt, dann ist die Frage, welche Behörden die zügige Abwicklung der Öko-Kontrollen rund um die Uhr gewährleisten können. Was ist bei Einfuhren bei Nacht, am Wochenende und bei Luftfracht? Lagerplatz beim Zoll ist immer knapp und teuer. Frischeprodukte können häufig nicht gelagert werden, bis am nächsten Werktag eine Öko-Kontrolle stattfinden kann, weil sie dann verderben. Zusätzlich ist der Umfang der Dokumentenkontrolle ausgeweitet worden (z.B. über den Transportplan). Gerade bei Luftfracht von Frischeprodukten wird es häufig der Fall sein, dass nicht alle Dokumente für die Nämlichkeitsprüfung vorliegen. Wie schnell kann dann künftig die Ware geprüft, freigegeben und weiter transportiert werden?
4. Wenn die Bio-Kontrolle vor der Verzollung stattfinden muss, dann muss dort auch die Probenahmen nach Quote oder nach Leitlinien für Hochrisikoprodukte vor der Verzollung stattfinden. Probenahmen müssen geplant und durch Sachverständige durchgeführt werden. Deshalb benötigt die Probenahme üblicherweise mehrere Arbeitstage Vorlauf. Umgekehrt kann die Probenahme nicht beim Zoll Stunden oder Tage warten, weil sich die Sendung verzögert hat.
5. Bio-Importe müssen künftig mit ihrem genauen Ankunftstermin vorangemeldet werden. Dies wird, besonders bei Bio-Importen per Schiff, nicht funktionieren und viele Korrekturen notwendig machen, weil Verzögerungen während der Einfuhr häufig vorkommen und kaum planbar sind.
In der Summe wird das geplante Verfahren Bio-Einfuhren stark erschweren und damit verteuern. Wir bitten darum die bewährten Verfahren und Abläufe wieder zu ermöglichen, damit Bio-Importe auch in Zukunft reibungslos möglich sind.

Feedback:
Es muy loable el intento de regular de forma clara todo lo relativo a las exigencias de los productos ecológicos importados de terceros países, de tal manera que a éstos les sean exigidas las mismas normas de producción que los que tienen un origen comunitario.

Ésa precisamente ha de ser la base sobre la que gire cuanta modificación normativa se persiga en este campo: la de asegurar la igualdad de condiciones en la producción y en el acceso al mercado. A nivel comunitario tenemos unas altas exigencias de calidad y requisitos de producción y consideramos que las mismas deben ser extrapolables y por tanto exigibles a productos similares producidos en terceros y que entran a competir directamente por el mercado en la Unión Europea.

No podemos por tanto bajar la guardia y el nivel de exigencia de unos productos además que por su propia naturaleza es lógico que exijan un plus de cumplimiento de normas.

short_title: Fruit and vegetable production - more flexibility in the calculation of the value of damage caused by natural disaster
Feedback:
Extreme weather conditions have had a strong impact on fruit and vegetable production in some regions of the EU. The 2021 stone fruit and pear harvests represent the smallest harvests on record in Europe in the last 30 years. Therefore, Copa and Cogeca would like to thank the Commission for the proposal for a delegated act that provides for additional flexibility in the calculation of the value of marketed production of producer organisations in the event of a reduction in the value of marketed production due to natural disasters, adverse climatic events and disease or pest infestations. 
However, the Commission’s measure is largely insufficient and inadequate. The seriousness of the recent adversities faced by the fruit and vegetable sector requires more than the 2021 confirmation of the derogation allowed the previous year. Measures such as raising the EU co-financing rate of operational programmes to 70% are required.
However, Copa and Cogeca have identified a problem when it comes to the competent national authorities having to define requirements for both options (85%, 100%), notably: 
- proving that “those reasons were falling outside its responsibility and control” and 
- "that it has taken the necessary preventive measures against the natural disaster, climatic event, plant disease or pest infestation concerned".
What will the requirements for the "competent national authorities" be when auditing compliance according to the conditions listed above?
In short, we call for differentiation between the two percentages (85% and 100%) to be avoided and therefore for the higher percentage of 100% to be adopted. This would avoid having to demonstrate that the PO has adopted the preventive measures against disasters, plant diseases and pest infestations
In addition, Copa and Cogeca would welcome an extension of all derogations introduced in 2020 concerning operational funds and operational programmes for the year 2021 as the producer organisations have learned how these derogations can be implemented.
The greater flexibility indicated in the proposal, however, may prove to be ineffective. Indeed, in many cases, natural disasters, climatic adversities, plant diseases and pest infestations have taken their toll for consecutive years. For example, in northern Italy this is a recurring situation as many fruit crops were affected by frost and the Asian stink bug both in 2021 and in 2020. Pushing back the reference period for the calculation of the damaged product by one year does not solve the problem. To mitigate the effect of this, POs should at least be allowed to opt to take (as a basis for calculation) the two-year period preceding the reference year.

short_title: Evaluation of mandatory country of origin labelling for certain meats
Feedback:
BEUC, the European Consumer Organisation, welcomes the opportunity to provide feedback on the EC roadmap for the evaluation of origin labelling rules for fresh meat from pig, poultry, sheep and goat.

BEUC has long supported, and continues supporting, aligning rules on the origin labelling of all types of fresh meat on those already in place for beef (i.e. labelling of the countries of birth, rearing and slaughter). This was found to “offer the origin information most valued by consumers at a limited additional cost to the meat supply chain and with modest impact on intra-EU and third country trade” by the LEI Institute study that was supposed to inform the impact assessment of the implementing measure on origin labelling for unprocessed meat from pig, poultry, sheep and goat.

Against this background, we find it essential that the forthcoming evaluation assesses whether the current rules effectively meet consumer expectations in terms of origin information, or whether they might in fact have the potential to mislead them (e.g. due to the absence of information on the country of birth, or due to the way the rearing periods are determined/calculated for various species).

Another major loophole with the current rules lies with the fact they do not cover meat served in the food service and catering sector. Yet a survey (http://www.sverigeskonsumenter.se/nyheter-press/senaste-nytt/granskning-rodlistat-kott-doljs-av-lunchrestauranger/) published by BEUC’s Swedish member, Sveriges Konsumenter, in September found that eight out of ten Swedes want to know where meat served in restaurants comes from – whilst this information is hardly ever provided. Similar results were found in a Finnish survey (http://www.europarl.europa.eu/cmsdata/148302/Hielm_040618%20COOL%20Finland.pdf), prompting the Finnish government to introduce a measure mandating origin information also in the out-of-home sector. To fully assess the impact of the current rules and whether their objectives were fully met, the evaluation should therefore consider the information gap that persists in the food service and catering sector.

Finally, BEUC wishes to reiterate its strong support for EU-wide mandatory origin labelling (at country level) of meat, also when it is used as an ingredient in processed foods. We hope that the upcoming Member States' reports on the various national trials of such measure will be the opportunity for resuming an EU-level debate on this important issue for European consumers.

short_title: Evaluation of mandatory country of origin labelling for certain meats
Feedback:

In relation to that, EU poultry meat producers believe that consumers should have better access to information about the origin of meat consumed in food services/mass catering as well as processed meat and meat used as an ingredient, especially when meat is imported from third countries. 

EU producers have to comply with very stringent EU rules, whereas imports from third countries may not be fully compliant with these same standards all along the food chain.

Therefore, although EU producers recognise the complexity of such labelling, AVEC is advocating the mandatory labelling of all products containing poultry meat with the mention “EU” or “non EU”, along with the name of the country where the meat comes from outside the EU.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
The mid-term evaluation of the previous Forestry Strategy and the recently published State of the Environment Report 2020 show that EU’s forested area increased between over the last two decades due to active afforestation and natural processes. Unfortunately, this does not necessarily mean healthier and more biodiverse forests. Only 15% of forests in the Natura 2000 network are in a favourable status.
A stronger commitment is required and the upcoming Forest Strategy should function as a unitary framework informing all forest related policies.
The following recommendations are based on over five years of researching forest governance, forest livelihoods, illegal logging and timber trade within the EU. 
 
Wellbeing of rural areas
I strongly support the provision mentioning that ‘forests should preserve lively rural areas and help maintain wealthy rural populations; and preserve landscapes, culture and heritage’. The upcoming EUFS should align environmental and social objectives, therefore a strong bottom-up approach should be at its core.   
Local communities, landowners of any size and customary users should be incentivised to participate in the design, implementation and evaluation stages of EUFS. Cooperation with stakeholders should be tailored to cultural specificities, as poor consultation can lead to tensions, contestations and missed targets. 
The Commission should take a rights-based approach to forest protection and management, promoting social justice and gender equality. 

ICCAs are effective forest protection institutions
Policy support for community conservation initiatives, including voluntary commitments, have proven to be a more effective protection mechanism than top-down imposed conservation projects. 
The Commission should recognise and actively support indigenous and community conserved areas (ICCAs) as effective forest conservation and restoration approaches in Europe. The upcoming EUFS must respect the forest governance rights of such communities. The role, rights, needs and aspirations of women and young members of ICCAs should be given particular attention. Wherever strict protection of forests is considered, free prior and informed consent (FPIC) should be obtained before proposing the respective measures.  

Long-term commitment 
The EUFS should strengthen the motivation of forest owners of all sizes and managers to continue taking care of their forests. The Roadmap document lists a set of very ambitious expectations related to climate change, biodiversity, bioeconomy and rural wellbeing, therefore proportional financial incentives should be dedicated to motivate owners and managers to commit to these goals. Proper compensation mechanisms should be in place, readily available and clearly communicated in order to avoid fundamental rights violations as a result of use and access restrictions. In addition to forest owners and managers, the customary users of forest resources and direct beneficiaries should be taken into consideration. 
In many MS these groups already face challenges that they cannot control, due to climate change, wildfires, pests and diseases and the Commission should increase allocation of funds to help countering present and future disasters.  

Illegal logging should be clearly addressed
The Roadmap does not specify if the future EUFS will be coherent with the European Union Timber Regulation (EUTR) and the FLEGT framework. In order to achieve its ambitious goals, the EUFS should directly address illegal logging and timber trade within the EU and from third countries, EUTR and FLEGT being essential tools for this purpose. 
A broad range of research suggests that a strengthened forest protection within the EU will indirectly impact forest management in third countries, as demand for timber will likely remain high. An increase in timber and forest products imports from outside the EU could foster unsustainable harvesting and management practice.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
We ask to consider the following suggestions:
Planting new trees should also take place in non-forest areas, especially along roads, in fields, between forest complexes, in rural areas, which will act as ecological corridors, will maintain connectivity between isolated forests. Planted trees in open areas will be source of seeds needed to natural succession.
Apart of old growth and primeval forests (not much left in the Europe), should be protected mature and almost mature natural and semi-natural forests that appeared by natural succession and swampy, wet forests preserving water resources.
Stable forests, prepared for challenges related to the climate, appearance of pathogens and invasive species  should have broad gene pool among tree populations. Foresters should use natural succession instead of plantations created from a limited number of parent trees are very susceptible to pathogens.  Size of the clear cuts should be limited.  Clear cuts should be replaced by small size logging, selective extraction.
To reduce CO2 emissions and increase carbon sequestration, foresters should desist plowing, or should reduce plowing to the necessary minimum.
To ensure protection of forest-related biodiversity EU members should approve conservation plans in Natura 2000 forest areas. Protection plans should have properly identified threats to protected species, habitats and adequate conservation measures.  In Poland many Natura 2000 sites, especially those covering old forests still do not have approved any documents related to Natura 2000 protection. Volume of dead wood should be increased, especially in countries where volume is very low e.g. Poland.
Private forests and forests belonging to non-governmental organizations should be allowed to be protected because protection of private forest is not possible in Poland. Owners are obliged to follow forest management plans approved by authorities.
Wood from forests must not be treated as a renewable energy source and used on a massive scale as an energy source. In some countries it is the main motivation for logging of valuable forests.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
Carbon counting, offsets and nature-based solutions: We fear that some in the EU may be hoping to offset a lot of GHG emissions using forests and new plantations plus mass planting of unspecified trees as carbon sinks and we note the promise of carbon-mapping from Microsoft.   

We are therefore concerned about the possibility that ‘nature-based solutions’ (a term so vague that it can mean almost anything) and biodiversity in general may be used as offsets to allow high emissions to continue; or facilitate destructive projects by promising to ‘green’ some aspect of them. The EU forest strategy must not be complicit in that. In this context carbon farming and payments for environmental services are not a good strategy; instead it is vital to support the true restoration and regeneration of forests with native species right across the EU.

Logging must be reduced across the EU: It is therefore vital to reduce logging for whatever purpose, especially for bioenergy from timber, which is not an acceptable alternative for energy generation. All forms of support for wood-based bioenergy in the EU should be phased out.

Contradictions between CAP and the new Forest Strategy must be addressed: It is worrying to see that some aspects of the new Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) seems to be in contradiction with plans for forest regeneration and may need reform; policy across the EU needs to be consistent although we are aware that sometimes inconsistency may be used to undermine policy objectives and we hope this is not the case here.

Address perverse incentives:  It is also vital to identify and phase out perverse incentives (Aichi Target 3, Biodiversity Convention) with a deleterious impact on forests. The money saved from such incentives should be re-invested in true forest restoration and protection

True forest restoration and regeneration: end monoculture plantations: We note the emphasis on afforestation and reforestation rather than restoration and natural regeneration in the strategy, and we call for an end to monoculture plantations, particularly of non-native trees. Degraded former forest areas need to be sensitively replanted with native trees in such a way as to allow for the regeneration of natural forests and the development of the proper structural complexity of natural forests. These will play a vital role in addressing climate change as well as restoring biodiversity in the EU.


Community forest conservation vital: It is therefore essential to prohibit commercial logging or any other industrial activities in all areas under Effective Area-based Conservation Measures, including protected areas but also Indigenous Peoples and Community Conserved Territories and Areas (ICCAs) in the EU and Natura2000 sites, as well as all remaining old-growth or primary forests. 

Importance of ICCAs: Although forests have clearly flourished for millennia without being ‘managed’, a term which can mean very different things to different interests and which needs to be defined, we also feel that EU ICCAs can play an increasingly important role in the community conservation of forests of their role is properly recognised and respected.

Violations of logging bans: It is also important that violations of the policy by member states be rapidly dealt with; damage done is hard to rectify and delay may encourage a sense of impunity. We are particularly concerned about what is happening in Poland and Romania, where the EU as a whole needs to help to address the illegal logging that occurs as well as punish infringements – a collective effort is needed to address this major issue of collective concern. 

True forests are vital to address climate change and biodiversity loss: Protecting and properly restoring forests across the EU with native species is a crucial step to keeping temperature rises as close to 1.5 degrees as possible and reduce the disruption caused by climate change across the EU to the minimum possible.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
Forested river basins throughout EU countries suffered heavy damage within the last centuries. Still the role of the mountain, wetland and floodplain forests for water retention and redistribution is not recognised sufficiently. The role of forest catchments for hydrological cycles and biodiversity is very important. One of the basic tool of forest restoration is increasing the amount of the dead wood in the forests. Unfortunately the rush for energetic and material use of wood decreases amount of the dead wood in the forests and also depletes soil carbon stocks. 
There are nutrient rich stable forest soils, but also fragile soils and wetlands. It is necessary to adjust forest management practices with the respect to ecosystem services. Forests along forest streams and wetlands are such example and it is necessary to create management guidelines of sensitive forestry practices and restoration and revitalisation methods. In such forests maximum of dead wood should stay on the spot and be protected from the impact of heavy machinery and transport of wood. Also forest soil carbon should be maintained carefuly and not be depleted. It is not possible to claim sustainable role of wood in heat power generation and deplete soil carbon sinks in the same time.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
Revoir la stratégie forestière comme esquissée dans le document de Roadmap est nécessaire pour renforcer l'adéquation aux objectifs du Green Deal. Cette stratégie devrait se concentrer sur quelques objectifs-phares comme:
1°) augmenter la capacité des forêts à capturer le carbone en vue de l'objectif de neutralité climatique à 2050: stimuler l'augmentation de la surface forestière, non seulement par la plantation de 3 milliards d'arbres (aussi en zone urbaine) mais aussi par des aides à l'afforestation (via la PAC et la politique régionale) pour ne laisser aucune terre inoccupée. En plus il faut généraliser et parfaire les techniques de gestion durable des forêts qui maximisent le stockage de Carbone tout en protégeant la biodiversité. 
2°) prendre des mesures d'urgence et d'exception par une loi européenne pour la conservation absolue de la forêt primaire ou très ancienne, notamment la forêt primaire de Bialowieza (PL). Egalement à prévoir dans cette loi, un régime de création et sauvegarde d'espace forestiers et non-forestiers continus exempt d'activité humaine afin de conserver et protéger la vie sauvage (y compris des corridors).
3°) rapprocher la stratégie forestière de la stratégie pour la bioéconomie afin que toute exploitation de la biomasse forestière soit en ligne avec les objectifs du développement durable, notamment l'ODD 15.  Au sein de la PAC, des actions de développement massif de l'agro-foresterie devraient figurer dans chaque plan stratégique national. 
4°) la recherche européenne (Horizon Europe) devrait ouvrir des calls pour améliorer les techniques de gestion durable des forêts et les diffuser en intégrants tous les acteurs sur le modèle du PEI-AGRI. Un autre sujet prioritaire serait la compréhension des novelles maladies qui affectent les arbres et les moyens de soigner l'éco-système forestier dans le respect des principes de l'écologie. 
5°) la dimension internationale doit être abordée plus nettement. D'une part l'UE doit se mettre en avant et porter un modèle de gestions durables adaptées aux différentes forêts (tropicale, etc), d'autre part elle doit jouer de sa politique commerciale pour introduire une taxe carbone dissuasive à l'importation de bois et imposer une traçabilité complète de l'arbre sur pied à la grume pour empêcher les coupes illégales (illegal logging) qui serait une condition à tout accord bilatéral ou multilatéral. Enfin l'UE doit se montrer exemplaire et se défaire progressivement de tout commerce qui implique une déforestation dans les pays tiers. Ainsi il faut viser à une plus grande indépendance protéique de l'UE et le soja résiduel qui devra être importé pour l'alimentation animale devrait être soumis à un certificat pour garantir que les terres où il a été cultivé ne sont pas issues d'une déforestation sur une période passée à déterminer

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
EU Forest Strategy
Feedback: I would like to call on the Commission and Member States to reflect that there is a growing demand from citizens, to protect primary and old-growth forests and address the problem of having a large fraction of primary forest currently outside strictly protected areas. Forest strategy is a forest strategy, not "forestry strategy". It should encompass the application of non-intervention principle. I would like you to consider conducting full, certified lifecycle carbon accounting for EU forests and the production of forest products and bioenergy. Specify the appropriate scale of forest carbon accumulation and storage in meeting overall climate goals. Please, avoid further emissions from forests, storing additional carbon in them is essential. Prevent and halt, together with Member States, the negative developments which occur in Estonia and Latvia which are turning into emitters due to market demand for their cheaper wood/pellets. Identify strategies and create policies and legislation that are based upon available scientific knowledge. The only means for removing atmospheric carbon dioxide at scale to achieve the stated EU climate goals in the coming decades is to protect the carbon stocks in remaining primary and older forests, and allow these and secondary forests to grow and restore their ecological potential for carbon storage and biological diversity. Work with proforestation method. If this is not done, irreversible and uncontrollable alteration of the climate will occur, and these systems will become less resilient in protecting the climate and biodiversity. Redirect subsidies for carbon intensive bioenergy to effective low carbon technologies like wind and solar and enhanced energy performance through efficiency measures. Your Strategy should result in healthy, resilient, living, diverse forests, which are not monocultures.

short_title: EU Forest Strategy
Feedback:
NOAH-Friends of the Earth Denmark is a member of Global Forest Coalition and we support their submission (also attached here). 
Coming from Denmark it is relevant to pinpoint bioenergy use as a certain threat to the forests, where Denmark plays a particularly destructive role.

In the EU, more than 60% of the renewable energy has come from biomass (mainly forest wood for electricity and heating, but also including biogas, biofuels and renewable waste). Looking at the renewable energy trajectory since 1990, the share of bioenergy has been more or less constant. In Denmark, the share is even larger than the EU average although we do not have much forest. Therefore, our country imports huge quantities of wood pellets from other European countries.

The use of bioenergy is undermining the urgent need to halt deforestation and restore the soil and plant systems as soon as possible. The removal of biomass for energy from the forests is ongoing and it will take decades, or even centuries, for the lost carbon to be re-captured by regrowth – if ever. If this practice continues, the EU is derailing its own commitments to stop runaway climate change and loss of biodiversity.

According to the European Commission’s own calculations and estimations, carbon stocks of European forests have fallen since 2010 and are expected to fall further due to, among other things, increased demand for biomass for energy. Forest management in several forest rich countries are even expected to become a source of emissions. 

Healthy forests, wetlands, grasslands, coastal vegetation and farmland soils are essential carbon storage ecosystems needed to mitigate against runaway climate change. We only have a chance to reach the necessary climate goals if we, as a world community, understand and learn to restore these carbon stocks. 

Therefore, to ensure the recovery of the European (and global) forests), it is of utmost importance that all incentives to use biomass for energy is removed.

Feedback:

short_title: Agriculture - List of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback:
L'Union Européenne (UE) a lancé une consultation publique sur un projet de règlement d’application qui menace les importations d'ananas biologiques vers l'UE et aurait un impact important sur les agriculteurs qui ont déjà investi dans l'agriculture biologique. Nous pensons que si l’UE donne suite à sa décision, elle affectera gravement les producteurs et les acheteurs mentionnés.
Conformément aux dispositions de ce projet de règlement d’application et de ses annexes, l’Union Européenne va vers l’interdiction de l’utilisation de l’éthylène dans la production de l’ananas biologique. 
De nos jours, la production commerciale de l'ananas ne peut se faire sans induction florale ; et accepter ces règles, signifie qu’aucune substance ne peut être utilisée pour l'induction florale de l'ananas biologique, ce qui signifie que la production pour le marché de l'UE ne sera plus commercialement viable. Cela aura un impact sérieux sur les moyens de subsistance de nombreux petits opérateurs dans les pays en Développement et en particulier ceux du Bénin qui ont consacré des ressources limitées à l'établissement et à la certification de la production biologique. Cela découragera également de nouveaux investissements dans les systèmes biologiques, une situation qui n'est pas compatible avec la stratégie de la ferme à l'assiette, et la volonté de promouvoir et de soutenir l'agriculture biologique et les systèmes agro-alimentaires durables dans le monde entier.



L’UE est bien consciente de ce que l'éthylène est utilisé pour l'induction de la floraison des ananas et sans éthylène, la production d'ananas n'est pas possible. Mais la seule difficulté réside dans « sous quelle forme il faut utiliser l’éthylène gazeuse » ? A cet effet, COLEACP a réalisé sous financement du Fonds Européen de Développement, une étude dénommée « Efficacité de la technique d’induction florale d’Ananas comosus (L.) Merr au moyen de charbon actif enrichi à l’éthylène (TIFBio) » dans trois pays producteurs d’ananas en Afrique à savoir le Togo, le Ghana et le Cameroun.
Cette étude a démontré que l’éthylène peut être utilisé au moyen de charbon actif enrichi à l’éthylène. Ce charbon actif enrichi à l’éthylène est utilisé pour faire l’induction florale de l’ananas avec de meilleurs résultats présentés dans l’encadré ci-dessous.




Les essais réalisés avec du charbon actif enrichi à l’éthylène montrent que le traitement permet d’obtenir des floraisons de plus de 80 % à 10 semaines, que ce soit pour les modalités d’application par voie sèche ou par voie humide. Les différentes modalités d’application par voie humide ont montré un effet de la dose et de la répétition du traitement. Le taux de floraison culmine à 100 % dès 8 semaines pour les meilleurs résultats obtenus lors du traitement par voie humide à 250 mg par plant répété à 2 jours d’intervalle. Les traitements par voie sèche ont tous produit des taux de floraison compris entre 85 et 90 % à 10 semaines pour les différents essais, suggérant un facteur environnemental li





De plus aucun produit n'est autorisé en l'Etat actuel du règlement de l'UE pour faire cette opération dans les parcelles d'ananas. En effet la seule utilisation indiquée pour l'éthylène c'est son application en atmosphère confinée (serre, bâtiment de murissement etc.) Ce qui n'est pas le cas pour l'induction florale de l'ananas qui se fait en plein champ. 
Si le règlement est adopté en l'Etat, aucune production d'ananas biologique du Bénin frais comme transformé ne peut encore être exporté.  



Le Bénin expérimente depuis décembre 2019, auprès des producteurs d'ananas biologique le charbon actif enrichi à l’éthylène avec de meilleurs résultats. Il ne saurait accepter l’adoption de ce projet de règlement dont la consultation publique est lancée par l’UE.

short_title: Agriculture - List of products and substances authorised in organic production
Feedback: Plant protection products based on natural substances are a small but essential element of the organic approach to plant health, mainly for fruit crops. The limited amount of substances available is a bottleneck that can impair the organic production and limit the willingness of farmers to convert, even in a likely scenario of available subsidies and policies fostering organic farming. Having this in mind, it is important to support the availability of substances currently listed, such as quassia, which is a plant extract traditionally used in organic fruit growing and essential for the control of the key pests of fruit crops such as sawfly and aphids. The possibility to continue producing organic pomefruits (apples and pears) as well as some stonefruits (i.e. plums) and hop for organic beer production relies strongly on such kind of substances, and quassia in particular.
