short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
We think that if we restrict the use of seed mixtures to fodder would have a negative impact on organic production, and slow down the adoption of techniques that have a real impact on biodiversity and soil health, such as the use of green manure and flowering strips.Therefore, the relevance of seed mixtures for other use than fodder seed mixtures cannot be stressed enough. 
 
Second, the harmonized level of minimum 70% organic and in-conversion seed across Member States allowed in seed mixtures (Point 2.1.3. of Annex II) needs to be clarified. In Sweden, we have currently a minimum level for each species/group of varieties already varies in most cases between 70 and 100%. If the harmonized level means that mixtures can be sold in Sweden with a minimum of 70% this would decrease the current standard and will not contribute to the development of organic seed production. A minimum threshold should be set in Europe, but national authorities should set minimum level in their country according to the national seed availability of individual species/group of varieties. 

Third, efforts should be made to avoid administrative burden to farmers when related to the use of seed mixtures. As suggested by IFOAM EU, once the (national) threshold met, it should be possible for the producer of the mixture or a national seller (of a seed mixture produced in another Member State) to apply for an authorization (for the non-organic components of the mixture) at the national authority directly.

Last, we are in favour of IFOAM EUs suggestion regarding the listing of organic, in-conversion and non-organic components on the label. Such listing should be possible independently of the total percentage of organic and in-conversion seeds, as suggested in Point 2.1.3. of Annex II. This is important because certain seed mixtures that are used in organic farming do not reach the 70% threshold due to (currently) limited availability of organic seed for specific crops, for example in the case of seeds for flower strips. For these mixtures as well, a listing of the organic and in-conversion species on the label facilitates the process to request an authorization for non-organic components for farmers and competent authorities. In addition, this listing stimulates producers of seed mixtures to include organic & in-conversion components in the mixtures as much as possible.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
KRAV develops organic standards and promotes the KRAV-label in Sweden. About 4000 Swedish farms are certified according to KRAV standards, and the KRAV-label is well-known among Swedish consumers. KRAV wants to bring up the following feedbacks and stress the importance of the suggested changes from the perspective of producers in Sweden and in the Nordic countries in general. 

1. The relevance of seed mixtures for other use than fodder seed mixtures cannot be stressed enough. It is necessary to open the possibility of using seed mixtures to other mixtures such as green manure and flowering strips. The scope of the Delegated Act should therefore make explicit reference to non-fodder plant mixtures, in line with Article 13 of Directive 66/401/EEC. To restrict the use of seed mixtures to fodder would have a negative impact on organic production, and slow down the adoption of techniques that have a real impact on biodiversity and soil health, such as the use of green manure and flowering strips.

2. The harmonized level of minimum 70% organic and in-conversion seed across Member States allowed in seed mixtures (Point 2.1.3. of Annex II) needs to be clarified. In Sweden, we have currently a minimum level of organic seed in fodder seed mixtures set per species or group of varieties. The minimum level for each crops already varies between 70 and 100%, with exceptions for three crops that have levels between 40 and 60%. If the harmonized level means that any mixtures can be sold in Sweden with a minimum of 70% this would decrease the current standard and will not contribute to the development of organic seed production. We therefore welcome a minimum threshold throughout Europe for mixtures, but beyond this minimum threshold, national authorities should set minimum level according to the national seed availability of individual crops. If organic/in conversion seeds of a specific crop are available in sufficient quantities, it is should be clear that non-organic seeds of this given crop cannot be part of the mixture. The minimum threshold at the European level should gradually increase to promote the development of organic seed production in Europe.

3. Efforts should be made to avoid administrative burden to farmers when related to the use of seed mixtures. As suggested by IFOAM EU, once the (national) threshold(s) met, it should be possible for the producer of the mixture or a national seller (of a seed mixture produced in another Member State) to apply for an authorization (for the non-organic components of the mixture) at the national authority directly.

4. We are in favour of IFOAM EUs suggestion regarding the listing of organic, in-conversion and non-organic components on the label. Such listing should be possible independently of the total percentage of organic and in-conversion seeds, as suggested in Point 2.1.3. of Annex II. This is important because certain seed mixtures that are used in organic farming do not reach the 70% threshold due to (currently) limited availability of organic seed for specific crops, for example in the case of seeds for flower strips. For these mixtures as well, a listing of the organic and in-conversion species on the label facilitates the process to request an authorization for non-organic components for farmers and competent authorities. In addition, this listing stimulates producers of seed mixtures to include organic & in-conversion components in the mixtures as much as possible.


Thank you for the possibility of leaving feedback and for considering them. 
Kind regards,

Eve Roubinet
KRAV - MARKET AND REGULATION DEVELOPPER – PLANT PRODUCTION

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
BioNederland is the Dutch organisation for processing and trade of organic products. Regarding the labelling of feed, we very much welcome the proposal from the Commission in point 2.1.2 to reintroduce, for compound feed that cannot be labelled in accordance with Article 30(6), the indication that such feed may be used in organic production in accordance with this Regulation.

However the feed labelling issue is not completely solved with this proposal. The issue of labelling remains for diets that do not match the criteria of art 30(6) (b) and (c) but are completely in line with allowed diets for organic animals. This is the case for diets with a small % of conventional agricultural raw materials (diets for young poultry and pigs) and diets with >5% dry matter components of non-organic origin (such as diets containing high amounts of minerals like diets for laying hens). Still, these products are not allowed to be labelled with ‘organic’, and derivatives thereof, in their name. This created and will continue to create unclarity for agricultural operators and consumers (via retail), to whom they are supplied.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
Feedback to public hearing on seed mixtures:

Due to limitations in the organic seed production it may be necessary to allow a certain percentage of non-organic seed in seed mixtures. But, the proposal in Annex 2.1.3 requiring at least 70% organic or in-conversion seeds in mixtures based on weight might be counterproductive for the development and market share of certain seeds in organic quality. 

We see a potential risk that the more expensive and challenging seeds will no longer be part of the seed mixtures in an organic quality, if this proposal is not followed by strict guidelines to the competent authorities.

It should be clear that non-organic seeds of a specific crop cannot be part of the mixture, if other varieties of the same type of crop is available in an organic quality. If this is not the case, we fear that the existing market for smaller varieties in organic quality of e.g. white clover will no longer be part of the seed mixtures used in organic production across the EU.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
The proposed text in Annex 2.1.3 does not state that mixtures should contain the highest possible share of organic and in-conversion seed - it is based on the availability of organic and in-conversion seed and a minimum of 70 % organic and in-conversion seed. 
In a situation where companies apply to sell mixtures in other countries it should not be possible to approve a mixture of only 70 % organic and in-conversion seed if similar mixtures with a higher organic share is available in the respective country. 
In Denmark, many mixtures have a share above 70% organic and in-conversion seeds, and it would be uneven competition if mixtures with 70% organic and in-conversion seed could be approved, as these would be cheaper to produce than 100% organic mixtures. To promote the use of organic seed and avoid uneven competition, it should be added in the proposal that only mixtures with the highest possible organic share must be approved.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
A utilização de misturas pratenses/forrageiras (com variedades melhoradas) pode ser o complemento mais eficiente para os sistemas agro-silvo-pastoris e uma estratégia que permitirá a intensificação sustentável dos sistemas extensivos típicos de muitas das regiões do Mediterrâneo. A importância da utilização de misturas de sementes (melhoradas ou não) para revestimentos de entrelinhas e culturas permanentes e para cobertura/melhoramento de solos são soluções cada vez mais valorizadas. Sendo assim, é importante que no regulamento em análise sejam consideradas misturas pratenses, forrageiras e para revestimento/cobertura do solo.

Considerando que, em alguns países da EU, a curto/médio prazo, será extremamente difícil conseguir quantidade de semente produzida e certificada em modo de produção biológico suficiente para satisfazer o mercado será importante que seja aumentado a possibilidade de utilização de semente produzida em modo não biológico.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
- Seed mixtures are widely used today and are becoming ever more important to deliver a variety of benefits such as soil fertility, nitrogen fixation and functional biodiversity (through flower strips etc.), not only as fodder crops. 

- The explicit specification of fodder plants does not do justice to the growing and increasingly diversified use of seed mixtures, which includes mixtures for intermediate and subsidiary crops and flowering strips. Therefore, the scope of the Delegated Act should make explicit reference to non-fodder plant mixtures, in line with Article 13 of Directive 66/401/EEC.

- A minimum percentage of 70% by weight of organic and in-conversion seeds in seed mixtures has the potential to stimulate the production and use of organic and in-conversion seed across all Member States. However, it needs to be clear what a harmonized threshold of 70% (Point 2.1.3. of Annex II) means in practice. If the threshold is met, it should be possible for the producer of the mixture or a national seller (of a seed mixture produced in another Member State) to apply for an authorization (for the non-organic components of the mixture) at the national authority directly. If farmers must apply for authorizations for single components of seed mixtures individually, then this administrative burden would likely decrease the use as well as complexity and performance of the mixtures. 

- A listing of organic, in-conversion and non-organic components on the label should be possible independently of the total percentage of organic and in-conversion seeds, as suggested in Point 2.1.3. of Annex II. This is important because certain seed mixtures that are used in organic farming don’t reach the 70% threshold due to (currently) limited availability of organic seed for specific crops, for example in the case of seeds for flower strips. For these mixtures as well, a listing of the organic and in-conversion species on the label facilitates the process to request an authorization for non-organic components for farmers and competent authorities. In addition, this listing stimulates producers of seed mixtures to include organic & in-conversion components in the mixtures as much as possible.

- The reference in the draft delegated act to the required conformity with the authorisation issued under point 1.8.5 of Part I of Annex II to Regulation (EU) 2018/248 is essential to guarantee consistency with national authorization procedures.

short_title: Labelling of organic products and certain feed and mixtures of fodder seeds that may be used in organic production
Feedback:
FEFAC representing the European Compound feed and premixtures Industry in the EU welcomes the proposal for amendment of par. 2.1 of the Annex III of Regulation (EU) No 2018/848 to make it possible to specify on the labels of compound feed containing non-organic feed ingredients (such as in-conversion feed or mineral feed materials) that they may be used in organic production (par. 2.1.2 (e) of the annex of the proposal). This possibility was unintendedly removed from the organic farming rules when reshaping them in 2018 and it is appropriate to reinstate it.

Regarding the proposed measures themselves, FEFAC experts hold the view that the provisions in par. 2.1.2 should not only be applicable to compound feed but also to premixtures: like compound feed, premixtures may contain both organic and non-organic feed ingredients and it is essential that the information that the premixture may be used in organic production can be transmitted along the supply chain as appropriate.

We thank you for taking these comments into account.

short_title: Action plan for the development of EU organic production
Feedback:
Desde APAEMA, la asociación de productores ecológicos de Mallorca, valoramos positivamente la iniciativa de desarrollar un plan de acción para el desarrollo de la agricultura ecológica en Europa. 

No obstante, creemos que ante los retos a que se enfrenta la sociedad (crisis pandémica, emergencia climática, desigualdades sociales crecientes, pérdida de recursos naturales, inestabilidad geopolítica, etc.) es imprescindible apostar por la producción agraria ecológica de una forma ambiciosa, valiente, para que este tipo de agricultura no sea una más, sino el objetivo a conseguir en un periodo razonable para afrontar estas retos globales a tiempo.

El nuevo plan de acción debe tener en cuenta las particularidades de cada territorio, sus potencialidades y debilidades, para que las políticas de fomento de la producción ecológica y el consumo ecológico sean implementadas y desarrolladas a ritmos parecidos en todos ellos. Para eso, proponemos que cada estado miembro tenga que redactar su propio plan, así como cada región. Esto tendría que significar también que las administraciones estatales, regionales e incluso locale tengan que implicarse para llegar a los objetivos marcados.

Creemos que un plan de acción sensato tendría que ir asociado a unos presupuestos específicos, suficientes y coherentes, que permitan su implementación a todos los niveles. Estos deberían dar cabida a ayudas públicas para la promoción de la agricultura ecológica, entre productores y consumidores, ayudas a la reconversión de explotaciones agrarias e industrias hacía la producción eco, ayudas a compensar los costes de control y certificación de pequeños productores, y ayudas al mantenimiento de la producción ecológica que compensen la internalización de costes y los beneficios públicos ambientales y sociales generados. Son imprescindibles también las ayudas a la creación de sistema alimentarios territorializados, infraestructuras colectivas o cooperativas, iniciativas que permitan un cambio de escala en la producción, transformación, comercialización y consumo en determinados territorios europeos. Hay que tener en cuenta, además, la importancia de la innovación, la investigación asociada y el desarrollo de nuevos métodos y tecnologías en agricultura ecológica. Mención especial a la necesidad de ayudar a mantener la ganadería extensiva frente a la caída permanente de la demanda de carne de calidad, por su importancia en el ciclo de nutrientes y energía en las fincas y reducir el coste territorial de la agricultura eco.

Feedback:
The roadmap "Action Plan for the development of EU organic production" clarifies that an increase in the consumption of organic products is paramount to achieve the aim of increasing organic sector. Therefore i find it impossible to understand why the aim on ogranic farming in the F2F and BD strategy refers to the share of agricultural area under organc production. In Austria - which is often mentioned as role mode for this Action plan - 26% of the agricultural area is already used for organic production whereas the domestic consumption of organic food legs far behind with a share of less than 9%. short_title: Action plan for the development of EU organic production
Feedback:
The regulations for organic food hinder the development of plant-based foods
There is an accelerating increase in demand for plant-based foods. New, often complex, products are constantly entering the market. The need to enable EU organic certification of these foods is key. Today’s consumers often demand products that are both organic and plant-based. Unfortunately, it is at current however often difficult to use the EU organic label on compound plant-based products due to regulatory obstacles. 

A concrete example of regulatory obstacles is that organic plant-based drinks, e.g. oat drink or soya drink, are not allowed to be enriched with vitamins and minerals according to the organic regulatory framework, even if organic cow´s milk can be enriched (through the feed). From a nutritional point of view, it is important to facilitate enrichment. Consumers who choose to plant-based food and drinks should not need to choose between an organic or an enriched product. It is therefore necessary to develop EU regulations for organic foods and remove obstacles to enable the EU labelling of plant-based foods. Regarding the example above on plant-based drinks, there is a great need for creating an opening for increased use of enrichment agents in plant-based compound organic foods. 

Another obstacle is that there is a lack of access to suitable organic ingredients in the manufacturing process. The list of approved additives needs to be expanded so more plant-based products can gain an organic label. There are texture additives, e.g. methylcellulose, which are common in plant-based protein alternatives, but difficult to replace. 
Overall, without these changes in EU regulations for organic foods, it will be difficult to meet consumer demand for plant-based organic foods.

A shift to a more plant-based diet supports the EU’s climate targets
The AGRI Committee has voted to boost the EU climate ambitions and adopted a position calling on the EU to increase its emissions reduction target for 2030 from at least 40% to 55%. This increased climate ambition will require engagement and action on the ground by all economic sectors, citizens, authorities and civil society. In this context, the production and consumption of food is key. The Farm to Fork Strategy stresses that agriculture is responsible for 10.3% of the EU’s GHG emissions and nearly 70% of those come from the animal sector. In addition, 68% of the total agricultural land is used for animal production.

It is thus clear that the transition to a sustainable food system and reduced emissions will not happen without a shift to more plant-based foods in people’s diets. EU strategies and actions need to put more focus on sustainable food consumption than on organic farming. It is important to at least ensure that the strategy for organic farming does not stand in the way of the development of plant-based food. Organic farming is important for biodiversity. However, its impact on reducing emissions is limited and will not help the EU to reach its ambiguous 2030 climate targets and the overall objective to become climate-neutral by 2050.

short_title: Action plan for the development of EU organic production
Feedback:
Desde la SEAE-Sociedad Española de Agricultura Ecológica- pedimos un Plan de acción para el desarrollo de la producción ecológica de la UE atrevido y coherente con los objetivos de las estrategias de La Granja a la Mesa y de Biodiversidad, que implique a las administraciones de todos los niveles para asegurar coherencia de las políticas públicas con el Plan y que cuente con el sector ecológico también a todos los niveles para la definición y aplicación del mismo. 
Solicitamos que se definan objetivos cuantitativos específicos y se establezca un calendario para su ejecución, que se asigne presupuesto específico y se pida a los Estados miembros que desarrollen sus propios Planes de Acción, a nivel estatal o regional, en colaboración con el sector ecológico del territorio y con la implicación de las administraciones a todos los niveles, así como de la sociedad civil y agentes del sistema alimentario local.
Comisión y Estados miembros deberían acordar unos mínimos obligatorios progresivos de inclusión de productos ecológicos en las Compras Públicas Verdes, en especial en centros educativos, residencias de ancianos y hospitales, hasta llegar a un mínimo de un 25% en 2030.
Para que producción y consumo crezcan a la vez, se necesitan políticas y ayudas de promoción e información a los consumidores sobre los beneficios de la producción ecológica para el medio ambiente y el bienestar animal, y para facilitar la conexión entre productores/as y consumidores/as, así como entre el campo y la ciudad. Y, a la vez, resulta imprescindible favorecer la producción y disponibilidad de todos los insumos necesarios para el crecimiento de la producción ecológica.
Es necesario poner en valor y facilitar el acceso a toda la información y conocimiento generada por el sector ecológico, creando redes del conocimiento y buenos servicios de asesoramiento (libres de conflictos de intereses) y favoreciendo las redes de socialización e intercambio de conocimiento a nivel europeo y la transferencia horizontal del conocimiento campesino/a a campesino/a. Los presupuestos de investigación e innovación dedicados a la producción ecológica deben estar en consonancia con el objetivo de superficie ecológica plantead y dedicar el 25% del presupuesto de I + i agraria a la generación y gestión del conocimiento e innovación ecológicos.
Es fundamental que el Plan de Acción cuente con un seguimiento y evaluación desde el principio, supervisándose su implementación por parte de la Comisión y realizándose una revisión intermedia para poder identificar las deficiencias y solucionar sus causas o reorientar las actuaciones en caso necesario.
Los Planes Estratégicos de PAC, deberán contemplar las necesidades del sector ecológico y establecer un objetivo estatal en colaboración con el sector ecológico del país y la Comisión y definir una estrategia, incluyendo, como mínimo, ayudas a la conversión, mantenimiento, control y fomento de la producción ecológica.
Para afrontar el problema de la omnipresencia de residuos de plaguicidas en todo el medio (viéndose doblemente perjudicado el sector ecológico) debería aumentarse el presupuesto destinado a investigación e innovación en métodos agrarios ecológicos para encontrar soluciones I + D a este problema. A su vez, deberían simplificarse el sistema de registro de productos fitosanitarios aptos para la producción ecológica, tales como las sustancias naturales y asegurar una mayor armonización en el manejo de las detecciones de residuos de plaguicidas e investigar las posibilidades de imposición de responsabilidad a los productores/as y usuarios/as de plaguicidas, sobre la base del principio de quien contamina paga y considerar la opción de exigir responsabilidades en las casos de contaminación ambiental por productos fitosanitarios o incluso contemplar la prohibición de la comercialización y uso de estas sustancias.

short_title: Action plan for the development of EU organic production
Feedback:
Growing Media Europe AISBL (GME) is a non-profit industry association representing the producers of growing media and soil improvers on European level. Europe is the global leader in growing media production (40 Mm3/yr). Growing media are essential in society, used on a strongly increasing level to grow food and green up urban areas (trees, flowers, parks etc.). Growing plants in growing media in a protected environment (greenhouse) is called « Controlled Environment Horticulture (CEH) » or “Protected Cropping”. This innovative way of producing plants helps to solve the main challenges in today´s horticulture due to following advantages: weather conditions have lower or no impact; less fertilizers, pesticides and water are needed to harvest the same yield, a reduced land-use footprint is achieved, less labor is required and labor conditions are better and plants are more resilient thus developing less soil-borne diseases. It is not surprising that the global demand for growing media is sharply rising and that growers switch from an open-field production to Protected Cropping. 

Growing in growing media is,  next to conventional and organic agriculture, an integral part of the solution to the biggest challenges our food system is facing:
- Growing media make it possible to produce more food while using less resources and less or no arable land
- Local production closer to consumption (greenhouses close to/inside cities) → less transport and more resilient supply chains
- Plants grow more controlled → less plant diseases → safer food and less food waste
- Less use of chemical pesticides and fertilizers; instead, the use of biostimulants that are mixed into the growing medium has proven to be a promising innovation in modern horticulture and biocontrol using insects is more effective when growing in growing media.

Representing this highly sustainable way of growing plants, we consider the existing general principle of excluding plants grown in growing media ("demarcated beds") from the scope of organic production rather incomprehensible. The general requirements of the plant production rules state that organic production should be based on nourishing the plants primarily through the soil ecosystem and be soil-related, and that growing plants in ‘demarcated beds’ should not be allowed. We in particular do not follow the reasoning behind the existing derogations from this principle for young plants (seedlings) as well as herbs and ornamentals grown in pots. In several Member States, climate conditions are not supporting the growing of several types of fruits and vegetables in open field horticulture. These countries will effectively depend on imports for organic fruits and vegetables (after the transition phase ends in 2030).

The organic sector needs a well-balanced and reliable legislative framework that is based on scientific evidence and supports the best available growing techniques, providing environmental, social and economic benefits.

short_title: Action plan for the development of EU organic production
Feedback:
The main limitations of the existing Action Plan 2014-2020 were the absence of quantitative, time-bound objectives as well as the absence of a dedicated budget. Also, the 2014-2020 Action Plan mainly focuses on actions that the European Commission should carry out, without focusing on how the national, regional, or the local level could support organic farming and the whole organic food chain.
Therefore, we suggest that the next Organic Action Plan include quantitative, time-bound objectives with a dedicated budget.
Furthermore, we propose that Member States should establish legally binding and time-bound targets nationally. Member States should set up objectives for 2026 regarding the target share of organic land and market development/share in their country. These National Organic Action Plans should include actions aimed at supporting the development of organic in the whole supply chain (not only production). Member states should report their progress to the European Commission.

The European Commission and Member States should monitor the implementation of the Action Plans and produce a mid-term review. If there are major gaps in the implementation of the action plan, the European Commission should evaluate how to close these gaps.

Feedback:

In some cases, conventional farming might even be the best solution from a sustainability point of view. The regulatory framework for organic farming needs to be reviewed to also include e.g. human waste and promote enrichment of plant-based products.

Today’s consumers often demand products that are both organic and plant-based. Unfortunately, it is at current however often difficult to use the EU organic label on compound plant-based products due to regulatory obstacles. 

A concrete example of regulatory obstacles is that organic plant-based drinks, e.g. oat drink or soya drink, are not allowed to be enriched with vitamins and minerals according to the organic regulatory framework, even if organic cow´s milk can be enriched (through the feed). From a nutritional point of view, it is important to facilitate enrichment. Many people replace cow’s milk with plant-based drinks, and therefore plant-based drinks need to be enriched with similar enrichment that you find in cow´s milk (e.g. calcium, vitamin D and iodine). Consumers who choose to drink plant-based drinks should not need to choose between an organic or an enriched product. Both organic as well as conventional farming needs development. 

Oatly wants to emphasise that it is necessary to develop EU regulations for organic foods. It is important to facilitate and remove obstacles to enable the EU labelling of plant-based foods. Regarding the example above on plant-based drinks, there is a great need for creating an opening for increased use of enrichment agents in plant-based compound organic foods. 

Another obstacle is that there is a lack of access to suitable organic ingredients in the manufacturing process. The list of approved additives needs to be expanded so more plant-based products can gain an organic label. There are texture additives, e.g. methylcellulose, which are common in plant-based protein alternatives, but difficult to replace. 
Overall, without these changes in EU regulations for organic foods, it will be difficult to meet consumer demand for plant-based organic foods.
A shift to a more plant-based diet supports the EU’s climate targets
The AGRI Committee has voted to boost the EU climate ambitions and adopted a position calling on the EU to increase its emissions reduction target for 2030 from at least 40% to 55%. This increased climate ambition will require engagement and action on the ground by all economic sectors, citizens, authorities and civil society. In this context, the production and consumption of food is key. The Farm to Fork Strategy stresses that agriculture is responsible for 10.3% of the EU’s GHG emissions and nearly 70% of those come from the animal sector. In addition, 68% of the total agricultural land is used for animal production.

It is thus clear that the transition to a sustainable food system and reduced emissions will not happen without a shift to more plant-based foods in people’s diets. Therefore, Oatly thinks that strategies and actions need to put more focus on sustainable food consumption than on organic farming. It is important to at least ensure that the strategy for organic farming does not stands in the way of the development of plant-based food. Organic farming is important for biodiversity.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
I believe the new draft rule will be very useful for both for the operator and the CB in terms of establishing effective and efficient control system. However I have my doubt as well considering the system here in Ethiopia. Here we have a very huge groups (as high as 60000 farmers) which have been under certification for more than 15 years. This groups are the major fine coffee exporters in and very successful in the export market thanks to the certifications; which make them competent.
Saying this I put my few comments on the new rule article by article:

Article 4 Size limit of the groups
As I mentioned above our groups are very large in size. This is because of the fact that our farmers are too poor to operate in small group. The large size give them the opportunity to buy processing machinery, to hire professionals and to successfully compete with the huge farms. According to the new rule we have to split a single group to more than 30 small groups in time of 3 years; which is not  possible practically.
Their large size is equally important for the groups as does the certification.

Article 5 Farm Detail
It may not be possible to provide farm maps as plot maps are not available in Ethiopia. Farmers details(addresses) also unavailable as street names or House Numbers are not provided in rural part of the Country, while the farmers barely use cell phones.

Article 7 Sampling size
Sampling size of 10% seems very high considering the rough rural terrains where one have to walk from village to villages. Considering that a single farmer may have 2 or more plots, a good inspector manages to inspect 5-6 farmers per day which could take more than one month to inspect one group (considering the 2000 group limit). I think the IFOAM system of square root is more realistic together with effective Risk assessment system (as the number is sample could rise with the associated risk factor)
In Ethiopia most groups request certification for EU and NOP all together. So far we use one form (The IFOAM Form) for both standards. As USDA/NOP also revising the rules as well ,I kindly ask the commission to communicate this new rules with them so that we can use one procedure which still could satisfy both parties.
Generally it would be better if the commission also considers the reality in Africa in such a way that continuous improvement system could be applied ; so that our poor farmers would not be frustrated and going back

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
The main aim of the Anti Fraud Initiative is to improve communication among inspection and certification bodies, trade companies, label organisations and authorities to strenghten organic integrity.
We would like to comment on Draft implementing regulation - Ares(2020)3996465.
Article 1 (2) of this regulation will decrease the number of notifications received from operators because only accredited lab results shall be considered (leaf, soil and input tests taken at supplier visits are never accredited. Sampling reports are not always available. It is unclear why these specific requirements are introduced.
Article 2 of this regulation details the methodology of the official investigation. Article 2 (1) prescribes in detail all steps which MUST be followed during an official investigation ("shall"). Our experience is that food fraud, which might concern also the authenticity of organic products, requires a flexible response oriented to the nature of the case. This is why Article 14 of Reg. 2017/625 details different options for official controls. We propose that the word "shall" is replaced by "may" and that an additional sentence is added that official investigations must be conducted in an effective way avoiding unnecessary bureaucratic burden to the operators concerned. The information according to Article 2 e) is typically not available. There is no option that the control sector conducts a quick check first in order to evaluate whether an official investigation is useful or not. This could be an important contribution to avoid unnecessary bureaucratic burden.
We fear that the unilateral focus on the presence of unauthorized products or substances may lead to a situation that fraudulent practices involving residue-free conventional products ("label fraud") are no longer investigated with the intensity these cases deserve. This could undermine consumer protection and fair competition on the organic marketplace.
We miss completely in the draft that operators which have been involved repeatively in suspect cases which are not due to the nature of  products naturally accumulating pesticides (eg. dried leafs, product with high oil content) shall be submitted to a higher risk class and more frequent controls.  
For the Annex - Ares(2020)3996465, we fear that many informations required for the OFIS system might be not available at the time of the first notification about a suspected or established non-compliance. It remains unclear what happens then. It would be a pity if a quick reaction could not happen due to the fact that certain informations are not available at the time of first notification.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback: Fairtrade Africa is aware that improvements in certain areas are needed in the management of group of operators. Nevertheless, the changes currently proposed for certification rules would create unnecessary administrative and financial burdens to cooperatives, federations of cooperatives as well as processors and traders who have set up well working organic sourcing programmes with small farmers in developing countries. The risk is that the system will be weakened because groups would need to spend their scarce resources on expensive legal registrations, administration processes and increased certification costs instead of focusing on farmers training and support. Fairtrade Africa recommends that cooperatives, federations of cooperatives, and processors/exporters with affiliated farms be recognized as certifiable legal group entities and do not need to be split in two or more ‘’legal’’ groups. A certified legal group entity (e.g. a cooperative) should be permitted to create a sub-group of its registered members for the purposes of organic certification, but without the need to form a new separate legal entity or a separate Internal Management and Control System for each sub-group.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
The Alliance for Organic Integrity (AOI) is a US registered 501.c.3 non-profit organization, founded in 2019. It brings together all those around the World who share the goal of protecting and enhancing the quality and integrity of the organic guarantee being provided to consumers. It works
on developing and sharing best organic practices, harmonizing organic platforms and developing additional tools to prevent fraud.
Both the EU and US/NOP are developing rules for, among other areas, Groups of Operators (Grower Groups or GG’s) and we are very concerned that the measures proposed are diverging, both from each other and from the IFOAM-OI Guidance. If unaddressed this will cause undue costs, confusion and complications especially for the many GG’s that seek both EU and US markets.
This paper aims to address the consultations of both the EU and the US/NOP and therefore has recommendations for both regulatory frameworks. Some of the explanations are of a general nature and common to both. The recommendations are clearly headed as either for the EU or US/NOP or both.
Our Alliance consultation process on Harmonization is ongoing so, with the comment period for the US/NOP proposed rule being October 5th, our submission may have developed further beyond this current draft.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
INAO (Institut National de l’Origine et de la Qualité), autorité compétente, en France, pour le contrôle en agriculture biologique avant la mise sur le marché, souhaite adresser à la Commission les commentaires suivants : 

L’article 2 sur la méthodologie des enquêtes officielles ne précise pas ce qui est entendu par présence de produits ou substances non autorisés. Le texte devrait préciser que la présence de pesticides est avérée quand le laboratoire détermine la présence d’une substance à un niveau supérieur ou égal à 0.02mg/kg (sans tenir compte de la mesure d’incertitude). Cette précision permettra d’harmoniser la gestion des cas. 

L’article 5 sur les documents et enregistrements à tenir par le groupe d’opérateurs doit prévoir que les rapports d’inspections internes décrivent a minima les manquements relevés et la portée du contrôle. 
Également, le paragraphe (g) sur les contrats de sous-traitance a besoin d’être clarifié. S’agit-il des activités de production/transformation (etc) sous-traitées ou bien de la sous-traitance des inspections internes.

L’article 7 concernant les pourcentages de contrôles ne fixe pas de base commune de calcul. Le nombre d’opérateurs engagés auprès d’un organisme de contrôle varient sensiblement tout au long de l’année et des disparités d’application entre les États membres existent. Aussi, cet article doit préciser une base de calcul, qui pourrait être le nombre d’opérateurs engagés auprès de l’organisme de contrôle au 1er janvier de l’année, afin de faciliter sa mise en œuvre et le contrôle de son respect par l’autorité compétente. 

Enfin, l’article 8 sur le catalogue national de traitement des manquements mérite d’être clarifié. Le paragraphe b) précise les critères à prendre en compte pour caractériser un manquement comme mineur/majeur/grave. Or, deux de ces critères sont déjà eux-mêmes des manquements : absence de traçabilité, l’absence de mesures de précaution. 
Pour caractériser un manquement, il faut évaluer son impact sur la qualité biologique du produit et s’il s’agit d’une récidive, la mesure appliquée doit être plus forte.
En outre, les catalogues de traitement des manquements ne peuvent pas prévoir une mesure pour toutes les situations (avec ou sans traçabilité, avec ou sans mesures de précaution…).
Les catalogues nationaux permettent d’harmoniser les pratiques. Toutefois des mesures différentes peuvent être prises par les organismes de contrôle, si la situation le justifie.

short_title: Mandate for negotiations with Panama on withdrawal of its WTO tariff rate quotas on milk products
Feedback:
EDA strongly supports to European Commission’s roadmap serving the purpose of preparing the negotiations with Panama on compensation for its withdrawal of WTO tariff rate quotas. 

EU27 dairy companies export more than 5,000 tonnes of dairy products per year to Panama which account for more than 20 million euros. Considering the dairy market situation, Panama is far from being self-sufficient in milk production (38% self-sufficiency in milk in 2019). Milk production has been decreasing annually during the past 6 years. 

For these reasons, European dairy companies have great expectations when it comes to trading relations with Panama. They reaffirm their high interest in maintaining business, especially in the liquid milk sector. In the past, UHT milk contingents were tendered in public auctions, and the maximum quantities historically won were below 1,000 tons for a semester. We believe the EU has big exports competitors on the Panama market and should not be targeted by such increased duties. 

In addition, the negotiations at WTO level on the compensations related to Panama’s withdrawal for its WTO tariff rate quotas on milk must take into account that these quotas, officially removed since last August 2020, were in reality suspended since January 2020. 

If a general duty-free import is no longer possible, the EDA members would like to see tariff-reduced quotas to be negotiated during the upcoming WTO discussions. We also believe that tariff reduction for other dairy products, for instance cheeses, would be considered as a small compensation for the withdrawal by Panama of its WTO tariff rate quotas of milk. 

Sources: IFCN, Eurostat, EDA surveys

short_title: New authorized inputs and extended derogation for non-organic pullets and non-organic protein feed in organic production
Feedback:
The International Platform of Insects for Food and Feed (IPIFF) - the umbrella association of the European insect sector wishes to present its position regarding the public consultation on 'Organic farming - new authorised inputs and extended exemption for non-organic hens and non-organic protein feed'. IPIFF is a non-profit organisation which represents the interests of actors active across the insect production value chain at European level. Bringing together more than 70 members - most of which are European insect producing companies - IPIFF promotes the use of insects and insect-derived products as a top tier source of nutrients for human consumption and animal feed.

IPIFF strongly believes that - in the near future - insects and insect-derived feed ingredients (e.g. insect PAPs, insect lipids) will be a reliable complementary source of nutrition in poultry feed (for more information on this subject, please refer to the IPIFF factsheet on animal nutrition: https://ipiff.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/IPIFF-Nutritional-benefits-of-insects-in-animal-feed.pdf). 

While presently standards for the organic certification activities are being developed by the European Commission, IPIFF suggests the inclusion of up to 5% insect-derived ingredients in organic poultry feed (as part of the 5% derogation). In our view, this possibility will also support organic and/or in-conversion poultry farmers to reach the 30% objective for regionally produced feed (article 1.9.4.2. Nutrition - Regulation (EU) 2018/848) - and implicitly support the growth of the organic sector, in line with the 'Farm to Fork' objectives.

To this end, and in the perspective of implementing the new EU organic legislation (from January 2022), IPIFF has devised a three steps policy plan: 

• Exploring the possibilities for including insect products in feed for organic aquaculture animals;

• Supporting the inclusion of insect proteins (derived from non-organically produced animals) in organic poultry and swine feed (up to 5 %);

• Developing EU regulatory standards for the organic certification of insect production activities.

For reference, please consult the IPIFF Regulatory Brochure (chapter IV) - available through this link: 
https://ipiff.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/IPIFF-RegulatoryBrochure-update07-2020-1.pdf

short_title: New authorized inputs and extended derogation for non-organic pullets and non-organic protein feed in organic production
Feedback:
Herzlichen Dank für die Möglichkeit zur Kommentierung des Entwurfs. Von Seiten des BÖLW, des Dachverbandes für Bio-Bauern, Bio-Verarbeiter und Bio-Händler in Deutschland, möchten wir folgendes einbringen:

Um den Übergang zum neuen Bio-Recht zu gestalten, sind die Fristen für die Fütterung von konventionellem Eiweiß und für den Zukauf 18 Wochen alten konventioneller Junglegehennen um ein Jahr verlängert worden. Das ist inhaltlich konsequent. 
Für Eiweißfutter unterstützen wir dies auch inhaltlich, denn die Verfügbarkeit von genügend ökologischen Eiweißkomponenten bleibt eine Herausforderung in der EU. 
Die erneute Verlängerung der Frist für den Zukauf von 18 Monaten alten Junglegehennen unterstützen wir jedoch nicht, denn in Deutschland setzen die Bio-Geflügelhalter schon seit vielen Jahren ökologische Geflügelherkünfte ein. Wenn Engpässe bei der Versorgung mit Öko-Junggeflügel auftreten, dann greifen die Geflügelbetriebe auf konventionelle Eintagsküken zurück. Die inkonsequente Ökologisierung der Geflügelherkünfte in anderen EU-Ländern und der Ausnahme für 18 Wochen alte konventionelle Junghennen führt zu massiven Wettbewerbsverzerrungen innerhalb der EU. Deshalb halten wir eine erneute Verlängerung nicht für angemessen. Im Sinne einer konsequenten Anpassung aller Fristen und um die Initiative zur Verschiebung nicht in Frage zu stellen können wir sie jedoch akzeptieren.

Hinsichtlich der Aufnahme der vorgeschlagenen Futtermittel sowie Zusatz- und Hilfsstoffe haben wir keine Einwendungen. Sie basieren auf Empfehlungen des letzten EGTOP-Berichts, und es ist zu begrüßen, dass die Anpassungen in Anhang V und VIII zeitnah erfolgen und nicht erst mit der Übernahme der Anhänge in die künftige Verordnung.

short_title: New authorized inputs and extended derogation for non-organic pullets and non-organic protein feed in organic production
Feedback:
Por mi parte creo que es necesario que se introduzcan explícitamente como insumos ciertos ácidos orgánicos y sus sales que se utilizan como prebióticos en la actualidad y que al no estar reflejados explícitamente como insumos autorizados en la norma, crean controversia en su utilización dependiendo de la zona en la que estemos. Incluyo una leve lista de aquellos que creo que sería interesante plantear: 
•	Butirato sódico
•	Acetato amónico
•	Formiato amónico
•	Propionato amónico
•	Ácido butírico
•	Monobutirina
•	Tributirina
Todos estos insumos ya los utilizamos comunmente en la avicultura convencional y son parte importante en los programas de reducción del uso de antibióticos basados en la salud intestinal.  

La prohibición del uso de aminoácidos sintéticos, como la metionina, por ser de síntesis química, obliga a incrementar la proporción de materias proteicas en la dieta, especialmente en las aves más jóvenes (período de recría). La materia prima de elección para cubrir las elevadas necesidades nutricionales de las modernas aves de puesta es la soja, pero aumentar su presencia en la fórmula nutricional de las pollitas debe equilibrarse con los perjuicios derivados de sus factores antinutritivos. Estos, por encima de unos límites, reducen el aprovechamiento del pienso y pueden derivar en problemas metabólicos y sanitarios. Las raciones de las pollitas de cría ecológicas se formulan en estos momentos rozando esos límites, lo que se traduce en un aumento de los efectos indeseados derivados de las restricciones establecidas a la alimentación de estas aves.
La escasez de soja y otras materias primas ecológicas en España y la UE genera una elevada dependencia de las importaciones, en su mayoría procedentes de China, India y Brasil, en la avicultura de la UE. La prohibición del uso de la metionina incrementa la utilización de estas materias primas proteicas en la ración, lo que afecta a la huella ambiental de la producción ecológica de huevos por el transporte a larga distancia de los ingredientes.
A la mayor huella ambiental derivada del transporte de las materias primas ecológicas se suma otro impacto negativo adicional: el aumento de las emisiones de amoníaco, una de las principales preocupaciones en las políticas ambientales, que afecta especialmente a la avicultura. Las mejores técnicas disponibles para la reducción de emisiones se basan en la prevención, y las más eficaces para la reducción del nitrógeno total excretado se refieren al adecuado manejo nutricional. Las técnicas de manejo nutricional incluyen: Reducir el contenido de proteína bruta y alimentación multifase (teniendo en cuenta las necesidades de los animales), y adición de cantidades controladas de aminoácidos esenciales en una dieta baja en proteínas brutas, así como el uso de aditivos autorizados.
La producción avícola ecológica en la UE no es igual en la práctica en todos los países, y estas diferencias deben contemplarse en la normativa. El Norte de Europa tiene un clima muy diferente al del Sur. En España y en otros países mediterráneos se plantea un importante desafío para la producción en los meses de verano, por la dificultad de cubrir las necesidades nutricionales de las aves en períodos de altas temperaturas, cuando las pollitas reducen el consumo y la ingesta de pienso difícilmente alcanza los requerimientos de las aves de puesta de las modernas estirpes. En estas situaciones existen serios riesgos de que aparezcan déficits nutricionales, retardo en el crecimiento o problemas derivados de los factores antinutritivos de la soja utilizada en alta proporción, que impactan no solo en la productividad, sino en el bienestar y la sanidad de las aves.
Las restricciones a los tratamientos veterinarios: Las gallinas ponedoras ecológicas tienen que tener una sanidad adecuada, para lo que se vacunan 
También decir que actualmente hay dudas sobre la disponibilidad de las pollitas ponedoras en los próximos meses

short_title: New authorized inputs and extended derogation for non-organic pullets and non-organic protein feed in organic production
Feedback:
Thank you for the  possiblity for feedback on this delegated act. On behalf ABCERT, the German CB for organic production, we have the following remarks:
 
In general, all sprouts – seed and vegetative propagating material including bulbs – shall be allowed. However, it is crucial to include also bulbs (such as tulips) which are also cultivated in an inert medium and only use the reserves in the bulbs. Particularly the ornamental sector is growing in organic and should be allowed to do so. The production of tulips is very similar to the production of chicory or other bulbs (which also need to be covered by these rules).
Cress has to be deleted because cress seedlings are sprouted. Otherwise other sprouted seeds such as rape, beetroot, beans etc. would be excluded. 
 
The inserted reference to components authorised in compliance with Article 24 contradicts the restriction to an inert medium! The only relevant category of authorised substances according to Article 24 is the list of fertilizers, soil conditioners and nutrients – but these materials are non-inert (because if they were, they may not be listed!), they  provide nutrients to the plant. Therefore, the reference to Art. 24 shall be deleted.
 
Forcing of chicory is either done in water in an inert material for stabilisation (e.g. sand). Both production methods should be allowed. It must be clarified that only an inert medium is permitted. For allowed substrates according to Art. 24 please see comment above. The reference to Art. 24 should also be deleted for chicory.

short_title: Fruit and vegetables sectors - Recognition criteria of producer organisations and operational programmes
Feedback:
In linea con la strategia "New Green Deal and Farm to Fork" della Commissione, per far si che il settore ortofrutticolo possa contribuire a migliorare le soluzioni di imballaggio apportando, al contempo un beneficio ambientale, è opportuno che, siano rendicontabili nei Programmi Operativi le spese legate:
- all' utilizzo e alla gestione degli imballaggi riutilizzabili a sponde abbattibili, utilizzate dall'OP e/ suoi soci e/o filiali. (Infatti secondo uno studio del Dipartimento di Ingegneria industriale dell'Università di Bologna, l'impiego di imballi in plastica riutilizzabili a sponde abbattibili, da parte delle aziende ortofrutticole, garantisce una maggiore sostenibilità ambientale, dal momento che tali imballaggi, potendo essere utilizzati volte (fino ad un centinaio) grazie ad un regolare flusso di ritorno, e riciclato successivamente, garantiscono minori emissioni di CO2, quantificabili attraverso la metodologia LCA-Life Cycle Assessment.);
- all'acquisto di nuovi macchinari per l'utilizzo di imballaggi riciclabili (ad esempio una macchina che monta imballaggi in cartone), per sostituire gradualmente quelli necessari per altri tipi di imballaggio.
Inoltre, per ridurre gli spechi, riducendo gli scarti post-raccolta e nel contempo avere una riduzione dei consumi energetici per la frigoconservazione, si ritiene opportuno, poter rendicontare nei Programmi Operativi i costi per l'acquisizione e l'impiego di prodotti che prolungano la conservabilità dei frutti, quali ad esempio l' uso del 1-Metilciclopropene (1-MCP), come riscontrabile da alcune ricerche: Brown G., 2011. “Saving apples storage cost”. Australian Fruitgrower Vol. 5/IUSSE n. 1, February 2011, pp. 19-21; Kittemann D., McCornick R., Neuwald D.A., 2015. “Effect of high temperature and 1-MCP application or dynamic controlled atmosphere on energy savings during apple”. Europ.J.Hort.Sci. 80 (1) 33-38 (ISSN 1611-4426 print and 1611-4434 online - ISHS 2015).).

Si evidenzia che per le Organizzazione di Produttori,  l’utilizzo di imballi in plastica a rendere, a sponde abbattibili, che possono essere riutilizzati fino ad un centinaio di volte grazie a regolari flussi di ritorno e che a “fine ciclo di vita” il materiale plastico di cui sono fatte viene ri-granulato per essere utilizzato per la produzione di nuove cassette a sponde abbattibili, rappresenta una importante evoluzione verso performance ambientali migliorative. short_title: Fruit and vegetables sectors - Recognition criteria of producer organisations and operational programmes
Feedback:
Bulgaria welcomes the initiative of the European Commission to amend Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/891 in connection with the new CAP Reform which should be in application in 2023. In this context there is room for improvements, clarifications and further simplification of EU secondary legislation on fruit and vegetables before the new CAP legislative framework enters into force and is in application.
In this regard Bulgaria would like to suggest an amendment to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/891 related to provisions on national strategies.
Bulgaria is in the process of amending the National Strategy for Sustainable Operational Programs of Fruit and Vegetable Producers' Organizations in the Republic of Bulgaria for the period 2017-2021 (the Strategy) and the question arose about the duration of the Strategy and which operational programs will be approved under its terms.
According to Art.25 (1) (b) of Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/892 operational programs shall be approved when in compliance with Article 33 of Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 as well as with the national strategy.
The approval of the operational programs and their amendments is carried out in accordance with the strategy in force at the time of submission of the operational program for approval according to Art. 6 (1) of Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/892, although the implementation period of the operational programs may go beyond the duration of the strategy.
According to the draft Regulation (EU) 2020/… of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down certain transitional provisions for the support by from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) and by from the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) in the years 2021 and 2022 (Transitional Regulation), the operational programs that are being implemented at the moment of entry into force of this Regulation can be extended only until 31 December 2022, ie the current Strategy 2017-2021 will apply to them.
In addition, this Strategy, which is in force until 31 December 2021, will apply to the submission for approval or amendment of the operational programs by 15 September 2021 and will cover their entire implementation period - until 2024 (for three annual operational programs as set in the Transitional Regulation).
In this situation, a new strategy should be drafted, which will set the terms and conditions only for operational programs submitted in 2022 that will be implemented  until 2025 (for three annual operational programs as set in the Transitional Regulation). Drafting a new strategy for just one submission would increase the administrative burden for the applicants for operational programs.
The current European legislation regarding operational programs in the fruit and vegetables sector does not fix the duration of the national strategy, but according to Annex 1, point 1 of Implementing Regulation (EU) 2017/892, the duration of the strategy is to be indicated by the Member State.
In view of the above, Bulgaria would like to suggest an amendment to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/891 that will give member states the flexibility to extend the duration of current national strategies by one or two years till the Rеgulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing rules on support for strategic plans to be drawn up by Member States under the Common agricultural policy (Regulation for strategic plans) is in application – 2023, which would create a legislative framework for all operational programs approved under the old rules.
After the entry into force of the Regulation for strategic plans, the operational programs submitted for approval in 2023 will be considered according to the new rules.

short_title: Production rules concerning feed and veterinary parasite treatments in aquaculture and sprouted seeds
Feedback:
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

Wir sind Anbauer und Händler von biologischen Chicorée-Wurzeln. Unsere Chicorée-Wurzeln werden von Chicorée-Produzenten in ganz Europa abgenommen und getrieben.
Im Zusammenhang mit der Ankündigung der neuen EU-Öko-Verordnung, die ab 2022 in Kraft treten soll, erklären wir gerne, warum sie nicht auf die Chicorée-Treiberei zutreffen soll. 
Die Wahl des Treibens des Chicorées in Erde in Kisten ist genommen, da die Erde ein gutes Medium ist, die Erträge besser zu versichern. Wenn man Chicorée in Erde in Kisten treibt, kann man das Klima im Treibraum besser steuern und den Druck von Krankheiten vermindern. Manche Krankheiten wie Phytophthora und Sklerotien breiten sich durch Wasser schnell aus. In Erde geht diese Verbreitung viel langsamer. Diese Krankheiten können die Produktion bis zu 100% zerstören. Die Erde wird in solchen Treibereien nur als Wachsmedium eingesetzt. Die Erde verbessert auch den Wasserhaushalt in der Treibkiste. Chicorée, der in so einer Treiberei produziert worden ist, wird nicht als Erd-Chicorée verkauft. Das ist auch nicht das Ziel. Dieses System kombiniert die Effizienz einer Wassertreiberei mit den Vorteilen des Wachsmediums Erde.  
Um das Angebot von biologischem Chicorée in der Zukunft auch erreichbar und bezahlbar zu halten, suchen wir als Chicorée-Produzenten immer nach neuen Arten von Zuchttechnik, gemäß der Richtlinien für die Produktion von Bio-Gemüse. Im Einklang mit der Richtung der Europäischen Union, wo man redet von 25% biologischer Anbau der Flächen in Europa in 2030, ist die Wahl für Kisten mit Erde eine gute Unterstützung, um dieses Ziel zu erreichen. 
Wir bitten Sie um weitergehende Zulassung der Produktion von Chicorée in Kisten mit Erde. Falls Sie weitere Erklärung verlangen, können wir uns gerne mal unterhalten.

Die Erde wird in solchen Treibereien nur als Wachsmedium eingesetzt. Die Erde verbessert auch den Wasserhaushalt in der Treibkiste. Chicorée, der in so einer Treiberei produziert worden ist, wird nicht als Erd-Chicorée verkauft. Das ist auch nicht das Ziel. Dieses System kombiniert die Effizienz einer Wassertreiberei mit den Vorteilen des Wachsmediums Erde.  
Um das Angebot von biologischem Chicorée in der Zukunft auch erreichbar und bezahlbar zu halten, suchen wir als Chicorée-Produzenten immer nach neuen Arten von Zuchttechnik, gemäß der Richtlinien für die Produktion von Bio-Gemüse. Im Einklang mit der Richtung der Europäischen Union, wo man redet von 25% biologischer Anbau der Flächen in Europa in 2030, ist die Wahl für Kisten mit Erde eine gute Unterstützung, um dieses Ziel zu erreichen. 
Wir bitten Sie um weitergehende Zulassung der Produktion von Chicorée in Kisten mit Erde. Falls Sie weitere Erklärung verlangen, können wir uns gerne mal unterhalten.

short_title: Production rules concerning feed and veterinary parasite treatments in aquaculture and sprouted seeds
Feedback:
The EU Federation of Organic Farming & Production IFOAM Organics Europe would like to provide the Commission with the following comments on the proposed amendments to point (1)(3)(a) on sprouts of Part I Annex II of Regulation (EU) 2018/848 :

- The newly inserted reference to components authorised in compliance with Article 24 contradicts the restriction to an inert medium. The only relevant category of authorised substances according to Article 24 could be the list of fertilizers, soil conditioners and nutrients, but these materials are not inert as they provide nutrients to the plant. Therefore, the reference to Article 24 shall be deleted, unless a specific annex for allowed inert materials is planned.

- All sprouts (seed and vegetative propagating material including bulbs) should be allowed. It is crucial to include also bulbs - such as tulips - which are also cultivated in an inert medium and only use the reserves in the bulbs. Organic ornamental sector is growing and should be allowed to do so. The production of tulips is very similar to the production of chicory or other bulbs, which also need to be covered by these rules. 

- Cress should be deleted because cress seedlings are sprouted seeds or cress should be mentioned only as an example. Otherwise, other sprouted seeds such as rape, beetroot, beans etc. would be excluded.

short_title: Production rules concerning feed and veterinary parasite treatments in aquaculture and sprouted seeds
Feedback:
The Biodynamic Federation – Demeter International is an umbrella organisation with 46 members organisations in 37 different countries across the world. It is the only organic association that has built up a network of individual certification for biodynamic farming worldwide. The Federation welcomes the possibility offered by the European Commission to give its feedback on the amended rules as regards organic production rules on sprouted seeds and chicory heads, on feed for certain aquaculture animals and on aquaculture parasite treatments. We would like to attract the European Commission´s attention on the following aspects described below regarding organic horticulture.

To support organic horticulture, it is particularly important that the forcing of bulbs as cut flowers in spring in boxes with unfertilised substrate material (mainly tulips), the forcing of bulbs of chives in boxes in winter and early spring (for bundles especially) and the forcing of chicory roots in boxes with soil with unfertilised substrate is maintained in the new EU Organic Regulation. These practices are an integral part of traditional and professional organic horticulture and the production processes in accordance with art. 2g of EU Regulation 889/2008. Indeed, the main growth steps for these three production areas all take place in the grown soil, the forcing is only a final cultivation step mainly in spring (also in winter for chives) according to the climatic conditions. The forcing of bulbs and chicory in clear water with an inert stabilisation and carrier material and no addition of any fertiliser should be maintained as well, as this is an alternative traditional production method to the forcing in unfertilised substrates.

A change in these practices could affect the entire European organic horticulture sector since it would jeopardize the offer of bunches of chives in winter and early spring and the production of organic tulips in spring. The supply of organic chicory would also go down as most small and medium farmers cannot afford to switch to water drifting. At a time when regional and local markets, as well as organic production, should be reinforced, it seems essential for the new EU Organic Regulation to support further the development of the organic horticulture sector instead of putting it in jeopardy.

short_title: Production rules concerning feed and veterinary parasite treatments in aquaculture and sprouted seeds
Feedback:
Vielen Dank für die Möglichkeit zur Stellungnahme zu diesem Rechtsakt-Entwurf.

Wir (BIO AUSTRIA) möchten folgende Punkte einbringen:

-	Die Verweise auf Art. 24 unter (1) a und (1) b sollten unbedingt gestrichen werden. Das Trägermaterial würde sich am ehesten in der Kategorie der Düngemittel, Bodenverbesserer und Nährstoffe verorten lassen – jedoch widerspricht auch diese Kategorie grundsätzlich der Anforderung, dass ein „inertes Medium/Trägermaterial“ verwendet werden muss - und die gelisteten Stoffe aus der Kategorie Düngemittel, Bodenverbesserer und Nährstoffe per-se Nährstoffe liefern.
-	Die aktuelle Formulierung unter (1) a bezüglich „sprouted seeds“ könnte den Rückschluss zulassen, dass nur Kresse erlaubt ist, aber keine anderen Sprossen. Kresse sollte daher nicht explizit herausgegriffen werden, sondern wenn, dann nur beispielhaft angeführt werden.
-	Die Treiberei von Blumenzwiebeln sollte ebenfalls in diesem Rechtsakt berücksichtigt werden, da diese ähnlich wie bei Chicorée durchgeführt wird. Der Bio-Anteil im Zierpflanzen-Sektor wächst und sollte daher auch durch diese Regelung unterstützt werden.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
1.	Proponemos que se especifique en la nueva Reglamentación del Reglamento UE 2018/848 que la certificación externa se base en el Sistema Interno de Control, no necesariamente en la como está conformada la organización si es de primer o segundo grado, como del número de familias que la integran. En concordancia con el punto anterior, solicitamos que en esta nueva Reglamentación que los sistemas de control interno puedan incluir organizaciones de segundo y tercer nivel, incluyendo sus organizaciones y productores de base, sin la necesidad de certificados individuales para cada grupo de primer nivel. 
3.	Solicitamos, eliminar en la Ley Secundaria la exigencia de certificados separados para los procesos de procesamiento y comercialización de los grupos de operadores dedicados primariamente a la producción, porque ello sería cohibir o limitar a las familias y sus organizaciones en actividades de transformación, preparación o comercialización de alimentos.

Proponemos que se especifique en la Reglamentación Secundaria que los límites de tamaño y de ingresos máximos de los productores que formen parte de un grupo de operadores puedan ser variables, dependiendo del área geográfica y del producto en cuestión, dado que no necesariamente las 5 ha máximos o los €25,000/€15,000 euros de valor máximo, (aún en el caso en que los costos de la certificación individual no rebasen el 2% del valor de negocio), tal como señalados en el Reglamento UE 2018/848.
