short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
Comments on proposed model of certificate: 
• Livestock and livestock products are not marketed as in-conversion product, therefore the presence of such option to tick seems to be provocation; 
• Quantities of products covered with the granted certification do need clarification: calculated for full period of certificate validity, or per 12 months from the date of issue, or per seasonal harvest? Harvests depend on the weather conditions, diseses and pests. In case of procesor or importer quantities rely on products availability and on market demand, so how to predict/estimate it? In case of apiary – quantities rely on changeal availability of bee feeds. Any estimation is a wishful approach, but some competent authorities take it seriously as quantitative permit for sale (if the producer sells a bit more – sanctions apply). This may bring a burden instead of harmonization. 
• Quantities of conventional products produced by organic operator looks out curiously and doesn’t make any important value (what for?). It is enough to list the conventional products produced at the operation, without quantities (that may change along months). 
• List of premises on the certificate is curiosity! What is the aim of it? It may get accused of violence of privacy. 
No meaning for the product certification and unnecessary extension of the certificate. (If a new storehouse is included, should the CB update a certificate?). 
• List of subcontractors on the certificate seems to be a reveal of business secrets and company’s relations. A notice that a given product is produced by subcontractor, without its name and address, should be enought.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
Comments to the  COMMISSION DELEGATED REGULATION (EU) …/... of XXX amending Regulation (EU) No 2018/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the requirements for groups of operators and the model of certificate attesting compliance with the rules on organic production.

General comment: 
proposed model of certificate will be difficult for certification bodies (how to predict the yield in early spring? Or how to predict how many rolls the bakery will bake?) and not clear for traders and consumers. This approach is against the idea of simplification, transparency and will not bring any benefit for producers and consumers.

1.1.	 Livestock and unprocessed (as well as processed livestock products)  - the category of livestock and livestock products in-conversion shouldn’t be labelled as “in-conversion” and shouldn’t be listed on the certificate. It will create misunderstandings and potential fraud. 
1.2.	 CN codes - CN codes will be too difficult to check, the consumers will understand the certificate and they don’t need it. It creates additional  and unnecessary bureaucratic burden.
1.3.	 Quantities - It is too difficult to estimate the quantity of many products, for example rolls in the bakery at the start of the production or the yield of raspberries in the year of long warm autumn. It is  additional unnecessary bureaucratic burden.
1.4.	Quantity of conventional products - It is nonsense to estimate the quantity of conventional products on the certificate of organic production! It is additional unnecessary bureaucratic burden.
1.5.	 Surface in hectares - The idea why to use it on the certificate is not clear. It will only create additional problems with exact data of the organic production  surface.
1.6.	 List of premises - Only the main address of the producer should be indicated, not all his barns, storehouses etc. It is  additional unnecessary bureaucratic burden.                                          
1.7.	 List of subcontractors - The subcontractors may change within the year, so each time the certificate should be changed.  It is  additional unnecessary bureaucratic burden.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
Comments to the  COMMISSION DELEGATED REGULATION (EU) …/... of XXX amending Regulation (EU) No 2018/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the requirements for groups of operators and the model of certificate attesting compliance with the rules on organic production.

General comment: 
The proposed model of certificate is not compatible with idea of simplification, transparency and as such will not bring any benefit for producers or consumers.

Further remarks:
MODEL OF CERTIFICATE

Part I. 6 (b) livestock and unprocessed livestock products – livestock products cannot be offered as “in-conversion” on the market. This kind of expression would be misleading.

Part II. 1 CN-codes – although proper, they would not be informative at all (especially for regular organic consumer). names of products of groups of products should be listed (maybe taking advantage of CN-code classification).

Part II. 1 quantities – very often difficult to be precise. It is usually an estimation and as such should be treated. Maybe it would be possible to resign publishing the quantities, at least i case of trade companies that cannot predict their future transactions at all.

Part II. 1 quantities of conventional products – why should CBs estimate conventional production quantities? there is no prerequisite for that in 2018/848. It would be absolutely non-informative burden.

Part II. 4 Information on the land / surface in hectares – eventually, organic producers does not sell organic land on the basis of certificate. The comparison of organic production and land surface should be carried our by CBs that are responsible for analysing the outcome and putting down a proper, checked quantities of organic products within the certificate.

Part II. 6 List of subcontractors – Presenting list of subcontractors would be in contradiction with business secret. Not every company want to share the information of the subcontractors with e.g. rare and expensive technologies. Worth of reconsideration.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
A: 	Ursula Gertrud von der Leyen, Presidenta de la Comisión Europea
	Janusz Wojciechowski, Director General de la DG Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural
Nicolas Verlet, Director de la Unidad Orgánica de la DG de Agricultura y Desarrollo Rural

AUTORIDADES COMPETENTES DE LA COMISIÓN EUROPEA

De antemano expresamos nuestro agradecimiento por esta oportunidad de presentar la retroalimentación con respecto al capítulo relacionado a la certificación de Grupos de Operadores del nuevo Reglamento UE 2018/848, a entrar en vigor el próximo primero de enero. 
Símbolo de Pequeños Productores Global (SPP Global) es una red intercontinental de 122 organizaciones de cientos de miles de familias pequeños productores orgánicos de 25 países de América Latina, África y Asia que lucha por el reconocimiento de alta calidad de nuestros productos y trabajo en favor de una vida digna y un planeta sano para todos, llevando a la mesa del consumidor un producto saludable, orgánico, respetando siempre la sustentabilidad y conservación del medio ambiente. 
Hacemos un llamado a la Comisión Europea para tomar en cuenta que las realidades y condiciones de vida en que viven y producen los pequeños productores de otros continentes no son necesariamente similares a las de los miembros de los grupos de operadores dentro de la propia Comunidad Europea, y que el mercado europeo tiene la necesidad de abastecerse de los productos que producen estos productores. 
Propuestas:
1.	Proponemos que se especifique en la Reglamentación Secundaria del Reglamento UE 2018/848 que la certificación externa se debe basar en el Sistema Interno de Control, no necesariamente en la composición de la membresía legal de la organización de productores. De esta manera se evitará la desintegración forzada de organizaciones de pequeños productores y el riesgo de quiebra de tanto las organizaciones como de los productores individuales a expulsar.
2.	Solicitamos especificarse en esta Reglamentación Secundaria que los sistemas de control interno puedan abarcar organizaciones de segundo y tercer nivel, incluyendo sus organizaciones y productores de base, sin la necesidad de certificados individuales para cada grupo de primer nivel. De esta manera se evitará la multiplicación de certificados y costos para organizaciones basadas en la integración vertical.
3.	Solicitamos, por los mismos motivos que los del punto anterior, que se elimine en la Ley Secundaria cualquier ambigüedad con respecto a la eventual exigencia errónea de certificados separados para los procesos de procesamiento y comercialización de los grupos de operadores dedicados primariamente a la producción. De esta forma se respetaría lo que especifica el artículo 36.1. a) que dicta que estos operadores “puedan dedicarse a la transformación, preparación o comercialización de alimentos o piensos”. 
4.	Proponemos que se especifique en la Reglamentación Secundaria que los límites de tamaño y de ingresos máximos de los productores que formen parte de un grupo de operadores puedan ser variables, dependiendo de la región geográfica y del producto en cuestión (eventualmente a espeficicar en anexos a la Ley), no necesariamente las 5 ha máximos o los €25,000/€15,000 euros de valor máximo, (aún en el caso en que los costos de la certificación individual no rebasen el 2% del valor de negocio), tal como señalados en el Reglamento UE 2018/848. Con esta medida se evita el impacto no intencional de la expulsión de un sin número de pequeños productores del mercado europeo. 
Muchas gracias por la atención prestada a las presentes propuestas, le pedimos de favor  tomar nota  de la comunicación más amplia anexada, de parte de SPP Global, firmada por su Presidente, Nelson Melo Maya y su Director Ejecutivo, Jerónimo Pruijn.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
WFTO-Europe strongly supports organic farming and encourages the European Commission to uphold strong and high quality organic regulation and certification system. However, we must stress that any articles in the proposed regulation that would merely place additional costs or significant administrative burdens on groups of operators, farmers and cooperatives, particularly in Third Countries, would be counterproductive to the Commission’s efforts – and similar efforts of Civil Society and movements like the Fair Trade movement – to incentivise organic production within and outside the EU.
In particular, we urge the Commission to focus on public policies that help increase the quality and frequency of trainings in organic farming practices and organic regulation for groups of operators and their farmer members, especially in Third Countries. Such public policies should further ensure provision of technical assistance, and should in general aim at supporting small-scale farmers in particular. Foremost, however, we urge the EU to support partnerships between EU-based businesses and Third Country-based groups of operators when the former supports the latter with capacity-building for improving organic practices, with administrative matters for compliance with EU regulation, and helps invest in more sustainable and healthy farming and production patterns. 

Please see the attached annex for our detailed feedback on this Delegated Regulation.

short_title: Control rules in organic production
Feedback:
Comercio Alternativo Apícola en México S.C manifiesta la siguiente postura, en relación a la reglamentación secundaria en la Unión Europea. 
 
1.     Es urgente que los reglamentos y procedimientos de certificación sean claros y precisos para los pequeños productores, pues la legislación actual es ambigua en tanto sus términos se aplicación son generales y no se enfocan en una evaluación por sector productivo, región o país. 


2.     Por lo anterior, solicitamos que en la reglamentación europea principal y en la reglamentación secundaria sobre Certificación y comercialización FLO, se estipulen parámetros claros, definidos y específicos para la apicultura, ya que la mayoría de los lineamentos tienen una escritura y medición de cumplimiento en función de las actividades agrícolas, por ejemplo, se habla de hectáreas en lugar de número de apiarios y/o colmenas. Lo anterior, genera que tengamos complicaciones para entender y operar la reglamentación, sea esta primaria o secundaria.  
 
3.    Para el caso de la apicultura de las organizaciones socias de CAPIM S.C, que se desarrolla en la zonas geográficas del centro y sur del país, es muy difícil de establecer una delimitación de superficie en has. de manejo orgánico, más bien, esta medición se debe de estipular en número de apiarios y/o de colmenas. Además, es importante señalar que muchos pequeños productores de estas regiones apícolas  no cuentan con terrenos propios para el desarrollo de la actividad y muchas veces rentan los espacios. 

 4.    Se debe de considerar que muchas veces un pequeño productor inicia su actividad con un mínimo de 35 colmenas al iniciar su trabajo como socio de una organización y muchas veces sin terreno propio. Este apicultor (a) debe de comprometerse en aumentar el número de colmenas y de apiarios conforme va recibiendo capacitación y acompañamiento técnico. Por lo anterior, solicitamos que se implementen una medida para que el costo de certificación no aumente de manera anual, ya que afecta seriamente a los pequeños apicultores, los cuales también tienen que solventar el incremento de los costos de producción, procesamiento, comercialización y pago de otras certificaciones, además de enfrentar crisis ambientales, económicas y caídas de precios de la miel a nivel mundial.  

5. Pensamos que es necesario que en el tema de Comercio Justo haya una sola regulación para todos los países en los diferentes continentes, ya que las organizaciones y operadores tienen que pagar diferentes certificaciones de FLO, de acuerdo al país en donde se va a comercializar. 
 
6.     No estamos de acuerdo en la separación de operadores dentro de una misma organización, ya que ello debilita el empoderamiento colectivo de las organizaciones de productores/apicultores y lo deja en desventaja ante las negociaciones comerciales con los grandes importadores.  

Martha Torres Chávez
Directora General de CAPIM S.C

short_title: Farm Accountancy Data Network (FADN) - collecting data on farm incomes and its economic activities
Feedback:
About the variable A.OT.232.C Number of members of Producer Organisations (POs):
The legal basis of the FADN (Council Regulation n ° 1217/2009) defines "accouncy data" as ‘any technical, financial or economic data relating to an agricultural holding derived from accounts consisting of entries made systematically and regularly throughout the accounting year' (Article 2). In addition, it stipulates that data collection can be carried out by accountancy offices and not necessarily from the farmer (Article 7).
As a service provider of the farmer for the keeping of his accounts, the accounting office can legitimately ask his client to provide him the specific documents and information necessary for the establishment the accounts: invoices, securities ownership, loans and other operating commitments. On the other hand, the accounting office has no legitimacy to question the farmer on his commercial strategy or ON THE NUMBER OF MEMBERS OF POs TO WHICH HE SELLS ITS PRODUCTION, these questions not falling within the scope of the definition of accounting data.
These questions can only be addressed to the farmer and not to his accountant.
The obligation to collect this information would imply a direct investigation. A modification of this level cannot be proposed in the implementing acts of the FADN, because it is a substantial modification which falls under the basic act (Regulation (EC) 1217/2008).

short_title: Farm Accountancy Data Network (FADN) - collecting data on farm incomes and its economic activities
Feedback:
Concernant la variable A.OT.232.C Nombre de membres des organisations de producteurs (OP) :

La base juridique du RICA (règlement du Conseil n ° 1217/2009) définit les « données comptables » comme « toute donnée technique financière ou économique caractérisant une exploitation agricole, résultant d'une comptabilité comportant des enregistrements systématiques et réguliers au cours de l'exercice comptable » (article 2). En outre, il stipule que la collecte des données peut être effectuée par des offices-comptables et non obligatoirement auprès de l’agriculteur (article 7).

En tant que prestataire de service de l’agriculteur pour la tenue de sa comptabilité, l’office-comptable peut légitimement demander à son client de lui communiquer les documents et informations spécifiques nécessaires à l'établissement de ses comptes : factures, titres de propriété, emprunts et autres engagements de l'exploitation. En revanche, l’office-comptable n'a aucune légitimité pour interroger l'agriculteur sur sa stratégie commerciale ou SUR LE NOMBRE DE MEMBRES DES OP AUXQUELLES IL VEND SA PRODUCTION, ces questions n’entrant dans le champ de la définition des données comptables.

Ces questions ne peuvent s’adresser qu’à l'agriculteur et non à son comptable. 

L'obligation de collecter ces informations impliquerait une enquête directe. Une modification de ce niveau ne peut être proposée dans les actes d'exécution du RICA, car il s'agit d'une modification substantielle qui relève de l'acte de base (règlement (CE) 1217/2008).

Svar från Föreningen Lokal Utveckling Sverige (LUS) - svensk version

I sin feedback pekar ELARD på några viktiga aspekter LUS ställer sig bakom med följande förtydligande:

LUS instämmer i att det är välkommet att utvärdera om den gemensamma jordbrukspolitiken har bidragit till att stärka även socialekonomiska aspekter av territoriell utveckling.

LUS anser också att det är viktigt att bedöma den helhet begreppet CLLD står för, inte enbart LEADER som metod kopplat till Landsbygdsprogrammet, för att kunna greppa det mer omfattande arbete organisationen som leder arbetet i respektive leaderområde utfört i denna period med koppling till alla ingående fonder. Detta för att kunna visa vilka framgångsfaktorerna varit, långsiktiga Leader-effekter och om vi bidragit till att stärka landsbygden ur flera olika brett formulerade aspekter 

LUS menar att det är viktigt att i framtida program definiera och formulera tydliga långsiktiga effekter som LEADER / CLLD kan styra emot för att senare utvärderingar ska kunna bedöma om LEADER-metoden har varit effektiv på förväntat sätt

Att ELARD menar att LAG-strukturen i sig förmodas ge ett mervärde ställer sig LUS självklart också bakom liksom behovet av att ge europeiska LAG möjlighet att själva formulera de långsiktiga mål som lokalt eftersträvas, så att LAG kan utvärderas mot de egna målen i nästa skede 

LUS menar i likhet med ELARD att det kan vara intressant och lärorikt att studera de LAG som redan nu uppnått goda långsiktiga effekter och jämföra dem med LAG som uppvisar färre långsiktiga effekter, för att kunna hitta vad som skiljt deras arbete åt under innevarande programperiod. Eftersom denna typ av studie är mer tidsödande kan det dock vara svårt att hinna dra nytta av de resultat som framkommer redan inför planeringen av nästa programperiod.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development
Feedback:
ILDN represents Ireland’s 49 Local Development Companies (LDCs) that deliver LEADER and other EU/national initiatives.Until the last decade, Ireland was a forerunner in applying LEADER specificities - there has been slippage due to government policy but a strong commitment remains in LDCs/civil society. ILDN contends that the specificities offer an appropriate framework for the evaluation of LEADER.
The territorial approach
Area-based approaches enable a harnessing of territorial resources and the mobilisation of actors.  Rural development territories need to be small enough to ensure differentiation, and large enough to enable inter-actor networking. In Ireland, this implies enabling LEADER, where appropriate, to operate in smaller geographical units to local authorities (counties) and on a cross-jurisdictional basis.  Decisions in respect of identifying natural areas of development should be taken locally. Evaluation indicators ought to assess territorial assets and potential.
The bottom-up approach
Community-led local development (CLLD) – enabling citizen participation, strengthening social capital and cultivating local leadership – represents best practice. Animation and capacity building (A&CB) are valuable investments in generating innovation, fostering creativity and delivering sustainable projects. LDC Boards and sub-structures are important vehicles of participative democracy. ILDN supports the EU contention that public bodies should not dominate structures or processes. Evaluation indicators ought to capture social and human capital; processes ought to be participatory, and contribute to learning communities.
Horizontal partnership
As multi-stakeholder partnerships, LDCs are strongly positioned to act as conduits for a wide range of development initiatives, and have a proven track record in delivering programmes on behalf of government and EU. LDCs’ autonomy is integral to ensuring their innovation and the delivery of programmes in line with local needs, priorities and development potential.  Evidence-based decision-making, drawing on the expertise of all partners, gives LEADER a rounded set of perspectives. Thus, evaluation should contribute to reflexive practice and to transferring lessons to agencies and policies.
Innovation
The LEADER experience demonstrates a strong correlation between innovation and A&CB and the promotive roles assumed by Boards and by development officers.  Thus, Boards and staff need to focus more on innovation, territorial asset mapping and developing promoters’ capacity, rather than ensuring compliance with vacuous, administrative straightjackets. Civil society, social partner organisations and the private sector demonstrate a high innovative capacity, and ought therefore to play a promotive role in defining evaluation indicators and methodologies and in undertaking evaluations.
Integration & multi-sectorality
LEADER is a distinctive approach to development, a core innovation of which is that it avoids the silos that can be associated with programme delivery.  Instead, it enables multi-sectoral approaches - with one programme adding value to the other. Thus, evaluation indicators can extend beyond programme indicators and encompass the totality of partnership impacts on territorial resources.
Networking and inter-territorial cooperation
Spatial and institutional collaborations lead to knowledge transfers and increases in innovation.  There are merits in LEADER areas / groups jointly undertaking LEADER evaluations.  As with other specificities, decisions in this regard ought to be taken locally and in consultation with stakeholders, and LDCs ought to regain decision-making autonomy over inter-territorial projects.
Devolved financial management
Evaluation ought to be factored into local-level LEADER budgets, and allow for participatory approaches – including self-evaluation. LEADER boards ought to have ultimate sign-off powers in respect of resourcing, initiating and overseeing evaluations.

É indiscutível que o LEADER/DLBC através da metodologia "Abordagem ascendente", permite uma maior aproximação da Europa dos cidadãos, através da elaboração de estratégias integradas, multissectoriais privilegiando as parcerias, o trabalho em rede e a cooperação.
Os Grupos de Ação Local, muitos com mais de 20 anos de existência, com base na sua experiência e conhecimento do território, têm desempenhado um papel fundamental no desenvolvimento dos territórios rurais e costeiros, pelo trabalho que desenvolvem de proximidade com as comunidades, sendo necessário que seja reconhecido o seu trabalho, através da atribuição estatuto de agentes de desenvolvimento do território, não obrigado a um reconhecimento sempre que se inicia um novo período de programação. Estes grupos ao serem representantes genuínos das zonas rurais, ampliaram a dimensão da ferramenta LEADER desde o PIC LEDAER I, permitindo um desenvolvimento sustentável do território.

Nos Açores e no território de intervenção da GRATER (Ilhas Terceira e Graciosa), o LEADER/DLBC tem sido uma ferramenta essencial para o desenvolvimento desses territórios de pequena dimensão e de baixa densidade populacional, permitindo a promoção da diversificação da economia e do emprego, a promoção da melhoria da qualidade de vida nas zonas rurais e a preservação do património cultural, natural e ambiental.

No futuro e no período de programação 2021-2027, é necessário uma maior concertação entre o que é pretendido pela União Europeia e o que perspetivam os Estados Membros no que se refere ao desenvolvimento local: envolvência comunitária; transição para uma economia mais verde, preservação de património histórico, arquitetónico, cultural e natural; aproximar serviços e pessoas, dinamizar a economia e a criação de riqueza, promover os serviços digitais, são pilares essenciais para o desenvolvimento das pequenas comunidades.

Considerando a avaliação que esta a decorrer, e com a qual nos congratulamos, defendemos que é fundamental que no próximo período de programação (2021-2027), o LEADER/DLBC continue a permitir a:
•	Qualificação e diversificação da Economia Rural através da valorização do potencial económico dos recursos endógenos,
•	Criação de condições para a fixação e atração de população, através da promoção da coesão social e territorial,
•	Afirmação da identidade rural através da valorização do Património Cultural e Natural.

É fundamental avaliar o impacto das estratégias monofundo em comparação com as estratégias plurifundos e os modelos de governação que os estados membros implementam para a execução dessas estratégias.

Em conclusão o LEADER/DLBC, deve continuar a contribuir nas zonas rurais, para o aumento os níveis de empregabilidade, para aumentar o investimento e dinâmica económica no território de intervenção, melhorar a viabilidade e competitividade dos negócios existentes, melhorar a atratividade e dinamizar o território para a oferta turística, densificar os serviços básicos para a população rural, contribuir para a conservação e valorização do património rural, contribuir para a diversificação de atividades nas explorações agrícolas e contribuir para o aumento da produção de energia a partir de recursos renováveis.

SMEunited, the association of crafts and SMEs in Europe, has repeatedly stressed the importance and effectiveness of cooperation programmes managed by local level actors in local action groups (LAG). SMEunited believes that LEADER/CLLD actions have an essential impact on the activities of SMEs in rural areas and on the economic and social development of regions.

The general view is that LEADER/CLLD actions have proved to be a very efficient tool allowing for a good cooperation between local actors, in particular farmers and SMEs. However, the real economic, social and environmental impact of LEADER/CLLD actions is still unknown. SMEunited requests to assess the socio-economic impact of actions, analyse the partnership methods between local actors and conduct specific analysis of the impacts on SMEs and microenterprises, benefiting from LEADER/CLLD actions. 

Beyond the actions themselves, the LAG principle has become a method of cooperation and partnership between local actors and demonstrated its effectiveness. Therefore, we call for strengthening existing LEADER/CLLD actions and developing a large number of local initiatives. This can be achieved by greatly increasing the allocation of funds for this method under cohesion and rural development policy. We also ask for a comprehensive approach to simplify administrative procedures and give way to more simplified cost options.

SMEunited acknowledges the information activities of the LEADER-networks towards local stakeholders. However, national, regional and local SME organisations should be also entrusted with communication and dissemination activities addressing local businesses and decision-makers. In this regard, we ask for the involvement of SME organisations at all levels in programming, projecting and implementing of LEADER/CLLD actions.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development
Feedback:
The concept of an integrated local/rural development through LEADER approach has been playing a key role in the European Union policy. In this sense, this initiative is congratulated, as evaluation is a highly valuable tool for determining not just how successful the implementation of the LEADER measure may have been after resources and funding were applied, but rather (i) a broader view of its implementation (different implementation methods); (ii) the long-term sustainability of the outcomes for the rural communities; (iii) the always difficult to assessing LEADER/CLLD added value.
Our first comment is about the evaluation timing. Despite the great importance of the LEADER evaluation, it seems, however, rather extemporaneous if one of its main objectives is to help design better support for rural areas and communities under the CAP strategic plans and feed into the future Rural Development Police (and, we would say, also to the Cohesion Policy, considering the interdependence of Funds under mutifund CLLD).
For the purpose of evaluating the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development, the roadmap refers the use of data provided by Member States. However, and taking into account the RDPs monitoring and evaluation system, and as mentioned in the roadpmap, although Managing Authorities in Member States have to carry out RDP evaluation, which include LEADER, they do not necessarily analyze the instrument in the same way/depth, which makes it difficult to scale conclusions at EU level.
Thus, and with regard to the collection of information, it is also suggested that the roadmap includes the results of any initiatives at Member State level that may contribute to surpass some of the constraints associated with the quantity and quality of information to be used in the context of this evaluation process, namely those initiatives implemented by LAGs, networks of LAGs and National Rural Networks (NRNs).
In this context, the work developed in Portugal (Mainland) stands out. Having regard to the need to demonstrate the results of the application of European public policies through the LEADER approach, and in an unprecedented framework, the Regulation laying down common and general provisions for the European Structural Investment Funds, requires the mandatory evaluation of Local Development Strategies (LDS), implemented by the Local Action Groups (LAG) through Community Led-Local Development.
Taking advantage of the first experience of applying a legal framework for evaluation at the local level, it was considered useful to summarize the results of this capacity building process in a specific report with the aim of taking stock of its main virtues and main constraints. The main conclusions of the analysis of the LDS mid-term evaluation reports were that the conditions for the development of evaluation processes were not the most appropriate and the MAs and LAGs did not give the proper priority and importance to the evaluation process. 
This context has resulted in reports with very different levels of quality, and in which a large part of the LAGs did not follow the recommendation to adopt the more comprehensive evaluation concept (i.e., of the results of the animation activities, and the implementation and added value of LEADER approach), which, in a certain way, hampers the relevance and usefulness of the evaluation processes.
However, after the conclusion of the evaluation period, it was considered essential and opportune to carry out an analysis of the results included in the LDS mid-term Evaluation Reports. In this sense, it is being produced a Report that contains a cross-sectional analysis of the contents of 51 Reports made available by the LAGs, with a special focus on the conclusions and recommendations, as well as the main concerns and expectations for the next programming period (2021-2027). This report will be available in the next month.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development
Feedback:
Het LEADER-programma en de LEADER-werkwijze dragen in Nederland bij aan brede plattelandsontwikkeling. Het platteland is steeds minder afhankelijk van de agrarische sector als werkgever. Het aandeel van de primaire sector in de (plattelands)economie is gering. Om het platteland leefbaar te houden is een blijvende investering in het platteland en in de plattelandseconomie noodzakelijk om werkgelegenheid te garanderen. Met LEADER kunnen gebieden bottom-up bepalen op welke thema's er geïnvesteerd moet worden en wat er aansluit bij de behoeftes die er in dat specifieke gebied leven. Hierdoor wordt op lokaal niveau gewerkt aan diversificatie van de economie. De meeste LAG's in Nederland hebben hier maatregelen voor opgenomen in hun lokale ontwikkelingsstrategie. Diversificatie van de regionale economie gebeurt door een functieverbreding bij een agrarisch bedrijf of bij een niet-agrarisch bedrijf te ondersteunen of door te investeren in bijvoorbeeld de toeristische sector. Door te investeren in werkgelegenheid blijft een gebied aantrekkelijk om te wonen en blijven voorzieningen intact. Ook zijn er diverse projecten waarbij LEADER heeft bijgedragen aan de herbestemming van vrijgekomen (agrarisch) erfgoed.
 
LEADER investeert ook in het maatschappelijk weefsel van plattelandsgebieden, de basis van een vitaal landelijk gebied. LAG's hebben de mogelijkheid om maatregelen in hun strategie op te nemen die bijdragen aan de sociale cohesie in het gebied, bijvoorbeeld door te investeren in ontmoetingsplaatsen of het stimuleren van het verenigingsleven. 
 
Ook zijn er verschillende gebieden die doelstellingen in hun programma hebben opgenomen die ook terugkomen in de doestellingen van het nieuwe GLB. Er zijn diverse projecten uitgevoerd op het gebied van klimaatadaptatie, voedsel (waaronder korte ketens) en verduurzaming van publieksvoorzieningen. 
 
LEADER is als een van de laatste Europese programma's in staat een directe link te creëren tussen inwoners van de regio en de Europese Unie. Omdat LEADER-middelen vaak investeringen zijn die zichtbaar zijn voor een groot publiek brengt het Europa dichter bij de burger. Het wordt beleefd als een moderne manier van governance, waarbij een groot deel van de verantwoordelijk van een programma in het gebied zelf ligt. 
 
Aandachtspunt voor het goed kunnen uitvoeren van het LEADER-programma en van de bottom-up werkwijze is de aanwezige regeldruk. In de nieuwe GLB-periode vindt de verantwoording aan de EU meer op prestaties plaats dan voorheen. Niettemin zijn lidstaten in staat om een eigen invulling te geven aan de wijze en diepgang van verantwoording aan de EU en de positionering van het betaalorgaan in dit proces. Een te grote regeldruk vanuit de lidstaten kan ernstige afbreuk doen aan de LEADER-werkwijze. In onze lidstaat is meermaals aangedrongen op een vermindering van de regeldruk en de administratieve lasten. Nederland blinkt uit in de zwaarte er van. Dit heeft onmiskenbaar een negatieve invloed op initiatiefnemers die worden afgeschrikt door de regeldruk en de consequenties bij fouten. Dit treft juist de groepen van de bevolking waar LEADER in wil investeren.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development
Feedback:
En base a la experiencia y al conocimiento del territorio y de sus tejidos social y productivo, los Grupos de Acción Local, gestores del Programa Leader, debemos continuar nuestra labor, en cumplimiento con nuestras Estrategias de Desarrollo Local participativo para atender a los siguientes  factores del territorio , ya que de no ser corregidos, al margen de las iniciativas concretas que deseen implantarse será complicado revertir el proceso de despoblación que afecta al territorio rural.

1.	El fenómeno de la despoblación no es homogéneo, la despoblación de las distintas comarcas que conforman el medio rural  no está motivado por los mismos factores, por lo que es preciso focalizar las medidas  concretas a aplicar en función de las causas que determinan la evolución demográfica de cada territorio.
2.	Es necesario afrontar una agilización administrativa de los procesos productivos y una reducción drástica de la carga burocrática que llevan asociados, ya que en la actualidad este factor está actuando como un elemento desmotivador para las iniciativas emprendedoras y la inversión.
3.	Es necesario relacionar las ayudas y subvenciones con un retorno productivo en el territorio (incremento de la facturación, generación de empleo, incremento del nivel de transformación, apertura de nuevos mercados…), con el fin de “provocar” una mejora continua en el tejido empresarial y, por tanto, en las dinámicas económicas a escala local.
4.	Se han de relacionar las prestaciones sociales otorgadas a personas en situación de desempleo de larga duración a trabajos comunitarios o algún tipo de contrapartida que genere actividad en la localidad que habitan estas personas ya que, en la actualidad, están actuando como un factor de apalancamiento y de desmotivación de la iniciativa privada.
5.	En el corto plazo, no se ha de medir la eficacia de las medidas a adoptar en términos cuantitativos (crecimiento / decrecimiento de la población), el objetivo a corto plazo ha de buscar mejorar la calidad de vida de la ciudadanía rural y dinamizar las actividades social y económica. Es decir, la reversión de la tendencia demográfica ha de ser observada como una consecuencia de la mejora de la calidad de vida en el Medio Rural y, como tal, ha de ser un fin a alcanzar en el medio – largo plazo, por lo que se ha de tener paciencia en las estrategias de actuación que se planifiquen a partir de este proceso.
6.	Aplicación Rural Proofing.- Los servidores públicos deben tratar de comprender los problemas que tienen las áreas rurales particulares y adaptar soluciones a ellos. "La dificultad está en la concepción: si vas a abordar el problema, tienes que identificarlo". En lugar de intentar preservar los servicios exactamente como son, los responsables políticos deberían analizar la mejor manera de garantizar que las comunidades rurales puedan acceder fácilmente a los servicios que necesita, y no poner el acento en la forma en que se proporcionan. La complejidad del medio rural requiere de una visión propia en la aplicación de los servicios que garanticen el equilibrio del sistema y que no esté únicamente basada en términos de eficiencia económica
7.	Es necesario ser innovador y disruptivo, basándonos en el hecho empírico de que las medidas adoptadas hasta el momento no han cambiado la tendencia. Como ejemplo proponemos un CONTRATO ADAPTADO Y MODULAR DE COMPROMISO ENTRE JÓVENES Y EL ENTORNO RURAL.- Necesidad de establecer nuevos mecanismo de interrelación entre el medio rural y personas que quieren vincular su proyecto rural al medio rural. Por ello planteamos un modelo existente a nivel sectorial como es la “incorporación de jóvenes agricultores”, o el “ ticket rural asturiano”, en el que se establezca un contrato entre personas que quieran desarrollar su proyecto empresarial y vital en el medio rural, pero que permita adaptarse a las necesidades personales de cada uno y a las de la propia comunidad rural.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of LEADER on balanced territorial development
Feedback:
LEADER est aujourd’hui un outil financier pertinent dans les zones périurbaines et rurales :
-	En donnant l’occasion à ces territoires d’élaborer une stratégie locale de développement de manière ascendante, en créant une gouvernance locale pour gérer la mise en place de cette stratégie, basée sur un partenariat public/privé
-	En permettant de financer certains projets peu aidés par ailleurs (ingénierie territoriale, projets innovants) 
-	En permettant une animation dédiée sur le terrain, donnant ainsi une certaine lisibilité à ces fonds européens, et en paraissant proche des citoyens
-	En mettant des moyens pour la coopération avec d’autres territoires ruraux, en France et en Europe

Toutefois, d’importants freins tendent à limiter l’intérêt du recours à LEADER et sont susceptibles de discréditer les fonds européens auprès de petits porteurs de projets en milieu rural. On constate en effet :
-	Une importante lourdeur administrative pour la constitution, l’instruction et le contrôle des dossiers, généralement disproportionnée par rapport au montant financé ;
-	Que la déclinaison des stratégies LEADER en fiches-action « contrôlables » est certes vertueuse pour faciliter les opérations de contrôles postérieures, mais s’oppose sur le principe à l’accueil d’opérations réellement innovantes dans LEADER, car éloigne la perspective de pouvoir soutenir en cours de programmation un projet qui émergerait de façon atypique, porteur d’innovation dans ses réalisations ou sa méthode ;
-	Que la connaissance du dispositif LEADER sur le terrain est très dépendante de la qualité de l’animation mise en place par le GAL ;
-	Que les difficultés de mises en œuvre connues en France lors de la première moitié de la période de programmation 2014-2020 ont dissuadé certains porteurs (notamment privés) de recourir à LEADER
-	Que les enjeux rencontrés par les territoires ruraux gagneraient à être dissociés des politiques agricoles et forestières afin de gagner en lisibilité
-	Une difficulté de montage des plans de financement, en raison de l’incompatibilité du fonctionnement du FEADER en la matière avec la multitude de cofinanceurs en France, d’autant plus pour des petits projets en milieu rural (communes, EPCI, syndicats mixtes départements, Régions, Etat, diverses agences nationales ou régionales…).

Quelques pistes simples peuvent être imaginées pour gagner en lisibilité et en simplicité d’utilisation de l’outil LEADER :
-	Rendre les règles de cofinancement plus souples en s’inspirant des règles sur le FEDER et le FSE
-	Dissocier LEADER du FEADER, afin de sortir des règles de gestion trop strictes non adaptées aux petits projets
-	Travailler sur une plus grande proportionnalité des règles de gestion, afin de s’adapter aux projets à faibles montants.

short_title: Rules for organic production (supplementing rules)
Feedback:
The International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movement - EU Office (IFOAM EU) would like to recommend the following points: 

- First of all, it is crucial that the organic status of products is never affected when the products are produced under officially acknowledged catastrophic circumstances.

- On Recital (7): the proposed regulation does not cover the situation when - due to animal diseases as African Swine Fewer - the availability of young organic animals is affected by biosafety rules. Those circumstances should be also mentioned.

- On Recitals (9)  and (10): the proposed regulation does not cover the situation when permanent grassland is temporary flooded for many weeks in such a way that the area is not covered by water, but soaked, and the animals cannot access the area and the grass can not be mown with the use of tractors and relevant machines. Those circumstances should be also mentioned.

- On Recitals (9) and (10): the proposed regulation does not cover the situation when the area has slid after heavy rainfall and the farmer practically loosed his/her field or a part of the field. Those circumstances should be also mentioned.

- On Article 2: the situations indicated for Recitals (9) and (10) should be taken into account in Article 2 in relation to minimum access to outdoor areas. By way of derogation from point 1.8.1. of Part I of Annex II to Regulation (EU) 2018/848, for the production of plants and plant products other than plant reproductive material, non-organic plant reproductive material may be used when the use of organic or in-conversion plant reproductive material is not possible, provided that point 1.8.5.3. of Part I of that Annex are complied with.

short_title: Rules for organic production (supplementing rules)
Feedback:
De acuerdo con el registro de semillas de producción ecológica del Ministerio de Agricultura, en España operan 22 proveedores de semillas ecológicas que ofrecen un total de 995 productos de semillas ecológicas. En función del sector, cereales, forrajes, huerta y de la especie concreta, dentro de cada sector, que se quiere cultivar, hay un número muy variable de operadores de productores de semillas ecológicas. 9 en acelga, 7 en alfalfa, 11 en brécol (bóculi), 105 en tomate, 11 en cebada, 4 de trigo blando y ninguno en maíz, arroz, colza o guisante proteaginoso, pero si bajamos a la variedad concreta que quiere cultivar el agricultor nos podemos encontrar en numerosos casos que solo uno o dos proveedores lo tienen disponible, por poner cifras al asunto y ayudar a la comprensión de la enmienda de nueva incorporación que proponemos al texto de la Comisión. 

La falta de oferta de semilla de producción ecológica en España, hace que sea frecuente recurrir a la opción que permite el Reglamento UE 834/2007 y que se desarrolla en el Reglamento UE 889/2008, sobre la normativa de producción y etiquetado de los productos ecológicos. 

Pero es dramático para el productor, cuando la autoridad competente en autorizaciones excepcionales de las normas de producción, que contempla el artículo 45 del Reglamento UE 889/2008, te obliga a haber de comprar la variedad elegida a un solo proveedor, pues solo el ofrece esa variedad ecológica, pero la semilla ofertada no tiene la calidad de semilla que necesita el agricultor ecológico profesional.

Por todo lo expuesto, consideramos que se ha de incorporar un considerando nuevo y un punto 3 nuevo en el artículo 1 de la propuesta con el siguiente texto, con el objetivo de poder mantener la producción ecológica en España, hasta que no haya un mercado maduro de proveedores de semilla ecológica y material vegetal ecológico que permita cierta competencia y asegure no solo la disponibilidad de semilla ecológica o material vegetal ecológico, sino, también, de su calidad. 

Considerando:

La falta suficiente de oferta de semilla ecológica en determinados estados miembros hace necesario, para garantizar el mantenimiento de la producción ecológica, que los Estados miembros puedan equiparar la falta de oferta de semilla y material vegetal a una circunstancia catastrófica. 

Punto 3 nuevo del artículo 1:   

3. Los estados miembros, en función de la oferta de semilla de producción ecológica y material vegetal ecológico, podrán considerar la falta de oferta de semilla y material vegetal ecológico como una situación equivalente a una circunstancia catastrófica, tal y como indica el punto 1 de este artículo.

Feedback:
Stellungnahme zum  Entwurf einer delegierten Verordnung für Ausnahmen von der Öko-Verordnung

Die neue Verordnung 2018/848 enthält in Artikel 22 Regelungen für Ausnahmen von den Produktionsvorschriften. In Abs. 1 wird der Kommission die Befugnis zum Erlass delegierter Rechtsakte übertragen, in denen u. a. Kriterien für die Einstufung einer Situation als Katastrophenfall infolge „widriger Witterungsverhältnisse“, „Tierseuchen“, eines „Umweltvorfalls“, einer „Naturkatastrophe“ oder eines „Katastrophenereignisses“ im Sinne des Artikels 2 Absatz 1 Buchstaben h, i, j, k bzw. l der Verordnung (EU) Nr. 1305/2013 oder von ähnlichen Situationen festgelegt werden.

Im vorliegenden Entwurf einer delegierten Verordnung für Ausnahmen von der Öko-Verordnung werden allerdings nur Ausnahmen in Katastrophenfällen geregelt. Die Möglichkeit, in diesem Verordnungsentwurf auch Ausnahmen für "ähnliche Situationen" (z. B. Brandfälle) zu regeln, greift die Kommission nicht auf. Somit kann einem Biobetrieb, dessen Stall durch einen Brand zerstört wird, nicht die Möglichkeit gegeben werden, seine Tiere bis zur Wiederherstellung des Stalls bei konventionell wirtschaftenden Betrieben einzustellen. Die Kommission sollte hier auch Ausnahmemöglichkeiten schaffen und regeln.

In Art. 3 Abs. 6 des VO-Entwurfs wird offenbar davon ausgegangen, dass Bienenvölker nur in Katastrophenfällen zugefüttert werden. Diese Auffassung geht weit an der Realität vorbei.

Feedback:
Spanish Association of Sea Salt Producers (SALIMAR) welcomes the opportunity to comment on the draft. 

Regulation (EU) 2018/848 on organic production and labelling of organic products applies to certain other products closely linked to agriculture, such as sea salt and other salts for food and feed.

In relation to item (5) of the Draft delegated regulation - Ares(2019)5658405, “It is necessary to lay down in this Regulation the exceptional production rules that may be applied in case of catastrophic circumstances for plant, livestock, aquaculture and wine production in terms of derogation and their conditions”,  we would like to point out that “sea salt and other salts for food and feed” have not been included among the possible products to which exceptional production rules may apply in case of catastrophic circumstances. However, the production of “sea salt” may also be affected by catastrophic circumstances like “adverse climatic event”, “environmental incident”, “natural disaster” or “catastrophic event” in the same way as some of the products included in this item (plant, livestock, aquaculture and wine production). In case these circumstances occur, “organic salt producers” will not be able to use exceptional production rules.

To fix the terms of derogation and their conditions, it is necessary to previously stablish the Organic Salt Production Rules, which have now been deleted from the draft delegated act on Production Rules amending Regulation (EU) 2018/848. An EGTOP salt sub-group will be created in the next days and will work on the list of positive and negative production techniques and products and substances used. After EGTOP’s report, the Commission will prepare a new version of the draft delegated act defining the rules for organic salt. 

If salt production is included in the supplementing Regulation (EU) 2018/848 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards exceptional production rules in organic production, once the Organic Salt Production Rules are adopted, it could be possible to amend this supplementing Regulation by fixing the terms of derogation and their conditions in case of salt production. Thereby, salt producers would have legal certainty on the new rules that will apply in case of catastrophic circumstances like other operators have.

SALIMAR hopes the above raised concern will be taken into account.

short_title: Rules for organic production (supplementing rules)
Feedback:
In annate particolarmente sfavorevoli, e dunque a maggior ragione in caso di 'circostanze catastrofiche', le uve possono presentare problematiche serie di pre-ammostamento e conseguente estrazioni di frazioni polifenoliche indesiderate.
Si ritiene dunque utile, inserire all'art. 3 del presente Regolamento Delegato, la possibilità di utilizzare - nella produzione di vino biologico - il PVPP (polivinilpolipirrolidone). 

Il PVPP, omopolimero del vinilpirrolidone, è uno stabilizzante ideale per prevenire o correggere gli inconvenienti dovuti ai processi ossidativi che si possono verificare nel corso della vinificazione e, soprattutto, della conservazione dei vini.
Il PVPP è una polvere leggera, igroscopica, di colore bianco. Insolubile in acqua, in solventi organici e nel vino. Le sue proprietà nel prevenire le ossidazioni e nell’eliminarne le conseguenze sono dovute alla sua fortissima capacità di adsorbire i polifenoli flavanici, substrato fondamentale (catechine ed epocatechine) di tutti i fenomeni di maderizzazione e di imbrunimento dei vini bianchi e rosati. Inoltre, l’impiego di PVPP migliora la fragranza, l’aroma ed il gusto nel vino, in quanto rimuove l’eccesso di polifenoli che conferiscono ruvidezza ed astringenza al sapore del vino, accentuando le migliori sensazioni sensoriali senza conferire alcun off-flavour.
Per la sua alta specificità d'azione il P.V.P.P. è consigliato nel trattamento di vini di pregio sia per prevenire che per curare gli effetti delle ossidazioni a carico delle sostanze fenoliche. In particolare trova impiego nelle chiarifiche o in filtrazione allo scopo di migliorare le caratteristiche dei vini bianchi ossidati, per eliminare la tonalità gialla del colore dei vini rossi per limitare la tannicità di vini rossi giovani. 
Il PVPP viene utilizzato durante la flottazione dei mosti per eliminare i composti fenolici ossidati. Altro passaggio in cui il pvpp risulta efficace è nella fase post fermentativa in quanto elimina aromi amari dovuti a polifenoli o fecce di lievito pesanti.
Durante la stabilizzazione proteica è particolarmente utile per eliminare i leucoantociani che possono creare il fenomeno del pinking, ovvero quando un vino bianco tende a prendere la colorazione rosa, o di browning, un vino che diventa color marrone.
Per i motivi sopra riportati il PVPP è una validissima alternativa al carbone enologico che a differenza del polimero sopracitato non ha azione selettiva. Infatti, il carbone, come il PVPP, agisce sul colore e sui polifenoli ossidati, ma agisce anche su tutte le frazioni aromatiche presenti nei vini generando perdita di aromi nobili e degrado della caratterizzazione del vitigno e del territorio.
E’ in pratica un trattamento squisitamente qualitativo al fine di dare maggiori possibilità ai vini biologici sul mercato anche in annate meno fortunate.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback:
The organic movement have committed to the goal of 100% organic seeds. However, if organic seeds are not available or not available in sufficient quantity, clear rules are essential to enable farmers to use non-organic untreated plant reproductive material (PRM). In this context, Ekologiska Lantbrukarna welcomes the inclusion of points 1.8.5.6-7, which establishes that competent authorities of the member-states shall create a ‘positive’ list of species, subspecies or groups of varieties for which it is established that organic or in-conversion material is available; and are allowed to grant general authorization for the use of non-organic untreated PRM when no organic material is registered in the database. General authorizations are essential to prevent an unnecessary administrative burden and costs, particularly for small-scale growers with a diversified production, when no organic PRM are available. In the other hand it is important that the production of organic PRM is awarded and stimulated and that the same conditions regarding PRM applies for all organic farmers.  

    The opportunity for all seed companies to register organic PRM in all member states might however lead to difficulties for the assessment of the varieties’ suitability (‘agronomic and pedoclimatic conditions, point 1.8.5.1 c) for a given region/country. If there is no requirement for seeds companies to deliver in a given country when they register organic PRM, there is a risk that delivery costs fall on the growers themselves, which would lead to different conditions for growers depending on their country.
 
    The requirement to keep record of the quantities of non-organic untreated PRM used by organic farmers (points 1.8.5.5 and 1.8.5.7) brings a risk of administrative burden to growers if they have to register themselves their use of non-organic untreated PRM (in any other way than ordering/receiving an invoice/delivery note). Such a requirement could impact the willingness of small-scale growers with a diversified production to certify their production. This is particularly unfortunate given the increase in small-scale horticulture, with direct sales to consumers, which we are currently seeing in Sweden.
 
    While the DA and its annex put organic and in-conversion PRM by and large on the same level, point 1.8.5.1 suggests that organic seed is still prioritized above in-conversion seed. This raises some practical questions about how the competent authorities should handle this. This aspect puts high requirements for the database that needs to be continually updated and easy to use & understand for the users. In addition, many unclarities remain regarding the marketability of in-conversion PRM. The demand for in-conversion PRM is based on the availability of organic PRM and is therefore difficult to estimate at the time seed production is planned. There are reports from seed companies avoiding the production of in-conversion PRM since it is perceived as difficult to market. It is therefore crucial that the situation arising from the New Organic Regulation is clarified to seed producers. The production of seeds during the conversion has been a well-established, and profitable crop for farmers during their conversion to organic farming. The regulation for ‘in-conversion’ PRM needs to guaranty a certain profitability to the sector (producers and seed companies), otherwise it risks being pointless and leading to in-conversion PRM being sold as conventional.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback:
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

wir als Deutsche Saatveredelung AG produzieren ein breites Angebot an Futtergräser und Leguminosen aus ökologischer Produktion in Europa und sind ein wichtiger internationaler Lieferant für viele Bio-Betriebe in Deutschland, Dänemark, Polen, Niederlande, Österreich etc.
Die aktuelle Unklarheit zum Umstellungssaatgut, hat uns bereits dazu gezwungen, dass wir viele Umstellungsbetriebe bei der Produktion von Saatgut für die Ernte 2021 abweisen mussten. Es ist zwingend erforderlich, dass eine Gleichstellung der Saatgutproduktion auf Umstellungsflächen mit der auf Ökoflächen zu ermöglichen. Für viele Umstellungsbetriebe ist die Vermehrung von Saatgut auf Umstellungsflächen gerade in den ersten beiden wirtschaftlich schwierigen Umstellungsjahren ein wichtiges wirtschaftliches Einkommen. Durch die Gleichstellung der Umstellungsware mit anerkannter Öko-Ware im Saatgutbereich sind wir als Saatgutproduzenten in der Lage, deutlich höhere Preise an unsere Vermehrer zu zahlen (Öko-Preise).

Für die Saatgut Versorgung für den ökologischen Markt, sind die Erzeugnisse auf Umstellungsflächen ein wichtiger Wachstum Motor und sollten zwingend in der ganzen EU, weiterhin, natürlich mit gesonderter Kennzeichnung, als Saatgut mit Öko-Saatgut als Einzelkomponente und in Saatgutmischungen gleichgestellt werden.

Nur wenn der Weg der Umstellung wirtschaftlich beschritten werden kann, können die Ökoflächen innerhalb der EU ausgeweitet werden.
Wir bitten dringendst um eine klarere Ausarbeitung des Gesetzestextes!

i.A.

Sascha Sokoll

Feedback:
Centrum Jakości AgroEko Sp. z o.o. is one of certification bodies in Poland. As such, we would like to highlight a few issues concerning the proposed draft and amendments of Annex II.

According to the point 1.8.5.1. (b) it would be advisable to precise the term "reasonable time" in regard to ordering the specific plant reproductive material (PRM). It should be pinpointed what are the specific premises of the "reasonable time" or this time should be definied within the scope of the Annex (one week / two weeks / the year or two before to enable the PRM producer to grow the material???).

According to the point 1.8.5.1. (c) it should be described what are the possible/accaptable forms of justification that registered alternatives of PRM are not appriopriate for the operator. Should it be a producer declaration or an expert opinion?

According to the point 1.8.5.3. (second paragraph) the expression "where appriopriate" should be replaced with exact infromation what are the cases when the parcel should be the subject of conversion period. If there is no exact information on the prerequisites for land conversion after using non-organic PRM  treated with prescribed chemical treatment, there will be questions left: who will decide if it is appropriate to convert the parcel? Why, if PRM is authorised and the treatment was prescribed in accordance with Reg. (EU) 2016/2031, the parcel is a possible subject to conversion?

We would also like to support the view that in-conversion PRM should need no special authorisation.

Wir begrüßen die letzten vorgenommenen Änderungen im delegierten Rechtsakt.

Wir appellieren jedoch bezüglich der Verwendung von Bio-Saatgut und Umstellungs-Saatgut noch folgenden wichtigen Punkt zu überdenken und zu adaptieren:

Generell unterstützen wir die bevorzugte Verwendung von Bio-Saatgut und die damit einhergehende Förderung der Verfügbarkeit von Bio-Saatgut. Jedoch ist der Punkt 1.8.5.1 derzeit so formuliert, dass er negative Auswirkungen auf die Verfügbarkeiten und Entwicklungen hätte.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback: In der neuen EU-Verordnung ist zwingend eine Gleichstellung der Saatgutproduktion auf Umstellungsflächen mit der auf Bioflächen zu verankern/zu ermöglichen. Die umso mehr da der Bedarf an Biosaatgut mit der weiteren Förderung umstellungswilliger Betriebe weiter steigen wird. Bereits jetzt ist die Nachfrage nach Biosaatgut kaum zu decken. Dies resultiert neben den schwierigen Witterungsverhältnissen der letzten Jahre (Dürre in weiten Teilen Europas), aber auch der Tatsache, dass es nur noch wenige Landwirte gibt, die sich mit einer Saatgutvermehrung auf ihren Feldern beschäftigen wollen. Saatgut ist nicht einfach "Ernte", sondern muss hohe Qualitätsanforderungen hinsichtlich Reinheit und Keimfähigkeit erfüllen. Die Voraussetzungen dafür beginnen auf dem Feld und bedürfen umfangreiches Spezialwissen. Die Vermehrer tragen also doppeltes und damit hohes wirtschaftliches Risiko. Bei einer Nicht-Gleichstellung von Saatgut aus Umstellung und Biosaatgut werden umstellungswillige konventionelle Saatgutvermehrer nicht auf Bio umstellen und was viel schlimmer wäre, aus der Saatgutproduktion aussteigen. Aus langjähriger Erfahrung mit Vermehrern wissen wir, dass wenn sie mit der Saatgutproduktion aufhören, später auch nicht wieder in die Saatgutproduktion einsteigen. Sie gehen damit nicht nur der Saatgutwirtschaft als Produkzenten verloren, sondern  mit ihnen verliert die Landwirtschaft damit auch ein hohes Maß an Spezialwissen. Dies wäre äußerst bedauerlich und insbesonder auch mit Blick auf wichtige Förderprojekte der EU (Lifeseed/Horizon 2020) geradezu kontraproduktiv. Die Kommission würde dem Bioanbau damit einen "Bärendienst" erweisen. Auch aus wirtschaftlicher Sicht kann man umstellungswilligen Landwirten nicht erklären, dass sie die Saatgutproduktion nach Biorichtlinien durchführen sollen, sie die hohen Qualitätsstandards an Saatgut erfüllen, aber ihre Produkte dann konventionell vermarkten müssen. Auch mit den Beihilfen für die Umstellung auf Bio ist es für einen Landwirt dann nicht möglich, Wirtschaftlichkeit für seinen Betrieb herzustellen.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback:
BÖLW is the German umbrella organisation of organic farmers, processors and retailers. On behalf the German organic sector, we would like to give the following comments:

We greatly appreciate the changes proposed in this delegated act. In particular, the closer alignment of organic and in-conversion plant reproductive material (PRM) far better represents the underlying logic and aspirations of this regulation and is a step in the right direction, but not yet sufficient. The currently unclear status of in-conversion PRM has already caused some upheaval on the German seed market. We therefore urge the EU Commission to further clarify that in-conversion PRM can be used just like organic PRM without the requirement of a special authorisation. We propose changing point 1.8.5.1 as follows: 

"1.8.5.1. By way of derogation from point 1.8.1 the operator may use in-conversion plant reproductive material in accordance with point (a) of the second subparagraph of Article 10(4) without requiring an authorisation. 
Where organic and in-conversion plant reproductive material is not available and where data collected in the database referred to in Article 26 (1) or the system shows that the qualitative and quantitative needs of the operator regarding relevant organic or in conversion plant reproductive material are not met, competent authorities may authorise the use of non-organic plant reproductive material subject to points 1.8.5.3. to 1.8.5.7."

These changes are important to provide sufficient amounts of PRM which can be used by organic farmers. Making in-conversion PRM too difficult to access and to market would likely counteract the intent of this regulation by decreasing in-conversion PRM and thus potential future organic PRM and therefore requiring more derogations for non-organic PRM. 

A further improvement we would like to highlight is the inclusion of a compulsory national list of species, subspecies or groups of varieties for which no authorisations are to be granted (Point 1.8.5.6). This is important for the further expansion of organic PRM. In Germany we have made good experiences with such a list, which in our case is drawn together by authorities in cooperation with experts from the organic sector. At the same time the reintroduction of general derogations (Point 1.8.5.7) is valuable because it is a pragmatic solution to current realities on the organic PRM market. 

Furthermore, the clarification that the plant protection product treatments prohibited in point 1.8.5.3 are those taking place after harvest was important in order to not exclude non-organic vegetative material from derogations. In particular for many crops that are reproduced vegetatively there is little to no organic PRM available. The predominant (non-organic) practice of vine PRM for wine production however currently uses a fungicide in order to protect vines during storage over winter. We would therefore suggest, that a transition period of five years for this specific practice be considered, in order to adapt the production process and find more adequate alternatives to secure healthy vines for organic wine growers.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback:
LRF supports that there will be possible for Member States to grant general authorization of derogations if appropriate organic reproductive material is not available. This is very important.
In order for the regulation to not imply a risk of spreading severe pests, it is important that farmers are not forced to choose seeds or reproductive material that have an unacceptable high risk of pests. We believe that in some cases it might be better to use non-organic reproductive material in order to provide better preconditions to produce according to organic principles. This would mean that when you look at possible derogations, one must take regard to the significance of for example plant health as an important part of its appropriateness as reproductive material. 
This can partly be the case when the risk of infection is relatively low, but the consequences are very serious and affect the existence of the entire company and other related companies. There are a number of serious quarantine pests. Seed potatoes can spread various diseases and nematodes. Tomato seeds can spread Clavibacter, Pepinomosaic Virus or ToBRFV. The latter can also be spread by a number of relatives to tomato. Particularly organic greenhouse cultivation is exposed, as a cultivation with soil beds cannot be decontaminated in the same way as conventional greenhouse cultivation. The grower's possibility to choose reproductive material that is controlled and safe must not be diminished in the case of crops with such risks. It may be about not selecting reproductive material grown in regions where quarantine pests occur (for example nematodes on potatoes). It can also be that the producer may choose seed that has been virus tested or cultivated according to Good Seed and Plant Practices (GSPP) to avoid Clavibacter.
The grower also needs to be able to avoid infections that are common, such as leaf mold in onion sets and seed potato. It is common that an infected onion or tuber is found in the seed batch that the grower buys. This type of infection then spreads rapidly to the entire field. The cultivation must then be stopped prematurely and the harvest will be considerably lower. There is also a great risk that the infection will spread to other crops that will need to increase chemical control.
The reproductive material should meet a certain standard that guarantees plant health. Good Seed and Plant Practices (GSPP) could be such a standard that should be a reason for granting derogations.
We believe that when general derogations are made by the authorities, consideration must be taken to plant health. It must be clear to the grower what tests and controls have been subject to the reproductive material, especially those that have a high risk of containing pests, in order for the grower to make a proper decision of safe reproductive material.
We do not think that a species requirement should be made if the organic reproductive material is untested whereas there is conventional reproductive material that is tested. It should neither be demanded if the organic reproductive material is from regions that are confirmed with pests. Plant health must go first.
Finally, we are skeptical about the requirement for Member States to report quantities of used reproductive material to the European Commission, according to point 1.8.5.5. It seems like an unnecessary demand that would mean extra administrative burden for all involved.

short_title: Organic food - use of in-conversion and non organic plant reproductive material
Feedback:
The organic movements have committed to the goal of 100% organic seed. However, if organic seed is not available or not available in sufficient quantity, clear rules are essential to enable farmers to use non-organic untreated plant reproductive material (PRM). In this context, IFOAM EU welcomes the inclusion of point 1.8.5.6, which establishes that competent authorities of the member-states shall create a ‘positive’ list of species, subspecies or groups of varieties for which it is established that organic or in-conversion material is available. 
While the DA and its annex put organic and in-conversion PRM by and large on the same level, point 1.8.5.1 suggests that organic seed is still prioritized above in-conversion seed. This is pertinent, as preferably organic PRM should be used. However, this raises some practical questions about how the (delegated) competent authorities (often certifiers) should handle this. It should be clear that no authorisation is required to use in-conversion PRM. In addition, IFOAM EU wants to make you aware that there is apparently still some unclarity among seed producers regarding the marketability of in-conversion PRM and there are reports from seed companies avoiding the production of PRM on in-conversion fields since it is perceived as difficult to market. It is therefore crucial that the situation arising from the New Organic Regulation is clarified to seed producers. 
Regarding the terminology used, varieties should be replaced by ‘groups of varieties’ in the delegated act and the annex. This concerns: DA point (6) as well as points 1.8.5.6 & 1.8.5.7 of the DA annex. This is important since we cannot have a list of non-derogation for a specific variety but only for subspecies or groups of varieties. In general, it is crucial to emphasize that while the purpose of the database (referred to in Art. 26(1) or Art. 26 (2)(a)) is to list varieties, the needs for a ‘non-authorization’ list (point 1.8.5.6) or a ‘general authorization’ list (point 1.8.5.7) are different in that they should list species, subspecies or groups of varieties and NOT single varieties. Following from this, also point 1.8.5.7 (b) should be changed, as there should be no general authorizations for single varieties.

In point 1.8.5.1 (d), reference to the quality can only be relevant for vegetative PRM, as the quality of seeds is strictly defined by the horizontal legislation. 

In point 1.8.5.3, a transition period exclusively for vines would be helpful to find adequate solutions that are compatible with organic products. This relates to the current practice in some Member States of vine plants being treated before they are stored over winter and which would require changes in procedure from non-organic producers of grape. Simply cutting the treatment might result in substantial loss of newly planted vines for organic farmers in some Member States.

short_title: Evaluation of the EU agricultural promotion policy
Feedback:
Fur Europe considers agricultural promotion policy an important tool in supporting EU agriculture. Therefore, it regrets that the eligibility criteria in Article 5 of Reg. 1144/2014 do not cover fur.

While the fur sector in the EU maintains its profitability without any direct public support, EU remains a global leader (over 50%) in fur production. Majority of this fur is exported outside of EU, wanted for its superior quality and production standards and methods.

At times, however, the market faces specific challenges, putting in risk tens of thousands EU citizens whose subsistence depends on it. In such cases, EU agricultural promotion policy should be able to help the sector to restore normal market conditions.

Annex I of TFEU includes fur animals but does not include fur as the product. Reg. 1144/2014 correctly anticipates such exclusions and in its Art. 5 allows, especially via Annex I of this regulation, for some sectors or products excluded by TFEU to be part of the EU agricultural promotion policy. These are, among others, cotton (raw material for textile and clothing) or alcoholic beverages.

Therefore, Fur Europe considers it necessary to expand the Annex I of Reg. 1144/2014 to include fur and calls for European Commission to initiate such procedure.

short_title: Evaluation of the EU agricultural promotion policy
Feedback:
Euromontana est très satisfaite de voir l'évaluation de ce programme de promotion, qui a permis d'apporter une contribution importance à la promotion des produits alimentaires. Afin d'augmenter encore son efficacité, nous recommandons: 
- Renforcement du budget dédié aux Sigles d’Identification d’Origine et de Qualité (SIQO) . Le renforcement de la notoriété des SIQO – à date trop peu reconnus par les consommateurs - passe par des programmes de promotion ambitieux et donc d’ampleur budgétaire conséquente. Si Euromontana reconnait l’importance des deux lignes de travail actuellement dédiées aux SIQO (pour les programmes simple et multi), nous regrettons néanmoins que leur montant reste encore trop faible au regard des objectifs de promotion de la Commission européenne. Ces enveloppes, diluées sur tous les SIQO (AOP, IGP, bio, RUP…), sur tous les pays de l’UE ne permettront pas des progrès significatifs pour améliorer la notoriété des SIQO (cf. données Eurobaromètre n°389). 
Euromontana suggère donc une augmentation de la part financière de la ligne dédiée aux SIQO et d’avoir des sous-catégories spécifiques pour les différents schémas : AOP, IGP, bio, produits de montagne, RUP afin de faciliter leur valorisation et leur reconnaissance par les citoyens européens. Cela permettrait également de mieux répondre à l’obligation qui est faite dans le règlement 1144/2014 de porter de prendre en compte les handicaps des régions montagneuses, insulaires et ultrapériphériques. 

- La majorité des IG enregistrées en UE ont très naturellement un marché très local. Peu d’entre elles ont une capacité à exporter intra UE et vers des pays tiers. Idem pour les produits de montagne. Aussi, la majorité de ces produits de qualité ne profitent pas des augmentations budgétaires pour les actions dédiées aux pays tiers. Ce qui renforce la nécessité d’augmenter le budget des lignes de travail dédiées aux programmes simple et multi car peu de schémas de qualité iront candidater sur les lignes pour les pays tiers. Plus précisément, la ligne programme simple doit être renforcée puisque peu de produits de montagnes ont une capacité à mettre en marché des produits au-delà d’une échelle nationale. 

- Il pourrait également être intéressant de pouvoir cumuler les critères (ou les topics) (ce qui ne semble pas possible aujourd’hui). Par exemple si un projet simple sur une IGP régionale (donc dans un seul pays) concerne en même temps un produit de la filière porc, alors ça pourrait améliorer le ranking. Il semble qu’aujourd’hui on doive choisir : soit proposer un projet simple dans le topic « quality schemes » soit proposer un projet dans le topic « filière prioritaire porc ».

- Sur l’aspect pratique, nous souhaiterions avoir une plus grande lisibilité du calendrier en avance afin de connaitre la date de soumission des candidatures. Cela faciliterait le travail notamment des petites structures, qui ne peuvent pas forcément mobiliser de nombreuses ressources pour répondre à ces appels et qui doivent pouvoir s’organiser et connaitre en avance les dates de soumission.
