short_title: Food & feed imports -“first-come, first-served” tariff quotas (delegated rules)
Feedback:
The consultation refers to the ongoing comprehensive revision of the management rules for the agricultural sector's first-come, first-served quotas (FCFS). 
As with the licence quotas currently under revision, the individual quota-specific provisions for the FCFS quotas will be brought together in a delegated regulation and an implementing regulation. In addition, some licence quotas that have been little used will be converted into FCFS quotas.

As far as can be seen at present, hardly any material changes are planned compared to the previous regulations. Except for the abolition of import rights and licences, the previous handling of the quotas is provided for, whereby the obligation to provide evidence pursuant to Article 5 of Regulation (EC) No 412/2008 for quotas under the a+b rule is not applicable.
Among the FCFS quotas, which will in future be administered via the combined legal acts, is also the hqb II quota under EC No. 481/2012. Its function remains essentially the same, except for the definition of "frozen" beef.

Some FCFS quotas, such as the import quota 09.0833 for sheep meat from Iceland, are not (yet) covered by the present draft of Annex I. In addition, the related legislation (EU 2018/1206) is not (yet) repealed. 

UECBV requests the justification for this and demands that transparency and congruence must be ensured with regard to the comprehensive new regulations.

short_title: Rules on the evaluation of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme
Feedback:
We welcome the opportunity to comment on the draft Commission Delegated Regulation as regards the evaluation of the implementation of the school scheme. 

The European Plant-based Food Sector has long advocated in favour of including plant-based alternatives to dairy products which are made from European crops in the scope of the School Milk Scheme. All plant-based foods have a role to play in a balanced and sustainable diet and deserve to be promoted as foods made from high quality agricultural products grown in Europe. In addition, children who cannot consume dairy products due to milk allergy or lactose intolerance are deprived from alternative sources of protein, which certain plant-based drinks can provide. Most of these products also contain calcium matching the levels that can be found in dairy products. 

While we understand that the evaluation will focus on the implementation of the School Milk Scheme in its current form, i.e. with plant-based foods outside of the scope, we would like to point out two specific considerations to be taken into account: 

-	One of the objectives of the Scheme is to educate children about healthy eating habits. A healthy diet is a balanced diet, in which plant-based foods can play a role, thanks notably to their low saturated fat content. Several national dietary guidelines have integrated plant-based alternatives to dairy products in healthy eating recommendations. 

-	Recent changes to the Scheme have made flavoured dairy products eligible for support within the Scheme. We believe this goes against the above mentioned objective of promoting healthy eating, given the total sugar content of these products. As a matter of comparison, a chocolate-flavoured dairy milk contains approximately 11 g of sugar per 100 ml, whereas the total sugar content of a chocolate-flavoured soy drink which is typically 7.5 g /100 ml.

Beyond the scope of this evaluation of the School Milk Scheme, we would like to take this opportunity to once again call for the inclusion of sustainable plant-based foods products in agricultural promotion schemes, as suggested by the European Commission in its report on the development of plant proteins in the EU and in line with the ambition of the upcoming Farm to Fork Strategy for sustainable food systems.

short_title: Evaluation and checks of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme
Feedback:
This feedback is submitted on behalf of the Swedish industry organisation Plant-food Sweden (Växtbaserat Sverige), which is an industry organization representing food producing companies of plant-based food and drinks. 

Plant-food Sweden appreciates the opportunity to provide the Commission with feedback on the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme and would like to submit following comments: 

When evaluating the school milk scheme, Plant-food Sweden  would like to stress that one indicator that should be taken into account and consequently included in the evaluation of the school milk scheme is the change in direct and indirect consumption of drinking milk by children (quantity and/or frequency). As such, the school scheme hopes to increase the daily intake of healthy foodstuffs with children. Following this line of reasoning, Plant-food Sweden advocates the extension of the school scheme (as limited under Article 23 of Regulation 1308/2013 establishing a common organisation of the markets in agricultural products (COM(2018)0394 – 2018/0218(COD)) to also cover nutritious plant-based alternatives to ‘milk’ drinks and processed milk products. 

The exclusion of plant-based alternatives to ‘milk’ drinks, the current school scheme distorts the market. According to the preamble of Regulation 1308/2013 (Article 23), the purpose of the scheme is to give children the opportunity to drink and eat more of these goods and to permanently increase the proportion of these products in the children's diet at the age when their eating habits are established. Nutritious fortified plant-based alternatives to milk and milk products have existed for many years and their inclusion in the school scheme can be justified by the following reasons: 

•	Ensuring equality for children with intolerances or allergies: The school scheme fails to recognize that lactose intolerance, and to some extent cow’s milk protein allergy, is a common condition with many children. Furthermore, many children/families abstain from animal-based dairy on cultural and/or ethical grounds, or as a means to reduce their climate footprint. In many schools, children are required to produce documentation of a disability or a special medical or dietary need in order to receive an alternative to cow’s milk. In addition, there are schools where plant-based alternative drinks, if available, cost the pupil extra. The school milk scheme hence risks leading to unfair treatment of children who either cannot, or do not want to drink cow’s milk by limiting the choices available. 

•	Ensuring children have access to a wide taste palate of healthy foodstuffs, to encourage healthy eating habits: It is essential for young people to encounter a range of tastes, including of plant-based foodstuffs, to ensure that they develop a full range of taste preferences as their palate develops. Extending the school scheme to also include plant-based drinks would ensure this and will remove this artificial and unfair regulatory barrier. 

•	Plant-based foods and drinks from a public health and climate perspective: Research, IPCC among others, shows that a change in the food system and a shift to consumption of plant-based food and drinks is needed to tackle challenges linked to climate change and public health, as well as managing to feed the growing population. This also recognized and addressed in the EU Initiatives Green deal and Farm to Fork-strategy. Plant-based alternatives to dairy have a considerably lower carbon footprint compared to their animal-based counterparts.

As a conclusive remark, Plant-food Sweden would like to urge the Commission to ensure policy coherence between the current proposal and, the up-coming proposals of the Farm to Fork strategy and the Green Deal. We are looking forward to a continued dialogue with the European Commission.

short_title: Evaluation and checks of the EU school fruit, vegetables and milk scheme
Feedback:
The school scheme hopes to increase the daily intake of healthy foodstuffs with children. When following this line of reasoning, Oatly advocates for the extension of the school scheme (limited under Article 23 of Regulation 1308/2013 establishing a common organisation of the markets in agricultural products (COM(2018)0394 – 2018/0218(COD)) to also cover nutritious plant-based alternatives to ‘milk’ drinks and processed milk products. 

By not including plant-based alternatives to ‘milk’ drinks, the current school scheme distorts the market. According to the preamble of Regulation 1308/2013 (Article 23), the purpose of the scheme is to give children the opportunity to drink and eat more of these goods and to permanently increase the proportion of these products in the children's diet at the age when their eating habits are established. Nutritious fortified plant-based alternatives to milk and milk products have existed for many years and their inclusion in the school scheme can be justified by the following reasons: 

• Encouraging children’s uptake of nutrients by broadening the offer under the school scheme with nutritious plant-based drinks: Plant-based drinks offer a healthy addition to the products offered under the school scheme, since they are unsweetened, rich in unsaturated fat and low in saturated fats. They also contain several nutrients including vitamins, minerals, and fibre. Many of these nutrients may not be consumed in adequate amounts by children and some of these are not provided by cow’s milk, for example, vitamin D and fibre. 

• Ensuring children have access to a wide taste palate of healthy foodstuffs, to encourage healthy eating habits: It is essential for young people to encounter a range of tastes, including of plant-based foodstuffs, to ensure that they develop a full range of taste preferences as their palate develops. Extending the school scheme to plant-based drinks would ensure this and will remove this artificial and unfair regulatory barrier. 

• Ensuring equality for children with intolerances or allergies: The school scheme fails to recognize that lactose intolerance or a cow’s milk protein allergy are common conditions. Furthermore, many children/families abstain from animal-based dairy on cultural and ethical grounds, or to reduce their climate footprint. In many schools, children are required to produce documentation of a disability or a special medical or dietary need in order to receive an alternative to cow’s milk. In addition, there are schools where plant milks, if available, cost the pupil extra. The school scheme hence risks leading to unfair treatment of children who cannot or do not want to drink cow’s milk by limiting the choices available. 

• Encouraging children to be conscious about the environmental impact of their food and drinks consumption:  Research (https://www.ipcc.ch/site/assets/uploads/2019/08/Fullreport-1.pdfs) shows that a change in the food system and a shift to increase the consumption of plant-based food is needed to tackle challenges linked to climate change and public health, as well as managing to feed the growing population. This also recognized and addressed in the EU Initiatives Green deal and Farm to Fork-strategy. Plant-based alternatives to dairy have a considerably lower carbon footprint compared to their animal-based counterparts. Furthermore, it is important that we give children the opportunity to try more plant-based foods and drinks. The demand for plant-based nutritious food and drinks should not be seen as a consumer trend, but as a permanent shift in consumption habits, led by the younger generation (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/360/6392/987).

For all of the above reasons, Oatly strongly believes that the school scheme should be amended to ensure parity between animal-based milk and plant-based drinks so school children across the EU have access to this wider range of products.

short_title: Organics production rules
Feedback:
Introduction to the Soil Association
The Soil Association was founded in 1946 by people who were concerned about the health implications of increasingly intensive farming systems. Their main concerns were:
•	The loss of soil through erosion and depletion
•	Decreased nutritional quality of food
•	Exploitation of animals
•	Impact on the countryside and wildlife

For the first 30 years, the Soil Association was based on a farm in Suffolk, which was divided into three. The first section of the farm used intensive farming techniques, the second had traditional systems and the third was a mixture of both.
This research, called the Haughley experiment, helped to shape the Soil Association’s first organic standards in 1967. These standards stated that in order to be successful in organic growing you need to create and sustain a ‘living’ soil.

IN 1972 the Soil Association was one of the founding members of IFOAM – Organics International and we continue to support the work of IFOAM in leading, uniting and assisting the organic movement in its full diversity.

The Soil Association charity continues to set standards that exceed the legal requirements for organic food and farming.  It is also a founding member of GOTS - the Global Organic Textile Standards and COSMOS -the international standard for organic and natural cosmetics. Our standards development process is through open public consultation and overseen by our Standards Board which represents citizens and stakeholders from all areas of the organic movement.

Our certification scheme launched in 1973, at a time where there was increasing demand from shoppers and farmers for a system that proved food was high-quality and made with integrity.

Today, Soil Association Certification still provides that reassurance. The Soil Association symbol is more than just a trade mark: it represents a set of standards that are developed to achieve our aims and embody our organic principles of ecology, fairness, care and health. 70% of organic food in the UK is certified by Soil Association Certification.

short_title: Organics production rules
Feedback:

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,
wir betreiben eine Junghennenaufzucht und für uns sind die vorgesehen Übergangsfristen für die Realisierung des Grünauslaufes viel zu kurz, da wir aufgrund der nationalen Auslegung der derzeit geltenden EU-VO unsere Aufzucht mit übergroßem Wintergarten gebaut haben. Um die für einen Auslauf nötigen umliegenden Flächen nutzen zu können müssen langfristige Pachtverhältnisse gekündigt werden oder Flächen, welche sich in langfristigen Pachtverhältnissen befinden, getauscht werden. In unserer Situation halten wir eine Übergangsfrist von 15 Jahren für angebracht.
Weiterhin sehen wir keinen Grund dafür in Volierensystemen nur noch die Grundfläche und 2 weitere Ebenen als Nutzfläche anzurechnen zu können. Unsere Aufzucht wurde nach geltendem Recht und den derzeit gelten Verbandsrichtlinien mit 3 erhöhten Ebenen gebaut. Bei uns wachsen in diesem System, gesunde und sehr mobile Junghennen auf, die durch die hohe Anzahl an verschiedenen Ebenen auf jedes erdenkliche Legehennensystem sehr gut vorbereit sind. Auch wurden alle wirtschaftlichen Kalkulationen auf ein Volierensystem mit 3 erhöhten Eben ausgelegt. Eine, durch die Reduzierung auf 2 erhöhte Ebenen, Herabsetzung der Besatzdichte im Stall würde dazu führen, dass unser Stall nicht mehr wirtschaftlich betrieben werden kann. Auch sollte bedacht, dass sich die Aufzuchtkapazität somit um 1/6 reduziert und dies der positiven Entwicklung der Verfügbarkeit von Ökojunghennen entgegen steht. Falls es bei der Reduzierung auf zwei erhöhte Ebenen bleiben wird müsste zumindest auch hier die Übergangsfrist auf 15 Jahre erhöht werden, da die Abschreibung eines Aufzuchtstalles auch bei 15 bis 20 Jahren liegt.

short_title: Organics production rules
Feedback:
Als zweitgrößter Bio-Geflügel-Verband spricht der Biokreis e.V. für über 100 Geflügelhaltungsbetriebe im Haupterwerb. Nach den aktuellen Entwürfen der der EU-Kommission für das Durchführungsrecht stehen ab 2021 über 100 Existenzen auf dem Spiel. Wir beziehen klar Stellung gegen diese drastischen Verschärfungen.

Geflügel: Nichtanrechenbarkeit der Veranda auf die Stallfläche: Mit dieser Regelung würde der deutschen Geflügel- und Eierproduktion ca. 25 bis 30% der Bio-Stallfläche verloren gehen und die Zahl der gehaltenen Bio-Tiere müsste entsprechend reduziert werden. Diese Vorgabe bedroht nicht nur Öko-Geflügelhalter mit festen Ställen in ihrer Existenz, sondern auch die besonders tiergerechten mobilen Haltungssysteme. Für zukünftige Stallbauten gäbe es keinen Anreiz mehr, die aufwendige und für das Tierwohl wichtige Veranda zu bauen. Die Tiere nutzen die beiden Stallabteile Veranda und Warmstall entsprechend ihrer Bedürfnisse. Die Abkehr von dieser Praxis würde die Stallbau- und Haltungskonzepte der letzten 15 Jahre in Frage stellen.
Forderung: Die Veranda soll weiterhin auf die nutzbare Stallfläche angerechnet werden können.

Keine Anerkennung der Veranda als Auslaufersatz: Diese Änderung macht eine Erweiterung der Ausläufe in Junghennen- und Elterntierbetrieben erforderlich. Wenn den Geflügelhaltern künftig eine Haltung mit einem geschützten Auslauf verwehrt sein wird, die Veranda nicht mehr als Stallfläche anerkannt wird, aber gleichzeitig Grünauslauf verpflichtend angeboten werden muss, sind diese Vorreiterbetriebe gleich mehrfach wirtschaftlich betroffen. Auslaufflächen lassen sich in vielen Fällen nicht einfach erweitern und Stallerweiterungen sind baurechtlich problematisch. Dies schwächt die in Deutschland erfolgte Pionierarbeit zur Öko-Geflügelzüchtung und die Versorgung mit Bio-Geflügel insgesamt. Die Nutzung des Auslaufs ist aus hygienischen Gründen problematisch und die Risiken für die Betriebe sehr hoch, weil sie zum Verlust der wertvollen Öko-Zuchttiere führen können.
Forderung: Anerkennung der Veranda als Auslaufersatz bei Elterntieren und Junghennen.

Schweinehaltung Summenregelung: Wenn kleinere Stallinnenflächen nicht mehr durch größere Auslaufflächen im Freien kompensiert werden dürfen, dann sind über 30% der Mastschweinhalter in Deutschland sowie alle Freilandhaltungsbetriebe mit Hüttenhaltungssystemen betroffen. Das führt entweder zu teuren Umbaumaßnahmen der Ställe oder Bestandreduktion, egal ob neu gebaute Ställe oder alte Ställe. Besonders existenzbedrohend ist, dass dafür keine Übergangsfrist und kein Bestandsschutz vorgesehen ist. Gerade bei den besonders tiergerechten Freilandhaltungssystemen wird die Wirtschaftlichkeit in Frage gestellt.
Forderung: Die Summenregelung muss weiterhin für Schweine ermöglicht werden.

Erweiterung der Ausläufe für Sauen: Die Auslaufflächen für tragende Sauen soll jeweils um ein Drittel vergrößert werden. Mit den Änderungen durch die Summenregelung wird dies in Deutschland zu einem Abbau der Bestände um ca. 25% führen. Dies stellt die Rentabilität der Bio-Schweinehaltung grundsätzlich in Frage. Die Reduzierung bei den Zuchtsauen wird sich auch auf die Selbstversorgung mit Bio-Ferkeln durchschlagen – obwohl das Angebot an Bio-Ferkeln schon heute zu niedrig für den deutschen Markt ist. Da jedes vierte Bio-Schwein der EU in Deutschland erzeugt wird, ist der gesamte Bio-Schweinemarkt in der EU betroffen. Die vorgesehene Übergangsfrist von fünf Jahren reicht für die geforderten Anpassungen bei Weitem nicht aus.
Forderung: Die bisherigen Größenvorgaben für die Ausläufe bei Sauen müssen beibehalten werden.

Rinderhaltung Summenregel: Das Ende der Summenregelung trifft insbesondere tiergerechte Ställe in aufgelöster Bauweise, die einen attraktiven Außenbereich und viel Auslauf bieten. Mit dieser Regelung wird ein großer Teil der Öko-Rinderhalter in Deutschland zu Umbauten gezwungen sein.
Forderung: Die Summenregelung muss weiterhin für Rinder ermöglicht werden.

short_title: Organics production rules
Feedback:
Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren, wir begrüßen es sehr, dass im aktuellen Entwurf der Auslaufradius von bis zu 350 m in der Geflügelhaltung auch für Masthähnchen und Legehennen (Gallus Gallus) weiterhin möglich ist. Würde es hier zu Einschränkungen kommen, stünden viele ökologische Legehennen- und Masthähnchenhaltungen vor dem Aus. Denn oft wird der Zuschnitt des Auslaufes durch die geografischen Gegebenheiten bzw. Grundstücksgrenzen vor Ort bestimmt. Dazu zählen beispielsweise Bachläufe, Waldstücke oder Nachbargrundstücke, die entweder bebaut sind oder landwirtschaftlich von konventionellen Nachbarn bewirtschaftet werden und nicht erworben werden können. Somit kann der Auslauf nicht immer arrondiert um den Stall herum angelegt werden, sondern muss oft auch asymmetrisch gestaltet werden. Käme es hier zu einer Begrenzung auf 150 m, könnte für 30 – 50 % der ökologischen Legehennen- und Masthähnchenbestände nicht mehr der erforderliche Grünauslauf bereitgestellt werden. Dies wäre ein finanzielles Desaster für die betroffenen Landwirtsfamilien, die im Glauben an einen wachsenden sowie politisch und gesellschaftlich gewünschten Ausbau der ökologischen Tierhaltung investiert haben.
Hier bedarf es einer unbedingten Planungssicherheit für die bäuerlichen Betriebe.

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
COCERAL, the European association representing the trade in cereals, oilseeds, rice, feedstuffs, olive oil, oils and fats and agrosupply welcomes the Commission’s initiative in launching a public consultation on the simplification of the Tariff Rates Quotas Management. This below response is to both consultations on the implementing and delegated draft regulations.
A well-functioning management of the TRQ system is essential for operators in cereals and rice sectors. While the current system can represent a burden for public administrators, the few changes resulting from the harmonisation of the procedures to all sectors could be seen as challenging for operators. 
Firstly, regarding the period of submission of applications, the current system is well adapted to the grain market realities, where it gives flexibility to operators in the cereal trade to apply weekly to the quotas available. As such, we would oppose changes towards a monthly application. In the case of a monthly application, if the allocation of the licence happens towards the end of the month, timing flexibility to execute the contract needs to be given to the operators.  
Secondly, we welcome that most of the quotas in the cereals and rice sectors remain under the management of DG Agri, administered via applications and import licenses. At the same time, the barley quota (EU regulation n°2305/2003, quota number 09.4126), as being underutilised, will be managed under the “first come, first served” system. However, we consider that when the UK would become a 3rd country post-Brexit, we could see significant oversubscription as the UK is among one of the main suppliers of barley to EU27. In this case, we would consider keeping this barley under the import licence application. 
Lastly, regarding the rice quotas under the order numbers 09.4138, 09.4148, and 09.4168, for the sub-period staring from October, operators commented that period of validity of the licence is reduced compared to the previous sub-periods. If the transport of the merchandise is delayed due to weather conditions, it is possible that it arrives after the end of the quota period, when the licence is no longer valid. For the last sub-period starting from October, it is important to offer the same duration than the other sub-periods, i.e. to expire on the last calendar day of the month following the end of the sub-period. 
COCERAL stands by the current legal framework of TRQs management in the cereals and rice sector, which has proven to work properly. We consider that the current system is the simplest possible: it is predictable, transparent and provides the necessary confidence for performing trade.

Een algemene opmerking: NEPLUVI is van mening dat de voorwaarden voor de referentiehoeveelheden beter in de Implementing Act vermeld kunnen worden dan in de Delegated Act, om zo de flexibiliteit van de TRQ-administratie te verbeteren. 

Pluimveevleessector: 
Voor de verdeling van de TRQ’s van importen van pluimveevlees uit derde landen naar de EU wordt een volledige verschuiving verwacht van invloed op de stromen naar producenten in derde landen ten koste van Europese producenten. Het grote voordeel zal gaan naar grote leveranciers uit derde landen, voor pluimveevlees voornamelijk Brazilië en Thailand. Deze leveranciers krijgen alle mogelijkheid om de TRQ’s volledig onder controle te krijgen, waarbij de facto de rol van alle MKB-bedrijven in de EU en daarmee de EU-pluimveevlees-industrie verdwijnt. De grote ondernemingen uit derde landen krijgen daarmee macht op de EU-pluimveevleesmarkt. 
Het huidige voorstel zal werken als stimulans voor derde landen om ook hun export buiten de quota aanzienlijk te verhogen, omdat dit onmiddellijk tot het gevolg leidt dat ze een groter deel van het quota toegewezen krijgen. Aangezien de export vanuit de EU ook niet meegenomen zal worden in de verdeling van de quota, kunnen de producenten in de derde landen de controle volledig overnemen. De importeurs hebben dan  namelijk geen vergunningen meer en worden compleet afhankelijk van de quota van de producenten in derde landen. 
Vandaag de dag wordt al 25% van het in de EU geconsumeerde borstvlees geïmporteerd uit derde landen. De verandering van het quotasysteem zal leiden tot een dermate grote machtsverschuiving dat de leveranciers uit derde landen de prijs van borstvlees op de EU-markt gaan bepalen. 
De gevolgen hiervan zullen zijn dat het bedrijfsleven in de EU binnen vijf tot zes jaar uitgesloten zal zijn van de TRQ’s en er een toename zal zijn van het aantal producten in het hoogste segment (filet) die door derde landen in de EU verkocht worden. 

De COM heeft als oplossing voorgesteld om alleen  de invoer van een bepaalde GN-code van een bepaalde oorsprong als referentiehoeveelheid voor een nieuwe toepassing van datzelfde product te kwalificeren, het zogenoemde like-for-like principe. Een voorbeeld hiervan is dat alleen Thais bereid pluimvee in aanmerking komt als referentie voor vergunningen voor Thais bereid pluimvee. 
Het gevolg van deze oplossing zal zijn dat de marktwerking volledig verloren zal gaan en in feite de huidige exploitanten een levenslange vergunning krijgen die alleen kan worden bedreigd door invoer met volledige heffingen door producenten uit andere derde landen. 
Hierdoor zal er bovendien geen flexibiliteit meer zijn en in het geval van dierziekten in die derde landen kunnen de exploitanten in de EU, die van deze importstroom gebruik maken, vastlopen. 

Om ervoor te zorgen dat deze nadelige effecten beperkt worden en om marktstabiliteit te garanderen, moeten er twee belangrijke wijzigingen aangebracht worden in de huidige voorstellen: 
-	Introduceer flexibiliteit waar mogelijk; er mag geen like-for-like zijn op GN-codes en oorsprong. In plaats daarvan zou kwalificatie mogelijk moeten zijn met alle GN-codes die binnen de groep van overvraagde TRQ’s vallen. 
-	Exporten naar derde landen moeten als referentie gelden. Kwalificatie door export is de enige manier waarop EU-exploitanten kunnen hopen enige machtsverhouding te behouden met de grote producenten in derde landen. 
De onzekerheid door de verhoogde kans op een harde Brexit zou ons inziens moeten leiden tot uitstel van de TRQ discussie. Want wanneer er een no deal Brexit plaatsvindt, zal dit ernstige nadelige consequenties hebben op de stabiliteit van de pluimveevlees markt (de overige EU landen exporteren 500 000 ton naar het VK en het VK importeert 220 000 ton uit derde landen). Het implementeren van deze nieuwe wetgeving voordat er duidelijkheid is over de Brexit, zal voor de pluimveevleesmarkt dan ook leiden

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
Please find below the Dutch Meat Importers Associations (DMIA)
position on both the Delegated Regulation and on the Implementing Regulation. 

The DMIA represents the majority of the Dutch meat importers in both red and white meat within The Netherlands (with also a representation from Belgium importers), many members operate European Union wide. Most members would qualify as a Small or Medium Enterprise, an SME. 

In the last 4 years DMIA has tried to protect the interest of her members by actively informing and advising the EU and national authorities via the UECBV to try to find a balance between: 

* Simplification
* Protection of the SME’s
* Smoother legislation

Unfortunately, in the opinion of the DMIA, the current drafts do not meet these 3 points. 

DMIA position in a few words: 

It is very important that both texts of the EU commission (Delegated regulation and Implementing regulation) create room for a balanced approach which currently is not the case. 

Important is flexibility on origin and on CN codes for both poultry meat and beef in relation to the reference quantity.
In the comments put on basis of the EU consultation many questions have been put forward regarding the reference quantities. The problems announced in these comments could be solved if there would be much more flexibility for the reference quantity.
The requirements for the reference quantities should   be better taken up in the Implementing Act as in the Delegated Act which currently is the case. This would increase the flexibility of the TRQ administration.
The two years proof of trade that has always been there is important as well for the protection of SME’s and the market.

The DMIA is member of the UECBV our European organization based in
Brussels. We further support the UECBV position (attached as file)

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
COCERAL, the European association representing the trade in cereals, oilseeds, rice, feedstuffs, olive oil, oils and fats and agrosupply welcomes the Commission’s initiative in launching a public consultation on the simplification of the Tariff Rates Quotas Management. This below response is to both consultations on the implementing and delegated draft regulations.
A well-functioning management of the TRQ system is essential for operators in cereals and rice sectors. While the current system can represent a burden for public administrators, the few changes resulting from the harmonisation of the procedures to all sectors could be seen as challenging for operators. 
Firstly, regarding the period of submission of applications, the current system is well adapted to the grain market realities, where it gives flexibility to operators in the cereal trade to apply weekly to the quotas available. As such, we would oppose changes towards a monthly application. In the case of a monthly application, if the allocation of the licence happens towards the end of the month, timing flexibility to execute the contract needs to be given to the operators.  
Secondly, we welcome that most of the quotas in the cereals and rice sectors remain under the management of DG Agri, administered via applications and import licenses. At the same time, the barley quota (EU regulation n°2305/2003, quota number 09.4126), as being underutilised, will be managed under the “first come, first served” system. However, we consider that when the UK would become a 3rd country post-Brexit, we could see significant oversubscription as the UK is among one of the main suppliers of barley to EU27. In this case, we would consider keeping this barley under the import licence application. 
Lastly, regarding the rice quotas under the order numbers 09.4138, 09.4148, and 09.4168, for the sub-period staring from October, operators commented that period of validity of the licence is reduced compared to the previous sub-periods. If the transport of the merchandise is delayed due to weather conditions, it is possible that it arrives after the end of the quota period, when the licence is no longer valid. For the last sub-period starting from October, it is important to offer the same duration than the other sub-periods, i.e. to expire on the last calendar day of the month following the end of the sub-period. 
COCERAL stands by the current legal framework of TRQs management in the cereals and rice sector, which has proven to work properly. We consider that the current system is the simplest possible: it is predictable, transparent and provides the necessary confidence for performing trade.

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
Background
There is an ongoing revision of the EU regulations governing tariff rate quota (TRQ) management and in particular on some aspects of the proposed administration for the overdemanded TRQs. 

Main objectives to administer TRQ in a fair, objective and transparent manner, is to increase the efficiency of the administration for genuine operators, to prevent its misuse by so called “shelf companies” and to avoid market disruption.

Key point
The priority for UECBV is to keep bargaining power in Europe and to protect EU SME’s.

Position 
Due to the consultation opened 25. July 2019 and closed 22. August 2019 UECBV’s position is as uploaded as annex.

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
By default, Copa and Cogeca support efforts to simplify and modernise the current regulatory framework. Regarding the current proposal to simplify rules concerning reduced tariffs schemes we believe that the Commission must take in account the conclusions of the meeting of the Committee of agriculture and rural development of the European Parliament that took place on 19 February 2019, and the opinion of the EU stakeholders and revise the current proposal by maintaining  some of the flexibility of the current system while providing the simplification aimed with the revision. The revised draft should:
	include exports as reference for over demanded TRQs;
	remove limitations on CN codes and origin for all over demanded TRQ’s;
	move the details of the requirement for reference quantity from the “Delegated Act” to the “Implementing Act” so as to improve the future flexibility of the TRQ administration;
TRQs are applied to products that are considered sensitive. Following more than 70 international trade agreement and other trade arrangements, the management of TRQs became an effective tool for market management, with direct impact on prices for producers. 
•	According to our experts, the current proposal will drastically decrease the effectiveness of TRQ management as market management tool in order to help to balance our internal market for poultry. It will in fact provide an unnecessary concession to third countries multinationals. 
•	In recent negotiations with Canada and Mexico, the EU negotiator understood the importance of retaining the power to manage TRQs. Therefore, has managed to retain the control of management of TRQs for new market access for sensitive sectors.  Taking in account that currently 25% of the poultry breast consumed in the EU is imported (overall poultry imports amount to 900.000 tonnes of poultry meat), mostly from Brazil, Thailand and Ukraine, the proposed changes (to the existing TRQs) will, de facto, transfer the bargaining power from the EU to multinationals from third country exporters. 
•	Operators can only increase their share of the allocated licenses by importing on full duty. Importing on full duty is impossible for EU SME importers, so they will lose market share. Third country producers (such as Brazil, Thailand or Ukraine) will be instantly rewarded with extra licenses for every kg of imports on full duty – and they have the economical capacity to do it. Only large 3rd country producers can build new reference quantities which will offer them dominance in the TRQs concerned.
•	Large 3rd country producers will take full control of quota within a matter of (few) years. The elimination of EU importing SMEs has an impact in the capacity to export EU produce to third countries. In addition, it will allow third country multinationals to build capacity in the EU market, through their subsidiaries, leading to an increase of EU imports from third countries (even) with full duty. 
With this shift of bargaining power, third countries multinationals will be able to set the price in the EU market. Thanks to the increase of the quota rent, the 3rd country exporters will sell more high-value products (such as the poultry breast) in the EU, with full-duty payment. For example, it’s important to keep in mind the dynamics of the EU market, each poultry breast imported into the EU leads to the replacement of one broiler in the EU.
In a period of trade uncertainty and higher chances of Hard brexit, we call on the Commission to revise the draft according to the proposals of the EU agricultural sector.

Feedback:
The International Meat Trade Association (IMTA), based in the UK, has represented businesses engaged in the international meat trade since 1895. We represent around 65 trading members (importers and exporters) and around 25 associate members, these are businesses who operate in relevant industries (e.g. customs agents/freight forwarders, shipping lines). Our trading members cover beef, lamb, pork and poultrymeat.

•It is important to recognise that in the case of oversubscribed quotas the allocation method chosen inevitably artificially impacts on the market.
•Whilst we welcome the opportunity to simplify and harmonise quota rules there are some elements in the proposals where there is a danger that existing businesses could be severely affected. We appreciate that it would have been very difficult to carry out an impact assessment on this aspect. For this reason it would seem prudent if elements relating to the reference quantity (Article 9 of DA) could be moved to the IA thus allowing the EU Commission the ability to respond quickly to any inadvertent negative impacts on businesses.
•A number of previously oversubscribed poultry TRQs have been undersubscribed for over a year. Will the EU Commission review Annex 1 of the IA before final adoption?

short_title: Tariff quotas with licences
Feedback:
AVEC, representing the poultry meat sector in the EU, would like to thank the Commission for offering us the possibility to provide feedback on this regulation.

Poultry meat sector:
For the poultry meat TRQs, AVEC expects that the new proposal will create a complete shift of value of the TRQs at the expense of the EU to the profit of suppliers from third countries (mainly Brazil and Thailand); those may have the opportunity to take full control of the TRQs, excluding de facto the role of all EU SMEs and the EU poultry industry, therefore achieving a much more powerful role in the EU poultry market.
Through the current proposal, third country producers will be stimulated to significantly increase their exports outside of quota as they are instantly rewarded with a bigger piece of the quota pie.
Today already 25 % of the breast meat consumed in the EU is imported from Third countries.
With this shift of power, third countries producers will be able to set the price of breast meat in the EU market.

The consequences will be:
-the exclusion of the EU SMEs from the TRQs within 5/6 years;
-the increase of the equalisation effect. Thanks to the increase of the quota rent, the 3rd country exporters will sell more high-value products (such as the breast) in the EU, with full-duty payment.

The Commission now suggests to overcome this by only allowing imports of a certain GN code from a certain origin to qualify as reference quantities for a new application of that same product. Ie. only Thai cooked poultry qualifies as reference for Thai cooked poultry licenses.
This will completely lock up the market and will basically give current operators a license for life with no possibility for newcomers to access the quotas and that can only be threatened by imports at full duty by third country producers.
All flexibility will be lost and in case of animal diseases in third countries operators in the EU might get completely stuck.
Further, third country producers could decide to take control by only offering on duty paid basis leaving importers with licenses they cannot use and no escape possibilities to other origins or products.

To limit those adverse effects and in order for the Commission to guarantee market stability, 2 important modifications should be brought to these proposals:
-Introduce as much flexibility as possible: there should not be like-for-like on GN codes and origin. Instead qualification should be possible with all GN codes that are within the group of over-demanded TRQs.
-Exports should qualify as reference. Qualification through exports is the only way through which EU operators can hope to maintain some balance of power with the large 3rd country producers.
In the current regulations where there is no reference system for most TRQs, companies qualify to apply for quota through exports. The general rules of the new Commissions proposal also include exports.
Excluding exports as qualification for the poultry quota would therefore be an unnecessary concession to third countries.

Last but not least, we believe that the uncertainty and the risk of a hard Brexit should lead the Commission to wait until more clarity on the future relation between EU and UK is defined.
A no deal scenario would have significant negative consequences on the stability of the EU poultry meat market (EU 27 exports 500 000 T to UK, while UK imports 220 000 T from third countries) and therefore applying these new legislations before Brexit will bring unnecessary additional risk and uncertainty on the poultry meat market.

General comments:
As a more general comment, AVEC suggests that the details of the requirement for reference quantity should be moved from the Delegated Act to the Implementing Act so as to improve the flexibility of the TRQ administration.

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
Dear Sirs,

We would like to make a suggestion regarding the list of substances authorized in Annex II, to include the use of Ozone in post-harvest treatment of fresh fruit.  Ozone is a naturally occurring substance, which has been shown to be effective in reduction of presence of rots and microbiological contamination, it is rapidly dispersed after application, and does not leave residues on the fruit. Properly handled and with appropriate health and safety measures in place, this serves as a safe alternative method that would be greatly beneficial to the sector to reduce post-harvest losses and food waste.

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
The company Biochem welcomes the opportunity to comment the draft regulation amending the annexes of Regulation (EC) No. 889/2008. 
Our comment relates to the list of feed additives in Annex VI. 
We are pleased to see Betaine anhydrous as a new entry in the list of feed additives, but we would like to highlight that the requirement “and when available from organic origin” will limit the availability considerably. Article 24, paragraph 3, point e iv) of Regulation (EU) 2018/848 states that “the use of non-organic spices, herbs and molasses is necessary because such products are not available in organic form;”. Molasses as well as betaine are derived from sugar beets and thus availability of betaine from organic origin will be as low as the availability of organic molasses. Therefore we are asking for the deletion of the limitation regarding the organic origin of betaine anhydrous.

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
IFOAM EU (International Federation of Organic Agriculture Movements - EU Regional Body) would like to give some input on Annex II - Plant Protection Products:

- For clarity reasons and considering their growing number, the list of basic substances should be in a separated sub-chapter within Annex II, as proposed by in point 3.9 of EGTOP report on Plant Protection IV

- For sodium chloride the following restrictions should be included: ‘only sea and rock salt’. Subsequently, for reasons of consistency, sodium chloride in Annex I should also be changed to ‘only sea and rock salt’. This is also proposed in point 3.4 of EGTOP report on Plant Protection IV

- For Deltamethrin and Lambda-cyhalothrin, which can only be used in traps and only against Bactrocera oleae and Ceratis capitate Wied, alternatives exist and should be explored as much as possible as also the need in the different Member States should be properly evaluated . In any case, it is important to keep the medium-long term objective of phasing out these two substances. To be considered also the horizontal legislation. This recommendation is in line with point 3.7.3 of EGTOP report on Plant Protection IV.

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
Specialised Nutrition Europe (SNE) would like to thank the European Commission (EC) for the possibility to comment on the proposed draft Regulation, and shares the following first comments. Taking into account the timing of this consultation, SNE can only provide below a non-exhaustive list of the sector’s comments. SNE will be pleased to provide further detailed comments at a later stage to the EC.

1)	Transition period
In Recital 5 of the Draft Regulation, it is specified that: “To allow for sufficient time to adapt to that new requirement, operators should be given a three-year transition period.” SNE therefore asks that the new rules apply as from 1 January 2023 (instead of 1 January 2022).
SNE would like to note that the 3-year transition period is needed as a transition to organic for the raw material part requires time. Due to the nature of organic production and its reliance on sometimes uncontrollable climatic and natural conditions, there may not be a consistent and adequate supply of organic ingredients so a safe and suitable non-organic alternative is required for these situations.

2)	Food additives specific conditions or restrictions in addition to Regulation (EC) 1333/2008
• Annex IV, Section A – E170 Calcium carbonate: 
SNE proposes to amend the proposed specific conditions and restrictions as follows: “Shall not be used for colouring of products”. 
Rationale: Calcium carbonate (E170) may be used as a source of calcium in foods. Prohibiting use of calcium carbonate as a source of calcium in these products would be inconsistent with its allowed use in non-organic versions of the same products from a scientific perspective, which in turn could put organic products at a disadvantage in the marketplace. 

• Annex IV, Section A – E322 Lecithin:
SNE questions the meaning of the proposed specific conditions and restrictions for lecithin (“With regard to foodstuffs of animal origin: Milk products Only when derived from organic production”):
- Does this mean that lecithin is only allowed in milk products, but not other animal-derived products? 
- Would foods for infants and young children (IYC) fit into that category? Or is this a reference to the amount of lecithin that is calculated when determining % organic? 
	
• Annex IV, Section A – E407 Carrageenan:
Similarly as for Lecithin (see above), SNE questions the meaning of the proposed specific conditions and restrictions for carrageenan (“With regard to foodstuffs of animal origin: milk-based products”):
- Does this mean that carrageenan is only allowed in milk-based products, but not other animal-derived products? 
- Would foods for IYC fit into that category? Or is this a reference to the amount of carrageenan that is calculated when determining % organic? 

• Annex IV, Section B:
SNE is very concerned by the following provisions:
- Both calcium carbonate and calcium hydroxide would not be allowed in the preparation of organic products produced from animals;
- Magnesium chloride would only be allowed for use as a “coagulation agent”;
- Thiamin hydrochloride would only be allowed for “use in processing of fruit wines (…)”.
Rationale: Similar to the one provided above for calcium carbonate. SNE would question why nutrient sources such as calcium carbonate are considered as acceptable for non-organic products and yet it is proposed to exclude them from organic products? Nutrients should be acceptable for all product types. SNE suggests that if there is a wish to promote organic produce from the EU then there should be equivalence in relation to permitted nutrients. 

• SNE would also appreciate confirmation of the below interpretation:
SNE reads these new requirements as applicable only for the direct use of additives – meaning that additives allowed to be added in nutrients intended to be used in foodstuffs for IYC as per Regulation (EC) 1333/2008, Annex III, part 5 section B, are not in scope. Can the EC confirm this interpretation?

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
Dear Madam or Sir

 We have the following suggestions:

Annex I: 
-	Stone meal and clays: For legal reasons in fertilizer legislation, clay minerals such as betonite cannot be classified under "stone meal and clays". As a result, soil conditioners containing bentonite cannot be used. It is therefore important that the clay minerals are added to this category of the organic regulation.

-	Biochar: The specification "After harvest" must be added, otherwise the raw material for the plant charcoal would have to be organic from seed to the production of the charcoal and only organically treated material would be allowed. It will hardly be possible to exclude conventional raw materials and in addition to prove the organic origin of the raw materials in biochar. So the condition of use for biochar should be amended as follows: „Only from plant materials, untreated or treated with products from annex II after harvest“  

Annex II:
-	Calcium hydroxide: Currently calcium hydroxide has the restriction “When used as fungicide, only in fruit trees, including nurseries, to control Nectria galligena” this is already specified in horizontal law and therefore need not be specified here. The same approach has been chosen for other substances in Annex II, for instance copper.

-	Pyrethroids (only deltamethrin or lambda-cyhalothrin): we are still opposed to synthetic pyrethroids and strongly urge their exclusion. Alternatives do exist and Member States still reliant on deltamethrin or lambda-cyhalothrin should explore those and invest in their adoption and optimisation.


Annex VI: e) silage additives: 
-	lactic, formic, propionic and acetic acid: The silage additives, especially formic acid but also the other acids should be used in buffered salt form due to work safety and corrosion. Since the pure acids are not offered as silage additives either, their salts, the proprionates, the salts of propionic acid (E 280), are more frequently used as silage additives. They contain less acid, are easier to dose and therefore easier to handle. It is therefore important that the salts of the organic acids, or at least the propionates, are also mentioned here. The salts of proprionic acid are sodium proprionate (E 281), calcium proprionate (E 282) and potassium proprionate (E 283). So the entrance should be changed to „lactic, formic, propionic and acetic acid and their salts“. 

Annex VIII:
-	Activated carbon:
The authorization for activated carbon as a processing aid for the processing of food of plant origin should be extended to food of animal origin with the addition: "for the standardization of vitamin B-2 levels in milk raw materials in infant and toddler food". A dossier had already been submitted in June 2017 and has not been evaluated by EGTOP.
Activated carbon is used primarily as an adsorbent to remove unwanted colorants, flavors and odors from gases, vapors and liquids. By using activated carbon as adsorbent, the vitamin B2 content can be standardized in the production of milk raw materials such as e.g. lactose by filtering out vitamin B2 during the production process from liquid organic whey. Thus the vitamin B2 content of lactose is reproducible within certain limits. 
At present, vitamin B2 supplementation to infant formula is still necessary in order to reach the contents required by baby food legislation. Due to the low availability of GM-free vitamin B2, much attention should be given to reducing or even eliminating the supplement. A standardization of the vitamin B2 content in the raw materials could be an important step to lower the dependency on biotechnically produced vitamin B2.

Annex VIIIa:
-	Copper Sulphate: We recommend re-introducing copper sulphate in Annex VIIIa. For one the use of cupric citrate due to its composition with bentonite can require additional filtration. Also for certain uses and timing of uses only copper sulphate can be used, for instance in sparkling wine. 

Best regards

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
Suite à la mise en consultation du projet de Règlement visant à modifier les Annexes I, II, VI, VIII et VIIIa du Règlement (CE) n°889/2008, Synadiet, en tant que Syndicat français des Compléments Alimentaires, apporte le commentaire suivant :

Les compléments alimentaires sont des denrées alimentaires possédant des spécificités techniques particulières. Certains additifs et auxiliaires technologiques sont donc indispensables à la conception de ces produits. La révision des annexes VIII (listant les additifs et auxiliaires technologiques autorisés en production biologique) et IX (listant les ingrédients non bio d’origine agricole autorisés en production biologique) du Règlement (CE) n° 889/2008 impacte donc directement notre secteur.

-	Dans le projet de Règlement, il est indiqué en annexe IV, Section A, que l’utilisation du glycérol en production biologique sera autorisée dans les extraits de plantes, dans les arômes, dans les gélules en tant qu’humectant et dans les comprimés pour le revêtement des surfaces. Cependant, qu’en est-il des extraits de matières premières d’origine animale ou levures qui utilisent le glycérol en tant que solvant ou support ? C’est pourquoi nous proposons d’élargir cette condition afin de considérer également les matières premières d’origine animale ou levure. Synadiet demande donc de remplacer “For plant extracts, flavourings, humectant in gel capsules and as a surface coating of tablets” par “For plant and animal and yeast extracts, humectant in gel capsules and as a surface coating of tablets”.

De plus, il est également ajouté une seconde contrainte pour le glycérol, seul le glycérol bio sera autorisé dans les produit bio à compter du 1er janvier 2022 (soit dans 17 mois). Qu’en sera-t-il des produits contenant du glycérol non bio mis sur le marché avant le 1er janvier 2022 avec des dates limites de consommation ou des dates de durabilité minimale dépassant cette date ? Synadiet demande qu’un écoulement des stocks de produits contenant du glycérol non bio fabriqués avant le 1er janvier 2022 soit possible et que cette mention soit introduite dans le texte.

-	Le stéarate de magnésium (E470b) n’est actuellement pas autorisé en bio, or cet additif a une réelle utilité dans la fabrication de complément alimentaires sous forme de comprimés ou de gélules car il a des propriétés d’antiagglomérant et de lubrifiant. Le stéarate de magnésium, grâce à sa composition chimique, possède des propriétés hydrophobes, l’autoriser permettrait aux fabricants de compléments alimentaires de proposer aux consommateurs un choix plus large de compléments alimentaires bio. La sécurité du stéarate de magnésium a été réévaluée par l’EFSA, (Avis du 2 mars 2018). L’EFSA a alors conclu qu’il n’était pas nécessaire de définir d’ADI pour cet additif et qu’il ne présentait pas de préoccupation en termes de sécurité. Synadiet demande donc l’ajout de cet additif à l’Annexe IV, Section A, afin d’autoriser son utilisation en bio. 

-	Synadiet souhaite également appuyer la nécessité de bien conserver certains additifs déjà présents dans ces listes. En effet, un certain nombre d’additifs sont indispensables à la conception des compléments alimentaires bio. Leur présence dans ces listes est donc cruciale. Parmi les additifs indispensables, on peut par exemple citer l’hydroxypropyl méthyl cellulose (HPMC) (E 464) qui entre dans la composition des gélules végétales, les lécithines (E 322) pour leur fonction d’émulsifiant, le dioxyde de silicium (E 551) en tant qu’agent d’écoulement ou encore l’acide citrique (E 330) et le talc (E 553b). 

Concernant les auxiliaires technologiques, il est primordial de bien conserver dans ces listes, l’éthanol, qui est un solvant très utilisé pour l’extraction, ou pour la suspension de pelliculage, la cire de carnauba utilisée en tant qu’agent de démoulage, ou encore le gel ou solution colloïdale de dioxyde de silicium pour son rôle d’antiagglomérant.

short_title: Amendment of products and substances allowed in organic production
Feedback:
FEFAC welcomes the opportunity to provide comments concerning the draft regulation amending the annexes of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008 and organic farming. Our remarks and proposals below relate to the list of feed materials and feed additives authorised for feeding animals reared under organic farming conditions.

1.	Annex VI
1.1.	Alignment with Register of feed additives
It is a long standing request of EU feed business sectors to secure full alignment of Annex VI of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008 with the EU register of feed additives. Since the last review of Annex VI of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008, the conditions of authorisation of a number of trace-elements compounds (copper, manganese, selenium and zinc) and of lecithin have been changed in the framework of the re-authorisation of feed additives as provide for by article 10 of EU Regulation (EC) No 1831/2003. Therefore, Annex VI must be aligned to avoid misunderstanding. Attached is a file table listing the necessary amendments to Annex VI. 
1.2.	Chestnut extract
It is not clear to us why there should be a specific line for (sweet) chestnut extract as our understanding is that chestnuts are agricultural products and therefore are already permitted in organic farming via the general authorization of flavouring compounds being extracts from agricultural products.
1.3.	Alignment of Annex VI with article 25k of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008
Article 25k provides that for aquaculture products:
“4. Astaxanthin derived primarily from organic sources, such as organic crustacean shells may be used in the feed ration for salmon and trout within the limit of their physiological needs. If organic sources are not available natural sources of astaxanthin (such as Phaffia yeast) may be used. 
5. Histidine produced through fermentation may be used in the feed ration for salmonid fish when the feed sources listed in paragraph 1 do not provide a sufficient amount of histidine to meet the dietary needs of the fish and prevent the formation of cataracts.”
For the sake of consistency, it is therefore appropriate in our opinion to reflect these provisions in Annex VI as proposed in the attached file.

2.	Annex V
2.1.	Re-listing of calcium stearate, mistakenly removed from the list of feed binders authorised in organic farming
Calcium stearate of natural origin (E470) was listed in Annex VI of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008. In 2010, it was agreed that calcium stearate was not a feed additive but a feed material. In 2012 (Regulation (EC) No 505/2012), Calcium stearate was logically removed from Annex VI which deals only with feed additives, but it should have logically been included in Annex V since what changed was the status of the product, not its essentiality for organic farming. It is therefore necessary to reinsert Calcium stearate of natural origin in Annex V of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008 (see excel file).
2.2.	Alignment of Annex V with Catalogue of feed materials (Regulation (EC) No 2017/1017)
For the sake of transparency and similar to annex VI, We find it appropriate to align the content of Annex V of Regulation (EC) No 889/2008 with the EU Catalogue of feed materials (Regulation (EU) No 2017/1017. This means including an extra column pointing to the identification numbers specified in the EU Catalogue of feed materials for those feed materials listed in Annex V (see attached file).

short_title: Operation of the Farm Accountancy Data Network
Feedback:
The reflections below are based on the experiences in the Horizon 2020 project “Moving towards Adaptive Governance in Complexity: Informing nexus security” (MAGIC, ID 689669; https://magic-nexus.eu/). 
The MAGIC project uses quantitative information about farming types to establish a link among the factors relevant for analyzing sustainability in relation to the nexus between water, energy, food, land use and rural development. In particular, the MAGIC project aims to integrate information regarding: (i) the economic viability of agricultural systems, recognizing that farm workers currently receive approximately 40% less income compared to other economic sectors; (ii) the ecological feasibility of agricultural systems, checking the environmental impact that changes in the profile of distribution of different farm types over different geographic areas can have; and (iii) the desirability of changes in the agricultural systems in relation to the various dimensions of sustainability. For this reason, the information provided by the FADN is of great interest to us. However, for the type of research carried out by MAGIC —studying the entanglement over the flows of energy, water, and food in relation to environmental and socio-economic concerns— we find that the exclusive focus on economic variables limits the usefulness and potential of the database. Assessments provided in the FADN database in monetary terms have to be converted into the corresponding biophysical quantities in order to carry out analyses relevant for the sustainability of EU agriculture.
We understand that the regulation (EU) No 1217/2009 through which a legal framework is established by which “setting up a network for the collection of accountancy data on the incomes and business operation of agricultural holdings in the European Community” has the goal to obtain relevant information for the development of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). This explains why the economic criterion has been the predominant one both in the classification of the type of farming and in the presentation of the results (as reflected by the introduction of the standard output coefficient through the Implementing Regulation (EU) 2015/220). However, restricting the analysis to the economic dimension limits the enormous potential that this type of database could have for informing the CAP reform process in relation to the sustainability of EU agriculture (the greening of farm production for a more sustainable land use). For this reason, we strongly suggest to complement the current characterization of the types of farming based on economic variables with a characterization based on biophysical variables such as: area of land (ha), consumption of blue and green water (m3), consumption of direct energy (J), fertilizers (kg), pesticides (kg), labor (hours of activity) – that can be assessed using proxy variables. In addition, geo-localization of the EU farming types (across geographical zones) would provide a tremendous contribution to the enrichment of the discussion about the sustainability of the food system and the greening of the CAP.  
Indeed, to avoid the attractor of “silo governance” it would be important to characterize agricultural production in a transdisciplinary way. A richer information space would assist the Commission and the European Parliament as well as national regulators in gaining deeper insight in the options available to achieve a greener CAP compliant with more rigorous climate policies. 

Juan Cadillo Benalcazar & Mario Giampietro, Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona, Spain

Feedback:
Remarques de l'association FILIERE CHEVAL concernant l’acte d’exécution relatif au réseau d’information comptable agricole sur les revenus et l’économie des exploitations agricoles 			
			          - Consultation publique - Août 2019 -


L'association FILIERE CHEVAL composée des cinq organismes représentatifs de la filière équine française, France Galop, La société LeTrot, la Fédération Française d’Equitation – FFE, la Société Hippique Française – SHF, la Société Française des Equidés de Travail – SFET, s’inquiète  une fois encore de voir disparaitre les équidés des données permettant d’établir le coefficient de production standardisé des  exploitations agricoles en Europe. Alors même qu'ils étaient présents dans le règlement précédent (2008/1166),les équidés sont désormais absents de la liste des animaux devant être comptabilisés.

La FILIERE CHEVAL souhaite interpeller  la Commission sur le préjudice de notre filière  quant à l'abandon de toutes données statistiques, disparition entrainant  à plus ou moins  longs termes toutes  connaissances de notre secteur d'activité et toutes quantifications du nombre d'équidés détenus en Europe.

Cette orientation déjà dénoncée par notre association  depuis l’adoption du règlement 2018/1091 ( nouveau règlement Eurostat ),fragilise la position agricole des équins , fait peser un risque de remise en cause de son statut et pourrait, à terme, limiter encore plus l'accès à la PAC.
Pourtant cette décision semble aller à l’encontre de l'objectif premier du règlement qui est de   classer toutes les exploitations agricoles par type d’exploitation et par taille économique et de favoriser ( rappel considérant 2 et 3 ) :

le processus de décision au moyen de données actualisées  
l'élargissement de la base de connaissance statistique nécessaires à l’élaboration, à la mise en œuvre, au suivi, à l’évaluation et à la révision des politiques afférentes aux exploitations agricoles
une meilleure connaissance des éléments nécessaires pour le suivi de la PAC et notamment les mesures de développement rural, les politiques environnementales, les politiques d’adaptation au changement climatique et d’atténuation de celui-ci, les politiques de l’union concernant l’utilisation des terres et certains objectifs de développement rural. 

Les équidés sont de plus en plus concernés par l’ensemble de ces politiques et chaque secteur d'activité, chaque composante de notre filière apportent de nouvelles perspectives aussi bien économiques, environnementales, touristiques, que d'aides au maintien de la biodiversité en milieu rural.  

Retirer les équidés des données statistiques agricoles aura pour conséquence d'accroitre le phénomène de méconnaissance de la filière. A l'inverse, une connaissance accrue de la place des équidés dans les exploitations pourrait conduire à l’élaboration de politiques novatrices  proches  des objectifs de l’Union en matière agricole. 

Les équidés sont des animaux agricoles, élevés sur des terres agricoles, jouant un rôle de plus en plus important dans la volonté d'une agriculture toujours plus écologique. Une connaissance et un suivi de leur présence sont indispensables et certainement décisifs pour la mise en avant des efforts européens de préservation de l'environnement.

C'est pourquoi La FILIERE CHEVAL, association représentative de l'ensemble de la filière équine française, demande la réintégration systématique des équins dans toutes les opérations de comptabilisation des exploitations agricoles .

short_title: Operation of the Farm Accountancy Data Network
Feedback:
The French Society for Working Equines (SFET) is the umbrella organization for French draft horses, donkeys, mules and regional horse breeds. Its missions include promoting breeding, and encouraging the training and effective use, and marketing of working horses. It brings together 25 French breeds of equine, representing breeders and users from breed cradles and breeding regions across France.
The French Society for Working Equines (SFET) would like to draw the attention of the Commission on the long terms risk of loss of knowledge and reporting on equidea owned in the EU.
The Commission has taken this direction since its proposition on the regulation 2018/1091, related to integrated farm statistics. Nevertheless, it seems to go against the objective of this regulation, which is to “inform the decision-making process with updated data” (recital 3) and to “provide the statistical knowledge base necessary for the design, implementation, monitoring, evaluation and review of related policies” in relation to agricultural holdings. In particular, the Commission wishes to have necessary elements to monitor the CAP “including rural development measures, as well as environmental, climate change adaptation and mitigation and land use policies of the Union and some Sustainable Development Goals” (recital 2).
However, equidea are concerned by these subjects and have an impact on these policies (diversification of farmers’ incomes, biodiversity, impact on landscapes, management of grasslands, use of work horses, development of equestrian tourism in rural areas).
If the place of horses in these different policies is not currently well analysed, removing them from data related to agricultural holdings will increase this phenomenon. At the contrary, a better understanding of the place of equidea in agricultural holdings could lead to the elaboration of innovative policies and could help to reach Union objectives for agriculture. The presence of equidea have a role to play in “greening” of agriculture. A good knowledge and a reporting of their presence may be decisive to bring to the fore european efforts for environmental preservation.
Equidea are agricultural animals, breeded on farmland, although they are not always intended for food chain.
As the umbrella of 25 breeds of French equines, we would like the systematic reintegration of equidea in every accounting and reporting activities related to agricultural holdings.

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]
Feedback:
AVIALTER, Asociación Profesional de la Avicultura Alternativa en España representa los intereses de los profesionales dedicados a la producción avícola en sistemas alternativos.
La avicultura alternativa es una actividad enraizada en el terreno y no “deslocalizable” que aporta importantes beneficios al mundo rural y a los consumidores deseosos de productos originales y cargados de la historia, cultura y tradiciones del territorio y de sus gentes. Transmitir al consumidor los valores propios de estas producciones requiere de etiquetados claros y medidas eficientes para que quienes realmente no sean merecedores de éstos, no se los apropien indebidamente provocando así un grave perjuicio a los productores, a los consumidores, al mundo rural y a la credibilidad del sector agroalimentario en general. 
Estamos a favor de mantener lo regulado en el artículo 11 a 14 y anexo V del reglamento 543/2008. Entendemos que es necesario mantener los actuales sistema de cría con identificación en la etiqueta para una correcta ordenación del mercado de la carne de pollo. Este sistema ha permitido desarrollar una importantísima actividad avicola con inversiones al alcance de un pequeño agricultor que contribuye de manera decisiva a mantener un medio rural vivo al facilitar rentas complementarias en la renta familiar. Ha permitido identificar unos modos de producción que satisfagan a los consumidores y que animan a los agricultores a invertir en su actividad agrícola.
También estamos a favor de una regulación europea del término "crecimiento lento" para garantía de los consumidores y de los productores. Un real crecimiento lento no debería sobrepasar los 35 gramos de ganancia media diaria.
En lo que concierne al reglamento 589/2008, la obligación de indicar el tipo de granja con los códigos numéricos  y su correspondiente mención obligatoria del sistema de cría, es esencial  para tener una segmentación buena. Estos puntos de este texto deben ser mantenidos.
Para que todo esto se cumpla entendemos que es totalmente necesario establecer sistemas de control para evitar el fraude en el etiquetado, así como la inclusión de otras menciones que puedan inducir a error al consumidor.

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]
Feedback:
These statements are made on behalf of Eipro (https://eipro.de), an egg product company. Egg products are defined in No. 7.3 of Annex I to Regulation (EC) No 853/2004 laying down specific hygiene rules for on the hygiene of foodstuffs as “processed products resulting from the processing of eggs, or of various components or mixtures of eggs, or from the further processing of such processed products.” 

The CMO evaluation is a welcome opportunity to look at Commission Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 on marketing standards for eggs. It provides an unique opportunity for stakeholders to comment on the Regulation before it becomes ‘Lisbonised’ and probably rigidly unchanged for years to come. 

Manufacturers of egg products face a predicament when it comes to the compulsory indication of the type of farming under which laying hens are kept. Practices in the application of Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 vary between Member States (and sometimes within a single Member State) while it should be the task of the CMO to secure a level playing field across the internal market for egg products. If Union law makes the indication of the type of farming for laying hens compulsory, this uniformity should prevail across the EU notwithstanding national practices. 

A further complication is the summer season that usually sees a decline in overall consumption of eggs and consequently a surplus of free-range eggs and deep-litter eggs that is not absorbed by food retail. This surplus can only be absorbed by the egg product sector if these eggs can be processed without specific indication of type of farming. However, downgrading is currently not permitted. 

Given that the Commission is interested in hearing from stakeholders about the scope of the evaluation programme in this round of consultation, we would advocate including the particularities of the egg product sector and the indication of animal husbandry in the assessment of Regulation (EC) No 589/2008 that otherwise is considered generally operational. The egg product sector is keen to provide further explanations as studies progress and further market evaluations are undertaken.

Walter Peuker

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]
Feedback:
The AICV (The European Cider & Fruit Wine Association) is the European trade body representing producers of cider, perry and fruit wine within the European Union (EU). Cider is predominantly a European product accounting for 69% of global consumption. However, there is to date no EU definition of cider or perry (nor a global one). 
To ensure the sustainable development of cider and perry production within the EU and the continued investment in orchards to meet increasing demand the AICV believes that there needs to be a marketing standard for cider and perry. Such a standard would provide a guarantee to consumers as to the basic constituent of products, which bear a “cider” or “perry” descriptor and consequently lead to the improvement of the quality and economic conditions for the production and marketing of the products. The industry is in favour of a relatively simple Marketing Standard which would clearly identify our products as fermented alcoholic beverages (alcohol from fermentation only). By developing a marketing standard for cider and perry the provenance and heritage of the products describing themselves as cider or perry will be underpinned providing consumers with the reassurance about the products bearing those descriptors.

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]
Feedback:
The AIJN (European Fruit Juice Association) is the European trade body representing producers of fruit and vegetables juices and nectars in the European Union. The composition of fruit juices, concentrated fruit juices, dehydrated fruit juices and fruit nectars, their reserved names, their manufacture and labelling characteristics are subject to specific Community rules under Council Directive 2001/112/EC relating to fruit juices and certain similar products intended for human consumption. These products are defined on the basis of their composition and preparation processes so as to ensure that the terms are used correctly and not misleading. The Directive also defines particular designations used in certain countries and languages. The text lists the raw materials which may be used to manufacture juice and nectar, the minimum content of fruit juice and/or fruit purée in fruit nectar as well as all authorised treatments and substances.  
This Directive was amended in August 2009 by the Commission Directive 2009/106/EC and in 2012 by the Directive 2012/12/EU in order to be adapted to technical progress taking account of developments in relevant international standards, in particular the Codex Standard for fruit juices and nectars (Codex Stan 247-2005) and the AIJN Code of Practice for evaluation of quality and authenticity of juices.
From the industry perspective, this directive guarantees the level-playing field for the sector and sets clear and strict product definitions. It protects product names of juices and nectars, and although there are some unintended consequences in labelling provisions of the Directive that should be changed to avoid consumer confusion (i.e. not being able to use the ‘no added sugar’ term on juices), the industry is strongly in favour of maintaining and further improving this legal text.

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]

With reference to Commission Regulation (EC) No. 543/2008 of 16 June 2008 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No. 1234/2007 as regards the marketing standards for processed tomato products, TomatoEurope would like to request the inclusion of a mandatory requirement for processors to indicate EU/Non EU origin of the tomato raw material in processed products for which tomato is the main ingredient, with no mention of country-specific origin of the ingredient.

short_title: Evaluation of marketing standards [Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013]
Feedback:
