short_title: Changes to greening rules and clarifications of certain other direct payments' rules
Feedback:
Rappelons qu’avec le verdissement, les co-législateurs européens ont souhaité mettre la PAC à l’écoute des citoyens en garantissant la performance environnementale de l’agriculture.
Rappelons ensuite que les surfaces d’intérêt écologique (SIE), l’un des 3 volets du verdissement, ont pour principal objectif d’améliorer la biodiversité agricole (Règlt. 1307/2013[44]). Les législateurs ont clairement déclaré que les SIE ne devaient pas affecter la production agricole: « elles seront mises en œuvre de manière à ce que les terres ne soient pas retirées de la production, et à éviter toute baisse injustifiée du revenu des agriculteurs » (Conclusions du Conseil, 7-8/02/2013). La Commission a ensuite précisé que les SIE « ne doivent pas conduire à une réduction significative du revenu des agriculteurs » (Déclaration du 02/04/2014).
L’AGPB, qui représente les producteurs français de céréales, tient à affirmer leur opposition à l’interdiction des produits phytosanitaires sur les SIE et à la mise en place d’une durée minimale de 8 semaines sur les cultures intermédiaires-SIE qui figurent dans la proposition d’acte délégué (2016)6991856 du 15/12/2016. 
Il s’agirait là d’un changement important des « règles du jeu » en cours de route, qui ne ferait que les compliquer malgré l’objectif affiché de simplification.
Et surtout, ces mesures aboutiraient en pratique à une forte augmentation des surfaces en jachère et à une baisse significative de la production et du revenus agricole, en conséquence d’une réduction drastique des SIE productives que sont les cultures intermédiaires et les cultures fixatrices d’azote, alors qu’elles sont un élément clé de l’accord politique de 2013 entre le Parlement européen et le Conseil.  
En effet, si certains agriculteurs disposent naturellement de SIE “non productives” (éléments topographiques, bandes tampons…), que la PAC encourage à juste titre à préserver (facteurs de conversion élevés), d’autres en sont dépourvus et ont recours aux SIE « productives ». Ces dernières ont toute légitimité, puisque la PAC tient compte de leur impact sur la biodiversité (facteurs de conversion plus faibles) et que, conformément aux souhaits du législateur, elles pénalisent  peu la production et le revenu agricoles.
Les cultures intermédiaires n’ont de sens que si leur destruction laisse un sol propre qui ne pénalise pas la culture suivante. Une interdiction des herbicides laisserait le plus souvent le labour comme seule option. En sols argileux et humides au printemps, l’impossibilité de labourer interdirait toute culture intermédiaire. Dans les autres cas, le labour occasionnerait de nombreux effets pervers : hausse des coûts, des consommations d’énergie et des gaz à effet de serre, et plus d’herbicides utilisés sur la culture suivante. L’interdiction des phytosanitaires sur les jachères, qui laisserait pour seules solutions le broyage et le labour, aurait des conséquences similaires.
Quant aux protéagineux, ils voient leur rendement handicapé par les mauvaises herbes, insectes et maladies, ce qui est la principale raison qui limite leurs surfaces. Sur les SIE-cultures fixatrices d’azote, qui ont permis de stopper le déclin des protéagineux en Europe, l’interdiction des produits phytosanitaires conduirait à une perte de rendement telle que de larges surfaces seraient à nouveau abandonnées, malgré leurs bénéfices environnementaux (biodiversité, économies d’azote).
Enfin, une durée minimale de 8 semaines pour les SIE-cultures intermédiaires impacterait gravement les intercultures courtes (exemple des colzas succédant aux céréales d'hiver). Compte tenu du temps nécessaire à la préparation des sols avant semis, ces cultures ne seraient plus éligibles aux SIE. Dans les régions spécialisées en cultures d’hiver (nord-ouest de la France), ceci conduirait à une augmentation massive des surfaces en jachère, et serait incohérent avec la Directive Nitrates, qui impose des cultures intermédiaires en interculture courte après colza.

short_title: Changes to greening rules and clarifications of certain other direct payments' rules
Feedback:
Ich bin gegen das geplante pauschale Anwendungsverbot von Pflanzenschutzmitteln für die Greeninganerkennung von Eiweißpflanzen, weil dieses Verbot dazu führen wird, dass ein erheblicher Rückgang des Eiweißpflanzenanbaus zu erwarten ist. Auch von mit Pflanzenschutzmitteln behandelten Eiweißpflanzen geht  eine Bereicherung der Kulturartenvielfalt und Erhöhung von Blühpflanzen in der Agrarlandschaft aus, die gut für die Biodiversität ist. Ich lehne das Verbot daher auch deshalb ab, weil damit die positiven Wirkung des durch die Greening-Anerkennung deutlich gestiegenen Eiweißpflanzenanbaus für die Biodiversität wegfallen.
Durch ein generelles Verbot des Einsatzes von Pflanzenschutzmitteln auf ÖVF mit stickstoffbindenden Pflanzen (Leguminosen) stellt die Kommission deren Anbau grundsätzlich in Frage. Ohne Herbizide ist der Anbau in konventionell wirtschaftenden Betrieben nicht wirtschaftlich und erforderte  erhöhte Herbizid Anwendungen in den Folgekulturen. Ohne Insektizid Anwendung ist die Ernteware oft nicht vermarktbar (Erbsenwickler).

Die Verlässlichkeit und Stabilität der Gemeinsamen Agrarpolitik bis 2020 stellt sich in Frage. Die Landwirte planen nicht gern ständig die Fruchtfolgen um.

Der Biodiversität ist nicht geholfen, wenn die Landwirtschaft Anstelle von Leguminosen Stillegungen zur Erreichung der Greeningziehle einsetzt.

Gerade bei streifenförmigen ÖVF entlang von Bächen, Weg- und Waldrändern besteht nach wie vor Potential. Hier sind die Greeningvorschriften auch mit den Änderungsvorschlägen nach wie vor viel zu kompliziert und uneinheitlich. Hohe Kontroll- und Sanktionsrisiken sowie teilweise ein Abraten der Behörden zur Anlage solcher Streifen schrecken die Landwirte darüber hinaus ab.  Hier wäre eine Vereinfachung nötig.

short_title: Changes to greening rules and clarifications of certain other direct payments' rules
Feedback:
Se contesta, en nombre de WWF España, a la consulta de la Comisión Europea para revisar el impacto ambiental de las Superficies de Interés Ecológico (SIE), planteadas en la última reforma de la Política Agraria Común (PAC). Esta respuesta pretende contribuir a asegurar la consecución del objetivo original de las SIE, de mejorar el estado de la biodiversidad asociada a los sistemas agrarios europeos, no logrado hasta el momento. Así lo muestra el reciente informe de la IEEP (http://www.ieep.eu/publications/2016/12/ecological-focus-areas-what-impacts-on-biodiversity). En el mismo se recomienda, entre otras muchas cosas, la necesidad de prohibir el uso de plaguicidas en estas superficies, si realmente se pretenden beneficios ambientales.

Desde WWF España se apoya, por tanto, la propuesta de la Comisión de  prohibir el uso de fitosanitarios en las SIE. Dicha propuesta permitiría mejorar la eficiencia de las prácticas beneficiosas para el clima y el medio ambiente, contribuyendo a avanzar en el cumplimiento de los objetivos ambientales por los que se otorgan estos “pagos verdes”. La prohibicion de fitosanitarios fomentaría una mejora de las especies vinculadas a medios agrarios, en franco declive. Además de un mejor estado del suelo, asi como un aumento del control natural de plagas por fauna útil. 
Un greening bien diseñado aportaria beneficios ambientales y climáticos, pero también agronómicos, contribuyendo a asegurar el futuro de la propia agricultura. Además aseguraría el uso coherente de los fondos comunitarios, exigido a toda política pública.
Del mismo modo, WWF España propone ampliar la revisión del greening, más allá de este aspecto concreto de las SIE.  Un pago verde con objetivos ambientales reales debería incluir compromisos también para los cultivos leñosos, así como promover las rotaciones de cultivos en el caso de los herbáceos. Sólo de esta forma se avanzará  hacia la PAC más respetuosa con el medio ambiente y más justa con los agricultores que apuestan por la sostenibilidad, que demandan los ciudadanos europeos.

LPO-Ligue pour la Protection des Oiseaux, the BirdLife Partner in France, supports the proposal of the Commission to implement measures aiming at reducing/banning tpesticides  in sites of major ecological interest.
In France, there is no specific restriction of pesticide use in the sites of ecological interest (e. g. in Natura 2000 sites, or +/ 12% of the terrestrial country superficie). In such sites of major ecological interest, only partial restrictions are specified in contracts signed in the frame of agri-environmental schemes. Also, this concerns only a minor part of the area of these designated sites. 
Thus, there is only a minimal part of the total cultivated area which maybe considered as pesticide-free in this country (<5%, mostly organic agriculture)! As shown by indicators published regularly (e.g common bird indices), pesticide use explains to a large extend the rapid biodiversity decline, mostly in farmlands, including in Natura 2000 sites. 
The LPO-Ligue pour la Protection des Oiseaux supports the proposal of the Commission to implement measures aiming at reducing total intrants, in ecological sites, but also in the whole surface of farmlands, with a specific focus on pesticide ban. 
The complete ban of most toxic products is also an issue to be considered as a priority. No other argument coming from the agroindustry lobby should be considered as receivable since strong evidences based on scientific analyses prove the toxicity for wildlife, aquatic resources and human health of well known pesticides. Nature conservation and consumer NGOs urges UE to make complulsory the contradictory independent studies to be carried out on ecological toxicity assessment, previous to any indsustrial production and before the massive use in field of new toxic molecules, like medecines. The carried out assessments should also consider every ecolosystem services. The O option (ban of the new molecule) should be envisaged when studies conclude to ecological risks.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of the CAP on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity
Feedback:
Dear madam or sir,

the Society for Conservation Biology (SCB) is an international organization of over 4,000 conservation professionals. The SCB Europe Section (SCB-ES) membership extends to almost every country in Europe. SCB’s Mission is to advance the science and practice of conserving Earth's biological diversity. Advance the application of conservation science to management, policy and education is one of our Strategic Priorities.

SCB-ES has long been concerned about the sharp and continuing decline of biodiversity in farmland areas and the failure of key policy instruments – primarily the Common Agricultural Policy – in reversing these trends.

Having attended some of the discussions around the CAP reform, including the Public Consultation and the „CAP: Have your say“ conference, we have seen with great concern a biased delivery and take-up of inputs; imbalance in stakeholder participation both thematically and geographically; and lack of transparency in processes, data and relevant documents.

Neither the current CAP, nor the proposed CAP post-2020, seem to have taken up on the breadth of literature and knowledge which is available for a) improving existing instruments, b) improving the CAP’s effectiveness and efficiency with respect to environmental targets, and c) employing approaches for conflict reduction especially between agricultural production and biodiversity. 

Moreover, considering the context of nationalism, the commitment of the EU is more than ever essential and the Policy Committee is in favour of a strong European CAP instead of the proposed CAP for, essentially, 27 agricultural policies.
The Policy Committee of SCB-ES therefore sees great importance in a fitness check of the CAP, as long as it takes up a robust approach, and includes data, instruments, and the actors that are most relevant for a comprehensive evaluation of the CAP – the scientific community being one key partner to include. We anticipate seeing a call for scientific evidence and knowledge, and an effort to directly engage the scientific community in a dialogue over the CAP’s fitness. 

As a key organization holding experts in the field, SCB-ES should be a key partner for delivering such essential knowledge and networking with the scientific community.
We hereby express our expectation to see that the Fitness Check includes the following elements: 

1. A process toward developing and publishing a database of relevant literature including (access to raw) data and simulations by EC and JRC. 
2. An assessment of whether the CAP has sufficiently taken up knowledge and tools for developing robust objectives, indicators and monitoring; as well as for identifying and addressing conflicts and tradeoffs. 
3. A thorough assessment of administrative procedures linked to the implementation of biodiversity relevant agri-environment programs in particular.
4. An assessment following a DPSIR approach regarding the direct and indirect effects of the CAP on biodiversity, ecosystem functions and services as well as how all CAP instruments (including Agro-Environment-Climate Measures, Coupled and Decoupled Direct Payments but also Investments, payments for Areas of Nature Constraints etc.) affect land-use changes, intensification, and (non-) sustainable farming management.
5. A clear process to involve the scientific community in evidence collection, analysis and assessment of the CAP fitness check outcomes, including opening of the outcomes to evaluation.

We call for a transparent and robust process, which must consider and assess the Commission’s proposal for the CAP post-2020 and accordingly be used to improve the coming CAP design and implementation.

SCB-ES stands ready to participate in the much-needed science-policy dialogue and facilitate the link to the scientific community.

Stefan Kreft, Policy Committee Chair, SCB Europe

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of the CAP on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity
Feedback:
The EEB welcomes this initiative to evaluate the impacts EU farm policy has on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity.
However, we regretfully note that the current timing of the initiative does not allow for the findings to be reflected in the current proposal for a reformed CAP.

We strongly suggest the following improvements.

First of all, the initiative also needs to be based on the following sources:
•	Upcoming report and data from the updated State of Nature report by the EEA
•	The European Court of Auditors’ 2017 “Special report: Greening: a more complex income support scheme, not yet environmentally effective”
•	Fitness Check of the Common Agricultural Policy, by the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) https://www.idiv.de/web/cap_fitness_check.html and its respective database of publications https://idata.idiv.de/DDM/Data/ShowData/248
•	Studies assessing the effects the CAP had on biodiversity in new member states (e.g. https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/conl.12585 )

There needs to be full transparency on the data and sources used so that it is possible to retrace the conclusions drawn from them.

Additionally, the evaluation should assess which instruments of the CAP are beneficial and which are harmful to biodiversity and thereby neutralize any public money spent to preserve biodiversity (within the CAP and from other sources).
In that respect, the following tools need to be evaluated: Direct payments, Greening payments, Coupled supports (broken down by sectors), Areas of natural constraint, Investment aid under the EAFRD, Agri-environment schemes, Natura 2000 payments.
Likewise, we consider it necessary to include the impact of definitions such as the definition of permanent grassland as well as the impact of land needing to be kept in production-ready condition.

The impact of the CAP on Biodiversity should also be assessed in relation to the main drivers of biodiversity loss, such as direct land-use change and habitat conversion, water use, agricultural run-off, pesticide use, fertilizer use, direct persecution of wildlife, destruction/maintenance/restoration of landscape features, intensification of management (increased livestock density, mowing of grasslands and tillage). 

The initiative should investigate whether and to what extent the CAP is contributing to the appropriate gathering and use of biodiversity-relevant data and evidence (such as on protected areas, monitoring land use changes), including LPIS, IACS and monitoring and evaluation of agri-environment schemes, as well as data on the decline of insect biodiversity and pollinators.

The process of the evaluation should ensure that Article 191 of the Treaty of the Functioning of the European Union is respected.
The objectives of the birds and habitats directives should be strongly integrated and the effects of the CAP on the implementation of these directives should be properly analysed; in any case, DG Environment should be co-leading on this study, since they are the responsible DG on reaching the Biodiversity objectives.
Citizens should be provided with a more accessible public consultation, promoted so as to ensure a wider reach. Likewise, environmental NGOs need to be properly consulted in the analysis, with ample time for consultation and feedback.
If feedback, comments and consultation responses during the public consultation are disregarded, a justification should be provided.

§81: SEGES stated that the control of Septoria on winter wheat is becoming more difficult due to the declining efficacy of triazole fungicides; that there are limited alternatives to chemical pesticides, but growing more spring crops and sowing a mixture of varieties within the same field can help.

b. Which tools are best

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of the CAP on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity
Feedback:
Dear madam/sir,

Authors of this letter have conducted an independent Fitness-Check of the CAP, published in November 2017. This assessment was based on a literature review and trend analyses. It followed the fitness check criteria in assessing the CAP’s effectiveness, efficiency, coherence (internal and external), relevance and EU Added value. We covered a breadth of topics relating to the impacts of the CAP on a) land-use, farm structure and management, b) biodiversity, c) climate, d) soil and water, and ) other ecosystem services. We have also assessed the CAP’s contribution to sustainable agriculture and whether it can meet the UN’s SDGs. 
In the process of preparing the fitness check, we have developed a comprehensive database of relevant publications for the CAP evaluation, which has further been updated and expanded over the course of 2018.

Members of our team have further evaluated the Commission’s proposal for the CAP post-2020, and examined whether published evidence and knowledge have been taken up in developing a potentially-better CAP. We hereby wish to express our deep concern that the proposed CAP fails to address the policy’s key weaknesses, and offers more risks than potentials for environmental improvements. 

We strongly support the need for an evidence-based evaluation of the CAP and hence welcome the Commission’s decision to take up on the calls for a Fitness Check. We particularly welcome a Fitness Check process that builds on the existing database, and suggest look forward to seeing our comprehensive evaluation being included as one key document. A robust evaluation should build not only upon scientific evidence and knowledge, but also engage the producers of this knowledge – i.e., scientists and scientific organizations.

Accordingly, we call the Fitness Check to include: 
a. a database of relevant literature, including data and documents that have so far not been shared with the public.

b. a reflection of existing evidence, reviews and knowledge, and how these have been incorporated into the policy.

c. a clear separation between direct and indirect impacts of the CAP, systematically covering all CAP instruments (including coupled and decoupled support, ANC, investments) and placing particular emphasis on assessing the effects of those instruments that are not designated toward environmental protection.

d. an analysis of national, EU and global effects of the CAP, including direct and indirect facilitation of land-use changes both in the EU and at other regions and countries (i.e., „spillover“ effects or „telecoupling“).

e. as current CAP instruments are reported to fail in delivering on sustainability, we call the fitness check to include economic, social and political analyses on the processes that are repeatedly leading to the CAP’s weak design, incoherence and inefficient implementation of CAP instruments.

f. a clear process to involve the scientific community in a direct way, including further evidence gathering and synthesis, thus increasing transparency and credibility and avoiding potential biases in interpretation resulting from the origin of evidence provided by stakeholders.

g. A comprehensive assessment of factors for success and case study examples, including both CAP implementation and monitoring, as well as citizen science potentials and their uptake and support by the CAP.

h. Finally, given the timing of the assessment, we anticipate to see a robust analysis of how the proposed CAP addresses weaknesses identified by the Fitness Check – i.e., is the next CAP going to be more fit for purpose then the current one? Here we anticipate such an assessment to include both qualitative and quantitative analysis, and not only an opinion-based evaluation.

The authors of the fitness-Check are welcoming a transparent and open dialogue throughout the process. Further material including our database are available at www.idiv.de/cap-fitness-check.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of the CAP on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity
Feedback:
The Confederation of European Forest Owners (CEPF) welcomes the European Commission initiative to evaluate the impacts of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) on habitats, landscape and biodiversity. CEPF considers the five evaluation criteria (effectiveness, efficiency, relevance, coherence and EU added value) as highly relevant and suggests cost-effectiveness as a sixth criteria to highlight the link between the CAP funding instruments and their impacts.
More than 40% of EU’s land area is covered with forests of which approximately 60% are privately owned. European forests represent more than half of the designated Natura 2000 areas. Forests sequester CO2 from the atmosphere as they grow and deliver multiple goods and ecosystem services such as biodiversity, soil protection, drinking water, non-wood forest products and recreational spaces. At the same time, forests are a sustainable source of timber, pulp, paper and energy, providing the largest non-food renewable resource for a sustainable bioeconomy, growth in rural areas and around 4 million jobs in forestry and related industries. Forest resources, including growing stock and the size of forests, have been significantly increasing during last decades in Europe. Investments in active and sustainable forest management are one of the prerequisites for the development of healthy and viable forest resources.
The implementation and further development of sustainable forest management, integrating biodiversity, is at the core of forest owners’ activities in Europe. When assessing the impacts of the CAP on habitats, landscape and biodiversity, CEPF highlights the need to acknowledge time scale of changes in trends, as they are bound to the dynamic and long-term processes of forest ecosystems. Moreover, external factors such as climate change can have significant negative impacts on positive actions taken by forest owners and thus negatively impact positive trends. CEPF considers that relevant time-scale and external factors have to be explicitly acknowledged and taken into account in the evaluation of the impacts of the CAP.
European forest owners have a crucial role as managers of forest resource, not only on tackling challenges related to environmental, social and economic sustainability but also on challenges related to the impact of climate change on the resilience and vitality of forest ecosystems.
CEPF considers that when evaluating the impacts of the CAP on habitats, landscape and biodiversity, the link between sustainable management and long-term climate goals to be achieved via increased CO2 sequestration, carbon storage and substitution of fossil-based materials should be taken into account.
Overall, CEPF considers that it is of the upmost importance to ensure coherence between the current initiative and EU political priorities (including UN SDGs and the Paris agreement) and EU policies. Promoting and supporting the implementation of sustainable forest management in the EU is key to further enhance biodiversity and habitats, and is consistent with worldwide SDGs.
CEPF welcomes the opportunity to contribute to further steps of the evaluation and reminds that it is of utmost importance that European forest owners are considered as main partners, and not only as stakeholders, when it comes to assessing impacts of the CAP on forest biodiversity and habitats.

short_title: Evaluation of the impact of the CAP on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity
Feedback:
DNR welcomes the planned evaluation of the CAP’s impact on habitats, landscapes and biodiversity. It is important to note, however, that the evaluation of the current CAP impacts would have been helpful to obtain prior to the ongoing negotiations on the future CAP, since it can provide important insights for the upcoming reform.
Furthermore, we would like to point out that the continuing involvement of civil society as well as the scientific community is of great importance throughout this process. Additionally, since DG Environment is responsible for reaching the biodiversity targets within the Commission, they should be closely involved throughout the entire evaluation process. 
Europe is far from reaching the biodiversity targets set for 2020 in the Biodiversity Strategy. Therefore, it is important to optimize the CAP to that and other environmental aims.
It will be interesting to evaluate the following tolls of the CAP: payments, greening payments, areas of natural constraint, agri-environment schemes, investment aid, Natura 2000 payments.
Furthermore, the impact of the use of fertilizer and pesticides, land-use change, water use as well as the intensification of agricultural practice can have a significant impact on biodiversity. 
In light of the future CAP, the results of the evaluation should factor in the improvement of the catalogue of indicators proposed by the Commission in the legislative proposals. As the European Court of Auditors pointed out, the proposed model does not provide sufficient instruments to make progress in environmental ambition, especially in biodiversity, result-oriented and measurable.

Ban import of bees into Ireland, both honeybees and other species (bumblebees).

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
MEDIDAS PARA REDUCIR LA PÉRDIDA DE MATERIA ORGÁNICA DE LOS SUELOS  
Antecedentes
Las zonas mediterráneas se caracterizan por tener un régimen pluviométrico muy bajo. En 2017 la mayor parte de la   superficie de Catalunya registró precipitaciones acumuladas entre 250 y 550 mm (SMC, 2017). 
Los suelos de estas áreas tienen un bajo contenido de materia orgánica, siendo inferior al 2 % de carbono orgánico en la capa superficial del suelo .Se puesto  en evidencia que existe una gran dispersión de estos valores  a nivel de parcela y de sistema agrícola, lo que ofrece oportunidades notables para el secuestro del carbono , siendo viable en un número significativo de ellas llegar al 4 por mil 
En el ámbito Mediterráneo las pérdidas anuales de suelo por erosión pueden ir de los 36,5 a las 134,4 t ha-1 . Estas cantidades se reducen significativamente cuando se adoptan medidas de conservación adecuadas
Amenazas
La severidad de las sequías ha ido aumentando durante los últimos decenios en Catalunya, mientras que los períodos húmedos son menos extensos e intensos espacialmente y temporalmente (SMC, 2019).
Las previsiones, bajo los escenarios de cambio climático comúnmente aceptados, indican que los suelos mediterráneos experimentarán una pérdida lenta de materia orgánica por mineralización durante los próximos decenios (TICCC, 2017).
Los sistemas de bancales de piedra seca son sistemas muy complejos y caros de mantener. Su marginalización conduce con frecuencia a la degradación de los mismos lo que puede llegar a hacerlos inefectivos

Oportunidades
Existen regiones mediterráneas en donde se generan deyecciones ganaderas suficientes como para que su aplicación como enmiendas o fertilizantes cubra las necesidades de los cultivos desde el punto de vista de la cantidad de nutrientes; el reto se halla en incrementar la eficiencia en el uso de estos nutrientes de manera que se reduzcan las perdidas hacia el medio. Estas características han de permitir, a su vez, mejorar la eficiencia en el uso del agua y contribuir a reducir y mitigar la emisión de gases de efecto invernadero.
La evidencia científica demuestra que el secuestro  del C es más eficaz cuando se aplican los materiales orgánicos en suelos que estén lejos  de su punto de saturación en carbono orgánico 
Existen en el área mediterránea un patrimonio importante de área   con bancales de piedra seca funcionales, susceptibles de ser mantenidos y soportar una agricultura sostenible. 
 
Medidas hasta la fecha
En el marco de la actual PAC, la condicionalidad de las ayudas mediante las BCAM pretende que las explotaciones agrarias apliquen medidas encaminados a evitar la erosión y la pérdida de materia orgánica. A falta de evaluaciones en profundidad, globales y locales , todo apunta que estas obligaciones no  han resultado suficientes para revertir las tendencias negativas a la perdida de materia orgánica o de suelo. 
 
Medidas   futuras
Ante esta situación, el marco de la Nueva PAC, habría que aprovecharlas oportunidades que ofrecen la existencia de materiales orgánicos de deyecciones ganaderas impulsando el establecimiento de medidas compensar la pérdida de materia orgánica/incrementar el secuestro de carbono orgánico   y la conservación de los suelos y el agua.
-	En relación al apartado del secuestro de C/mantenimiento de la materia orgánica del suelo habría que impulsar la promoción del uso de las deyecciones ganaderas generadas. Ello debería incluir la toma en consideración un uso eficiente de los nutrientes, maximizar la retención de C (aplicación en suelos con la menor saturación de la menor saturación en C) y la calidad de los materiales fertilizantes
-	En relación a la conservación del suelo y el agua la conservación de los márgenes de piedra en cultivos arbóreos de secano, que contribuyen a un ecosistema equilibrado óptimo para el desarrollo de una agricultura sostenible.

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
The European Sustainable Phosphorus Platform (ESPP) supports the proposal to evaluate the impact of EU farm policy on soil management, because soil resources, both quantity (limitation of soil erosion) and quality (soil fertility potential and contamination avoidance) are critical to ensuring future food production and rural prosperity.

We suggest, in $A. Context, para. 2, after “soil erosion, compaction, organic matter, biodiversity, pollution or salinization” to add “nutrients (macro- and micro-nutrients)”.
	
For plants, the soil offers physical support and acts as a store for water and nutrients. Nutrients are thus fundamental to crop, forestry and grassland productivity and to soil health. Their supply by and via the soil is critical and complimentary to essential supply via mineral and organic fertilising materials (fertilising products, manures, crop residues …). Both nutrient content and nutrient form in soils impact immediate fertiliser application requirements, longer term crop fertility (quantitative yield, plant health and resilience, crop quality) and fertiliser needs, soil metabolism and health, possible nutrient losses to water and final food quality (e.g. taste, micronutrients in food products, nutrition).

This significance is recognised in the current proposal for a FaST (Farm nutrient Sustainability Tool) in the CAP revision.

We suggest adding to the list of stakeholder organisations consulted (under $B – Consultation):
-	Water management / water quality organisations
-	Food health and nutrition experts (crop quality, micronutrients)
-	Fertilising products supply industries

It would be appropriate to link to the proposed Horizon Europe “Soil, food and health” Mission.

Feedback:
FarmTech Society (FTS) is an international nonprofit association, that unites and supports the Controlled Environment Agriculture (CEA) industry. FTS strengthens the CEA sector as it develops and implements resilient, future-proof methods and technologies for the indoor growing of agriculture products. We welcome the European Commission invitation to help assess the extent to which the EU’s farm policy (the common agricultural policy) has helped farmers manage the soil more sustainably. There are multiple ways of supporting sustainable managing soil as an important resource.  It is our strong interest to actively participate in helping to shape the policy development to manage soil health. FTS would like to emphasize important (certainly not the only ones) contributions by CEA stakeholders which have not been considered in the roadmap. Existing and new growers both in metropolitan and rural areas need to be informed about all potential options based on highly resource-efficient systems and applications. CEA solutions are based on advanced technology with integrative practices utilizing circular economy principles. Shifting production into CEA will reduce significant pressure on remaining agriculture productive land and allow the implementation of regenerative practices for upgrading soil quality as well as create deeper biodiversity and recreational space in the landscape. CEA can also become highly instrumental in developing certain improved plant products for field applications and or support the applied research to do so. Novel plant phenotyping and disease reduced propagation has been demonstrated and will benefit every aspect of agricultural practice and subsequently soil management. Controlled environment agriculture or indoor farming is proving to be an efficient way to grow more agriculture products with fewer resources, in addition to conventional methods in field and soil application. One of the benefits is the fact that this method is less dependent on arable land availability and external climate conditions are managed. Additionally, the use of inputs such as irrigation water, nutrition, and pest control measures can be significantly reduced compared to conventional best practices for the same products. CEA can also reduce waste and integrate energy streams and does not depend on the intensive cold-chain distribution network due to its potential to grow products close to consumption. FTS can contribute to the development of policy instruments, vocational training, and implements education initiatives as well as best practice platforms and standards. FTS members can consult as expert system integration advisors, planners, and consultants in workshops and community interviews. FTS collects data and engages with all stakeholders regarding advanced technologies which are also important for the policymakers to understand and to develop well-balanced regulatory instruments for the industry.
In addition, CEA will empower growers to regain control over their own economic success in the form of reliable yields and less land and water resources without being overregulated and contribute to the community to improve the overall environmental footprint and a more sustainable soil management.

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
Sustainable management of natural resources is becoming increasingly imperative and necessary to preserve biodiversity and counteract the negative effects of climate change.
Especially in agriculture, where water and soil are the main resources, high quality soil is crucial for the future of both nutrition and agriculture.
EU Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is moving in the right direction by addressing the challenges that arise at European level by adopting measures to promote sustainable land use. The principle of sustainable compliance links direct payments with farmers' compliance with the basic standards of the environment and climate, food safety, animal and plant health, animal welfare and land conservation . It thus establishes a basis for environmental measures and encourages sustainable land use.
Concerning the sustainable management of non-hazardous waste organic solid, the EU has for many years legislated measures that lead organic waste producers to their legal and certified management to produce useful products, such as compost, that can help increase the quality and productivity of arable land as it contains no chemicals additives to increase nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium units and is rich in organic matter (> 30%), thus addressing a persistent and chronic problem of arable soils, lack of organic matter due to the misuse and/or overuse of chemically manufactured fertilizers.

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
The EEB welcomes the opportunity to comment on this roadmap for the evaluation of the CAP on the sustainable management of soils. Below, we highlight some important aspects which should be considered in the evaluation. 

This evaluation is very timely, and should be published at the earliest possible date in order to inform policy processes around the CAP and national Strategic Plans. Regarding the evaluation process, it should include an assessment of the European Court of Auditors’ special report n°33/2018: “Combating desertification in the EU: a growing threat in need of more action”; and should closely involve environmental authorities and non-governmental organisations (ENGOs). 

The management of soils should be studied in the context of soil quality and soil degradation. Soil degradation encompasses erosion as well as the “deterioration of the physical, chemical, biological, or economic properties of soil” (IPCC, 2019). All these elements should be included in a holistic assessment of soil management. Indeed, soil erosion is not a sufficient proxy; other elements of soil quality should be evaluated, including soil acidification, loss of soil biodiversity, and loss of soil organic matter. This evaluation should assess how the CAP is driving, mitigating, or reversing all aspects of soil degradation. 

The IPCC also brought to the fore the extent of the damage already caused: one quarter of our planet's ice-free land is degraded. In the EU, almost one third of our land area is affected by unsustainable erosion, and on average 2.2 tons of soil are lost per ha and year, while soil formation is only 1.4t (Pe’er et al. 2017). There is a real need for regenerating degraded soils: in many parts of the EU, “sustainable management” is no longer sufficient. The evaluation should assess to what extent the CAP is supporting regenerative action, as well as to what extent it is preventing further damage.

In doing so, the evaluation should look beyond instruments and measures that are deployed under environmental objectives. How are different agricultural practices impacting on the health of soils, and how does the CAP promote or inhibit different good or bad practices? There is undeniable evidence of the damage caused by common practices such as ploughing or N fertiliser application to soil health (with further environmental consequences). The role of the CAP in maintaining or transitioning away from such practices should be assessed as part of this evaluation.

The external coherence of EU policies with regards to soil is also an important issue. More specifically, the evaluation should assess how the CAP interacts with trade and international development policy, a.o., and the impacts of these policies on soils in third-countries, for examples in regions producing soya and other agricultural products for imports into the EU.

Finally, despite its critical importance and evidence of widespread land degradation, soil is not covered by EU legislation, except CAP legislation, unlike most other natural resources and environmental issues. It would be interesting to contrast the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of CAP instruments in protecting soils, with what could be achieved through an independent regulatory approach. Pe’er et al (2017) suggested that, for ecological minimum requirements, a regulatory approach would be less costly and more efficient than rules implemented through the CAP. A more detailed evaluation of both approaches would place the effectiveness of the CAP in a wider context, and would inform the best approach to soil protection going forward.

References
Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (2019). IPCC Special Report on Climate Change and Land - Chapter 4: Land Degradation.
Pe’er, G. et al. (2017). Is the CAP Fit for Purpose? An Evidence-Based Fitness-Check Assessment.

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
Die gemeinsame europäische Agrarpolitik hat in den letzten Jahren zu einer weiteren Intensivierung der Landwirtschaft geführt. Diese Intensivierung führt zu einem hohen Einsatz an Pestiziden, der sich negativ auf die Bodenorganismen und somit die Bodenfruchtbarkeit auswirkt. Der hohe Einsatz von Düngemitteln führt dazu, dass viele Böden stark mit Stickstoff versorgt sind. Die Einbringung von Stickstoff führt unter anderem zu einer Entwicklung von klimaschädlichem Lachgas. Die Phosphatdüngung, mit mineralischen Düngern sorgt für eine Anreicherung von radioaktivem Cadmium und Uran in den Böden (Umweltbundesamt 2017). Zusätzlich sind viele Böden in Deutschland nicht ausreichende mit Humus versorgt und die Humusgehalte der Böden nehmen durch die intensive Nutzung ab.  Eine weitere Folge der Intensivierung ist die Beschränkung auf wenige Feldfrüchte wie Getreide, Mais und Hackfrüchte,  welche als Humuszehrer wirken. Maßnahmen, die einen Humusaufbau fördern würden, wie vielfältige Fruchtfolgen, werden in der GAP nicht ausreichend adressiert und die Cross-Compliance-Anforderung zu einer Fruchtartendiversifizierung trägt nicht zur Entstehung vielgliedriger Fruchtfolgen bei. Nach wie vor werden auch Moorböden ackerbaulich bewirtschaftet was zu einem Verlust organischer Biomasse und der massiven Freisetzung von Klimagasen führt. Auch der Verlust von fruchtbaren Böden durch Erosion schreitet voran, vor allem die großen Bearbeitungseinheiten, entstanden als Folge der Intensivierung, verschärfen das Problem der Winderosion. Auch das Umwandlungsverbot von Grünland konnte nicht verhindern, dass Dauergrünland zur Narbenerneuerung umgebrochen wurde und danach neu eingesät. Sie sorgt für eine Verringerung der Humusauflage unter Dauergrünland und führt zu einer Freisetzung von Treibhausgasen.
Die Agrarumweltprogramme sind nicht in der Lage diesen Trend zu stoppen, da sie mit zu wenigen Geldern hinterlegt und in vielen Fällen nicht zielgerichtet genug sind. Deshalb müssen die Gelder der GAP für naturverträgliche Bewirtschaftung eingesetzt werden. Im Agrarbereich sollten Gelder aus öffentlichen Kassen nur noch für öffentliche Leistungen der Landwirtschaft verwendet werden, wie die Sicherung und Förderung von Boden, Biodiversität, Wasser, Klima und Landschaft. Zusätzlich sind ausreichend ambitionierte gesetzliche Mindeststandards gefordert, die garantieren, dass die Landwirtschaft flächendeckend nachhaltig wird. Dazu bedarf es eine Zweckbindung von 15 Milliarden Euro pro Jahr der Gelder der europäischen Agrarpolitik und einem Anteil von zehn Prozent der Betriebsfläche als nichtproduktive Fläche, die zu, Beispiel durch Brachen zum Humusaufbau betragen. Auch der aktuelle Vorschlag zur nächsten Förderperiode der GAP wird nicht in der Lage sein die Biodiversität und die Böden ausreichend zu schützen (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/365/6452/449).

short_title: EU farm policy - Evaluation of its impact on sustainable management of the soil
Feedback:
The European Agricultural Machinery Industry represented through CEMA - The European Agricultural Machinery Association – welcomes the Evaluation roadmap of the Common Agricultural Policy‘s impact on the sustainable management of the soil. The European Agricultural Machinery Industry drives innovation and encourages technology uptake in Farming. CEMA is however concerned that the European Commission’s Roadmap does not identify agricultural machinery and solutions as a key stakeholder consulted in the review. 
European farmers from farms of all sizes make great efforts to produce high-quality products, in a sustainable manner at affordable prices. The challenges in agriculture are immense: climate change, weather constrains, sustainable soil management, price volatility or aging of rural populations range among them. 
CEMA is committed to providing the best adapted technology solutions that respond to farmers’ needs and help them in tackling those challenges. CEMA represents an industry with 7,000 companies spread all over Europe, from numerous SMEs to global players, and 150,000 direct employees. The industry produces a variety of 450 types of machines that cover any field activity from seeding to harvesting and livestock equipment, helping customers in getting the most out of their land, protecting the environment while bringing economic benefits.
Precision Farming and Digital Agriculture are revolutions in the making and drive productivity, waste reduction and pro-active environmental protection. Their impact on the soils can be substantial, through savings on inputs such as water, fertilizers and pesticides, reducing farm-related CO2 emissions and soil compaction, and optimising yields and quality in agricultural production. 
Advanced precision spraying technologies are critical to cut anthropogenic nutrient and phosphorus inputs to seep from the fields into aquatic ecosystems. It is the prerequisite to protect drinking-water supplies and to reduce eutrophication of receiving waters, especially lakes, reservoirs, streams, and the upper reaches of estuaries. 
Advanced agricultural equipment could be used by all types of farm. They significantly contribute to the attractiveness of the sector for younger generations of farmers. The uptake of these technologies is currently dramatically lagging behind the pace of digital technology uptake in other sectors, due to the low profit margin generated by agriculture and associated limited investment capacities. CEMA sees a strong role for EU and national policy-making to mainstream Precision Farming and ensure a speedy digital transformation in European agriculture, to enhance the technology leadership of EU farm machinery industry, developed in the attached document. 
CEMA calls on the EU institutions to enable the uptake of advanced farming technologies, by all farms, in order to widely spread sustainable farming practices; to live up to the commitments set in the 2019 Joint Declaration on a smart digital future for European agriculture and rural areas; and to deliver on the €10 billion for research and innovation projects, to be implemented by the future Horizon Europe programme, for food, agriculture, rural development and the bio-economy. 
CEMA and its members stand ready to participate to the evaluation of the EU farm policy’s impact on sustainable management of the soil, contributing to the 2021 Commission report to the European Parliament and the Council on the performance of the CAP and providing evidence for policy development in this area.

Feedback:
Die Maßnahmen der Gemeinsamen Agrarpolitik sind in Salzburg das zentrale Instrument für die Bemühungen eine nachhaltige Landwirtschaft und Bodenbewirtschaftung zu erhalten und auszubauen.
 
Die Basis dafür bilden die Direktzahlungen der ersten Säule. Hinzu kommen die Maßnahmen des Agrarumweltprogramms der zweiten Säule. Rund 94% der Salzburger Betriebe konnten in der GAP-Periode 2014-2020 motiviert werden am Agrarumweltprogramm teilzunehmen. 57% der Flächen werden dabei biologisch bewirtschaftet. Auch die weiteren programmierten Maßnahmen wie etwa „Umweltgerechte Bewirtschaftung“, „Einschränkung ertragssteigernder Betriebsmittel“, „Silageverzicht“ und „Vorbeugender Grundwasserschutz“ werden gut angenommen und tragen wesentlich zu einer nachhaltigen Bodenbewirtschaftung bei.
 
Die gemeinsame Agrarpolitik bietet den Landwirten damit insgesamt ein Angebot ihre Betriebe in Richtung Nachhaltigkeit auszurichten, ohne dabei die Wirtschaftlichkeit des Betriebes zu vernachlässigen. Die GAP hat entscheidend dazu beigetragen eine nachhaltige Landwirtschaft in Salzburg weiterhin umzusetzen.
